head.headtext: Multidistrict litigation

codes.para.paratext: When civil actions involving one or more common questions of fact are pending in different districts, such actions may be transferred to any district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. Such transfers shall be made by the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation authorized by this section upon its determination that transfers for such proceedings will be for the convenience of parties and witnesses and will promote the just and efficient conduct of such actions. Each action so transferred shall be remanded by the panel at or before the conclusion of such pretrial proceedings to the district from which it was transferred unless it shall have been previously terminated: Provided, however, That the panel may separate any claim, cross-claim, counter-claim, or third-party claim and remand any of such claims before the remainder of the action is remanded.

Such coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings shall be conducted by a judge or judges to whom such actions are assigned by the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation. For this purpose, upon request of the panel, a circuit judge or a district judge may be designated and assigned temporarily for service in the transferee district by the Chief Justice of the United States or the chief judge of the circuit, as may be required, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 13 of this title. With the consent of the transferee district court, such actions may be assigned by the panel to a judge or judges of such district. The judge or judges to whom such actions are assigned, the members of the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation, and other circuit and district judges designated when needed by the panel may exercise the powers of a district judge in any district for the purpose of conducting pretrial depositions in such coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
Proceedings for the transfer of an action under this section may be initiated by—
the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation upon its own initiative, or

motion filed with the panel by a party in any action in which transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings under this section may be appropriate. A copy of such motion shall be filed in the district court in which the moving party's action is pending.

The panel shall give notice to the parties in all actions in which transfers for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings are contemplated, and such notice shall specify the time and place of any hearing to determine whether such transfer shall be made. Orders of the panel to set a hearing and other orders of the panel issued prior to the order either directing or denying transfer shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the district court in which a transfer hearing is to be or has been held. The panel's order of transfer shall be based upon a record of such hearing at which material evidence may be offered by any party to an action pending in any district that would be affected by the proceedings under this section, and shall be supported by findings of fact and conclusions of law based upon such record. Orders of transfer and such other orders as the panel may make thereafter shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the district court of the transferee district and shall be effective when thus filed. The clerk of the transferee district court shall forthwith transmit a certified copy of the panel's order to transfer to the clerk of the district court from which the action is being transferred. An order denying transfer shall be filed in each district wherein there is a case pending in which the motion for transfer has been made.

The judicial panel on multidistrict litigation shall consist of seven circuit and district judges designated from time to time by the Chief Justice of the United States, no two of whom shall be from the same circuit. The concurrence of four members shall be necessary to any action by the panel.

No proceedings for review of any order of the panel may be permitted except by extraordinary writ pursuant to the provisions of title 28, section 1651, United States Code. Petitions for an extraordinary writ to review an order of the panel to set a transfer hearing and other orders of the panel issued prior to the order either directing or denying transfer shall be filed only in the court of appeals having jurisdiction over the district in which a hearing is to be or has been held. Petitions for an extraordinary writ to review an order to transfer or orders subsequent to transfer shall be filed only in the court of appeals having jurisdiction over the transferee district. There shall be no appeal or review of an order of the panel denying a motion to transfer for consolidated or coordinated proceedings.
The panel may prescribe rules for the conduct of its business not inconsistent with Acts of Congress and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

Nothing in this section shall apply to any action in which the United States is a complainant arising under the antitrust laws. “ Antitrust laws” as used herein include those acts referred to in the Act of October 15, 1914, as amended (38 Stat. 730; 15 U.S.C. 12), and also include the Act of June 19, 1936 (49 Stat. 1526; 15 U.S.C. 13, 13a, and 13b) and the Act of September 26, 1914, as added March 21, 1938 (52 Stat. 116, 117; 15 U.S.C. 56); but shall not include section 4A of the Act of October 15, 1914, as added July 7, 1955 (69 Stat. 282; 15 U.S.C. 15a).

Notwithstanding the provisions of section 1404 or subsection (f) of this section, the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation may consolidate and transfer with or without the consent of the parties, for both pretrial purposes and for trial, any action brought under section 4C of the Clayton Act.

credit.block.credit: (Added Pub.L. 90-296, § 1, Apr. 29, 1968, 82 Stat. 109; amended Pub.L. 94-435, Title III, § 303, Sept. 30, 1976, 90 Stat. 1396.)

para.paratext: The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, referred to in subsec. (f), are set out in this title.

Section 4C of the Clayton Act, referred to in subsec. (h), is section 4C of Act Oct. 15, 1914, c. 323, as added by Pub.L. 94-435, Title III, § 301, Sept. 30, 1976, 90 Stat. 1394, which is classified to section 15c of Title 15, Commerce and Trade.

GENERALLY
Generally

para.paratext:
A transfer under this section permitting transfer for pretrial proceedings is a change of venue for pretrial purposes.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Construction

para.paratext:
Absent argument by plaintiff wishing to have conditions imposed on transfer of action to another court for pretrial proceedings that Judicial Panel should use its discretion or should forbear use of its statutory powers on principles of comity, plaintiff's contention that Panel had no power to transfer class action issue involved in the action presented questions of construction of this section authorizing transfer.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Construction with other laws

para.paratext:
Even if this section were to be regarded as a partial repeal of venue provision of National Bank Act, section 94 of Title 12, it came within category of repeal by implication recognized where provisions in two acts are in irreconcilable conflict.
Matter of New York City Mun. Securities Litigation, 572 F.2d 49 (2d Cir. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Section 1404 of this title governing change of venue and this section providing for transfer, for consolidated pretrial proceedings, of civil actions involving common questions of fact are not mutually exclusive and may properly be used in concert and to complement one another.
General Tire & Rubber Co. v. Jefferson Chemical Co., 50 F.R.D. 112 (S.D. N.Y. 1970).
Federal Courts  2901; Federal Courts  2951

After actions had been transferred under this section for consolidated pretrial proceedings, the actions are thereafter returned to their respective transferor courts for trial unless they have previously been terminated in the transferee court or transferred by the transferee judge under section 1404 of this title providing for change of venue or section 1406 of this title providing for cure or waiver of defects.
In re Drowning Incident at Quality Inn Northeast, Washington, D. C., on May 3, 1974, 405 F. Supp. 1304 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

Section 1404 of this title relating to change of venue, § 1406 of this title, laying venue in wrong division or district, and this section are not mutually exclusive and, when appropriate, should be used in concert to effect the most expeditious disposition of multidistrict litigation.
In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239 (J.P.M.L. 1969). See, also, In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

This section is not exclusive vehicle for insuring just and efficient conduct of cases having common questions of fact, and statutes relating to change of venue, when applicable, may be used in conjunction with or in place of it to transfer related cases to single court.
In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Purpose

para.paratext:
Essential purpose of Congress in enacting this section was to permit centralization in one district of all pretrial proceedings when civil actions involving one or more common questions of fact are pending in different districts; objective of legislation is to provide centralized management under court supervision of pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation to assure just and efficient conduct of such actions.
Matter of New York City Mun. Securities Litigation, 572 F.2d 49 (2d Cir. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

In enacting statute authorizing multidistrict litigation, Congress intended to provide centralized management of pretrial proceedings and to ensure their just and efficient conduct.
U.S. ex rel. Pogue v. Diabetes Treatment Centers of America, Inc., 238 F. Supp. 2d 270 (D.D.C. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Purpose of statute allowing consolidation of multidistrict litigation is to promote just and efficient conduct of multidistrict actions, in part by eliminating potential for conflicting contemporaneous rulings by coordinate district and appellate courts.
In re Air Crash off Long Island, N.Y. on July 17, 1996, 965 F. Supp. 5 (S.D. N.Y. 1997).
Federal Courts  2951

Basic purpose underlying enactment of this section was to secure, in multidistrict civil litigation as in all other civil litigation, the just, speedy and inexpensive determination of every action.
In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

This section relating to multidistrict litigation was not intended to provide procedure which would absolutely insure that repetitious and duplicative discovery would be avoided.
In re Frost Patent, 316 F. Supp. 977 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Civil Procedure  1261

During course of multidistrict litigation, this section authorizing transfers for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is an appropriate means of avoiding injury to like parties caused by inconsistent judicial treatment.
In re Fourth Class Postage Regulations, 298 F. Supp. 1326 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Remedial aim of this section permitting transfer of action for pretrial proceedings is to eliminate potential for conflicting contemporaneous pretrial rulings by coordinate district and appellate courts in multidistrict related civil actions.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968). See, also, State of Utah v. American Pipe & Const. Co., 316 F. Supp. 837 (C.D. Cal. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

Congress adopted transfer procedure authorized by multidistrict litigation for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings law for specific purpose of superseding voluntary procedures of the coordinating committee.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Law governing

para.paratext:
Van Dusen rule, that transferee court applies substantive state law, including choice-of-law rules, of jurisdiction in which action was filed, does not apply by analogy where case is transferred under multidistrict litigation statute to federal court that has different construction of relevant federal law than federal court in which action was filed.
Menowitz v. Brown, 991 F.2d 36 (2d Cir. 1993).
Federal Courts  2958

When analyzing questions of federal law in multidistrict litigation, transferee court should apply law of the circuit in which it is located.
In re Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) Implants Products Liability Litigation, 97 F.3d 1050 (8th Cir. 1996).
Courts  96(4)

Law of transferor forum on federal question merits close consideration, but does not have stare decisis effect in transferee forum situated in another circuit; each federal circuit has obligation to engage independently in reasoned analysis, with binding precedent for all set only by the Supreme Court, and for district courts within circuit, only by Court of Appeals for that circuit.
In re Korean Air Lines Disaster of Sept. 1, 1983, 829 F.2d 1171, 265 (D.C. Cir. 1987).
Federal Courts  2958

Federal district court in California had to apply New York substantive and choice-of-law rules to all state law legal issues in removed state court securities fraud action that was transferred to it by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation for resolution of any pretrial matters.
In re Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortgage-backed Securities Litigation, 943 F. Supp. 2d 1035 (C.D. Cal. 2013).
Federal Courts  2958

Application of California law on nationwide basis was not warranted in multidistrict litigation against automobile manufacturer to recover damages for diminution in market value of plaintiffs' vehicles in light of defects in those vehicles that led to incidents of sudden, unintended acceleration (SUA), where cases were filed in multiple states, parties did not agree on choice of law, and states' laws varied materially with regard to manifestation of alleged defect, privity requirement for implied warranty of merchantability claims, and statutes of limitations.
In re Toyota Motor Corp. Unintended Acceleration Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 785 F. Supp. 2d 925 (C.D. Cal. 2011).
Limitation Of Actions  2(1); Products Liability  105; Products Liability  203; Sales 425

Law of transferor courts applied to resolution of motion to dismiss Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act claims against manufacturing corporation in multidistrict litigation.
In re Dow Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 666 F. Supp. 1466 (D. Colo. 1987).
Federal Courts  2945

While a transferee court in multidistrict litigation-transferred case normally would apply the same law applied by the transferor court when sitting in diversity, the transferee court should follow its own circuit on questions of federal law.
U.S. ex rel. Hockett v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp., 498 F. Supp. 2d 25 (D.D.C. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

In a diversity action transferred pursuant to multidistrict litigation statute, the transferee court applies the choice-of-law rules of the state where the transferor court sits.
In re U.S. Office Products Co. Securities Litigat., 251 F. Supp. 2d 58 (D.D.C. 2003).
Federal Courts  2958

Governing statutes of limitations in multidistrict litigation under ERISA and LMRA by coal miner pension benefit trust to collect delinquent contributions from employers were those of transferor fora; rule that district court must apply law of transferor forum following transfer was not limited to diversity actions, but, rather, applied to federal question cases as well.
In re United Mine Workers of America Employee Ben. Plans Litigation, 854 F. Supp. 914 (D.D.C. 1994).
Federal Courts  2958

In litigation involving cases transferred pursuant to statutes governing multidistrict suits, the court must apply the choice of law rules of the transferor court.
In re Educational Testing Service Praxis Principles of Learning and Teaching: Grades 7-12 Litigation, 517 F. Supp. 2d 832 (E.D. La. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

In cases filed in, or removed to, federal courts across the country and transferred to a multi-district litigation (MDL) court by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, the MDL court must apply the law of the transferor forum, that is, the law of the state in which the action was filed, including the transferor forum's choice-of-law rules.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 478 F. Supp. 2d 897 (E.D. La. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

United States district court to which action is transferred for consolidated and coordinated pretrial proceedings, must apply substantive law of transferor state and circuit.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Boston, Massachusetts on July 31, 1973, 399 F. Supp. 1106 (D. Mass. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

When diversity action is transferred as part of multidistrict litigation (MDL), transferor court's choice-of-law rules continue to apply even if complaint is later amended in transferee court.
In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 489 F. Supp. 2d 932 (D. Minn. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

In case consolidated under statute covering multidistrict litigation, law of transferor forum must be given “close consideration,” but law of transferee forum ultimately controls.
In re Donald J. Trump Casino Securities Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 543 (D.N.J. 1992), order aff'd, 7 F.3d 357 (3d Cir. 1993).
Federal Courts  2958

In multidistrict diversity jurisdiction action, cases commenced in other districts would be treated as if they were pending in those other districts, whether transferred to transferee court for pretrial purposes under this section or transferred for trial for convenience of witnesses.
In re Agent Orange Product Liability Litigation, 580 F. Supp. 690 (E.D. N.Y. 1984).
Federal Courts  2958

In multidistrict diversity jurisdiction action, cases commenced in other districts would be treated as if they were pending in those other districts, whether transferred to transferee court for pretrial purposes under this section or transferred for trial for convenience of witnesses.
In re Agent Orange Product Liability Litigation, 580 F. Supp. 690 (E.D. N.Y. 1984).
Federal Courts  2958

In actions against airline on claims arising out of crash of airplane, airline's defense of lack of authorization of decedent's next of kin to sue was within breadth of rule governing capacity to sue, and thus Louisiana law would apply to resolution of such defense inasmuch as actions were commenced in United States district courts in Louisiana even though cases were subsequently transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to the Eastern District of New York.
Windbourne v. Eastern Air Lines, Inc., 479 F. Supp. 1130 (E.D. N.Y. 1979).
Federal Courts 157

In actions against airline on claims arising out of crash of airplane, airline's defense of lack of authorization of decedent's next of kin to sue was within breadth of rule governing capacity to sue, and thus Louisiana law would apply to resolution of such defense inasmuch as actions were commenced in United States district courts in Louisiana even though cases were subsequently transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to the Eastern District of New York.
Windbourne v. Eastern Air Lines, Inc., 479 F. Supp. 1130 (E.D. N.Y. 1979), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 632 F.2d 219 (2d Cir. 1980).
Federal Courts 157

Law of the transferor court applies to class certification in multi-district litigation; however, law of the transferee court applies to pre-trial issues such as motions to dismiss or discovery disputes.
In re Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE) Products Liability Litigation, 241 F.R.D. 435 (S.D. N.Y. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Court to which case is transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation applies its own interpretation of federal law, not that of the transferor court, and to the extent that the action involves issues of state law, court applies the choice of law rules that would govern in the transferor forum.
In re Parmalat Securities Litigation, 412 F. Supp. 2d 392 (S.D. N.Y. 2006).
Federal Courts  2958

Although district court would review and give deference to opinion issued by judge of another district court prior to transfer of case by Multidistrict Litigation Panel, district court was required to evaluate motions to dismiss on merits de novo, and was bound by Second Circuit law, not District of Columbia law, which was applied by the other district court.
In re Terrorist Attacks on September 11, 2001, 349 F. Supp. 2d 765 (S.D. N.Y. 2005).
Federal Courts  2958

Amendments to a complaint to add parties and the issuance of summonses after transfer by a multi-district litigation (MDL) panel do not affect the choice of law to be applied by a district court sitting in diversity.
In re Ski Train Fire In Kaprun, Austria on Nov. 11, 2000, 257 F. Supp. 2d 717 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).
Federal Courts  2958

In § 10(b) securities fraud cases transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, applicable limitations period was that of transferee, as opposed to transferor's, district; claims derived from federal law, limitations periods were procedural matters, and applying transferor's limitations periods would allow investors to file claims in inconvenient forum and then take longer limitations period with them when their case was transferred.
In re Integrated Resources Real Estate Ltd. Partnerships Securities Litigation, 815 F. Supp. 620 (S.D. N.Y. 1993).
Securities Regulation  134

The amenability of defendant to suit in a diversity action is normally governed by the law of the state in which the federal district court sits.
Jayne v. Royal Jordanian Airlines Corp., 502 F. Supp. 848 (S.D. N.Y. 1980).
Federal Courts  3025(4)

Federal court, to which litigation was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was required to apply substantive law of transferor forum.
Stirling v. Chemical Bank, 382 F. Supp. 1146 (S.D. N.Y. 1974).
Federal Courts 157

In cases transferred under this section, the substantive law of the transferor forum applies after transfer.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 219 (W.D. Okla. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Law of transferor district is to be applied in multidistrict litigation transfers.
Philadelphia Housing Authority v. American Radiator & Standard Sanitary Corp., 309 F. Supp. 1053 (E.D. Pa. 1969).
Federal Courts  2958

Principle derived from cases transferred from one federal district to another that transferee court should apply law of transferor court regardless of who initiated transfer—is traditionally followed in cases consolidated by multidistrict panel.
In re San Juan Dupont Plaza Hotel Fire Litigation, 745 F. Supp. 79 (D.P.R. 1990).
Federal Courts  2958

Choice of law rules of transferor court applied where case was transferred by Judicial Panel for Multidistrict Litigation for convenience and efficiency.
In re Enron Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA" Litigation, 511 F. Supp. 2d 742 (S.D. Tex. 2005).
Federal Courts  2958

Substantive law of transferor forum will apply after transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Plumbing Fixtures Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 756 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

Court to which multidistrict litigation has been transferred must apply law of transfer forum.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Hanover, N. H., 314 F. Supp. 62 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Choice of law, law governing

para.paratext:
Federal district court in California had to apply New York substantive and choice-of-law rules to all state law legal issues in removed state court securities fraud action that was transferred to it by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation for resolution of any pretrial matters.
In re Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortgage-backed Securities Litigation, 943 F. Supp. 2d 1035 (C.D. Cal. 2013).
Federal Courts  2958

Application of California law on nationwide basis was not warranted in multidistrict litigation against automobile manufacturer to recover damages for diminution in market value of plaintiffs’ vehicles in light of defects in those vehicles that led to incidents of sudden, unintended acceleration (SUA), where cases were filed in multiple states, parties did not agree on choice of law, and states' laws varied materially with regard to manifestation of alleged defect, privity requirement for implied warranty of merchantability claims, and statutes of limitations.
In re Toyota Motor Corp. Unintended Acceleration Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 785 F. Supp. 2d 925 (C.D. Cal. 2011).
Limitation Of Actions  2(1); Products Liability  105; Products Liability  203; Sales  509

In a diversity action transferred pursuant to multidistrict litigation statute, the transferee court applies the choice-of-law rules of the state where the transferor court sits.
In re U.S. Office Products Co. Securities Litigat., 251 F. Supp. 2d 58 (D.D.C. 2003).
Federal Courts  2958

In litigation involving cases transferred pursuant to statutes governing multidistrict suits, the court must apply the choice of law rules of the transferor court.
In re Educational Testing Service Praxis Principles of Learning and Teaching: Grades 7-12 Litigation, 517 F. Supp. 2d 832 (E.D. La. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Court to which case is transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation applies its own interpretation of federal law, not that of the transferor court, and to the extent that the action involves issues of state law, court applies the choice of law rules that would govern in the transferor forum.
In re Parmalat Securities Litigation, 412 F. Supp. 2d 392 (S.D. N.Y. 2006).
Federal Courts  2958

Amendments to a complaint to add parties and the issuance of summonses after transfer by a multi-district litigation (MDL) panel do not affect the choice of law to be applied by a district court sitting in diversity.
In re Ski Train Fire In Kaprun, Austria on Nov. 11, 2000, 257 F. Supp. 2d 717 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).
Federal Courts  2958

Choice of law rules of transferor court applied where case was transferred by Judicial Panel for Multidistrict Litigation for convenience and efficiency.
In re Enron Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 511 F. Supp. 2d 742 (S.D. Tex. 2005).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Contemporaneous dual control of courts

para.paratext:
In separation and transfer of claims under this section and § 1404 of this title permitting transfer for pretrial proceedings or transfer for other reasons, contemporaneous dual control by two or more district courts of single claim for relief or separate issues thereof is not permissible in federal system.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2901; Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Government antitrust actions

para.paratext:
For purposes of this section, which provides that this section pertaining to transfer of actions does not apply to antitrust actions in which United States is a complainant, Tennessee Valley Authority, which conceded that it was a government corporation, was not equivalent of the United States and thus this section did not prevent transfer of the Authority's uranium antitrust claims for consolidation for pretrial proceedings with Illinois action which involved similar allegations.
In re Uranium Industry Antitrust Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 1223 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Neither government's civil nor criminal antitrust actions were subject to transfer to another district for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings with other similar private treble damage antitrust actions.
In re Toilet Seat Antitrust Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict action in which Securities and Exchange Commission sought injunctive relief against corporation and others would be consolidated and transferred, along with private damage actions under federal securities laws, to the District of Columbia, notwithstanding Securities and Exchange Commission's contention that its action should not have been consolidated because of same considerations leading to enactment of section, in view of subsec. (g) of this section, exempting government actions for injunctive relief under antitrust laws from transfer, where common fact questions existed, defendants wished to engage in substantial discovery and probable questions on access to Securities and Exchange Commission transcripts of testimony and exhibits could best be resolved by assigning all actions to single judge.
In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: Tag-along actions

para.paratext:
Delays experienced by plaintiffs who brought Holocaust-related actions against European insurers in California state court, which were removed and then transferred to New York for consolidation by Panel on Multi-District Litigation, did not warrant remand to California federal court; actions were “tag-along” to others already pending in New York, delay in deciding motions addressed to forum issues resulted from need to sift through voluminous submissions, plaintiffs had benefitted from being able to rely on briefs submitted by others, and district court expected to address promptly other pretrial issues.
In re Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. (“Generali”) Holocaust Ins. Litigation, 228 F. Supp. 2d 376 (S.D. N.Y. 2002).
Federal Courts  2958

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted with regard to 21 products liability actions and more than 30 tag-along actions, pending in 22 districts, alleging that plaintiffs who used the defendants' medication suffered severe bleeding or other injuries and that defendants did not adequately warn prescribing physicians or consumers of the risks associated with the drug; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Xarelto (Rivaroxaban) Products Liability Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1402 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in nine actions and 13 potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts, alleging that some of the defendants falsely touted a medication as providing superior cardiovascular benefits to those of aspirin, and knew or should have known, misrepresented, or failed to disclose various serious risks of taking the medication; actions involved complex common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Plavix Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 923 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer for pretrial proceedings of potential tag-along action, for inclusion in previously consolidated and ongoing pretrial proceedings in actions alleging that managed health care defendants engaged in unlawful cost-containment policies, was warranted, even though settlement had been proposed; actions involved common questions of fact, transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and settlement could have significant impact on remaining claims.
In re Managed Care Litigation, 246 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

Removed causes of action that were brought not by shareholders/bondholders of failed energy company but by shareholders of this company's subsidiary would not be transferred to Southern District of Texas, where securities and ERISA litigation involving this company was already pending, where conduct purporting to form basis for legal liability in removed actions was largely distinct from operative conduct at issue in Texas litigation.
In re Enron Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 227 F. Supp. 2d 1389 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957

Where additional potentially related action came to attention of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation too late to be included in hearing on motion to transfer, action would be treated as a “tag-a-long action.”
In re Preferential Drug Products Pricing Antitrust Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1027 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Where “tag-along” actions instituted by purchasers of distributorships and other actions previously transferred to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings contained similar allegations of illegal pyramid sales scheme involving defendants, “tag-along” actions would also be transferred.
In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 844 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

Cases filed after hearing on motions for transfer of actions to single district for coordinated or consolidated trial proceedings would be treated as tag-along cases.
In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Centralization of action

para.paratext:
Informal coordination was not a practicable alternative to centralization of litigation in 10 putative class actions and seven potential tag-along actions against ride-sharing company, including one action that also asserted claims against smartphone manufacturer, all of which arose from company's announcement that certain personal information of 57 million drivers and riders was inappropriately downloaded by individuals outside the company; the actions were pending in nine districts and involved 14 distinct groups of plaintiffs' counsel in complex litigation.
In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Data Security Breach Litigation, 304 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 41 actions, pending in 23 districts, arising out of allegations that the use of certain medications for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus resulted in heart failure or other conditions; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Onglyza (Saxagliptin) and Kombiglyze XR (Saxagliptin and Metformin) Products Liability Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was warranted in four putative class actions pending in four districts and raising allegations that a cellular telephone company improperly marketed and/or administered its internet telephone services; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to class certification issues), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Vonage Marketing and Sales Practices, 505 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Conditional transfer orders—Generally

para.paratext:
Request of plaintiff in federal action in New York, where he was represented by pro bono counsel, to condition the transfer of suit for coordinated pretrial proceedings on the appointment of a pro bono liaison counsel to represent him in the transferee district was beyond scope of power conferred upon Judicial Panel and request was more properly presented to transferee judge.
In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1167 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Conditional transfer order of clerk of Judicial Panel is an administrative device used to expeditiously transfer apparently related cases where there is no opposition to such transfer and should not be considered as a decision or judgment by the Panel which must be reversed before such order can be vacated.
In re Grain Shipments, 319 F. Supp. 533 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

Nine multidistrict plumbing fixture private treble damage antitrust actions would be transferred without condition to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for pretrial proceedings despite contentions by one plaintiff in one of the nine actions that conditions should be imposed on transfer permitting transferor court to determine class action questions after transfer and despite request that Panel require completion of discovery agreed on or ordered by transferor court.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Vacation, conditional transfer orders

para.paratext:
Order vacating prior order of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, conditionally transferring action for inclusion in consolidated pretrial proceedings, would be vacated, where action was the subject of a pending summary judgment motion in the district court which involved a potentially dispositive issue of Texas law unique to the action; transfer would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Accutane Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

Conditional transfer order was vacated where all pretrial proceedings concerning common issue of liability had been concluded in transferee district and all actions before judge in such district already had either been tried or settled and where it appeared that all parties in actions before panel already had access to all discovery obtained in the transferee district.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Upperville, Va. on December 1, 1974, 430 F. Supp. 1295 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Orders conditionally transferring multi-district patent infringement actions to Southern District of New York were vacated in that transfer would neither serve convenience of parties and witnesses nor promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and since pretrial proceedings on common validity issue had been concluded in transferee court, actions were remanded to their respective transferor districts, notwithstanding dissatisfaction of parties with pretrial discovery rulings of transferee court.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2956

Order conditionally transferring Oklahoma action to District of Kansas, to which all actions arising out of airplane crash had been initially transferred, would be vacated, since instant plaintiffs' theory of liability was based on an alleged breach of warranty, whereas plaintiffs in the actions in Kansas were alleging liability based on the certification and operation of the aircraft, meaning that the Oklahoma action raised only limited questions of fact common to the Kansas litigation, and since, additionally, discovery in the Oklahoma action was far advanced.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Silver Plume, Colo., on Oct. 2, 1970, 368 F. Supp. 810 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: Transfer of action

para.paratext:
Centralization was warranted in four putative class actions pending in four districts and raising allegations that a cellular telephone company improperly marketed and/or administered its internet telephone services; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to class certification issues), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Vonage Marketing and Sales Practices, 505 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of six actions, pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that individual telecommunications companies cooperated with Government surveillance of telecommunications activity, to Northern District of California, for inclusion in previously centralized pretrial proceedings there, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact with the previously centralized actions, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (particularly with respect to matters involving national security), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re National Sec. Agency Telecommunications Records Litigation, 474 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Notice

para.paratext:
Plaintiffs in one of four actions in different district court were not entitled to order dismissing motion to transfer to the extent that it effected their action on ground that they were not included on the original service list accompanying motion to transfer, where plaintiffs conceded that they received notice of the proceedings more than three weeks prior to the hearing, and where they, in fact, filed a brief opposing transfer of their action and also appeared at the hearing and orally argued their case.
In re Sta-Power Industries Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1398 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Term “parties” as used in this section relating to giving notice to parties where transfer of multidistrict litigation occurs should not be construed to include unserved defendants.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Motions—Generally

para.paratext:
Plaintiff's motion before Judicial Panel to consolidate discovery proceedings in pending actions relating to validity of patent owned by plaintiff, which brought action for declaration that defendant's patent was invalid and not infringed, was not inconsistent with and did not supersede plaintiff's motion in district court to transfer defendant's counterclaim seeking declaration that plaintiff's patent was invalid.
General Tire & Rubber Co. v. Jefferson Chemical Co., 50 F.R.D. 112 (S.D. N.Y. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

Ride-sharing company's pending and anticipated motions to compel individual arbitration did not warrant delaying centralization of litigation in 10 putative class actions and seven potential tag-along actions, which were pending in nine districts, against the company, all of which arose from company's announcement that certain personal information of 57 million drivers and riders was inappropriately downloaded by individuals outside the company; the timing and outcome of rulings on company's motions to compel arbitration in this growing litigation was highly speculative.
In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Data Security Breach Litigation, 304 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Denial, by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, of motion for centralized pretrial proceedings in cases in prior docket, did not foreclose defendants from filing a second such motion, even though some actions in the prior docket were also encompassed in second motion.
In re Plavix Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 923 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Persons entitled to file motions

para.paratext:
Party can only initiate proceedings for transfer of action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with similar action by filing motion with Panel and by filing copy of such motion with district court in which action is pending.
Tim W. Koerner & Associates, Inc. v. Aspen Labs, Inc., 492 F. Supp. 294 (S.D. Tex. 1980).
Federal Courts  2951

Where plaintiffs in antitrust actions were not parties in any action in which transfer was contemplated, they lacked standing to file motions for transfer for purpose of coordination or consolidation.
In re Western Liquid Asphalt, 303 F. Supp. 1053 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Necessity of motions

para.paratext:
District court lacked authority to transfer Chapter 11 debtor's adversary proceeding based on alleged securities fraud to New York district court in which analogous actions were pending, inasmuch as statute required either that party file motion before Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation or that Panel itself initiate motion to transfer.
Holmes v. Grubman, 315 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (M.D. Ga. 2004).
Bankruptcy 2084.10; Federal Courts  2957

Judicial Panel would not act sua sponte with respect to federal actions which did not appear to involve single, primary, common defendant. In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability litigation.
In re Celotex Corp. "Technifoam" Products Liability Litigation, 68 F.R.D. 502 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Where transfer of four treble damage actions to Southern District of New York would be for convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of actions and where the move was not opposed by plaintiffs in one of the four actions and where all defendants in all four suits favored such a transfer though plaintiff states in the other three actions opposed such a transfer, the suits would be transferred on initiative of Judicial Panel.
In re Protection Devices and Equipment, 297 F. Supp. 622 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Time of filing motions

para.paratext:
Where motion to include action along with private actions being transferred to a single district by the Judicial Panel was made too late to have the motion presented for the Panel for decision and where Panel decided to transfer all the private actions to the Southern District of California, motion before the Panel concerning the action became moot and the inclusion of that action with the private actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings became a matter properly within the discretion of the transferee court.
In re U. S. Financial Litigation, 64 F.R.D. 76 (S.D. Cal. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2957

Inasmuch as plaintiffs in patent infringement suit had filed motion with Judicial Panel for consolidation and pretrial transfer, and cases could possibly be resolved by multidistrict litigation transferee court on the basis of collateral estoppel, defendants' motions to transfer in the interest of justice were premature and would be denied pending disposition of motions filed with the Panel and the resolution of any pretrial motions by the multidistrict litigation transferee court.
Kaiser Industries Corp. v. Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., 328 F. Supp. 365 (D. Del. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Time of determination, motions

para.paratext:
Where actions involving corporation and its partnerships involved common questions of fact, eight of nine actions would be transferred to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, but, on principles of comity, Judicial Panel would defer its decision concerning transfer of ninth action because of pendency of defendants' motion for summary judgment, which was fully submitted to potential transferor judge.
In re Resource Exploration, Inc., Securities Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 817 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would not defer its ruling on motions to transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings 16 actions arising out of airplane crash, since record was sufficiently developed for Panel to make informed decision as to transfer and as to appropriate transferee district, and benefits of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings could best be accomplished by transfer at the earliest possible date.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Chicago, Ill., on May 25, 1979, 476 F. Supp. 445 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Decision on question of transfer of actions for consolidated pretrial proceedings would not be deferred because of pendency of certain motions for dismissal, which motions could be presented to and decided by transferee court following transfer.
In re Cement and Concrete Antitrust Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1299 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Where motion to dismiss in one action had not been submitted to court for decision and where that action was still pending, fact that motion to dismiss had been made did not require delay of decision to transfer the action pursuant to this section relating to multidistrict litigation.
In re Scientific Control Corp. Securities Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 791 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Where action arising from airplane crash in Alaska involved questions of fact identical to those raised in actions previously transferred to the Northern District of California, so that transfer of the instant action was necessary to prevent duplication of common discovery, and where transferee judge had been designated to sit as a judge in the District of Alaska and had been assigned to the instant action for all purposes, so that he had before him plaintiffs' motions for remand to state court, transfer would not be postponed until after the motions for remand had been determined.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Juneau, Alaska, on September 4, 1971, 360 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Ruling on motion of transfer of cases pending in Southern District of New York would be deferred where in such actions the district court had ruled adversely on a request for an interlocutory class action determination, and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit had held such interlocutory determination unappealable.
In re Concrete Pipe, 302 F. Supp. 244 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Pending motion, on which no ruling had been made, to transfer federal cases arising out of airplane crash from Western District of Missouri to Western District of North Carolina for all purposes could be considered after completion of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in Western District of North Carolina of all pending federal actions arising out of crash and did not constitute reason to delay transferring, pursuant to motion, all pending federal actions to Western District of North Carolina for pretrial proceedings.
In re Mid-Air Collision Near Hendersonville, N. C. on July 19, 1967, 297 F. Supp. 1039 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Orders of transfer

para.paratext:
Transfer order, transferring case to federal district court, was effective when it was filed in office of the clerk of transferee court, which would be deemed to be the date it was file-stamped as received.
In re Rezulin Products Liability Litigation, 133 F. Supp. 2d 272 (S.D. N.Y. 2001).
Federal Courts  2958

Judicial Panel would not, in its order of transfer, specify that only coordinated, rather than consolidated, pretrial proceedings should be held in the transferee court.
In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1021 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Persons entitled to object to transfer

para.paratext:
Railroad which was not a party to action involving claim for shortages in grain shipped in railroad cars had standing to attack transfer to district in which several other actions were pending against it.
In re Grain Shipments, 319 F. Supp. 533 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

Plaintiff in two multidistrict actions alleging antitrust and common law violations arising from computer manufacturer's marketing of typewriter and magnetic tape composition device had standing to oppose transfer of actions to district in which actions alleging similar violations arising from separate package marketing of computer hardware, software and related services were pending.
In re IBM, 316 F. Supp. 976 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Exclusion

para.paratext:
Two plaintiffs' requests to have their actions excluded from centralized pretrial proceedings, in actions arising out of the defendants' allegedly illegal use of their purported dominance of a software and hardware system intended to manage numerous functions of motor vehicle dealerships, would be denied; although one plaintiff's action was somewhat more advanced than the other actions, significant pretrial proceedings, including fact depositions and expert discovery, remained to be conducted, and the factual overlap of the other plaintiff's action was undeniable.
In re Dealer Management Systems Antitrust Litigation, 291 F. Supp. 3d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Class actions

para.paratext:
Antitrust actions brought by bus operators against manufacturers of “Special Mileage Commercial Tires” remained separate civil actions for purposes of determining parties to the actions, for purposes of determining if those parties should be permitted to act as representatives of the class alleged in individual complaints and for all other purposes other than pretrial proceedings notwithstanding transfer of the actions to district where similar actions had been brought for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 67 F.R.D. 59 (W.D. Mo. 1975).
Federal Civil Procedure  181.5

Multidistrict cases transferred to one court retain their individual identities and it is intended, at least theoretically, that they be returned to the courts of their inception at conclusion of pretrial proceedings; thus, avoidance of inconsistent adjudications with respect to class action claims must necessarily involve choosing among competing representatives or structuring complementary classes so as to avoid overlapping as much as possible.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 57 F.R.D. 569 (E.D. Wis. 1972).
Federal Civil Procedure  161.1

head.headtext: Masters

para.paratext:
Statute governing multi-district litigation did not apply to various actions brought by mooring master based on same accident until and unless mooring master established jurisdiction over one or more defendants in multiple districts.
Saudi v. Acomarit Maritimes Services, S.A., 245 F. Supp. 2d 662 (E.D. Pa. 2003), judgment aff'd, 114 Fed. Appx. 449 (3d Cir. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Amendment of complaint

para.paratext:
Where a case has been transferred by the Judicial Panel, an amended complaint, whether or not it adds a new party, should be filed with the clerk of the transferee court and not with the clerk of the transferor court and attempted filing of amended complaint in transferor court was not a timely filing.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 63 F.R.D. 115 (W.D. Okla. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Estoppel

para.paratext:
Defendants were not estopped from moving for transfer of venue of three nationwide class actions brought against them, even though they had earlier argued against transfer while engaged in settlement negotiations with one set of plaintiffs before the Panel on Multi-District Litigation (MDL), since their two positions were not clearly inconsistent and MDL had not adopted the position; defendants' procedural posture was different during settlement negotiations with Connecticut-only plaintiffs when they argued against transfer, as compared to facing litigation in three consolidated actions brought by plaintiffs in 30 states following court's denial of proposed settlement.
Wilson v. DirectBuy, Inc., 821 F. Supp. 2d 510 (D. Conn. 2011).
Estoppel  68(2)

Mere fact that cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings did not have the effect of merging the suits into a single cause, or change the rights of the parties, or make those who were parties to one suit parties in another.
In re Nissan Motor Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 471 F. Supp. 754 (S.D. Fla. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Immunity

para.paratext:
Order of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation consolidating five pending lawsuits for coordinated pretrial proceedings in Southern District of Indiana did not force suit upon Regents of University of California to which they had not consented; coordination of pretrial activities, for purposes of avoiding inconsistent and duplicative demands on parties, witnesses and judges, neither enlarged state's liability nor invoked federal judicial power beyond that already sought by state.
In re Regents of University of California, 964 F.2d 1128 (Fed. Cir. 1992).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Moot questions

para.paratext:
In multidistrict litigation, dismissal of consolidated New York actions deprived docket of its multidistrict character, requiring dismissal, as moot, of defendants' motion for centralization; 16 actions had been pending in two districts.
In re Duke Energy Corp. Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 271 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2133

Order of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferring two actions for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was effective before, and thus rendered moot, district courts' orders remanding actions to state courts; neither district court had mailed certified copy of its remand order or case file to respective state court on or before date on which Panel's order was filed with district court.
In re Baycol Products Liability Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2133; Federal Courts  2958; Removal Of Cases  107(8)

Mootness assertion was not reason to delay transfer of case where mootness issue was apparently contested by parties and transferee judge would be amply able to resolve matter if and when any motion to dismiss was filed.
In re New York City Municipal Securities Litigation, 439 F. Supp. 267 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Issue of propriety of transfer of actions, in multidistrict litigation, from Central District of California to Northern District of California was not moot although all actions pursuant to designation were currently before same judge, where possibility existed that additional actions with similar allegations might be filed in jurisdictions not encompassed within circuit, and thus transfer order would insure that all tag-along actions would also be assigned to same judge.
In re Gas Vent Pipe Antitrust Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 799 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Res judicata

para.paratext:
Despite fact that actions brought in Southern District of New York and District of Arizona arising out of creation of gas authority in Oklahoma, the purchase and construction of its facilities, and sale of its bonds to the public involved substantially similar allegations, where plaintiffs in Arizona action intervened in New York action, those plaintiffs apparently were willing to cease activity in Arizona action while New York action proceeded, and disposition of New York action could have res judicata effect on arizona action, there was no need for transfer of Arizona action.
In re Buffalo Valley Gas Authority Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1029 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Protective orders

para.paratext:
Defendant was not entitled to a protective order to prevent transmission of information obtained through discovery in multidistrict litigation to independent state cases brought against defendant on similar causes of action, but in order to monitor whether discovery required in nonmultidistrict cases had as its purpose nonrelevant matters, plaintiffs were required, prior to release of information to parties in nonmultidistrict cases, to state to court terms on which any information was to be provided to litigants and to include jurisdiction in which case was pending, attorneys involved, terms for payment and reimbursement, involvement of counsel in other cases, and information desired to be released.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic Cleocin Products Liability Litigation, 81 F.R.D. 482 (E.D. Mich. 1979).
Federal Civil Procedure  1271.5

head.headtext: Mandamus

para.paratext:
Defendant in class actions transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings satisfied requirement that it lack other adequate means to obtain relief in seeking mandamus relief from decision by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) to remand remaining cases to original transferor courts, rather than use partial final judgments so that appeals from transferee court's decisions would be before same circuit court, given statute requiring that review of orders of JPML be by extraordinary writ.
FedEx Ground Package System, Inc. v. U.S. Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, 662 F.3d 887 (7th Cir. 2011).
Mandamus  3(1)

Package delivery company lacked requisite clear and indisputable right to writ of mandamus in challenging decision by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML), following conclusion of consolidated pretrial proceedings in drivers' transferred class actions against company, to remand those cases in which claims remained outstanding to original transferor courts, so that all issues in same case would be appealed at once to same circuit court, instead of using partial final judgments in such cases so that all anticipated appeals from decisions of transferee court would come before same circuit court; choice between two methods of case management was discretionary matter best left to transferee court and JPML.
FedEx Ground Package System, Inc. v. U.S. Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, 662 F.3d 887 (7th Cir. 2011).
Mandamus  44

head.headtext: Burden of proof

para.paratext:
In class actions, under Sherman Antitrust Act, §§ 1–7 of Title 15, by city and other governmental authorities and others, throughout nation, all of which had purchased certain locks from one or more defendant manufacturers who had places of business respectively in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts, manufacturers failed to sustain burden of proving strong burden of inconvenience from maintenance of actions in Pennsylvania, wherein manufacturers were transacting business and wherein manufacturers had allegedly conspired.
City of Philadelphia v. Emhart Corp., 317 F. Supp. 1320 (E.D. Pa. 1970).
Federal Courts  2909

Where only a minimal number of actions are before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, parties moving for consolidated pretrial proceedings have a strong burden to establish that the common factual questions are sufficiently complex and that the accompanying discovery will be so time consuming as to justify transfer.
In re Magic Marker Securities Litigation, 470 F. Supp. 862 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2905

To justify transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where only a minimal number of actions is involved the movant is under a heavy burden to show that common questions of fact were sufficiently complex and that accompanying discovery will be so time consuming as to further the purposes of this section.
In re Garrison Diversion Unit Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 223 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Movants seeking to transfer action in District of New Jersey for breach of contract, unjust enrichment, unfair competition, deceit, tortious interference with business relationship and violation of federal antitrust laws to Southern District of Florida for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action brought there by same plaintiff, involving identical allegations against common defendants and related allegations against noncommon defendants, had heavy burden of showing that common questions of fact were sufficiently complex and that accompanying discovery would be so time-consuming as to justify transfer, but they failed to meet that burden.
In re 21st Century Productions Inc. “Thrilsphere” Contract Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 271 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Where a minimum number of actions are under consideration for transfer, movants bear a strong burden to show that common questions of fact are so complex and accompanying discovery so time consuming that transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Raymond Lee Organization, Inc. Securities Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 1266 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Where action was brought in the Southern District of New York arising out of creation of gas authority in Oklahoma and sale of its bonds to the public, where other action was brought in the Eastern District of Oklahoma by mortgagee and bond trustee against authority and others alleging breach of contract and seeking specific performance and damages, and where New York action was much more extensive than Oklahoma action, mortgagee and bond trustee failed to sustain burden of demonstrating that factual questions involved in the two actions were complex enough to justify transfer of New York action to the Eastern District of Oklahoma.
In re Buffalo Valley Gas Authority Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1029 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

When only a minimal number of actions are under consideration for transfer pursuant to this section relating to multidistrict litigation, the moving party bears a strong burden to show that the common questions of fact are so complex and the accompanying discovery so time consuming as to serve the overall convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Commercial Lighting Products, Inc. Contract Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 392 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

In order to demonstrate that just and efficient conduct of litigation would be promoted by transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where only minimal number of actions are involved, moving party bears strong burden of showing that common questions of fact are so complex and that accompanying discovery so time consuming as to overcome inconvenience to party whose action is being transferred and to witnesses.
In re Interstate Medicaid Patients at Good Samaritan Nursing Center, 415 F. Supp. 389 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Where only a minimal number of actions are involved, party moving for consolidation of cases bears strong burden to show that common questions of fact are so complex and could make discovery so time consuming as to overcome inconvenience to party whose action in being transferred and its witnesses.
In re Royal American Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 242 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Where there are minimal number of cases involved in the litigation the party moving for consolidation of cases bears a strong burden to show that common questions of fact are so complex and accompanying common discovery so time-consuming as to overcome the inconvenience to party whose action is being transferred and its witnesses.
In re Scotch Whiskey, 299 F. Supp. 543 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Stay

para.paratext:
Stay of multidistrict patent infringement litigation was warranted, pending reexamination by Patent and Trademark Office of patents in suit; discovery had not yet been completed, and potential six-month to three-year delay was not unduly prejudicial in light of clarity reexamination might bring to litigation.
In re Cygnus Telecommunications Technology, LLC, Patent Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 2d 1022 (N.D. Cal. 2005).
Patents  1842

Judicial economy and potential prejudice to pharmaceutical company weighed in favor of granting company's request for stay pending transfer by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) of consumers' action alleging strict product liability, negligence, and breach of express and implied warranties for manufacture, sale, and distribution of Zyprexa that allegedly caused consumers' diabetes, since stay would allow coordination of discovery and pre-trial proceedings.
Benge v. Eli Lilly and Co., 553 F. Supp. 2d 1049 (N.D. Ind. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Potential delay of several weeks before Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) issued transfer ruling would not cause significant hardships to cigarette smokers as would warrant denying stay pending JPML's decision of pretrial proceedings in class action against cigarette manufacturers alleging state law misrepresentation claims; while delay was regrettable, case was one of unusual complexity.
Good v. Altria Group, Inc., 624 F. Supp. 2d 132 (D. Me. 2009).
Action  69(5)

Stay of consideration of motion to remand products liability action against diet drug manufacturer, by patient who was prescribed drug, would be warranted, pending judicial panel on multidistrict litigation's ruling on manufacturer's motion to transfer the action as part of diet drugs product liability litigation; transferee court of multidistrict litigation had ruled on similar motions to remand involving state law claims against pharmacies, and stay would further goals of judicial economy and consistency.
Moore v. Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, 236 F. Supp. 2d 509 (D. Md. 2002).
Removal Of Cases  107(.5)

Removed state court actions brought by former users of diet drugs that were removed from market based on information suggesting connection between use of drugs and development of valvular heart disease, who opted out of settlement agreement in federal actions consolidated for multidistrict litigation (MDL) against drug manufacturer, would not be stayed pending transfer to MDL court; it was proper and efficient for motion court to rule on pending motions to remand rather than wait for Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) to decide whether to transfer cases to MDL court, since MDL court had no superior experience or expertise as to primary issue presented by motions to remand, involving Massachusetts law, and that issue was not one that was likely to arise in other diet drug litigation in other courts.
In re Massachusetts Diet Drug Litigation, 338 F. Supp. 2d 198 (D. Mass. 2004).
Federal Courts  2958

Pending re-examination proceeding before Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) did not warrant stay of multi-district litigation challenging patent's validity under doctrine of non-statutory double patenting; although the PTO proceedings could simplify or change the issues before the court, they would not have permitted plaintiffs to present their claims, district court case could proceed significantly faster, and stay would have significantly harmed plaintiffs by causing their potential damages to mount or forcing them to or needlessly invest money in efforts to design around the patent.
In re Columbia University Patent Litigation, 330 F. Supp. 2d 12 (D. Mass. 2004).
Patents  1842

Proceedings in removed case would not be stayed until case was transferred from the District of Nevada to multidistrict litigation (MDL) court, despite defendants' contention that MDL court was better suited to decide remand issue raised by pending motion to remand filed by defendants, where determination of jurisdictional issue would depend on interpretation of Nevada law, and it was unnecessary to cause additional delay by staying proceedings so that another court could determine the motion.
Greene v. Wyeth, 344 F. Supp. 2d 674 (D. Nev. 2004).
Removal Of Cases  116

Trial court could properly issue stay of car rental company's motion to preliminarily enjoin software-based advertising network, pending decision by multidistrict litigation regarding advertising network's motion to consolidate instant action with earlier-filed actions against it; stay pending consolidation motion was not for an indeterminate period, no competent evidence showed that rental company would be unable to secure effective relief after termination of stay.
Hertz Corp. v. The Gator Corp., 250 F. Supp. 2d 421 (D.N.J. 2003).
Action  69(6)

Stay of consideration of motion to remand would not be warranted, in Mexican and Venezuelan citizens' action against automobile and tire manufacturer, seeking damages for personal injury and property damages allegedly arising when at least one tire completely and suddenly failed, although defendants had moved to transfer action as multidistrict litigation; motion to remand would not be better decided by transferee court, and issues on remand motion, such as whether defendants would be liable in a Texas court applying Mexican or Venezuelan law, were unique to the instant action.
Bellorin v. Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., 236 F. Supp. 2d 670 (W.D. Tex. 2001).
Removal Of Cases  107(.5)

In state's Medicaid reimbursement action against drug manufacturer, removed by manufacturer on federal-question grounds, stay pending manufacturer's request for transfer and consolidation with existing multidistrict litigation (MDL) was inappropriate, and state's remand motion took priority; case was not yet MDL, but merely proposed as MDL, rules of procedure for Judicial Panel on MDL specifically allowed for resolution of jurisdictional issues in district court, and stay would essentially decide jurisdictional issue against state.
Utah v. Eli Lilly and Co., 509 F. Supp. 2d 1016 (D. Utah 2007).
Federal Courts  2951; Removal Of Cases  115

Transfer of multidistrict patent litigation was stayed as to one defendant pending disposition of motion to dismiss.
In re Kaehni Patent, 311 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Attorney fees

para.paratext:
Refusal to award attorney in antibiotic multidistrict antitrust litigation counsel fees of over $75,000 on grounds that he prevented settlement from becoming final, adding about $650,000 in escrow interest to the wholesaler-retailer share of the final total, was not an abuse of discretion where actions of attorney and others in rejecting offer of city, county and state plaintiffs to turn over $650,000 in interest to the wholesaler-retailer class if the proceeding were withdrawn was quite probably not in the best interest of the class.
Alpine Pharmacy, Inc. v. Chas. Pfizer & Co., Inc., 481 F.2d 1045 (2d Cir. 1973), on remand, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 722, 414 U.S. 1092, 38 L.Ed.2d 549.
Antitrust And Trade Regulation  990

Where fee awarded by court to lead counsel out of fund contributed to by all plaintiffs in consolidated actions was in proportion to the benefits which the litigation produced, where district court proceeded on concepts of quasi contract and restitution, where lead counsel were given a charge on the special fund and were not given a personal judgment against anyone, where the fund was created out of amounts received in settlement, where none of the settlements could be finalized without district court approval, and where lead counsel engaged in substantial work which benefited all claimants, the payment to the lead counsel was justified on the common fund doctrine.
Vincent v. Hughes Air West, Inc., 557 F.2d 759 (9th Cir. 1977).
Attorney And Client  155

head.headtext: Costs and expenses

para.paratext:
Although motion for transfer of two actions pending in one federal district court to another district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was denied, motion was not frivolous; thus movants would not be ordered to pay attorneys' fees and travel expenses of opponents of the motion.
In re Royal Typewriter Co. (Royal Bond Copier) Breach of Warranty Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 925 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Civil Procedure  2736; Federal Civil Procedure  2774(6)

Judicial Panel, which had ordered actions arising from air disaster transferred from Southern District of New York, Eastern District of Pennsylvania, and Middle District of Pennsylvania to District of Puerto Rico for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with related actions, would not order payment by United States of necessary travel expenses incurred by counsel in connection with pretrial discovery proceedings.
In re San Juan, Puerto Rico Air Crash Disaster, 316 F. Supp. 981 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: Remand

para.paratext:
Federal district court, on request by defendant manufacturer of prescription pain medication to grant a stay during pendency of request to Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) to transfer the action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, would consider plaintiffs' motion to remand to state court, which motion called into question the district court's subject matter jurisdiction.
Rutherford v. Merck & Co., Inc., 428 F. Supp. 2d 842 (S.D. Ill. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Decision on plaintiffs' motions to remand class actions would be deferred in multi-district litigation (MDL) proceeding encompassing actions arising from “late trading” and “market-timed” transactions of mutual fund shares, despite plaintiffs' contentions that their claims arose from their status as holders of mutual fund shares, and thus were not removable under Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act (SLUSA), where complaints were broad enough to include within proposed classes persons who purchased or sold mutual fund shares during class periods, and it appeared that late trades and market-timed transactions involved “purchase or sale of a covered security” and were allegedly “manipulative and deceptive.”
In re Alger, Columbia, Janus, MFS, One Group, Putnam Mut. Fund Litigation, 320 F. Supp. 2d 352 (D. Md. 2004).
Federal Courts  2958; Removal Of Cases  115

Motions to remand included in mortgage company's motion for centralized pretrial proceedings in actions that alleged predatory lending practices would be denied in the interest of economy and efficiency; motions could be presented to the transferee judge.
In re: Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortg. Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 582 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

Pendency of motion to remand to state court is not sufficient basis to avoid inclusion in multidistrict litigation proceedings.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951
