Removed shareholder/bondholder actions that were pending against failed energy company in the Middle District of Alabama, Northern District of California, District of Oregon, and Western District of Texas would be transferred to the Southern District of Texas, on ground that each of these actions involved common questions of fact with litigation already pending in that district and that transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, even though transferor court had not yet ruled on parties' remand or jurisdictional motions; remand and jurisdictional motions, if not resolved in transferor court by time of transfer, could be presented to and decided by transferee judge.
In re Enron Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 227 F. Supp. 2d 1389 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957; Federal Courts  2958

Plaintiffs in action which had been consolidated with others under rules relating to multidistrict litigation failed to provide adequate support for their motion to have the case remanded to transferor court.
In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1125 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Review

para.paratext:
Court of Appeals for circuit in which antitrust action was originally filed lacked jurisdiction to hear interlocutory appeal from district court to which case had been transferred by panel on multidistrict litigation for consolidated pretrial proceedings, and applications for permission to appeal would be transferred to circuit in which transferee court was located.
FMC Corp. v. Glouster Engineering Co., 830 F.2d 770 (7th Cir. 1987).
Federal Courts  2958

Court of Appeals for District of Columbia had jurisdiction over appeal from multidistrict litigation transferee judge's order of contempt issued over the telephone from judge's home district in Texas to nonparty witness who was being deposed in Washington, D.C. and who lived and worked in vicinity of District of Columbia.
In re Corrugated Container Antitrust Litigation, 662 F.2d 875, 213 (D.C. Cir. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Law of case

para.paratext:
Transferee judge's order vacating transferor judge's order compelling arbitration in multidistrict antitrust action violated the law of the case doctrine; transferee judge failed to find any extraordinary circumstances that would have justified vacating order, and multidistrict litigation transfer statute did not authorize a transferee judge to vacate or modify an order of a transferor judge.
In re Pharmacy Benefit Managers Antitrust Litigation, 582 F.3d 432 (3d Cir. 2009).
Federal Courts  2958

Order of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation consolidating five pending lawsuits for coordinated pretrial proceedings in Southern District of Indiana was not barred, under principles of law of the case, by prior decisions of Indiana and California district courts in the individual cases, where none of the decisions treated questions of commonality of facts, witnesses and parties addressed by Panel.
In re Regents of University of California, 964 F.2d 1128 (Fed. Cir. 1992).
Courts  99(7)

Federal District Court for the Central District of California had discretion to depart from law of the case doctrine, based on substantial change in circumstances, in order to vacate decision issued by Federal District Court for the Middle District of Florida appointing class counsel in consumer fraud putative class action; after Florida court's decision to appoint counsel had been made, case had been transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL Panel) with five other class actions against same defendant and consolidated into one action, which then required appointment of interim counsel for consolidated suit.
In re Oreck Corp. Halo Vacuum and Air Purifiers Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 282 F.R.D. 486 (C.D. Cal. 2012).
Courts  99(7)

Split between circuits of transferee and transferor courts on scope of public disclosure bar to qui tam claims, on which transferee court made pretrial ruling in multidistrict litigation in dismissing some of relator's claims, did not result in change in controlling law when case was remanded to transferor court for trial, so as to justify departure from the law-of-the-case doctrine through reconsideration of issue on remand to transferor court.
U.S. ex rel. Staley v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp., 587 F. Supp. 2d 757 (W.D. Va. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: POWERS AND DUTIES OF COURTS AND JUDICIAL PANEL
Transferor court, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel—Generally

para.paratext:
District Court for District of Michigan lacked jurisdiction to rule on motion for preliminary injunction, where two days prior to its decision action had been transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to District Court for Northern District of Ohio.
Glasstech, Inc. v. AB Kyro OY, 769 F.2d 1574 (Fed. Cir. 1985).
Federal Courts  2958

When action is transferred by Judicial Panel, until time it is remanded, transferor court is without authority to issue any orders or to entertain a motion for transfer for convenience of parties and witnesses, in interest of justice, from one district court to another or any other motion.
In re Aircrash Near Duarte, California, On June 6, 1971, 357 F. Supp. 1013 (C.D. Cal. 1973).
Federal Courts  2958

Order of Judicial Panel transferring cases by City of St. Paul and by State of Minnesota, charging conspiracy to fix prices of library editions of children's books, to the federal District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for pretrial proceedings effectively deprived federal District Court for Minnesota of further jurisdiction in cases until any subsequent order of remand by the Judicial Panel, but court would set date within which, defendants technically in default, must plead.
City of St. Paul v. Harper & Row Publishers, Inc., 292 F. Supp. 837 (D. Minn. 1968).
Federal Courts  2955

Case management order removing requirement that plaintiffs seek leave of court to amend their complaints to add additional defendants controlled conduct of pretrial proceedings in multidistrict asbestos litigation in joint transferee districts, notwithstanding allegedly contrary case management order issued by judge of transferor district, and despite claim that case management order applied only to case before signator judge; judge of transferor district no longer retained authority to issue orders in case, and case management order was clearly meant to control all joint district litigation.
In re Asbestos Litigation, 963 F. Supp. 247 (S.D. N.Y. 1997).
Federal Civil Procedure  1938.1; Federal Courts  2958

Federal district courts have no powers, such as Judicial Panel has, to summon all parties concerned in various actions in different districts, to weigh interests and convenience of all parties and, in proper case, to transfer all actions to one forum.
City of Philadelphia v. Emhart Corp., 317 F. Supp. 1320 (E.D. Pa. 1970).
Federal Courts  2909

District court maintained authority to rule on motion to remand in automobile owners' suit against manufacturer seeking both injunctive relief and damages for its failure to comply with Virginia's emission control system requirements, despite fact that case had been conditionally transferred to multidistrict litigation, since conditional transfer order did not affect or suspend orders or pretrial proceedings, nor limit district court's pretrial jurisdiction.
Claytor v. Volkswagen Group of America, Inc., 189 F. Supp. 3d 602 (W.D. Va. 2016).
Federal Courts  2958; Removal of Cases  111

Federal district court sitting in Wisconsin had jurisdiction to decide remand motion, motion to supplement record, and motion to file supplemental authority in support of motion to remand, filed by state in suit against pharmaceutical manufacturers claiming overcharges for drugs purchased by state, even though court had received Conditional Transfer Order transferring case to District of Massachusetts for consolidated pretrial proceedings involving similar suits.
State of Wisconsin v. Abbott Laboratories, 390 F. Supp. 2d 815 (W.D. Wis. 2005).
Federal Courts  2958

This section providing for transfer of civil actions involving common questions of fact to single district court for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings did not authorize transferor courts to determine scope and status of class action claims involved in individual civil antitrust actions which were to be transferred to single district for consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Pending motions for Judicial Panel, transferor court, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
If Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation had transferred “tag-along actions” prior to entry of remand order by transferor court, transferee court would have had jurisdiction to consider motion for remand after transfer, and entry of such transfer order would have deprived transferor court of jurisdiction until case was returned to it, but mere pendency of motion to transfer before multidistrict panel did not suspend jurisdiction of transferor court.
General Elec. Co. v. Byrne, 611 F.2d 670 (7th Cir. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Transfer of non-party's motion to quash manufacturers' subpoenas duces tecum to another federal district court outside of state was warranted, with regard to multi-district litigation against manufacturers of welding products which alleged personal injuries caused by exposure to welding fumes, since laws and rules of transferring district would apply in resolving motion, transferee court was readily familiar with underlying issues, transferee court could enforce documents-only subpoena, and transferee court issued standing order that it would relieve non-parties in other districts and their counsel of undue hardship.
In re Welding Rod Products Liability Litigation, 406 F. Supp. 2d 1064 (N.D. Cal. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Motion before Judicial Panel to transfer counterclaim for consolidated pretrial proceedings did not oust district court of jurisdiction to decide motion to change venue of counterclaim.
General Tire & Rubber Co. v. Jefferson Chemical Co., 50 F.R.D. 112 (S.D. N.Y. 1970).
Federal Courts  2902

Multidistrict litigation (MDL) court could rule on omnibus dispositive motion prior to transfer, on claim that manufacturer failed to warn patients that drug would increase their risk of developing type 2 diabetes, where no plaintiff claimed that she could produce expert on specific causation that would survive Daubert if court's ruling was correctly decided; remanding without ruling on summary judgment would have been inefficient, costly, and contrary to purposes of MDL statute, court was familiar with science and issues present and could dispose of issues far more quickly and efficiently than dozens of courts spread across country, and court was competent to consider law of multiple jurisdictions.
In re Lipitor (Atorvastatin Calcium) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 226 F. Supp. 3d 557 (D.S.C. 2017).
Federal Courts  2958

Mere pendency of motion to transfer before Judicial Panel does not affect or suspend orders and discovery proceedings in transferor district court and does not in any way limit jurisdiction of transferor court to rule upon matters properly presented to it for decision.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Paris, France, on March 3, 1974, 376 F. Supp. 887 (J.P.M.L. 1974). See, also, In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 362 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Mere filing of motion under this section relating to multidistrict litigation did not deprive court of jurisdiction to decide pending motion to transfer.
In re Frost Patent, 316 F. Supp. 977 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Subpoenas, transferor court, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Exceptional circumstances warranted transfer of subpoena dispute from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, where enforcement of third-party subpoena seeking production of documents was sought, to the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, as the issuing court in a putative antitrust class action against contact lens sellers being litigated as multidistrict litigation (MDL); resolution of the subpoena dispute by enforcing court risked disruption of the underlying MDL suit involving 50 separate actions against eye care professionals, interest in avoiding that disruption plainly outweighed negligible burden to third-party served with subpoena, and issuing court was best positioned to address merits of motion to enforce.
In re Disposable Contact Lens Antitrust Litigation, 306 F. Supp. 3d 372 (D.D.C. 2017).
Witnesses  9; Witnesses  16

Existence of statutory or case law regarding the enforceability of subpoena duces tecum issued by court in which claims later transferred as multidistrict litigation were originally filed was not new matter, as required to support nonparties' motion for leave to file surreplies addressing merits of plaintiff's motion to enforce subpoenas; rather than reply to merits of subpoenas, nonparties had challenged court's authority under multidistrict litigation statute to issue subpoenas.
U.S. ex rel. Pogue v. Diabetes Treatment Centers of America, Inc., 238 F. Supp. 2d 270 (D.D.C. 2002).
Federal Courts  2958

Alleged failure by relator of False Claims Act suit against diabetes treatment center to comply with local rules of district in which claims were filed was not prejudicial to nonparty that was subject to subpoena duces tecum issued by court in which claims were filed, on motion to deny relator's motion to compel discovery in multidistrict litigation court.
U.S. ex rel. Pogue v. Diabetes Treatment Centers of America, Inc., 238 F. Supp. 2d 270 (D.D.C. 2002).
Federal Courts  2958

District court in multidistrict litigation had jurisdiction to issue orders related to subpoenas issued by another district court.
In re Neurontin Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 245 F.R.D. 55 (D. Mass. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

District Court has jurisdiction to address motions to compel compliance with subpoenas and motions to quash subpoenas in multidistrict litigation actions whether they request oral testimony or production of documents.
In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 256 F.R.D. 151 (E.D. Pa. 2009).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Judicial Panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel—Generally

para.paratext:
Limitations on transfer contained in this section affect only the judicial panel and not the transferee court.
In re Viatron Computer Systems Corp. Litigation, 86 F.R.D. 431 (D. Mass. 1980).
Federal Courts  2958

Home bankruptcy court in which individual Chapter 11 debtor had commenced adversary proceeding to recover for stock brokerage firm's and securities analyst's alleged fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, and other misconduct was not proper court to decide whether proceeding should be transferred under multidistrict litigation statute, for coordination or consolidation with multidistrict securities fraud litigation pending against this brokerage firm, analyst and other defendants in Southern District of New York; rather, motion for transfer had to be filed with the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation.
In re Holmes, 306 B.R. 11 (Bankr. M.D. Ga. 2004).
Bankruptcy  2045; Bankruptcy 2084.15

Function of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation was not to supervise exercise of any individual party's right to transfer, inasmuch as no such right exists; rather, Panel weighs interest of all parties, considers multidistrict litigation as a whole in light of purposes of this section, and only then makes its determination regarding transfer.
In re New York City Municipal Securities Litigation, 439 F. Supp. 267 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

It is province of Judicial Panel to decide in the first instance whether litigation should be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding while it is the province of transferee judge to determine whether and to what extent the trial proceedings should be coordinated or consolidated.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Dismissal of parties, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel was not authorized to strike certain parties as defendants in multidistrict actions even though court to which actions had been transferred for coordinated pretrial proceedings entered order holding those parties entitled to summary judgment and no appeal had been taken from such order where no final judgment had been entered in favor of those parties; it was necessary for parties to seek relief from transferor courts.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 354 F. Supp. 275 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Civil Procedure  388

head.headtext: ——Notice to parties, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation lacked authority to notify potential litigants of proceedings before it.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Chicago, Ill., on May 25, 1979, 476 F. Supp. 445 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel was not empowered to enter order requiring defendant airlines to file list of passengers involved in collision of two jet aircraft, next of kin, and settled claims or to require airlines to notify passengers and next of kin of proceedings before Panel.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tenerife, Canary Islands on March 27, 1977, 435 F. Supp. 927 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Severance of claims, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Motion by Indiana plaintiff to exclude from transfer certain issues involved in Indiana action fell outside purview of Judicial Panel, where, while this section governing multidistrict litigation provides mechanism whereby Panel can effectively exclude claims from transfer, Panel can effectively exclude claims from transfer under such section, Panel was not empowered to carve issues for separate treatment under such section.
In re Resource Exploration, Inc., Securities Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 817 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel is not authorized to transfer one issue raised by a claim, such as liability, while remanding another issue raised by the same claim, such as damages.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Duarte, Cal. on June 6, 1971, 346 F. Supp. 529 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Transfer for trial, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
The Judicial Panel has no authority to transfer cases for trial; its authority is limited to transfers for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Antibiotic Antitrust Actions, 333 F. Supp. 299 (S.D. N.Y. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Discovery orders, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation does not have the authority, as alternative to transferring action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, to order expedited discovery in the district in which such action is pending.
In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Uranium Contract Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 990 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel does not have power to require completion of discovery underway or such discovery as parties have agreed to or which has been ordered by transferor court in connection with transferring action to another district for pretrial proceedings.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Attorney fees, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
District court acted within its discretion in awarding $51,584,012.54 in fees and $5,468,450.26 in expenses to lead counsel, following $750 million settlement of multidistrict litigation (MDL) concerning contamination of United States rice supply by makers of genetically modified rice; the MDL litigation had lasted longer than five years, it required international discovery, it involved thousands of plaintiffs and hundreds of lawyers, it included several bellwether trials, and it raised novel and complex issues of law, and in making award court appointed a special master to review the fee request, court permissibly approved the lodestar-based fee request and cross-checked that fee's reasonableness by determining the fee as a percentage of the total recovery, and approved disbursement amounted to approximately 8.4 percent of the total recovery for all plaintiffs.
In re Genetically Modified Rice Litigation, 764 F.3d 864 (8th Cir. 2014).
Attorney and Client  155

Ex post analysis was proper methodology to determine the reasonableness of fees in District Court's initial attorney fee capping order, regardless of whether contingent fee agreements between the claimants and their attorneys in a multidistrict products liability quasi-class action involving approximately 50,000 eligible claimants and a $4.85 billion global settlement fund may or may not have been fair at the time they were entered into.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 650 F. Supp. 2d 549 (E.D. La. 2009).
Attorney And Client  147

Judicial Panel was not authorized to order payment of fees due liaison counsel who had been appointed to coordinate pretrial efforts of plaintiffs whose actions had been consolidated for pretrial proceedings or to condition remand of cases to transferor forums on such payment; however, matter would be called to attention of transferor courts and liaison counsel would have right to seek relief in those courts following remand.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 354 F. Supp. 275 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Civil Procedure  2742.5

head.headtext: ——Costs and expenses, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
District court conducting pre-trial multi-district litigation (MDL) concerning contamination of United States rice supply by makers of genetically modified rice, did not have the power to order parties in cases not before it to contribute to a settlement fund.
In re Genetically Modified Rice Litigation, 764 F.3d 864 (8th Cir. 2014).
Federal Courts  2958

Power of the Judicial Panel does not include the power to require the parties seeking transfer to reimburse counsel for other parties for reasonable travel expenses they would incur in connection with attending the pretrial proceedings in the transferee district.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Florida Everglades on December 29, 1972, 360 F. Supp. 1394 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Remand, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) did not abuse its discretion by refusing remand of consumers' diet drug cases against pharmaceutical drug manufacturer from Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) court to transferor courts after generic liability discovery had concluded years previously, MDL judge was not engaged in centralized management of negotiations, and five years had elapsed since MDL court entered its first order suggesting remand, where there was absence of any current suggestion from MDL Court that remand of consumers' cases would have been appropriate and there was no evidence that consumers' cases had languished impermissibly on MDL court's docket.
In re Wilson, 451 F.3d 161 (3d Cir. 2006).
Federal Courts  2958

Under statute governing transfer and remand of cases in multidistrict litigation, power to remand a transferred case to transferor court lies with Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, not the transferee district judge.
In re Roberts, 178 F.3d 181 (3d Cir. 1999).
Federal Courts  2958

Only Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) may remand a case or cases transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding; a district court sitting as transferee court lacks that power.
U.S. ex rel. Hockett v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp., 498 F. Supp. 2d 25 (D.D.C. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Where action had been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation could only remand certain claims presented in the action to transferor court.
In re Air Crash Disaster in Ionian Sea on September 8, 1974, 438 F. Supp. 932 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Before the Judicial Panel will couple its order of transfer with the simultaneous separation and remand of any claims in an action, Panel must be convinced that the claims to be returned to the transferor court involve little or no factual overlap with the claims to be transferred.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975). See, also, In re 1980 Decennial Census Adjustment Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 648 (J.P.M.L. 1981).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel may separate any claim from the transferred action and remand that claim to the transferor district.
In re Aviation Products Liability Litigation, 347 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——State court actions, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel has no power to consider propriety of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in state court actions.
In re Celotex Corp. "Technifoam" Products Liability Litigation, 68 F.R.D. 502 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Court of appeals actions, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Where one action which plaintiff sought to have transferred had been dismissed by district court and was pending on appeal before court of appeals, it was no longer pending in a federal district court and thus was beyond jurisdiction of the Judicial Panel.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1091 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Transferee court actions, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
The Multidistrict Panel on Litigation has neither the power nor the inclination to dictate in any way the manner in which coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings are to be conducted by the transferee judge; the scope of the proceedings, including the extent to which discovery is permitted, is a matter exclusively within the control of the transferee judge.
In re Sundstrand Data Control, Inc. Patent Litigation, 443 F. Supp. 1019 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Judicial Panel is not empowered to dictate manner in which coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings are to be conducted by transferee judge.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

Judicial Panel, which transferred securities cases to the Western District of Oklahoma for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, would decline Illinois plaintiff's request to decide class representation claims asserted by the various plaintiffs, as this was a matter for transferee judge to decide.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 221 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

Although Judicial Panel transferred 26 related actions from other districts to District of Kansas and assigned them to one judge and one action originally filed in Kansas shared common questions of fact with other actions, Panel would not interfere with internal affairs of District Court in Kansas with respect to assignment of actions before motion to transfer had been submitted to district court in which affected actions were pending and would not assign that action to the district judge for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Grain Shipments, 305 F. Supp. 3 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel has neither the power nor the disposition to direct transferee judge on transfer of action for pretrial proceedings in exercise of his powers and discretion in pretrial proceedings.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Transferor court actions, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation does not have the power to dictate in any way the manner in which transferor or transferee judges supervise actions pending before them.
In re Capital Underwriters, Inc. Securities Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 955 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

The Panel on Multidistrict Litigation is neither inclined nor empowered to direct or suggest to a transferor judge how he or she should conduct further proceedings in actions after remand.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. "Dalkon Shield" IUD Products Liability Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 108 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Review of court decisions, judicial panel, powers and duties of courts and judicial panel

para.paratext:
Where Judicial Panel transferred Utah case to the Central District of California which entered order denying plaintiffs' right to intervene, appeal from such order lay in the Ninth Circuit, and the plaintiffs were not entitled to have their complaint in intervention and other moving papers remanded to the Panel for remand to the District of Utah in order to take an appeal to the Tenth Circuit.
State of Utah v. American Pipe & Const. Co., 316 F. Supp. 837 (C.D. Cal. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation has neither authority under this section nor inclination to review decisions of district court, whether they are transferor or transferee court.
In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 510 F. Supp. 1220 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2958

The Judicial Panel is not vested with authority to review decisions of district courts, whether they are transferor or transferee courts.
In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 805 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel is not vested with statutory authority to review decisions of district courts, whether they are transferor or transferee courts; the Panel is only authorized to determine whether transfer of civil actions to a single district will be for convenience of parties and witnesses and will promote the just and efficient conduct of such actions.
In re Motion Picture “Standard Accessories” and “Pre-Vues” Antitrust Litigation, 339 F. Supp. 1278 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel is not authorized to act as appellate forum for every litigant disgruntled by rulings of transferee judge.
In re Plumbing Fixtures, 332 F. Supp. 1047 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: POWERS AND DUTIES OF TRANSFEREE COURT
Powers and duties of transferee court generally

para.paratext:
Transferee court has authority to enter dispositive orders terminating cases consolidated under multidistrict litigation statute.
In re Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) Implants Products Liability Litigation, 97 F.3d 1050 (8th Cir. 1996).
Federal Courts  2951

Function of judge assigned cases pursuant to this section relating to multidistrict litigation is to coordinate pretrial proceedings with view of returning cases to transferor judge in condition to be tried expeditiously to benefit of all parties to litigation.
In re Motor Vehicle Air Pollution Control Equipment, 52 F.R.D. 398 (C.D. Cal. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

In multidistrict litigation (MDL), orders of the transferee court were binding on all cases pending before it, and those which could be transferred to it as tag-along matters, notwithstanding that those cases could ultimately be adjudicated in the federal and state courts in which they originated; orders issued by federal transferee court would remain binding if the case was sent back to the transferor court, or remanded to state court.
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 467 F. Supp. 2d 256 (E.D. N.Y. 2006).
Federal Courts  2958; Removal Of Cases  109

Following a transfer under this section governing multidistrict litigation, transferee judge has all jurisdiction and powers over pretrial proceedings in actions transferred to him that transferor judge would have had in absence of transfer.
In re FMC Corp. Patent Litigation, 422 F. Supp. 1163 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Jurisdiction, powers and duties of transferee court—Generally

para.paratext:
A transfer of a case under this section cannot be made unless federal district court properly has subject matter jurisdiction.
BancOhio Corp. v. Fox, 516 F.2d 29 (6th Cir. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Transferee judge's reassignment of cases assigned to him by Panel on Multidistrict Litigation did not affect new judge's subject matter jurisdiction over cases, even though Panel had exclusive power to select judge.
In re IKO Roofing Shingle Products Liability Litigation, 757 F.3d 599 (7th Cir. 2014).
Federal Courts  2958

Federal district court to which removed state court securities fraud action was transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation for resolution of any pretrial matters was appropriate court to resolve any jurisdictional issues connected with motion to remand or abstain, and would not stay decision thereon for resolution by court with ultimate responsibility for trial, if the action remained in federal system.
In re Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortgage-backed Securities Litigation, 943 F. Supp. 2d 1035 (C.D. Cal. 2013).
Federal Courts  2958

A transferred action “arrives” on a court's docket on the date when the clerk of the transferee court receives the file and the certified docket from the transferor court, although the transferee court's jurisdiction commences at the time when the conditional transfer order is filed in the transferee court.
In re Worldcom, Inc. Securities Litigation, 2003 WL 22299350 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).
Federal Courts  2958

Jurisdiction of transferee court over cases consolidated for pretrial purposes under rules of Judicial Panel is ended by termination in the transferee court by valid judgment, by transfer by the transferee judge under §§ 1404(a) or 1406 of this title, or by remand to the transferor court.
In re Penn Central Commercial Paper Litigation, 62 F.R.D. 341 (S.D. N.Y. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Personal jurisdiction, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Where civil antitrust class actions were filed in various district courts and were consolidated by Judicial Panel on Multi-District Litigation and assigned to Chief Judge of Southern District of Texas, nonparty witness was not subject to jurisdiction of District Court for Southern District of Texas.
In re Corrugated Container Antitrust Litigation, 655 F.2d 748 (7th Cir. 1981), on reh'g, 661 F.2d 1145 (7th Cir. 1981), judgment aff'd, 459 U.S. 248, 103 S. Ct. 608, 74 L. Ed. 2d 430 (1983).
Federal Courts  2958

District court was not barred by due process clause from exercising personal jurisdiction in multidistrict litigation over class members in Agent Orange litigation who lacked sufficient contacts with New York.
In re Agent Orange Product Liability Litigation MDL No. 381, 818 F.2d 145 (2d Cir. 1987).
Constitutional Law  3965(4)

Transferee court's jurisdiction in multidistrict litigation is limited to cases and controversies between persons who are properly parties to cases transferred, and any attempt without service of process to reach others who are unrelated is beyond court's power.
In re Showa Denko K.K. L-Tryptophan Products Liability Litigation-II, 953 F.2d 162 (4th Cir. 1992).
Federal Courts  2958

Federal district court to which certain federal cases arising from air crash had been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was without jurisdiction to require nonparty lawyers for a claimant who had not filed any action whatsoever in any court to make payment into a discovery fund, or to require such a payment in connection with settlement of another claim in state court.
Hartland v. Alaska Airlines, 544 F.2d 992 (9th Cir. 1976).
Federal Courts  2955

Court to which case had been transferred for pretrial proceedings pursuant to this section may by its process obtain jurisdiction over persons to same extent as could court of original jurisdiction.
Maricopa County v. American Petrofina, Inc., 322 F. Supp. 467 (N.D. Cal. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

When cases are consolidated for pretrial discovery, under statute governing multidistrict litigation, transferee court can exercise personal jurisdiction to same extent as transferor court could.
In re Telectronics Pacing Systems, Inc., 953 F. Supp. 909 (S.D. Ohio 1997).
Federal Courts  2958

Insurers that issued liability policies to limited partners in entities that owned and operated hotel had sufficient minimum contacts with Puerto Rico to be subject to personal jurisdiction there in multidistrict litigation arising from hotel fire; action was transferred to Puerto Rico based on finding of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation that all claims shared common questions of fact and that centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient resolution.
In re San Juan Dupont Plaza Hotel Fire Litigation, 789 F. Supp. 1212 (D.P.R. 1992).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of sugar industry antitrust litigation to Northern District of California would not deprive defendant sugar refiners of due process on theory that they did not have the requisite minimal contacts with California to give the California court in personam jurisdiction over them.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 399 F. Supp. 1397 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Pretrial proceedings—Generally

para.paratext:
While only pending actions may be transferred or consolidated for coordinated pretrial procedure, transferred actions are still subject to the same procedures as any other action at pretrial stage; the “pending” clause of this section describes a limitation on power to transfer actions thereunder but does not affect power of transferee court to fashion pretrial procedures in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure once the transfer is made.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 161 (C.D. Cal. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of cases from one district to another by Judicial Panel is for pretrial proceedings only.
Greyhound Computer Corp. v. International Business Machines Corp., 342 F. Supp. 1143 (D. Minn. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

In a case transferred under the multi-district statute, the law of the transferee circuit controls pretrial issues such as whether the court has subject matter or personal jurisdiction over the action, or whether the cases should be remanded to state court because the cases were not properly removed; likewise, the law of the transferee circuit controls discovery issues such as whether to compel a deposition or documents pursuant to a subpoena.
In re Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE) Products Liability Litigation, 241 F.R.D. 185 (S.D. N.Y. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of six actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that certain conduct by the pharmacy benefit manager defendants violated federal antitrust laws; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially on the issue of class certification), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Pharmacy Ben. Managers, 452 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of multidistrict litigation for purpose of coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings relates only to pretrial proceedings and not consolidation for purpose of trial.
In re Liquid Carbonic Truck Drivers Chemical Poisoning Litigation, 423 F. Supp. 937 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

All judicial proceedings before trial, including pretrial determination of class questions, are “pretrial proceedings”. Plumbing Fixture Cases, In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Pretrial proceedings, powers and duties of transferee court—Generally

para.paratext:
Statute authorizing consolidation and transfer of civil actions containing common questions of fact for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings empowers transferee court to enter dispositive pretrial order terminating case.
In re Donald J. Trump Casino Securities Litigation-Taj Mahal Litigation, 7 F.3d 357 (3d Cir. 1993).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

“Pretrial proceedings” are not limited to discovery by deposition, interrogatories and requests for admissions.
Humphreys v. Tann, 487 F.2d 666 (6th Cir. 1973).

While only pending actions may be transferred or consolidated for coordinated pretrial procedure, transferred actions are still subject to the same procedures as any other action at pretrial stage; the “pending” clause of this section describes a limitation on power to transfer actions thereunder but does not affect power of transferee court to fashion pretrial procedures in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure once the transfer is made.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 161 (C.D. Cal. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

For purposes of remanding a case or cases transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, pretrial proceedings do not conclude until a final pretrial order is entered, and all prior proceedings, including rulings on motions for summary judgment, are pretrial proceedings that may properly remain before the transferee court.
U.S. ex rel. Hockett v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp., 498 F. Supp. 2d 25 (D.D.C. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

It is duty of transferee court in multidistrict litigation to control pretrial procedures in consolidated cases in such a way as to avoid pretrial chaos which could exist as a result of conflicting prior rulings.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic Cleocin Products Liability Litigation, 81 F.R.D. 482 (E.D. Mich. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Transfer of cases from one district to another by Judicial Panel is for pretrial proceedings only.
Greyhound Computer Corp. v. International Business Machines Corp., 342 F. Supp. 1143 (D. Minn. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

In a case transferred under the multi-district statute, the law of the transferee circuit controls pretrial issues such as whether the court has subject matter or personal jurisdiction over the action, or whether the cases should be remanded to state court because the cases were not properly removed; likewise, the law of the transferee circuit controls discovery issues such as whether to compel a deposition or documents pursuant to a subpoena.
In re Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE) Products Liability Litigation, 241 F.R.D. 185 (S.D. N.Y. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Transfers of six individual actions, pending in five districts, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions alleging that bank regularly failed to comply with terms of the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) and breached contracts with the plaintiffs and/or breached a contract to which they were intended third-party beneficiaries, was not warranted; although the actions might share some questions of fact with the putative class actions, they would focus to a large extent on individual issues of fact that were unique to each plaintiff's interactions with the bank, and in fact several of the individual complaints did not mention HAMP at all.
In re: Bank of America Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP)Contract Litigation, 746 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of six actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that certain conduct by the pharmacy benefit manager defendants violated federal antitrust laws; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially on the issue of class certification), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Pharmacy Ben. Managers, 452 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of multidistrict litigation for purpose of coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings relates only to pretrial proceedings and not consolidation for purpose of trial.
In re Liquid Carbonic Truck Drivers Chemical Poisoning Litigation, 423 F. Supp. 937 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

All judicial proceedings before trial, including pretrial determination of class questions, are “pretrial proceedings”.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Degree of coordination and consolidation, pretrial proceedings, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Although effect of pretrial consolidations of various suits cannot be to merge suits into a single cause or to change rights of parties or make those who are parties in one suit parties in another, consolidation of pleadings for pretrial purposes is within the discretionary power of district court, particularly in context of complex pretrial proceedings.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 161 (C.D. Cal. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

It is the responsibility and within the sole discretion of transferee judge to determine whether, and to what extent, pretrial proceedings in a particular action should be coordinated, or if appropriate, consolidated with pretrial proceedings in other actions and trial court has the duty to fashion a pretrial program to prevent duplication of discovery and unnecessary inconvenience to the parties and the witnesses.
In re U. S. Financial Litigation, 64 F.R.D. 76 (S.D. Cal. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

For purposes of transfer by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, cases may be “coordinated,” and thus serve the purposes of transfer statute, even if all other cases have already been disposed of, so long as there is some “common core” that makes it more just or efficient that the cases continue to be handled in one court or before one judge.
U.S. ex rel. Hockett v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp., 498 F. Supp. 2d 25 (D.D.C. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

This section contemplates that degree and manner of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is left entirely to discretion of trial judge.
In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 510 F. Supp. 1220 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Since an action was already pending in district selected by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation as transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, any future question of whether that action should be included in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, and if so to what extent, would be more properly left to discretion of transferee judge.
In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Since one action, in which pretrial proceedings were allegedly much further advanced than pretrial proceedings in any of the other actions, was already pending in the district selected by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation as the transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, the question of whether that one action should be included in the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, and if so to what extent, would be more properly left to the discretion of the transferee judge.
In re Airport Car Rental Antitrust Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 273 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Questions of the degree and manner of coordination of pretrial activities following consolidation and transfer for such purpose is addressed to the transferee judge, not to the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation.
In re Cement and Concrete Antitrust Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 750 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Order of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferring cases to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings did not have any effect on determination of one district court which declined to consolidate two of the cases as it was for the panel to decide whether to transfer the actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and for the transferee judge to determine to what extent the pretrial proceedings of the transferred actions would be coordinated or consolidated.
In re South Cent. States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1127 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation preferred to leave the degree and manner of any coordinated pretrial proceedings between Court of Claims action and actions in transferee district solely within joint discretion of transferee judge and Court of Claims.
In re Western Elec. Co., Inc. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 378 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Under this section, whether and to what extent pretrial proceedings should be coordinated or consolidated is strictly the province of the transferee judge.
In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

It is province of transferee judge to determine whether and to what extent pretrial proceedings in transferred actions and actions pending in transferee district should be coordinated or consolidated.
In re Industrial Wine Contracts Securities Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 909 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

Degree of coordination between action by Securities and Exchange Commission and private actions involving the same and additional defendants, relating to the same factual issues, and which were transferred to the same judicial district, was a matter to be determined by the transferee judge.
In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

If separate treatment of certain issues appears warranted, with regard to actions, which have been transferred for purposes of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, plaintiffs may address their arguments to transferee judge who has responsibility to determine whether and to what extent the pretrial proceedings should be coordinated or consolidated.
In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1376 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Degree and manner of coordination or consolidation of cases transferred by Judicial Panel are within the sole discretion of the transferee judge.
In re General Adjustment Bureau Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Extent to which groups of cases should be consolidated for pretrial purposes is a question left to the discretion of the transferee judge.
In re Grain Shipments, 319 F. Supp. 533 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Scheduling, pretrial proceedings, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Where multidistrict litigation is transferred to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding the transferee judge has great flexibility in tailoring a pretrial schedule to accommodate the divergent interest of the parties in the separate actions.
In re Caesar's Palace Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1256 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee court may exercise its discretion in scheduling pretrial proceedings in a manner which will protect the legitimate interests of small defendants in the costs of litigation.
In re Concrete Pipe, 302 F. Supp. 244 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Unique to particular parties, pretrial proceedings, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
California state law claim, brought against the telecommunication provider defendants in action in the Central District of California, was unique and thus would not be included in the centralization, for pretrial proceedings, of actions seeking reimbursement of the communications excise tax on certain long-distance telephone service.
In re Long-Distance Telephone Service Federal Excise Tax Refund Litigation, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Judge to whom cases are transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings has authority to schedule discovery and other pretrial proceedings on any issue unique to particular action or party to proceed in separate tracks concurrently with common pretrial proceedings.
In re Cuisinart Food Processor Antitrust Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 651 (J.P.M.L. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

Where several actions have been transferred to single district for centralization, transferee judge has authority to schedule any pretrial proceedings that are unique to particular parties, claims or actions to proceed concurrently with common pretrial proceedings, thereby permitting litigation to proceed expeditiously in all areas.
In re IBP Confidential Business Documents Litigation, 491 F. Supp. 1359 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Civil Procedure  1921

Transferee judge has authority to schedule any pretrial proceedings that are unique to particular parties, claims or actions to proceed concurrently with common pretrial proceedings, thereby permitting litigation to proceed expeditiously in all areas.
In re Air Crash at Schenley Golf Course, Pittsburgh, Pa., on August 21, 1977, 509 F. Supp. 252 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee judge has authority to schedule any pretrial proceedings that are unique to particular parties, claims or actions to proceed concurrently with common pretrial proceedings ordered under this section governing multidistrict litigation, thereby permitting litigation to proceed expeditiously in all areas; moreover, transferee judge has power to provide that no party need participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to that party's interests.
In re Continental Grain Co., Inc., 482 F. Supp. 330 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

In litigation in which actions in various districts are centralized pursuant to this section for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, any pretrial proceedings regarding any issues unique to any action, claim or party may be scheduled by transferee court to proceed concurrently with pretrial proceedings on common issues, and thereby all aspects of litigation can proceed expeditiously.
In re Dept. of Energy Stripper Well Exemption Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 1282 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

A judge to whom multidistrict litigation is transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings had authority to schedule any pretrial proceedings that are unique to particular parties, claims or actions to proceed concurrently with the common pretrial proceedings, thereby permitting litigation to proceed expeditiously in all areas; moreover, transferee judge has power to provide that no party need participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to that party's interests.
In re Oil Spill by “Amoco Cadiz” Off Coast of France on March 16, 1978, 471 F. Supp. 473 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Any issues unique to a particular action transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceeding could be scheduled by the transferee judge to proceed concurrently with the common pretrial matters.
In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Transferee judge had discretion and flexibility to accommodate the needs of transfer plaintiffs, or any other party, for any unique discovery or judicial attention concurrently with conduct of common pretrial matters.
In re Cenco Inc. Securities Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1237 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

District judge to whom actions are transferred for consolidated or coordinated discovery and other pretrial proceedings has broad discretion to design a pretrial program that will ensure that the needs of each party for any unique discovery or individual judicial attention can be accommodated concurrently with the conduct of common pretrial matters.
In re Transocean Tender Offer Securities Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 382 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

Transfer of actions for consolidated pretrial proceedings would not delay the development of any unique factual questions in actions, principally as they related to issues of infringement and patent misuse, since the transferee judge is empowered to design a pretrial schedule for the concurrent processing of such questions along with the common pretrial matters.
In re Western Elec. Co., Inc. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 378 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Participation of parties, pretrial proceedings, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Party to action which has been consolidated with another action for pretrial proceedings does not have to participate in discovery or other pretrial matters in which it has no interest.
In re U. S. Financial Litigation, 64 F.R.D. 76 (S.D. Cal. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Court in multidistrict litigation has authority to order attendance of corporate officers or employees other than counsel at pretrial proceedings when appropriate in the circumstances; in so doing, the court exercises its jurisdiction over the corporate defendant by ordering it to designate a representative to fill the role established by the court's order.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Stapleton Intern. Airport, Denver, Colo., On Nov. 15, 1987, 720 F. Supp. 1433 (D. Colo. 1988).
Federal Civil Procedure  1921

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging a conspiracy to establish an electronic system for registering mortgages as a means for hiding true identity of actual beneficial owners of negotiable promissory notes; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems (MERS) Litigation, 659 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Southern District of Mississippi was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 12 actions alleging that certain of defendant's employees were entitled to compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); the constituent actions in that District had been advancing efficiently with a large number of potential claimants, and all parties supported centralization in the District.
In re Wayne Farms LLC Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

Where several actions have been transferred to single district for centralization, transferee judge has power to provide that no party need participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to that party's interest.
In re IBP Confidential Business Documents Litigation, 491 F. Supp. 1359 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Civil Procedure  1921

Transferee judge has power to provide that no party need participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to that party's interests.
In re Air Crash at Schenley Golf Course, Pittsburgh, Pa., on August 21, 1977, 509 F. Supp. 252 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

After transfer of multidistrict litigation for consolidated pretrial proceedings, additional defendants, as distinguished from common defendant, need not participate in discovery unrelated to single actions in which they are involved.
In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability Litigation, 68 F.R.D. 502 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

It was not necessary for parties to multidistrict private civil treble damage litigation involving plumbing fixtures to participate in pretrial conferences held by transferee court in Eastern District of Pennsylvania; depositions of Oklahoma parties and witness could be taken in Oklahoma.
In re Plumbing Fixtures, 311 F. Supp. 349 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Civil Procedure  1383

head.headtext: Discovery, powers and duties of transferee court—Generally

para.paratext:
Where products liability actions were consolidated by panel on multidistrict litigation, order of reference under this section vested exclusive control in transferee judge of all matters pertaining to subject matter of discovery in cases transferred to her.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic Cleocin Products Liability Litigation, 664 F.2d 114 (6th Cir. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

It is the responsibility and within the sole discretion of transferee judge to determine whether, and to what extent, pretrial proceedings in a particular action should be coordinated or, if appropriate, consolidated with pretrial proceedings in other actions and trial court has the duty to fashion a pretrial program to prevent duplication of discovery and unnecessary inconvenience to the parties and the witnesses.
In re U. S. Financial Litigation, 64 F.R.D. 76 (S.D. Cal. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Scope of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and extent to which discovery is permitted are matters exclusively within control of transferee judge.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

Language of this section relating to consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings is intended to confer on transferee judge the power to fashion discovery program to accommodate different facets and nuances of litigation.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Scope generally, discovery, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
District court's administrative order entered in multidistrict litigation, effectively ordering defendant to exact assessments for discovery-generated expenses incurred on behalf of plaintiffs if it wished to settle, pay verdict or share its discovery materials with any plaintiff or claimant not before court overreached district court's authority and raised questions of conflict with policy of comity between federal and state courts.
In re Showa Denko K.K. L-Tryptophan Products Liability Litigation-II, 953 F.2d 162 (4th Cir. 1992).
Federal Civil Procedure  2738

head.headtext: ——Unique to particular parties, discovery, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
In multidistrict cases, transferee judge has broad discretion to design pretrial program to obtain maximum efficiency for counsel and economy of judicial time and he may also establish separate discovery schedule for any issue unique to case while discovery on common issues proceeds concurrently.
Meeder v. Superior Tube Co., 72 F.R.D. 633 (W.D. Pa. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee judge with respect to local undercount questions or claims included in multi district census litigation has authority to schedule discovery and other pretrial proceedings on any issues unique to particular geographic area of party to proceed in separate tracks concurrently with common pretrial proceedings, and transferee judge has power to provide that no party need participate in pretrial proceeding unrelated to that party's interest.
In re 1980 Decennial Census Adjustment Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 648 (J.P.M.L. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

Upon transfer of multidistrict actions, transferee judge would have authority to group pretrial proceedings on different discovery tracks according to common factual issues or according to each defendant, if necessary for just and efficient conduct of litigation, and to schedule any discovery unique to particular parties, actions or claims to proceed in separate discovery tracks concurrently with common discovery, and no party need participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to that party's interests.
In re Multi-Piece Rim Products Liability Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 969 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Following transfer of action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, transferee judge has broad discretion to design pretrial program that will allow discovery on any issues unique to any action or party to proceed concurrently with common discovery and no party need participate in pretrial proceedings unrelated to that party's interest.
In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee judge would have broad discretion to design pretrial program that would allow discovery on any issues unique to either of the two actions that had been consolidated for pretrial proceedings to proceed concurrently with the common discovery.
In re First Nat. Bank, Heavener, Okl. (First Mortg. Revenue Bonds) Securities Litigation, 451 F. Supp. 995 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Where action brought by corporation's bankruptcy trustee against former officers and directors was transferred for inclusion with pending proceedings involving conduct of defendants with respect to operation of corporation and sale of corporation's stock, trustee remained free to move before transferee judge regarding any reasonable discovery needs, and transferee judge had broad discretion to design pretrial program which would allow discovery on any unique issues to proceed concurrently with discovery of the common issues, but trustee was under no obligation to participate in discovery unrelated to trustee's action.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 442 F. Supp. 547 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Upon transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, discovery on any issues that were unique to a particular action could be scheduled by the transferee judge to proceed concurrently with the common pretrial matters.
In re Investors Funding Corp. of New York Securities Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 1199 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Following transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, no party need participate in discovery unrelated to particular issues with which it is involved, and any discovery unique to a particular action may be scheduled by transferee judge to proceed concurrently with common discovery.
In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Judge to whom case is transferred for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings with other pending cases has broad discretion in designing pretrial program to allow discovery on any issues unique to particular action to proceed concurrently with discovery on common issues.
In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 1077 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Judge of district court to which multidistrict securities cases were being transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings had the broad discretion to design a pretrial program that would accommodate the needs of each party for any unique discovery or judicial attention concurrently with the conduct of common pretrial matters.
In re Colocotronis Tanker Securities Litigation, 420 F. Supp. 998 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Judge to whom an antitrust class action is transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with a similar action has broad discretion to design a pretrial program and schedule under which discovery and other pretrial activities on any unique issues can proceed concurrently with discovery and other pretrial proceedings on the common issues.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 712 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Civil Procedure  1923

On transfer of multidistrict litigation for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings the transferee judge is empowered to establish a separate discovery schedule for any issue unique to the case and discovery on such issues can proceed concurrently with other discovery.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 397 F. Supp. 884 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

This section would not preclude plaintiffs from pursuing their local discovery at same time that common discovery supervised by transferee judge was taking place.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 570 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

After transfer of cases consolidated for pretrial proceedings, discovery on unique factual issues may be scheduled to proceed concurrently with common discovery.
In re Celotex Corp. "Technifoam" Products Liability Litigation, 68 F.R.D. 502 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Judge, to whom several actions from different districts are transferred for consolidation, has the broad discretion to design a pretrial program which will allow discovery on any unique issues to proceed concurrently with discovery on the common issues.
In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Applicability to other actions, discovery, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Multidistrict proceeding is not appropriate mechanism for case-specific discovery, since by definition that discovery is not of general interest to parties in all of the individual cases which comprise multidistrict litigation.
In re Factor VIII or IX Concentrate Blood Products Litigation, 169 F.R.D. 632 (N.D. Ill. 1996).
Federal Courts  2951

In centralized pretrial proceedings in multidistrict (MDL) products liability actions against manufacturer and wholesaler of prescription drug, modification to prevent injustice was warranted as to district court's discovery order requiring that either side wishing to interview plaintiff's prescribing physician serve five days' notice to opposing counsel; breadth of order had chilling effect on MDL process and created inconsistencies with related state litigation, warranting narrowing of order so that same restriction remained in place for defendants, but plaintiffs' counsel could engage in ex parte interviews with physicians who had not been named as defendants.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 230 F.R.D. 473 (E.D. La. 2005).
Federal Civil Procedure  1271

In a case in which actions pending in various districts have been transferred to particular district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, pursuant to this section governing multidistrict litigation, transferee judge has authority to invoke procedures whereby discovery already completed in action pending in transferee forum can be made applicable to other actions.
In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

In litigation in which actions in various districts are centralized pursuant to this section for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, transferee judge has power to provide that any discovery heretofore completed in any action may be made applicable to all actions, and transferee judge also has power to provide that plaintiff in actions before such judge need not participate in discovery or other pretrial proceedings unrelated to their respective actions.
In re Dept. of Energy Stripper Well Exemption Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 1282 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Any discovery completed before centralization of pretrial proceedings could be made applicable to all actions by using recommended procedures.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic “Cleocin” Products Liability Litigation, 450 F. Supp. 1168 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Judge to whom instant case was assigned could issue order to show cause why all discovery heretofore completed in another district with respect to other similar cases could not be made available to the parties in the instant action and considered accomplished in the instant action.
In re Western Electric Co., Inc. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 404 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Judge to whom each action was assigned could take appropriate steps to insure that all theretofore completed discovery in transferee district was made available to all parties.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Upperville, Va. on December 1, 1974, 430 F. Supp. 1295 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Discovery relating to instant case, theretofore completed in actions already pending in transferee district, could be made applicable to instant case, also transferred to that district.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 676 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Place of discovery, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
While purposes of venue provision of National Bank Act, section 94 of Title 12, may be accommodated, despite transfer of proceedings by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, by an order that bank's documents be inspected only in its home district, such order must be requested of transferee judge and will not issue automatically.
Matter of New York City Mun. Securities Litigation, 572 F.2d 49 (2d Cir. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Transfer of an action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings does not mean that all discovery must take place in transferee district; for example, depositions of witnesses may still occur where they reside, and any party may request an order from transferee court that its documents be inspected at its offices or at another convenient location in or near the city in which it is located.
In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Under this section empowering transferee judge to exercise the powers of the district judge in any district for the purpose of conducting pretrial depositions, judge of district court to which actions are transferred by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation is authorized, in his discretion, to conduct depositions in not only the transferee district but also any other federal judicial district as well.
In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 791 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Motions, discovery, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Motions relating to nonparty discovery are transferable from the court in which they are filed to the court that has been designated as the transferee court for multidistrict actions.
In re Uranium Antitrust Litigation, 503 F. Supp. 33 (N.D. Ill. 1980).
Federal Courts  2958

Upon transfer of multidistrict actions, transferee judge would remain free to establish separate tracks for discovery and motion practice according to common factual issues in actions under federal securities law and ERISA.
In re Pfizer Inc. Securities, Derivative & Erisa Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Appointment of lead counsel, discovery, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
District court had authority to appoint a committee of lead counsel to conduct all discovery on liability issues in consolidated actions arising out of air disaster, with other counsel being permitted to initiate discovery proceedings or pretrial motions only with approval of lead counsel or the district court.
Vincent v. Hughes Air West, Inc., 557 F.2d 759 (9th Cir. 1977).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

head.headtext: Issues determinable, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Important questions of law may appropriately be determined in consolidated pretrial proceedings, though such cases would be transferred for trial back to jurisdiction from which they had been transferred.
Control Data Corp. v. International Business Machines Corp., 306 F. Supp. 839 (D. Minn. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Pending appeal from order which relieved the State of Ohio from operation of a judgment barring class actions against corporation and others of settled claims did not prevent a transferee court from hearing and deciding questions raised in the case transferred by Panel which would materially advance the coordinated or consolidated discovery and other pretrial proceedings in the several transferred cases.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 219 (W.D. Okla. 1974).
Federal Courts  3452

Where it was appropriate that antitrust actions commenced in District of Kansas and Western District of Missouri be consolidated and assigned to judge in Western District of Missouri, question whether contract claim, in one action in which antitrust counterclaim and antitrust third-party complaint had been filed, should be included was for decision by transferee court, and pretrial motion to sever antitrust allegations of counterclaim and third-party complaint and consolidate them with antitrust action in Western District of Missouri could also be addressed to transferee judge.
In re Cessna Aircraft Distributorship Antitrust Litigation, 359 F. Supp. 543 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee judge in multidistrict air disaster litigation would not be restricted in pretrial proceedings to discovery relating to liability, and with damages to be left to transferor courts, as it was more conducive to effective judicial management to allow transferee judge to determine which issues were appropriate for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and which should be reserved for further proceedings following remand.
In re San Juan, Puerto Rico Air Crash Disaster, 316 F. Supp. 981 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Motions, powers and duties of transferee court—Generally

para.paratext:
This section is intended to grant to the transferee court the power to pass upon all pretrial motions, including motions to dismiss, motions for judgment on the pleadings, or motions for summary judgment.
Kaiser Industries Corp. v. Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., 328 F. Supp. 365 (D. Del. 1971).
