Once a case has been transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, the transferee court assumes complete jurisdiction for pretrial purposes and has authority to settle all pretrial motions including dispositive motions such as those for summary judgment or approval of a settlement and transferee court is also authorized to handle matters relating to class action certification in order to prevent inconsistent rulings and to promote judicial efficiency.
In re Agent Orange Product Liability Litigation, 597 F. Supp. 740 (E.D. N.Y. 1984).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Class actions, motions, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Under this section, and with specific reference to class action determinations made by a transferor court prior to transfer under this section, the transferee court may resolve conflicting requests for class action determination, and review, modify, expand, revise or vacate any prior order as in its judicial discretion, is desirable or necessary in interests of justice.
In re Exterior Siding and Aluminum Coil Litigation, 538 F. Supp. 45 (D. Minn. 1982).
Federal Courts  3840

Intent of this section permitting transfer of action for pretrial proceedings is to invest transferee court with exclusive powers, after transfer, to make pretrial determinations of class action questions.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Complaints, motions, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Although case was before federal district court for limited purposes generally relating to discovery, ruling on motion for amendment to pleadings was clearly within jurisdiction of multidistrict litigation transferee court, even though motion involved important substantive issue.
Sentner v. Amtrak, 540 F. Supp. 557 (D.N.J. 1982).
Federal Courts  2958

Second amended complaint in action to recover damages under § 78j of Title 15 prohibiting use of manipulative and deceptive devices in purchase or sale of securities substantially complied with order of transferor judge that facts be pleaded with greater specificity with the exception of failure to plead the stock certificate numbers of corporate stock bought and sold by plaintiffs, a transferee judge in multidistrict litigation would require amendment of second amended complaint to include such certificate numbers and deny motion to strike for failure to comply with transferor judge's order.
In re Penn Central Securities Litigation, 62 F.R.D. 181 (E.D. Pa. 1974).
Federal Civil Procedure  839.1; Federal Civil Procedure  1105.1

Transfer of 30 pending actions for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceeding was not premature because of defendants' desire to challenge sufficiency of complaints and/or jurisdiction of federal courts; presentation of such matters to single judge will further purposes of this section.
In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Dismissal, motions, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
In multidistrict litigation (MDL) involving allegations that banks understated their borrowing costs, thereby depressing London InterBank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and enabling banks to pay lower interest rates on financial instruments sold to investors, order dismissing antitrust claims for lack of antitrust injury was final appealable decision for bondholder plaintiffs, who only asserted antitrust claims, even though state and federal law claims brought by over-the-counter (OTC) and exchange-based plaintiffs survived; nothing about initial consolidation of bondholder plaintiffs' action with other cases in the LIBOR MDL rendered the dismissal of their complaint in any way tentative or incomplete.
Gelboim v. Bank of America Corp., 135 S. Ct. 897, 190 L. Ed. 2d 789 (2015).
Federal Courts  3299

Transfer of multidistrict litigation for purpose of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was not to be delayed because of pendency of motions to dismiss certain of the constituent actions since such motions could be presented to and decided by the transferee judge.
In re Oil Spill by “Amoco Cadiz” Off Coast of France on March 16, 1978, 471 F. Supp. 473 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Stays, motions, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Where one party opposed remand order issued by Judicial Panel and moved the Panel to vacate its order remanding case to transferor court, the motion stayed the remand and transferee court retained such jurisdiction over the case as it was granted by the transfer.
In re Penn Central Commercial Paper Litigation, 62 F.R.D. 341 (S.D. N.Y. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Action, in Southern District of Ohio, which was virtually identical with previous action commenced in Northern District of California was first conditionally transferred to Northern District of California, then motion to vacate denied and stay of conditional transfer order lifted, where appealed dismissal of first action for lack of venue had been without prejudice to second action; whether transferred action should be stayed pending resolution of pending appeal of whether defendant should be required to participate in pretrial proceedings was matter to be decided by transferee judge.
In re Koratron, 314 F. Supp. 60 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Summary judgment, motions, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Entry of summary judgment for statin manufacturer in all statin patients' products liability actions alleging statin caused diabetes before multidistrict litigation (MDL) transferee court was proper, where court had excluded patients' expert opinion on general causation as to all but highest statin dose and expert opinion on specific causation from bellwether trial, and, after series of show cause orders, no patient had come forward with adequate evidence of specific causation; having dealt with the litigation at great length, court was familiar with the science and issues involved and could dispose of them more quickly and efficiently than transferor courts.
In re Lipitor (Atorvastatin Calcium) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation (No II) MDL 2502, 892 F.3d 624 (4th Cir. 2018).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee court under order of Judicial Panel had power to hear and decide motion for summary judgment filed by defendant in case which had been transferred for limited purpose of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
Humphreys v. Tann, 487 F.2d 666 (6th Cir. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Assuming that the law of the case doctrine was binding with respect to pretrial rulings, discovery and pretrial rulings on whether defendant pharmaceutical company produced two doses of allegedly contaminated heparin anticoagulant medication that were administered to hospital patient did not bear on common questions of fact that justified multidistrict litigation (MDL), and thus, primary purpose of MDL, which was to economize, would not be frustrated by non-MDL court's reconsideration, on defendant's motion for summary judgment, of MDL court's summary judgment ruling that there was no genuine issue of material fact that defendant had not produced the two doses, which reconsideration would be based on substantially different expert testimony from plaintiffs' new product-identification expert regarding sequence of numbers for doses drawn from hospital's computerized pharmaceutical dispensing machine, in action for strict liability due to manufacturing defect, negligence, statutory wrongful death, and statutory survival; MDL court did not have the benefit of new expert's opinion.
Allen v. American Capital Limited, 287 F. Supp. 3d 763 (D. Ariz. 2017).
Evidence  555.2

Assuming that the law of the case doctrine was binding with respect to pretrial rulings, substantially different expert testimony, from plaintiffs' new product-identification expert, regarding sequence of numbers for doses drawn from hospital's computerized pharmaceutical dispensing machine justified reconsideration by non-multidistrict litigation (MDL) court, on defendant pharmaceutical company's motion for summary judgment, of MDL court's summary judgment ruling that there was no genuine issue of material fact that two doses of allegedly contaminated heparin anticoagulant medication administered to hospital patient had not been produced by defendant, in action for strict liability due to manufacturing defect, negligence, statutory wrongful death, and statutory survival.
Allen v. American Capital Limited, 287 F. Supp. 3d 763 (D. Ariz. 2017).
Evidence  555.2

Once multidistrict private antitrust action brought by State of Arizona against several producers of gypsum wallboard was transferred to Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, motion of Arizona for severance of its second cause of action alleging that one of corporate defendants had transacted business in Arizona without having qualified as a foreign corporation as allegedly required by Arizona statutes would be denied, where there was no evidence that remand would promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and where most efficacious course to follow was to allow transferee court to rule on corporate defendant's assertion on its motion for summary judgment that Arizona's second cause of action failed to state a claim on which relief could be granted.
In re Gypsum Wallboard, 340 F. Supp. 990 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Orders of transferor courts, powers and duties of transferee court—Generally

para.paratext:
If a transferor judge has the power to vacate or modify a protective order when needed, the transferee court must also have the power under the multidistrict litigation transfer statute to vacate or modify a protective order of a transferor court when necessary and appropriate; concomitantly, absent such need or propriety, the transferee court simply does not have the power to vacate or modify an existing protective order.
In re Pharmacy Benefit Managers Antitrust Litigation, 582 F.3d 432 (3d Cir. 2009).
Federal Courts  2958

It is inappropriate for transferee court, acting under this section, to permit plaintiffs not to comply with previous orders of transferor judge.
In re Penn Central Securities Litigation, 62 F.R.D. 181 (E.D. Pa. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Discovery, orders of transferor courts, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
While transferee judge was not, following consolidation, obliged to require sharing of discovery with litigants not parties to multidistrict litigation, it was within her discretion to do so, despite protective orders earlier entered by transferor courts, where she perceived that cooperation in this respect would promote efficient exchange of discovery information in the litigation before her and where she was unable to perceive any prejudice to products liability suit defense; also, transferee judge did not abuse her discretion in vacating protective orders entered by transferor court to the extent that they restricted use of materials obtained by plaintiffs in discovery to parties in the immediate litigation, where more than half of the documents produced under protective order had been produced without any limitations on discovery in state cases, ruling was not intended to keep defendant from seeking protective orders in state cases, and, prior to release of information to enable judge to monitor its use.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic Cleocin Products Liability Litigation, 664 F.2d 114 (6th Cir. 1981).

Multidistrict litigation statute's grant of power to multidistrict litigation judge to act as judge of any district for pretrial depositions would include as an incident the power to enforce subpoenas duces tecum issued by court in which action originated, although subpoena was a documents-only subpoena not associated with a deposition; it would make no sense for the statute to confer authority to conduct depositions, but not the authority to require production of documents at deposition.
U.S. ex rel. Pogue v. Diabetes Treatment Centers of America, Inc., 238 F. Supp. 2d 270 (D.D.C. 2002).
Federal Courts  2958

Where Judicial Panel transferred all related private antitrust actions with common questions of fact to District of Connecticut for coordinated pretrial proceedings, parties would be expected to comply with all discovery orders entered prior to transfer and request for delays or extension should not be granted as a matter of course, and the better course would be to follow discovery schedule established in original district until modified by the transferee judge after initial pretrial conference.
In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Civil Procedure  1633

head.headtext: Parties, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Where claims in the underlying and consolidated complaints arose out of alleged fraud inducing purchase of corporation's securities by plaintiffs, addition of new claims and new parties, which had not been previously included in any of the underlying complaints, was proper where the new claims of parties arose out of the same alleged fraud in purchase of securities.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 161 (C.D. Cal. 1976).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

head.headtext: Remand, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Following transfer of case for resolution of any pretrial matters, pursuant to federal statute that provides for transfer of litigation back to original, transferring court once claims are ready for trial, it is transferee court, not the court with ultimate responsibility for any trial, that decides whether to abstain or equitably remand case.
In re Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortgage-backed Securities Litigation, 943 F. Supp. 2d 1035 (C.D. Cal. 2013).
Federal Courts  2958

Multidistrict litigation (MDL) transferee court had authority to remand MDL-transferred actions directly to state court.
In re New England Mut. Life Ins. Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 324 F. Supp. 2d 288 (D. Mass. 2004).
Federal Courts  2958

After court to which multidistrict litigation had been transferred for pretrial proceedings had remanded individual actions to respective transfer courts, the transferor courts had exclusive jurisdiction and the remanding court had no jurisdiction to entertain plaintiffs' motion for clarification and/or modification of the language in order of remand.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic Cleocin Products Liability Litigation, 508 F. Supp. 1020 (E.D. Mich. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

Remand of the non-punitive/exemplary damage claims in two asbestos products liability actions pending in centralized proceedings in multidistrict litigation, one to the Central District of California and the other to the Eastern District of Louisiana, was warranted; transferee judge's determination that remand was appropriate was entitled to great weight.
In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 545 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

Determination whether contract claims transferred together with antitrust claims should be separated and remanded to transferor court should be made by the transferee judge.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

Judge to whom litigation is transferred has power to rule on question of remand to state court.
In re Professional Hockey Antitrust Litigation, 369 F. Supp. 1117 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Whether inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings of one action which allegedly was ready for trial would delay expeditious handling of such case was for transferee judge to decide; if such action were indeed ready for trial transferee judge could proceed to set it for trial without hindering the just and efficient conduct of any of the other multidistrict actions.
In re Evergreen Valley Project Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 510 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Inasmuch as motions to remand to state court are pretrial motions, transferee judge, to whom multidistrict litigation has been assigned for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, has power in his capacity as transferee judge to rule on remand motions.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Juneau, Alaska, on September 4, 1971, 360 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Removal Of Cases  100

Trial judge to whom civil antitrust actions were transferred for pretrial proceedings would be free to determine that certain of the cases should be treated separately and to remand such cases to transferor court for trial as soon as all common discovery was completed.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Transfer of cases, powers and duties of transferee court—Generally

para.paratext:
At stage in proceeding where all issues in action against airline on claims arising out of crash of airplane, liability as well as damages, had yet to be resolved, decisions relative to transfer of cases were best reserved for district court below.
Winbourne v. Eastern Air Lines, Inc., 632 F.2d 219 (2d Cir. 1980).
Federal Courts  3794

As multidistrict transferee court, court had the authority to rule on motion to have all related cases on the dockets of other districts transferred to the transferee court.
In re Master Key Antitrust Litigation, 70 F.R.D. 23 (D. Conn. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Multidistrict litigation transferee court has power to transfer a case to itself for trial.
In re Viatron Computer Systems Corp. Litigation, 86 F.R.D. 431 (D. Mass. 1980).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee district court has authority to transfer cases transferred to it by the Judicial Panel.
In re Antibiotic Antitrust Actions, 333 F. Supp. 299 (S.D. N.Y. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Convenience of parties and witnesses, transfer of cases, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
United States district judge, to whom cases were assigned by Judicial Panel for pretrial proceedings, had power to issue order directing transfer of cases from 11 judicial districts in which they were filed to a certain district for trial for convenience of parties and witnesses.
Pfizer, Inc. v. Lord, 447 F.2d 122 (2d Cir. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

Federal district court to which case was transferred for pretrial purposes by Judicial Panel had jurisdiction to determine motions for change of venue pursuant to § 1404 of this title authorizing such for convenience of parties and witnesses and for transfer pursuant to § 1406 of this title authorizing dismissal if case is filed in wrong division or district or, in interest of justice to transfer such case to any district or division in which it could have been brought.
Jack Winter, Inc. v. Koratron Co., 326 F. Supp. 121 (N.D. Cal. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

District court's designation as transferee court under this section empowered it to transfer action, which had been consolidated before it for coordinated pretrial proceedings, to transferee or other district for all purposes, including trial, under § 1404 of this title providing for transfer of cases in interest of justice and for convenience of parties and witnesses.
Greyhound Computer Corp. v. International Business Machines Corp., 342 F. Supp. 1143 (D. Minn. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

Judge to whom cases are assigned by the Judicial Panel for pretrial proceedings has the power to issue orders directing transfer of cases from the judicial districts in which they were filed to another district for trial if the convenience of the parties and witnesses and other relevant factors warrant such action.
In re Caesars Palace Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 366 (S.D. N.Y. 1973).
Federal Courts  2958

Centralization of two putative nationwide class actions, pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations in the design, marketing and sale of life insurance policies used to fund defined benefit pension plans for small businesses, and failure to disclose that such policies might be deemed by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to be invalid tax shelters, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Indianapolis Life Ins. Co. I.R.S. 412(I) Plans Life Ins. Marketing Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

A motion for transfer for the convenience of parties and witnesses in the interest of justice may be presented to and determined by transferee judge, on transfer in multidistrict litigation for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Venue restrictions, transfer of cases, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Transferee judge is authorized to transfer cases in multidistrict litigation to transferee court, rather than remanding them to their respective transferor jurisdictions for trial following completion of pretrial proceedings, as long as transferee court is one in which action might have been brought and change of venue is effected for convenience of parties and witnesses, in interest of justice.
In re Dow Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 664 F. Supp. 1403 (D. Colo. 1987).
Federal Courts  2958

Although Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation may transfer actions for pretrial purposes unencumbered by venue restrictions, court to which those actions are transferred must abide by applicable venue requirements when transferring those actions for trial purposes.
In re Tax Refund Litigation, 723 F. Supp. 922 (E.D. N.Y. 1989).
Federal Courts  2958

Judge to whom case has been transferred for pretrial purposes by Panel has the power to order a transfer of the case, for the convenience of the parties, to any district in which it might have been brought.
In re Penn Central Commercial Paper Litigation, 62 F.R.D. 341 (S.D. N.Y. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

District judge to whom cases are transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings has the power to transfer actions in the transferee district to that district or to any other appropriate district for all purposes.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Chicago, Ill., on May 25, 1979, 476 F. Supp. 445 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Self assignment, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Federal district court conducting pretrial proceedings pursuant to multidistrict litigation statute has no authority to invoke change-of-venue statute to assign transferred case to itself for trial.
Lexecon Inc. v. Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, 523 U.S. 26, 118 S. Ct. 956, 140 L. Ed. 2d 62 (1998).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Appeals, powers and duties of transferee court

para.paratext:
Appeal of pretrial decision made by multidistrict litigation judge goes to the circuit of the district in which the deposition is being taken because of the need for uniformity in decisions on depositions within each of those circuits; this need balances out the danger of lack of uniformity within the multidistrict litigation.
U.S. ex rel. Pogue v. Diabetes Treatment Centers of America, Inc., 238 F. Supp. 2d 270 (D.D.C. 2002).
Federal Courts  3861

head.headtext: CONSIDERATIONS GOVERNING TRANSFER OF ACTIONS GENERALLY
Considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where actions involved common questions of fact and transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and where all parties to the actions agreed upon desirability of transfer.
In re Palizzio, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

Before transfer is ordered, Judicial Panel must be satisfied that all statutory criteria for transfer have been met.
In re Highway Acc. Near Rockville, Connecticut, on December 30, 1972, 388 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Factors which may be significant in determining propriety of transferring multidistrict cases include: (1) strength of showing that transfer is desirable, (2) presence or absence of plaintiff's good faith in naming unserved defendants, (3) extent of plaintiff's effort to serve each defendant with process, (4) degree to which unserved defendant's interests appear to be same as those of defendants coming before Judicial Panel, (5) number of unserved defendants, and (6) importance of their presence before Panel in aiding its decision.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Balance of interests, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation must consider interest of all parties, and must consider multidistrict litigation as a whole in light of purposes of this section.
In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Statutory mandate of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation is to weigh interests of all parties and to consider multidistrict litigation as a whole in light of the purposes of provisions authorizing transfer.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 442 F. Supp. 547 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

With respect to a motion to transfer actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, mandate of Judicial Panel is to weigh interests of all plaintiffs and all defendants, and to consider multidistrict litigation as a whole in light of the purposes of the law.
In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

In determining whether transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is appropriate, Judicial Panel must weigh interests of all plaintiffs and all defendants, and must consider multiple litigation as a whole in light of purposes of multidistrict litigation law.
In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311 (J.P.M.L. 1972). See, also, In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969); In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Antitrust actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization in Southern District of California was warranted with respect to pretrial proceedings in various putative class actions by consumers against producers of packaged seafood products, alleging conspiracy to fix prices; actions involved common factual questions arising from alleged conspiracy, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, and centralization would reduce duplicative discovery and prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, particularly with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re Packaged Seafood Products Antitrust Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in nine actions and 12 potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts, alleging that licensing agreements between a health insurer and its 38 licensees violated federal antitrust laws; actions involved substantial common questions of fact, and centralization would ensure streamlined resolution of the litigation, serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Blue Cross Blue Shield Antitrust Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2954

Six antitrust actions brought by various retail merchants who had opted out of antitrust litigation settlements in New York, against major credit card companies in three federal district courts, alleging that companies' “honor all cards” policy violated the Sherman Antitrust Act, would be transferred to Eastern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization in Eastern District of New York would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and would promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and centralization would avoid duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent or repetitive pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re Visa/Mastercard Antitrust Litigation, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict antitrust actions, four of which were pending in the Western District of Missouri, three of which were pending in the Northern District of California, and two of which were pending in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, and all of which involved a nationwide franchise system and presented virtually identical legal theories were transferred to the Western District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where the Missouri cases were in a significantly more advanced stage than were those in any other district, and class action motions had been briefed and argued before judge in cases pending in Western District of Missouri and he was well aware of existence of other cases and potential for conflicting class action determinations.
In re International House of Pancakes Franchise Litigation, 331 F. Supp. 556 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Bankruptcy of party, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of securities fraud actions pending in multiple judicial districts, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was not warranted where some actions were being stayed due to bankruptcy of defendant peculiar to those actions.
In re Adelphia Communications Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation, 237 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957

It was appropriate to centralize 32 district court actions pending in five federal districts, relating to applicability and reasonableness of bankrupt carrier's tariff rates, in the Western District of Wisconsin, where 128 adversary proceedings were pending in bankruptcy court; it would be left to discretion of district court to determine extent of any coordination between centralized district court actions and adversary proceedings.
In re Gross Common Carrier, Inc., Freight Undercharge Claims Litigation, 843 F. Supp. 1506 (J.P.M.L. 1994).
Federal Courts  2953

Potential bankruptcy of one defendant was irrelevant with respect to appropriateness of transfer of action to another district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Industrial Wine Contracts Securities Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 909 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Benefits or advantages, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in eight putative statewide class actions, pending in seven districts, alleging that bank regularly failed to comply with terms of the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) and breached contracts with the plaintiffs and/or breached a contract to which they were intended third-party beneficiaries; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Bank of America Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP)Contract Litigation, 746 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2951

Although questions of fact existed in various actions against manufacturer of the intrauterine contraceptive device to recover damages for injuries sustained in use of such device, motion to transfer cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied where inherent disadvantages of transfer outweighed benefits thereof.
In re G. D. Searle & Co. “Copper 7” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 1343 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2953

Where significant benefits are to be gained by coordinated and consolidated proceedings, transfer will be ordered by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation.
In re New York City Municipal Securities Litigation, 439 F. Supp. 267 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Choice of parties, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Judicial panel on multidistrict litigation has power to order transfer in multidistrict litigation even if no party favors transfer.
In re Natural Gas Liquids Regulation Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 665 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

The opposition of parties to transfer of multidistrict litigation to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is not by itself determinative of question of transfer; in an appropriate situation, the Panel has the power to order transfer even if all parties are opposed to transfer.
In re Asbestos and Asbestos Insulation Material Products Liability Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 906 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Where all parties generally agreed on desirability of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, antitrust action pending in Southern District of New York involved common questions of fact with actions pending in Northern District of Georgia, and transfer of New York action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would serve convenience of parties and their witnesses and further just and efficient disposition of litigation, New York action would be transferred to Northern District of Georgia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Chicken Broiler Antitrust Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 788 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Even though all but one defendant had filed motions challenging venue of action in district of the District of Columbia and the personal jurisdiction of that court, class actions which involved alleged antitrust violations in manufacture and sale of Griseofulvin would be transferred and consolidated for pretrial proceedings in the District of the District of Columbia.
In re Griseofulvin Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Where eight actions arising out of same disaster on board ship had been consolidated in New York, so that there were only two cases focusing on the common issue of liability, one in New York and one in South Carolina, where only parties who favored transfer of New York actions to South Carolina were those who were parties to both actions, so that possibility of duplicative discovery could be avoided through cooperative efforts, where certain parties were seeking stipulation that all discovery could be used in all actions, and where seven of the New York plaintiffs opposed transfer, motion of one defendant to transfer New York actions to District of South Carolina for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied.
In re USS Trenton Disaster Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Limited partnership actions, involving corporation which was subject of reorganization proceeding under § 501 et seq. of Title 11, and had its home, in District of Colorado were not subject to transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Colorado, where none of parties favored transfer for pretrial proceedings with other cases involving such corporation, and no showing was made of facts or issues raised in the limited partnership actions common to the other cases.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1179 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

Three plumbing fixture private antitrust cases which were filed after prior hearing ordering 37 cases transferred for pretrial proceedings were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania where all defendants urged that cases be transferred and where many of factual issues present were common to each other and to questions present in actions previously consolidated.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 483 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2954

Where one of the defendants filed motion to transfer case to the Northern District of Illinois for pretrial purposes, and where plaintiff filed a response to that motion stating that it did not oppose the transfer, an order would be entered transferring the case accordingly.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 1352 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally—Generally

para.paratext:
Centralization, for multidistrict litigation, of four nearly identical statewide class actions against car manufacturer and others was not necessary; the litigation involved only four actions pending in as many districts, the actions involved common factual issues arising from manufacturer's alleged marketing of cars as track-proven cars even though the cars allegedly overheated after approximately 15 minutes of track driving due to the alleged lack of an appropriate transmission cooling system, the consumers were represented by common counsel, as were the defendants, and cooperation among the few involved courts and these two groups of counsel appeared to be a workable alternative to centralization.
In re Corvette Z06 Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of venue to single district, rather than centralization by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, was appropriate in six pending Sherman Act putative class actions based on defendant's alleged agreements with its rivals not to compete in certain online search advertising auctions; there was a reasonable prospect that the resolution of motions to transfer could eliminate the multidistrict character of the litigation, since four of the actions had already been transferred to the District of Utah, and motions to transfer were pending in the two other actions.
In re 1-800 Contacts Antitrust Litigation, 282 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization in the Northern District of Indiana was warranted of various putative class actions against medical software company regarding data security breach; actions involved common questions of fact, many of the actions were nationwide in scope, centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources, majority of actions were pending in Northern District of Indiana, company's headquarters was located in District, and many healthcare providers affected by breach were located in District.
In re Medical Informatics Engineering, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization in Eastern District of Missouri was warranted with respect to pretrial proceedings in various putative class actions by consumers against “dating” website designed to facilitate intimate relationships for individuals who were either married or in a committed relationship, as related to data breach; actions involved common factual questions arising from data breach, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, and centralization would reduce duplicative discovery and prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, particularly with respect to class certification, and conserve parties' resources.
In re Ashley Madison Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation involving 14 putative class actions raising allegations relating to the initial public offering (IPO) of the common stock of a cellular telephone company; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to class certification issues), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Vonage Initial Public Offering (IPO) Securities Litigation, 471 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization was warranted, in fraud and negligent misrepresentation class action suits brought against common defendants in New York and New Jersey by buyers of telephone calling cards; centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re IDT Corp. Calling Card Terms Litigation, 278 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Three putative class actions pending in two districts, brought under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) on behalf of participants in company's investment plan and alleging breach of fiduciary duty by concentration of investments into company's stock and failure to disclose risks, would be centralized; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative pretrial proceedings, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, counsel and the judiciary.
In re Nortel Networks Corp. Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of pretrial proceedings was warranted in putative class actions against insurer for violations of Fair Credit Reporting Act in its use of consumer reports for qualification, underwriting and rate-setting processes for certain policies of insurance; both actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, particularly with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Allstate Ins. Co. Underwriting and Rating Practices Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Where actions were brought on behalf of same plaintiff class, it was desirable to have single judge oversee class action issues in both actions to avoid duplicative efforts; while voluntary coordination of discovery efforts among parties and their counsel is always commendable, transfer of actions to single district insures streamlining of discovery and other pretrial proceedings as well.
In re First Nat. Bank, Heavener, Okl. (First Mortg. Revenue Bonds) Securities Litigation, 451 F. Supp. 995 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Where class of plaintiffs designated in one action falls within the boundaries of class requests in other actions on the same factual issues, it is necessary to have all class action questions resolved by a single judge in order to eliminate the possibility of conflicting class determinations and to achieve the most expeditious methods of organizing the class or classes and any necessary subclasses.
In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel will transfer case to eliminate possibility of inconsistent class determinations.
In re Hotel Telephone Charge Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

The potential for conflicting class determinations by the transferor courts is a persuasive if not compelling reason for transfer of actions to a single judge.
In re Natural Resources Fund, Inc., Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is appropriate if not necessary where possibility for conflicting, inconsistent class determination by courts of coordinated jurisdiction exists.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973). See, also, In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1271 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Possibility for conflicting class action determinations is an important factor favoring transfer of an action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re 7-Eleven Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 286 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

It is in field of class action determinations in related multidistrict civil actions that potential for conflicting, disorderly, chaotic judicial action is the greatest.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Overlapping classes, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Fact that most of actions before Judicial Panel had been brought on behalf of similar or overlapping classes of purchasers of limited partnerships was justification for transfer, since it was desirable to have single judge oversee class action issues in these actions to avoid duplicative efforts and inconsistent rulings in this area.
In re Resource Exploration, Inc., Securities Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 817 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2951

Need to eliminate possibility of overlapping class determinations presents compelling reason to bring actions pending in different districts together for pretrial in single jurisdiction.
In re National Airlines, Inc. Maternity Leave Practices and Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 399 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Three actions arising out of sale of securities and distributorships of corporation and corporation's multi-level marketing practices were transferred to the Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where transferred actions raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to district and transfer of one action would prevent possibility of overlapping class determinations, though plaintiffs in second action based their claim for relief on legal theories different than theories presented in previously transferred actions, and though plaintiffs in third action claimed inconvenience because of their limited financial means.
In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Settlements, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of seven actions, pending in two districts, was not warranted even though all the actions arose out of allegations of a massive accounting scandal at the defendant company; since the six actions pending in one district had been consolidated for all purposes, the litigation consisted, in reality, of just two actions, and the consolidated action appeared to be nearing its conclusion, inasmuch as a proposed class settlement had been given preliminary approval.
In re Tesco PLC Securities Litigation, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1368 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2957

Centralization, for pretrial proceedings, of four actions, pending in two districts, challenging the propriety of a credit card company's alleged recording of certain calls with customers who had defaulted on their accounts, was not necessary to serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of the litigation; the parties in one of the actions had reached a settlement that had potential to extinguish the class claims in the other actions, only a minimal number of actions were involved, and informal coordination of the actions appeared practicable, since the four actions were pending before only two judges in adjacent districts.
In re HSBC Telephone Conversation Recording Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of “Bendectin” products liability actions would be granted where transferee judge entered order certifying class in the litigation for settlement purposes only and indicated probability that the entire litigation would be settled, and where representatives of plaintiffs' class for settlement purposes and defendant executed a settlement agreement before transferee judge.
In re Richardson-Merrell, Inc., 588 F. Supp. 1448 (J.P.M.L. 1984).
Federal Courts  2953

Action, in which plaintiff alleged that broker and employee managing his account violated provision of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and rule promulgated thereunder in connection with purchases of common stock made for his personal account, was transferred to Western District of Oklahoma where complaint appeared on its face to raise questions of fact common to actions previously transferred and action raised questions concerning the effect of class settlement and releases executed in connection therewith and, in event plaintiff was allowed to proceed with his action, his discovery would be largely common to that pursued by other individual plaintiffs who exercised their right to be excluded from settlement and were proceeding toward trial.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 355 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Even if it would be appropriate to concentrate litigation of action arising from airplane crash in single forum, procedure provided in this section would better serve the interests of the parties involved than determination to permit prosecution of action brought in Virginia as a class action, where, other than the named plaintiff and his two decedents, none of the potential class members in crash resulting in the deaths of some 95 persons had any apparent connection with Virginia, and where it did not appear that any witness, evidence or documentation was located in Virginia.
Causey v. Pan Am. World Airways, Inc., 66 F.R.D. 392 (E.D. Va. 1975).
Federal Civil Procedure  181

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of five actions, pending in two districts, concerning the cause of the crash of an aircraft, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Air Crash Near Edgartown, Mass., on October 6, 2000, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Airline tariff actions, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Multidistrict actions, in each of which it was alleged that defendant airlines had violated federal tariff regulations by overcharging for fares to domestic passengers who flew between two points in the United States for which no single joint fare had been established, were transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings to the Central District of California, where there was a real danger of conflicting class determinations unless actions were so consolidated, where four of the five actions were already under supervision of a single judge, and where the two actions pending in the Central District of California were more advanced than others in areas of discovery and pretrial.
In re Public Air Travel Tariff Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1397 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Where respective class actions, brought against domestic airlines on behalf of passengers who paid fares which were allegedly illegally increased, would be used not only to establish the airlines' liability to the class but also to establish total damage, the existence of conflicting and overlapping class action claims raised substantial common questions of fact justifying transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings under this section.
In re Air Fare Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1013 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Six antitrust actions, three of which had been brought in the Eastern District of Texas, two of which had been brought in the Western District of Louisiana, and one of which had been brought in the Middle District of Louisiana, on behalf of various classes of bakery product purchasers would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where two of the complaints alleged an overall conspiracy among all of the defendants in the various cases and the classes alleged in two of the complaints embraced the classes purported or determined in the other four actions.
In re South Cent. States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1127 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

The ever-present potential for conflicting class action determination with respect to nonsettled related civil antitrust actions transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated pretrial proceeding was a most persuasive reason for leaving all actions in the same district despite contention that the nonsettled cases should be transferred to another district.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 320 F. Supp. 586 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Bankruptcy proceedings, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Because of the potential if not likely conflict of class action determination in numerous civil actions arising out of collapse of financial services corporation, Judicial Panel would assign cases to single judge for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with sole responsibility for making class action determinations as soon as practicable.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Civil rights actions, class actions, class actions

para.paratext:
The need to insure uniform disposition of the competing requests for class designations in actions challenging weight standards promulgated by airline for its flight attendants presented a compelling reason for supervision of the actions in a single district.
In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict actions arising out of alleged racial discrimination in employment would be transferred to Western District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where duplicative discovery on conceded common factual issues would be avoided, where conflicting and overlapping class allegations of complaints raised indubitable possibility of inconsistent class determinations by courts of coordinate jurisdiction, where preliminary question in each action was effect of an Ohio consent decree and where selection of either court as transferee forum for litigation would not substantially inconvenience any of the parties.
In re Roadway Exp., Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 612 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Discrimination actions, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
The need to insure uniform disposition of the competing requests for class designations in actions challenging weight standards promulgated by airline for its flight attendants presented a compelling reason for supervision of the actions in a single district.
In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict actions arising out of alleged racial discrimination in employment would be transferred to Western District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where duplicative discovery on conceded common factual issues would be avoided, where conflicting and overlapping class allegations of complaints raised indubitable possibility of inconsistent class determinations by courts of coordinate jurisdiction, where preliminary question in each action was effect of an Ohio consent decree and where selection of either court as transferee forum for litigation would not substantially inconvenience any of the parties.
In re Roadway Exp., Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 612 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, class actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation arising from allegedly inaccurate statements concerning a renewable energy company's operational and financial condition, including its liquidity, classification of debt, and internal financial controls, as well as the alleged impropriety of its public filings; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings on class certification and other pretrial matters, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Sunedison, Inc., Securities Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2957

Four class actions against residential mortgage lender for alleged securities fraud in violation of Securities Act, claimed by investors in lender's stock, bonds, and debentures, did not warrant centralization in Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) proceedings that included eight class actions against lender for alleged securities fraud claimed by investors in lender's mortgage-backed securities (MBS), even though both MBS cases and non-MBS cases involved common questions of fact as to lender's alleged misrepresentations regarding origination practices for, and credit quality of, mortgage loans, since inclusion of non-MBS cases in MDL proceedings involving MBS cases would unnecessarily complicate MDL proceedings by introducing issues unique to non-MBS investors, and any required coordination of non-MBS cases with MBS cases could be done informally.
In re: Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortgage-Backed Securities Litigation, 812 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

Purposes of this section authorizing transfers for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings can best be achieved by having a single judge supervise not only private actions based on violations of securities laws but also a clearly related Securities and Exchange Commission action.
In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Where actions based on violations of federal securities laws were brought in three districts against the same defendants, where there were conflicting class representation claims between plaintiffs in two of the actions and where complex common questions of fact existed, cases would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings even though some divergent legal theories of liability were asserted.
In re Air West, Inc. Securities Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 609 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Where action filed in the Southern District of New York under the securities laws raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to the Western District of Oklahoma and defendants contended that plaintiff was a member of a class embraced by class action settlement approved by the Oklahoma court and had timely filed claim and release, transfer of the action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be ordered despite contention by plaintiff that his action, unlike the others, was based on evidence relating to indictment filed against one of the defendants in the Southern District of New York.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 373 F. Supp. 975 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Where in cases commenced against securities broker in the Northern District of Illinois and Southern District of Florida misrepresentations by broker and its representatives were alleged and in each case the plaintiff, as purchaser of corporate stock, was required to prove falsity of representations by ascertaining facts concerning corporations and their relationship with broker and proposed class-wide settlement of similar Securities Act claims asserted against broker and other common defendants in actions previously transferred to the Western District of Oklahoma had been submitted to transferee court for approval, instant proceedings would be likewise transferred to that court for consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 962 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

Where numerous actions arising out of corporation's alleged breach of securities regulations by dissemination of news and information with respect to major mineral discovery had already been consolidated for pretrial procedures in district court in New York and plaintiff who brought action in district court of Utah and who sought to establish new class had unsuccessfully sought to join New York proceedings, motion to transfer for pretrial procedures would be granted notwithstanding New York court had ruled that class Utah plaintiff sought to represent was not sufficiently numerous to authorize class action.
In re Texas Gulf Sulphur Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1398 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

Two actions alleging securities law violations by group of banks, underwriters and mutual funds in sale of common stock of transportation company and brought as class actions on behalf of all purchasers of stock did not involve the same central issue as was involved in actions which involved alleged inside trading, mismanagement and breaches of fiduciary duty within corporation and would not be consolidated with such cases.
In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 309 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Comity, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Where transferee judge had already formally ruled upon appropriateness of inclusion, in antitrust litigation in transferee district, of very claims now raised by particular parties in action sought to be transferred, transfer would undercut atmosphere of confidence, comity and good will among districts in context of docket, so that great weight would be given to determination that inclusion of claims sought to be transferred in litigation in transferee district would be contrary to interests of justice, thus precluding transfer.
In re Cessna Aircraft Distributorship Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 159 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

On principles of comity, the Judicial Panel will be reluctant to transfer any action that has an important motion under submission with a court.
In re L. E. Lay & Co. Antitrust Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 1054 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Consolidation of previous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally—Generally

para.paratext:
Transfers of three actions in multidistrict litigation, for inclusion in previously-ordered centralized pretrial proceedings in litigation concerning the safety and marketing of certain medications, was warranted; actions shared questions of fact with the previously-centralized actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Darvocet, Darvon and Propoxyphene Products Liability Litigation, 939 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation, 26 putative class actions, brought on behalf of purchasers of company's stock and alleging violations of federal securities laws, would not be transferred for consolidation with three actions under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), even though actions shared questions concerning company's financial condition and accounting practices; securities actions had already been consolidated under a single judge and had proceeded independently of the ERISA actions for over a year and a half.
In re Nortel Networks Corp. Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Although the eight actions, five in the Eastern District of Louisiana and three in the Eastern District of Texas, as a result of death of seven individuals in a helicopter crash presented some common questions of fact, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was inappropriate where four out of the five Louisiana actions had been already consolidated and a final pretrial conference was set therefor and the claims in the fifth Louisiana action were subsumed in the claims in the amended complaint in one of the four consolidated actions, while question of liability might never arise in other Texas actions.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Cameron, La., 443 F. Supp. 1022 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Master complaint, consolidation of previous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
In cases consolidated for multidistrict litigation (MDL) pretrial proceedings, the parties may elect to file a master complaint and a corresponding consolidated answer, which supersede prior individual pleadings; in such a case, the transferee court may treat the master pleadings as merging the discrete actions for the duration of the MDL pretrial proceedings, however, no merger occurs when the master complaint is not meant to be a pleading with legal effect but only an administrative summary of the claims brought by all the plaintiffs.
Gelboim v. Bank of America Corp., 135 S. Ct. 897, 190 L. Ed. 2d 789 (2015).
Federal Courts  2958

Consolidation of master complaint in multidistrict litigation (MDL) is merely procedural device designed to promote judicial economy, and, as such, it does not affect rights of parties in separate suits.
In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 489 F. Supp. 2d 932 (D. Minn. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Ongoing litigation, consolidation of previous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Inclusion of action which was in an advanced stage of proceedings, in previously-centralized proceedings involving claims relating to the alleged improper imposition of bank checking account overdraft fees, was not appropriate; extensive pretrial proceedings had been taking place in the action for two years and a trial date was set, whereas the other five actions were all in their beginning stages.
In re: Checking Account Overdraft Litigation, 677 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer, of two actions alleging that hemophiliacs acquired the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) through the use of concentrate blood products, pending in multidistrict litigation and consolidated for pretrial proceedings, to Northern District of Illinois for inclusion in an ongoing docket in multidistrict litigation involving the same issues, was appropriate; allegations were similar to those in previously centralized actions, and transferee judge was familiar with the factual issues relating to viral infection purportedly caused by contaminated factor concentrates.
In re “Factor VIII or IX Concentrate Blood Products” Products Liability Litigation, 303 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Contractual provisions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Provision in patent license agreement that court action thereunder should be brought only in San Francisco was not invalid as attempt to oust jurisdiction of court and would be enforced, where it did not appear that United States District Court for Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, would not fairly and competently determine issues in case, there was no great number of witnesses and there were pending in Northern District of California nine other cases which had substantially identical issues.
Jack Winter, Inc. v. Koratron Co., 326 F. Supp. 121 (N.D. Cal. 1971).
Contracts  127(4)

Although doctrine of collateral estoppel would likely dispose of patent and antitrust issues in North Carolina action, such action would not be ordered transferred for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings with previously instituted South Carolina action involving certain antitrust issues as well as the same patents since trial on liability issues in the latter proceedings had long since been completed and injection of North Carolina action would cause delay and parties stipulated that discovery in South Carolina action could be used in North Carolina proceedings and views of district judge in South Carolina action as well as those of Court of Appeals were well documented.
In re Deering Milliken Patent Litigation, 476 F. Supp. 461 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954; Federal Courts  2956

Although district court would decline to transfer patent infringement actions in the Middle District of Pennsylvania, Eastern District of New York, and Southern District of New York to the District of Delaware for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings since transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, suitable alternatives available to parties were that parties could ask judge assigned to particular action to issue an order to show cause why discovery already completed in any related action should not be made applicable to former action, or that parties simply could stipulate that discovery could be used in a particular action; additionally, consultation and cooperation among the three courts, if deemed appropriate by them, coupled with cooperation of parties, would minimize possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro, 464 F. Supp. 966 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2956

Where executors of estates of two airplane crash victims and airline had stipulated on issue of airline's liability, action by estates against airline no longer raised questions of fact common to other actions arising out of same airplane crash warranting transfer to district where those cases had previously been transferred.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Pago Pago, Am. Samoa, on January 30, 1974, 394 F. Supp. 799 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Where defendant in one action, cross-defendant in another, made 20 separate shipments of magnesium oxide to manufacturer which produced several batches of product for application to buildings and made several shipments of the product, which was applied to different buildings by different persons under varying conditions, best solution to possibility of repetitive discovery in actions for damage from use of product was stipulation, apparently acceptable to all parties, for deposing common witnesses before representatives of all parties and use of depositions in either action, and motion for transfer for pretrial coordination of actions was denied by Judicial Panel.
In re Boncoat Products Liability Litigation, 353 F. Supp. 1302 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: District court decisions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
While not binding on Judicial Panel, decisions of district court, that actions brought there arising from collapse of corporation should be transferred to district in which there were pending the corporate reorganization proceedings as well as related actions, were entitled to great weight.
In re Westec Corp., 307 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Courts  96(7)

head.headtext: Precedents in transferor courts

para.paratext:
Any circuit split on issue of consumer's Article III standing did not warrant finding that it would be inefficient to centralize putative consumer class actions pending in various state and federal districts against credit reporting agency, arising from agency's role in cybersecurity incident in which personally identifiable information of consumers was compromised, in the Northern District of Georgia; transferee courts considered a wide variety of legal issues subject to differing precedent in their transferor courts, and Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation did not have power, under statute allowing for transfer of civil actions, to consider possible implications with respect to standing, or other potential rulings, in selecting transferee district.
In re: Equifax, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1322 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2951

When determining whether to transfer an action to more convenient forum, it is not business of panel to consider what law transferee court might apply.
In re General Motors Class E Stock Buyout Securities Litigation, 696 F. Supp. 1546 (J.P.M.L. 1988).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Elimination of multidistrict aspect, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of six actions pending in two judicial districts arising out of accident in which individual was seriously injured after rented truck ran into him at construction site, for pretrial proceedings, was not warranted; there was reasonable prospect of elimination of multidistrict character of actions by district court action on motions for transfer of venue of two actions to district where other four actions were pending, which, if granted, would have placed all actions in single district for all purposes and not for pretrial purposes only.
In re Republic Western Ins. Co. Ins. Coverage Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer to a single district, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding, of 11 cases in the District of South Carolina and two in the Western District of Virginia which involved litigation concerning validity of patented process for endowing fiber with false twist to give yarn stretch and bulk and in which research corporation was plaintiff and 11 actions in the Middle District of North Carolina and one in the Southern District of New York in which sublicensees were plaintiffs against research corporation was denied where there was reasonable prospect that multidistrict character of cases would be eliminated by favorable action on research corporation's motion in all cases outside the District of South Carolina for transfer to that district.
In re Deering Milliken Patent, 328 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Estoppel, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Where six actions were brought involving disputes over validity of compound bow patent, determination of patent invalidity in action brought in Central District of California would likely prove dispositive of that issue in remaining actions under principles of collateral estoppel, suitable alternatives to transfer existed in order to minimize possibility of duplicative or unreasonable discovery, and where consultation and cooperation among concerned district courts and parties would be sufficient to minimize possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings, motion to transfer actions to Central District of California would be denied, despite alleged similarity of factual questions presented.
In re Allen Compound Bow Patent Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 248 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Favorable rulings by transferee court, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Prospect of unfavorable ruling by transferee court or possibility that another district judge may be more favorably disposed to litigants' contentions are not factors considered by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation in determining whether and to where transfer of multidistrict actions is appropriate.
In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 720 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Mere prospect of an unfavorable ruling by a transferee court or the possibility that another district judge may be more favorably disposed to a litigant's contentions are not factors to be considered in determining whether transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is appropriate.
In re Suess Patent Infringement Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1974). See, also, In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 805 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re 7-Eleven Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 286 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Texas Gulf Sulphur Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1398 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

Where action is otherwise appropriate for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, possibility of abuse of discretion or unfavorable ruling by the transferee court will not prevent transfer.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Toronto International Airport on July 5, 1970, 346 F. Supp. 533 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

Where counsel's motion for transfer of antitrust cases to single district court was not based on factors cognizable under this section but on prospect that another district judge might be more favorably disposed to his contentions, and it appeared from papers filed and arguments presented that one plaintiff was dissatisfied with discovery limitations imposed on it and that another plaintiff was dissatisfied with rejection of its class action requests, motion for transfer would be denied.
In re Motion Picture “Standard Accessories” and “Pre-Vues” Antitrust Litigation, 339 F. Supp. 1278 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Injunction issued, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Securities and Exchange Commission action in Colorado against corporation was inappropriate for transfer to District of Colorado for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where final judgment of permanent injunction had already been obtained against corporation, its officers, directors and employees, and the action was continued only against individual defendants, and where substantial discovery had been completed, as well as investigation by special counsel appointed to determine existence of possible causes of action on behalf of the corporation.
