In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1179 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: Jurisdictional issues pending, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation had jurisdiction to transfer Agent Orange case in which jurisdictional objection was pending, that objection to be resolved by transferee court; jurisdictional issue in question was easily capable of arising in hundreds or even thousands of cases in district courts throughout the nation and involved common questions of law and fact, some or all of which related to Agent Orange class action and settlement, and there were real economies in transferring case to one district judge who had been handling Agent Orange litigation for several years.
In re Ivy, 901 F.2d 7 (2d Cir. 1990).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2958

Removed shareholder/bondholder actions that were pending against failed energy company in the Middle District of Alabama, Northern District of California, District of Oregon, and Western District of Texas would be transferred to the Southern District of Texas, on ground that each of these actions involved common questions of fact with litigation already pending in that district and that transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, even though transferor court had not yet ruled on parties' remand or jurisdictional motions; remand and jurisdictional motions, if not resolved in transferor court by time of transfer, could be presented to and decided by transferee judge.
In re Enron Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 227 F. Supp. 2d 1389 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957; Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Law governing, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
When determining whether to transfer an action to more convenient forum, it is not business of panel to consider what law transferee court might apply.
In re General Motors Class E Stock Buyout Securities Litigation, 696 F. Supp. 1546 (J.P.M.L. 1988).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Merits of application, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Each application for consolidation must be considered upon its merits and in relation to particular problems in various pending suits which are subject of motion for consolidation or coordinated pretrial proceedings.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Falls City, Neb on August 6, 1966, 298 F. Supp. 1323 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Motive of moving party, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
None of the relevant considerations, including judicial economy, consistency in result, or fairness to the parties is advanced to allowing parties to consolidated pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation to deliberately stand by while others litigate in their interest in hope of receiving additional opportunities to relitigate a question if decided adversely.
In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 174 (S.D. Fla. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: National scope of litigation, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of 18 potentially related products liability actions pending in nine districts against medical device manufacturer was warranted, where actions shared factual questions concerning design, manufacture, marketing, and performance of manufacturer's line of hip implant products, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings on discovery and other issues, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re: Wright Medical Technology, Inc., Conserve Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred antitrust cases to the district of Arizona for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings there in view of fact that national conspiracy alleged in some actions in transferee district naturally encompassed statewide conspiracy alleged in actions to be transferred and in view of fact that transfer was important to ensure consistent treatment of class action issues.
In re Cement and Concrete Antitrust Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1299 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

Civil actions arising out of alleged antitrust conspiracy to reduce competition in governmental fleet sales by automobile manufacturers would be transferred to the Northern District of Illinois for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings, even though certain relevant documents might not have been removable from Michigan and some discovery had been begun in New York, where national aspect of litigation necessitated central location, documents could have been inspected or copies made and witnesses deposed in New York and Michigan, and automobile manufacturers' motions to transfer the cases for all purposes had been denied in two actions.
In re Government Auto Fleet Sales, 328 F. Supp. 218 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Number of actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization, under statute governing multidistrict litigation, of eight pending products liability actions against lock manufacturer and related entities was warranted where actions shared factual questions arising out of allegations that defendants' mechanical pushbutton locks could be disabled with magnet and so were defective, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re: Kaba Simplex Locks Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

Inclusion of five actions, in previously-centralized proceedings involving claims relating to the alleged improper imposition of bank checking account overdraft fees, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, transfers would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and Southern District of Florida had already been determined to be an appropriate forum for the actions.
In re: Checking Account Overdraft Litigation, 677 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation in which 22 actions alleging that defendants unlawfully conspired to fix prices for elevator and escalator sales and services were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to the Southern District of New York was appropriate; that district was where the first filed and largest number of the actions were pending, was an acceptable choice of a substantial number of the parties, and was equipped with the resources likely to be required by the complex antitrust docket.
In re Elevator and Escalator Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation involving more than 1100 actions and alleging that underwriters and initial public offering (IPO) issuers were responsible for misrepresentations in prospectuses and/or in underwriter research analyst reports, and manipulated prices of securities in the IPO aftermarket; actions shared common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and have a streamlining effect on pretrial proceedings.
In re Initial Public Offering (IPO) Securities Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation of pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation involving same parties' disputes over validity and infringement of complex patents was warranted, even though only three actions were involved and there was not complete identity of issues.
In re MLR, LLC, Patent Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2956

Where one of multiple patent infringement actions is proceeding expeditiously toward trial on a common validity issue or where a very bare minimum number of actions is involved, transfer of the litigations for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings may be denied.
In re Panty Hose Seaming Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Personal jurisdiction, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Alleged fact that no jurisdiction had been obtained over person of defendant was not ground for opposing transfer of case for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Gypsum Wallboard, 302 F. Supp. 794 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Power of Judicial Panel and courts to effectuate transfer under this section relating to multidistrict litigation is not vitiated by transferor court's lack of personal jurisdiction over defendant.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Where New York cases arising out of single aircraft disaster were about ready for trial and cases pending in Illinois, Texas and Nebraska had substantial venue and service questions, order to transfer New York cases would be denied without prejudice to subsequent motions for transfer.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Falls City, Neb on August 6, 1966, 298 F. Supp. 1323 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: Prior denials of transfer, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, when presented with a second motion for centralized pretrial proceedings in cases related to its previous denial of such a motion, will reach a different result only rarely, where a significant change in circumstances has occurred.
In re Plavix Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 923 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2951

Prior denial of transfer of action to another forum for convenience of parties and witnesses by district court is not dispositive of motion for transfer filed with Judicial Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re American Financial Corp. Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1232 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Denial of transfer of multidistrict antitrust litigation to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was without prejudice to right of any party to seek such transfer at a later time, should additional actions be filed.
In re Fotomat Franchisee Litigation, 394 F. Supp. 798 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Prospective or anticipatory actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Where five actions arising out of foreign airplane crash resulting in the death of over 150 people had been filed in five different districts, anticipation of additional filings did not make an order transferring litigation to particular district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding premature, since there had been sufficient development so that an informed decision on propriety of transfer and appropriate transferee court could be made and there were well-established procedures by which additional “tag-along” actions could be quickly considered for transfer.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Three cases arising from plane crash in which 47 persons were fatally injured and 18 persons were seriously injured would not be transferred from three different districts to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where, because of large number of fatalities and serious injuries, it was likely that additional actions would be filed, but denial of transfer would be without prejudice to right of any party to move for transfer at later time or of Panel to consider transfer at a later time on its own initiative.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Anchorage, Alaska on November 27, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 755 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: Purpose of transfer, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Consideration of motion to transfer all pending and related actions in multidistrict patent infringement litigation to the Northern District of Illinois for purpose of pretrial discovery disclosed that no useful purpose as contemplated by this section would be served by the transfer of any of the pending actions to any other district and motion was denied.
In re Eisler Patents, 297 F. Supp. 1034 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Removal from state courts, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Fact that cause is in federal court by removal from state court has no bearing on motion to transfer case for coordinated pretrial proceedings.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Settlements, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Where more than 150 related civil antitrust actions had been transferred to the Southern District of New York before a single judge for coordinated pretrial proceedings and 66 actions had been settled while 28 others were in the process of being settled, motion to transfer the 58 nonsettled cases, many of which sought class action status, to another district was denied, but because of the complexity and size of the litigation another federal district judge was assigned to the Southern District of New York and the nonsettled cases assigned to him for completion of the coordinated pretrial proceedings.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 320 F. Supp. 586 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

Possibility that transferee judge in antibiotic drug litigation might ignore nonsettling cases while he concentrated on administering settlement program was not ground to deny transfer, where none of parties in nonsettling cases had requested judge to proceed with pretrial discovery and there was no indication that judge was unwilling or unable to conduct pretrial proceedings while supervising settlement program.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 303 F. Supp. 1056 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: State law claims, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Transfer of action, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in centralized actions alleging that cellular telephone company's collection of particular state and local taxes violated the federal Internet Tax Freedom Act (ITFA) prohibition against the imposition of such taxes on internet access, was not warranted, where claims alleged in the action derived entirely from Texas law and did not arise under ITFA.
In re: AT & T Mobility Wireless Data Services Sales Tax Litigation, 710 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2953

Presence of a state law claim is no bar to transfer of an action to another district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation (East Coast), 471 F. Supp. 1089 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Fact that various actions may raise legal issues regarding application of the law of different states is an insufficient ground for denying transfer of litigation for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, since such issue can be presented to and resolved by the transferee judge.
In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Stay of proceedings, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
When considering motion to stay multidistrict litigation, court considers: (1) potential prejudice to non-moving party; (2) hardship and inequity to moving party if action is not stayed; and (3) judicial resources that would be saved by avoiding duplicative litigation if cases are consolidated.
Ortiz v. Menu Foods, Inc., 525 F. Supp. 2d 1220 (D. Haw. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Fact that four of the actions in question had been stayed in the district in which they had been brought pending the outcome of administrative proceedings did not affect the authority of the Judicial Panel to transfer the actions, nor did the transfer itself affect the present status of those actions.
In re Capital Underwriters, Inc. Securities Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 955 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2958

Transfers of actions arising out of failure of bank for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would in no way affect operation of stay brought about by bankruptcy rule, and thus Judicial Panel was not without authority to transfer the actions until stay was vacated or appropriately modified; question of effect of bankruptcy stay and any modification thereof was entirely a problem to be worked out by transferee court, the bankruptcy court and the parties.
In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

Multidistrict actions concerning validity and enforceability of patent were not transferred to Southern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where only actions remaining in the Southern District were actions which were against local distributors whom defendant manufacturers had agreed to indemnify and with respect to which stay of proceedings had been ordered pending final determination of litigation involving the manufacturers, and where motion for summary judgment by plaintiff in one of the only two active cases involving the patent was ripe for decision.
In re Lehman Equipment Co. Patent Infringement Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Venue, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Where case if filed in jurisdiction of proper venue would have been transferred for pretrial purposes by action of Judicial Panel, action would not be dismissed on venue grounds.
Maricopa County v. American Petrofina, Inc., 322 F. Supp. 467 (N.D. Cal. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of five actions pending in multidistrict litigation was not warranted, where pending action on a motion for transfer of venue in two actions might eliminate the docket's multidistrict character.
In re ATM Interchange Fee Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In considering whether to permit centralization of litigation, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation is not encumbered by considerations of venue.
In re Peanut Crop Ins. Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Discretion of Panel is not limited by venue considerations and fact that defendants may not all be amendable to suit in same jurisdiction does not prevent transfer to single district for pretrial proceedings where requisites of this section are otherwise satisfied.
In re Air Crash at Schenley Golf Course, Pittsburgh, Pa., on August 21, 1977, 509 F. Supp. 252 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Discretion of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation under this section was not limited by venue considerations, and fact that defendants may not all have been amenable to suit in same jurisdiction did not prevent transfer to a single district for pretrial proceedings, where prerequisites of this section were otherwise satisfied.
In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

In considering transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, the Judicial Panel is not encumbered by considerations of venue, including venue restrictions of section 94 of Title 12.
In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Discretion vested in Judicial Panel to transfer actions is unencumbered by venue considerations.
In re Hotel Telephone Charge Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1974). See, also, In re Vernitron Securities Litigation, 462 F. Supp. 391 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re New Mexico Natural Gas Antitrust Litigation, 482 F. Supp. 333 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer by the Judicial Panel of civil actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is for pretrial purposes only, and the fact that all parties are not amenable to suit in a particular district does not prevent transfer to that district for pretrial proceedings where the statutory prerequisites are otherwise satisfied; succinctly, venue is not a criterion in deciding the propriety of transfer.
In re Aviation Products Liability Litigation, 347 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

Discretion of Judicial Panel to transfer cases to a single district for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings is not limited by venue considerations but turns on the existence of common questions of fact and questions concerning the convenience of the parties and witnesses and the just and efficient conduct of the actions.
In re International House of Pancakes Franchise Litigation, 343 F. Supp. 948 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

When determination of necessity for change of venue on ground of convenience of parties, witnesses, etc., in the interest of justice has preceded decision of Judicial Panel under this section, panel has shown deference to the district court decision but when the Panel's decision precedes some potential transfers under § 1404 of this title, it is duty of the Panel to select the transferee district best able to serve as trial forum as well.
In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

Decision of Judicial Panel to transfer cases to a single district for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceeding is not limited by venue considerations and fact that defendants may not all be amenable to suit in same jurisdiction does not prevent their transfer to a single district for pretrial proceedings where prerequisites of this section are otherwise satisfied.
In re Kauffman Mut. Fund Actions, 337 F. Supp. 1337 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Miscellaneous considerations, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Other relevant factors may be considered in deciding whether suit should be tried in district where suit is first brought, with issue committed to sound discretion of the district court.
Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. v. Schneider, 435 F. Supp. 742 (S.D. N.Y. 1977).
Federal Courts  3956

head.headtext: Miscellaneous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally—Generally

para.paratext:
Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation arising from allegedly inaccurate statements concerning a renewable energy company's operational and financial condition; company's bankruptcy proceeding was underway in that district, the district had the support of defendants and several plaintiffs, and centralization there would facilitate coordination with the bankruptcy court on, inter alia, discovery, indemnification and settlement issues, and, given that many of the underwriter defendants were based in the district, many potentially relevant documents and witnesses might be found there.
In re Sunedison, Inc., Securities Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2957

Inclusion of four actions, pending in two districts, alleging that a manufacturer of automobiles equipped certain diesel engines with software designed to defeat emissions testing, in previously-ordered multidistrict litigation docket involving manufacturer's parent company and similar allegations, was warranted; actions had strong factual ties to the previously-ordered docket, and creation of a separate docket would create inefficiencies, since it would require retransfer of certain claims or coordination between two transferee judges as to discovery and motion practice, creating a heightened risk of inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Porsche "Clean Diesel" Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Four actions pending in four federal districts, brought against spice distributor by consumers who purchased black pepper products that did not contain amount of pepper by weight as disclosed on product labels, would be transferred for centralized pretrial proceedings to District of District of Columbia; actions in litigation involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, and would promote just and efficient conduct of litigation through guidance of judge well-versed in nuances of complex litigation, by eliminating duplicative discovery, avoiding inconsistent pretrial rulings, particularly on class certification, and would conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re McCormick & Company, Inc., Pepper Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that a home security system and alarm monitoring company's telemarketing calls violated the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA); actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Monitronics Intern., Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act Litigation, 988 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in ten actions, pending in two districts, alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning company's financial condition and accounting practices; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to questions of class certification), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Veeco Instruments Inc. Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of two consolidated actions pending in one district and one action pending in a second district, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer out of the docket in which the consolidated actions had been pending for almost two years, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Sumatriptan Succinate Patent Litigation, 381 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of 29 actions for consolidated pretrial proceedings was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary; centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, given that actions involved common questions of fact.
In re Nortel Networks Corp. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of three putative class actions and one potential tag-along action, arising out of an airline's alleged disclosure of its passengers' personally identifiable travel information to the Transportation Security Administration, and subsequent disclosure of that information to four private research companies, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re American Airlines, Inc., Privacy Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, involving claims of fraud and misrepresentation in connection with the sale of an island in the Bahamas, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Mush Cay Litigation, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of 24 actions and 16 potential tag-along actions, pending in seven districts and alleging that aspects of airline travel cause, or contribute to, development of deep vein thrombosis in airline passengers, was warranted, despite differences among the actions as to named defendants and legal theories of recovery; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Deep Vein Thrombosis Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of four Title VII actions in four districts alleging that railroad discriminated against female employees by excluding coverage for prescription contraception as benefit of employment, was warranted; actions involved common questions of law and fact, centralization in one district would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent or repetitive pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Union Pacific Railroad Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, action pending in the Northern District of California would be transferred to the District of New Jersey for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings; both actions involved common questions of fact and centralization in the District of New Jersey, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Mosaid Technologies Inc., Patent Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization, of four actions pending in two districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Georgeson Shareholder Communications, Inc., Share Exchange Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation involving 46 actions and 8 potential tag-along actions alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning the financial condition of a communications company; actions shared common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Adelphia Communications Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation (No. II), 273 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2003), subsequent determination, 2003 WL 22047621 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of three actions in multidistrict litigation against manufacturers of welding equipment, alleging personal injuries caused by exposure to welding fumes, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Welding Rod Products Liability Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of 21 actions in multidistrict litigation, alleging company's violations of federal securities laws or of Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Royal Ahold N.V. Securities, “ERISA” Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2957

Centralization of two actions pending in multidistrict litigation was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved, and/or numerous to justify transfer.
In re Personalized Media Communications, L.L.C., 261 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of three actions against numerous corporations was warranted, in multidistrict litigation seeking reparations on behalf of present and former residents of South Africa, allegedly victims of apartheid-related crimes; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization served convenience of parties and witnesses and promoted just and efficient conduct of litigation, and was desirable to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re South African Apartheid Litigation, 238 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of 22 actions against corporations was warranted in multidistrict litigation alleging that corporations made misrepresentations or omissions concerning accounting practices relating to recognition of certain types of revenue; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization served convenience of parties and witnesses and promoted just and efficient conduct of litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re AOL Time Warner, Inc., 235 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Actions seeking reparations on behalf of descendants of African-American slaves involved common questions of fact, and thus centralization of the actions in geographically central judicial district was warranted; centralization would prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including regarding class certification, and conserve resources, and geographically central district would be convenient for litigation becoming nationwide in scope.
In re African-American Slave Descendants Litigation, 231 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Actions against promoter, alleging nationwide investment scheme to defraud investors in commercial equipment leases, would be transferred to district in which almost half of the 23 constituent actions were already pending in district; the district was accessible and metropolitan, and in that district, transferee judge had prior, successful experience managing consolidated multidistrict litigation.
In re Commercial Money Center, Inc., Equipment Lease Litigation, 229 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings of 39 actions was warranted in multidistrict litigation against telecommunications corporation alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning its financial condition and accounting practices; all actions focused on significant number of common events, defendants, and witnesses, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re WorldCom, Inc., Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 226 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings of three actions in multidistrict litigation against telecommunications corporation bearing no relation to, or distinct from, actions focusing on alleged accounting and other financial irregularities was not warranted; centralization would neither have served convenience of parties and witnesses nor furthered just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re WorldCom, Inc., Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 226 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of two actions in different judicial districts relating to bank's credit card terms was not warranted, given minimal number of actions, counsels' representations that parties had been successfully informally coordinating pretrial proceedings, and that there were alternatives to transfer that could minimize whatever chances there might have been of duplicative discovery, inconsistent pretrial rulings, or both.
In re Fleet Bank Credit Card Terms Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Where actions involved common questions of fact and transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and where all parties agreed on desirability of transfer, action pending in the District of New Mexico was transferred to the Western District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions pending in that district.
In re Warhead Explosion Aboard USS Newport News on October 1, 1972, 411 F. Supp. 790 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of action which raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation and was necessary to eliminate possibility of duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and economize judicial effort, and transfer was therefore ordered by Judicial Panel.
In re Sta-Power Industries, Inc. Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 404 F. Supp. 476 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, miscellaneous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of multiple antitrust actions alleging price fixing in the market for polychloroprene rubber (CR) was appropriate; each of the actions was brought under the Sherman Act to recover for injuries sustained as a result of an alleged conspiracy engaged in by overlapping defendants to fix CR prices and allocate CR markets, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Polychloroprene Rubber (CR) Antitrust Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization of four actions brought in multidistrict litigation under the Sherman Act, to recover for violations arising in context of an alleged conspiracy to fix the price of rubber chemicals, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Rubber Chemicals Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of twelve actions and four potential tag-along actions alleging a conspiracy to fix, raise, maintain, or stabilize prices for foundry resins, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including those with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Foundry Resins Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of seven actions alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix the price of cotton yarn in the United States and/or to allocate the U.S. cotton yarn market and customers, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Cotton Yarn Antitrust Litigation, 336 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of eight actions and four potential tag-along actions alleging a conspiracy to fix prices for carbon black, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Carbon Black Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of three actions and nine potential tag-along actions alleging a conspiracy to fix and maintain the price of ethylene propylene diene monomer, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Ethylene Propylene Diene Monomer (EPDM) Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of sulfuric acid antitrust litigation in the Northern District of Illinois would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation; centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to class certification matters, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Sulfuric Acid Antitrust Litigation, 270 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings of 16 actions in multidistrict litigation alleging horizontal conspiracy to fix prices of polyester staple in United States or to monopolize U.S. market was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization served convenience of parties and witnesses, promoted just and efficient conduct of litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, and prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Polyester Staple Antitrust Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Miscellaneous actions—Misrepresentation

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentations by a mouthwash manufacturer regarding the plaque-fighting and cavity-preventing properties of its product; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, all responding parties agreed that centralization was appropriate, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Listerine Total Care Mouthwash Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, miscellaneous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of eight actions, pending in six districts, alleging infringement of plaintiff's patent relating to systems and methods of producing customized business forms and brochures through use of low resolution graphics, was not warranted; fact that only eight cases remained in the litigation, which previously involved 32 cases, suggested that the remaining cases might not require the significant judicial attention that centralization would afford, and the Panel found that plaintiff's selective, last-minute dismissals of defendants intending to present oral argument raised troubling question of whether it was attempting to prevent the presentation of opposing viewpoints at oral argument.
In re High Quality Printing Inventions, LLC, ( 070) Patent Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization of 14 patent cases involving patent for system for interconnecting standard telephony communications equipment to Internet protocol networks was warranted; while facts surrounding infringement varied from defendant to defendant, actions would share substantial background questions of fact concerning numerous anticipated arguments regarding validity and enforceability of patent and implicating factual issues concerning such matters as technology underlying patent, prior art, priority, and claim construction, and centralization offered substantial savings in terms of judicial economy by having single judge become acquainted with complex patented technology and construing patent in a consistent fashion.
In re: Bear Creek Technologies, Inc., ('722) Patent Litigation, 858 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization of eight actions in multidistrict litigation, involving the validity of a patent on a process for compression of digital still images and whether patent was infringed by products using the “JPEG” international standard for compression of images, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Compression Labs, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Order by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation centralizing two patent actions in one district was appropriate; both of the actions involved the same two complex patents, which related to methods for preventing or filtering unsolicited electronic mail messages, and could thus be expected to share factual and legal questions concerning such matters as patent validity, prior art, obviousness and interpretation of various claims of the patents.
In re Mailblocks, Inc., Patent Litigation, 279 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, miscellaneous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Consolidation for pretrial proceedings of 39 actions, pending in 21 districts, arising out of claims for products liability relating to heating and cooling systems used in operating rooms was warranted, given that 33 state court actions were also pending in eight states, rendering informal coordination no longer practicable; nearly all complaints alleged defendants knew or should have known that design or manufacturing defects made exhaust system susceptible to bacterial colonization, regardless of cleaning and disinfection procedures used, and that defendants failed to warn of the risks of infection, and discovery and pretrial proceedings would overlap regarding the design, manufacture, operation, and regulation of the device, the sufficiency of defendants' warnings, and plaintiffs' theory of general causation regarding the manner of transmission.
In re Sorin 3T Heater-Cooler System Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 289 F. Supp. 3d 1335 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in 21 actions, pending in 14 districts, as well as 16 potential tag-along actions, alleging that a widely-used herbicide could cause non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and that the manufacturer failed to warn consumers and regulators about alleged risks; actions involved multiple and complex common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Roundup Products Liability Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1346 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in actions in multidistrict litigation arising out of allegations that a drug caused or increased the risk of developing melanoma and that defendant manufacturer failed to warn consumers and health care providers of the alleged risk; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Viagra (Sildenafil Citrate) Products Liability Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Although 41 personal injury actions brought against pharmaceutical company alleging failure to warn of depression drug's withdrawal symptoms shared factual issues concerning drug's development, marketing, labeling, and sale, centralization was not warranted; cases were at substantially different procedural stages, substantial discovery had occurred, company made common discovery available to all plaintiffs in cases in which discovery had been served, plaintiffs were represented by one or more of four law firms, company was represented by same law firm, and this involvement of limited counsel made informal coordination and cooperation practicable.
In re Cymbalta (Duloxetine) Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 138 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of multidistrict personal injury actions against pharmaceutical drug manufacturer, alleging manufacturer's cholesterol-lowering drug caused female users to develop type 2 diabetes, was warranted, where there were 56 constituent actions and over 170 tag-alongs pending in more than 40 districts before more than 100 different judges, actions involved different counsel, similar cases were pending in at least three state courts and creation of multidistrict litigation (MDL) would likely make it easier to coordinate pretrial proceedings in both the state and federal cases, and MDL was not likely to prompt “non-viable” filings to coerce settlement.
In re: Lipitor (Atorvastatin Calcium) Marketing, Salespractices and Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 997 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of six actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in ten districts, alleging that certain of manufacturer's aluminum-clad windows were defective in their design, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Pella Corp. Architect and Designer Series Windows Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 996 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in seven actions arising out of injuries caused to users of an intrauterine contraceptive system as result of perforation and migration and the adequacy of the warning label with respect to those risks; although the actions presented a number of individualized factual issues, they also involved common issues, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Mirena IUD Products Liability Litigation, 938 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was warranted for pretrial proceedings in numerous actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging injuries resulting from use of Seroquel, an atypical antipsychotic medication, but not for similar actions involving other prescription drugs; the Seroquel actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Seroquel Products Liability Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of 27 actions and nine potential tag-along actions, pending in 21 districts, alleging illegal promotion and sale of the drug Neurontin for “off-label” use; all actions were purported class actions involving common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Neurontin Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of 12 actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in 14 districts and alleging that pharmaceutical defendants knew of side effects of a widely-used anti-depressant drug and either concealed, misrepresented, or failed to warn of them; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Paxil Products Liability Litigation, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of two actions and six potential tag-along actions in multidistrict litigation, against automobile manufacturer, alleging engine coolant in certain vehicles caused significant damage to the vehicles and/or did not perform as warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re General Motors Corp. Dex-Cool Products Liability Litigation, 293 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Misrepresentation, miscellaneous actions, consideration governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentations by a mouthwash manufacturer regarding the plaque-fighting and cavity-preventing properties of its product; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, all responding parties agreed that centralization was appropriate, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Listerine Total Care Mouthwash Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, miscellaneous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Investors' eight class actions against residential mortgage lender for alleged securities fraud, in violation of Securities Act, by allegedly materially false or misleading statements or omissions regarding loan origination practices in public offering documents for mortgage-backed securities (MBS), warranted centralization in Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) proceedings that included eight other class actions against lender for alleged securities fraud regarding MBS, although each MBS action involved some unique factual questions related to each offering, since unique questions could be handled by designating separate discovery or motions tracks, any standing issues could be resolved by adding new named plaintiffs, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient litigation by avoiding duplicative discovery and other pretrial proceedings on complex common factual issues, and ensure consistent rulings by single presiding judge thereby reducing duplicative expenditure of judicial resources.
In re: Countrywide Financial Corp. Mortgage-Backed Securities Litigation, 812 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of five actions involving the marketing of auction rate securities (ARS) was warranted, despite contention that actions did not share sufficient questions of fact and that some discovery in one action would not overlap with discovery in other actions; actions possessed common factual core regarding defendants' role in selling ARS or conducting ARS auctions, and centralization would foster pretrial program that allowed pretrial proceedings with respect to any non-common issues to proceed concurrently with pretrial proceedings on common issues, and that ensured that pretrial proceedings were conducted in streamlined manner leading to just and expeditious resolution of all actions to overall benefit of parties.
In re: JP Morgan Auction Rate Securities (ARS) Marketing Litigation, 717 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2957

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in 27 actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in four districts and alleging financial irregularities in connection with corporation's securities; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Qwest Communications Intern., Inc., Securities & “ERISA” Litigation (No. II), 444 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of 14 actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that cable television company violated federal securities laws by misrepresenting its financial condition and/or engaging in improper accounting practices, was warranted; centralization served convenience of the parties and witnesses and promoted just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Charter Communications, Inc., Securities Litigation, 254 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Trademark actions, miscellaneous actions, considerations governing transfer of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization, of five trademark infringement actions pending in four districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, particularly since one of the actions had purportedly settled, three were at an advanced stage, and the remaining action was an only tangentially related defamation action, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re MQVP, Inc. Trademark Litigation, 517 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings of nine actions in multidistrict litigation seeking determination whether operation of computer advertising network constituted trademark or copyright infringement was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization served convenience of parties and witnesses, promoted just and efficient conduct of litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, and prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Gator Corp. Software Trademark & Copyright Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: CONVENIENCE
Attorneys, convenience

para.paratext:
Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee district for pretrial proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging intracranial hypertension injuries caused by the hormonal component of an IUD contraceptive system; district was near defendant's corporate headquarters in New Jersey, where many common documents and witnesses were likely to be located, district would provide a geographically convenient forum for the nationwide litigation and ensure that any potential overlap with related litigation involving perforation and migration injuries was coordinated efficiently, and the transferee judge was experienced and had the willingness and ability to manage the litigation and steer it on a prudent course.
In re Mirena IUS Levonorgestrel-Related Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 249 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Only if inconvenience of counsel would impinge on convenience of parties or witnesses would convenience of counsel become factor to be considered by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation in deciding whether to order transfer or in selecting transferee forum for group of actions.
In re Anthracite Coal Antitrust Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 402 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Travel, convenience—Generally

para.paratext:
Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee district for pretrial proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging intracranial hypertension injuries caused by the hormonal component of an IUD contraceptive system; district was near defendant's corporate headquarters in New Jersey, where many common documents and witnesses were likely to be located, district would provide a geographically convenient forum for the nationwide litigation and ensure that any potential overlap with related litigation involving perforation and migration injuries was coordinated efficiently, and the transferee judge was experienced and had the willingness and ability to manage the litigation and steer it on a prudent course.
In re Mirena IUS Levonorgestrel-Related Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 249 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of antitrust action brought by individual adjuster against adjusting firm from Eastern District of Kentucky, to Southern District of New York, for consolidation with similar suits, was not prohibited on theory that forcing adjuster to travel to the Eastern District of New York would thwart public policy relating to energy crisis.
In re General Adjustment Bureau Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Attorneys, travel, convenience

para.paratext:
Motion to vacate conditional order transferring antibiotic drug civil antitrust case to Southern District of New York would be denied where, although some extra expense and inconvenience would be involved in plaintiff's counsel's travel to New York for pretrial conferences, expense and inconvenience would be more than offset by savings from and convenience of coordinating and consolidating pretrial proceedings directed by transferee judge.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 303 F. Supp. 1056 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

In view of savings from, and convenience of, coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, additional expense of counsel's travel was insufficient to preclude transfer from Illinois to Philadelphia of pretrial conferences in multidistrict private civil treble damage antitrust actions.
In re Plumbing Fixtures, 302 F. Supp. 795 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Parties and witnesses, travel, convenience

para.paratext:
Alaska plaintiffs' concern that transfer, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in multidistrict antitrust litigation, would impose extreme financial hardships upon them was unwarranted, since such a transfer is for pretrial proceedings only and thus there is usually no need for parties and witnesses to travel to transferee district for depositions or otherwise and judicious use of liaison counsel, lead counsel and steering committees would eliminate need for most counsel to travel to transferee district.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

It appearing that federal court actions instituted in New York and Illinois involved the factual issues common to the actions previously transferred to the Northern District of California for coordinated pretrial proceedings pursuant to this section, the federal actions in New York, and Illinois would also be transferred over objection that plaintiff in Illinois action could not afford to pay for transportation of witnesses from Illinois to California and objection of plaintiff in New York action, represented by pro bono counsel in New York, that he could not afford to hire California counsel.
In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1167 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Parties and witnesses, convenience—Generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of pretrial proceedings was unnecessary for the convenience of parties and witnesses or to further just and efficient conduct of the litigation, in six actions in three adjacent federal districts alleging violations of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) by debt collection agency allegedly using automated system to place calls, even though the cases shared factual questions; fact discovery was likely to be straightforward while individualized discovery would be significant, fact discovery closing within six months meant consolidation was unlikely to be efficient, prior cases involving agency and the TCPA indicated settlement was likely, and the limited number of involved counsel and the proximity of actions suggested that cooperation and informal coordination were practicable alternatives.
In re Enhanced Recovery Company, LLC, Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation (No. III), 278 F. Supp. 3d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of three actions pending in two districts and raising questions concerning the conduct of the Corps of Engineers with regard to the flow of water in the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint (ACF) River basin and/or the role of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (Service) in the Corps's conduct; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Tri-State Water Rights Litigation, 481 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is not mandated by finding that common questions of fact permeate the actions, and transfer will not be ordered unless convenience of parties and witnesses is served and just and efficient conduct of actions promoted by such transfer.
In re Photocopy Paper, 305 F. Supp. 60 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel must consider multiple litigation as a whole in the light of the law; however, there is no need to inconvenience witnesses since depositions can and should be taken at locations convenient to those witnesses.
In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Before transferring case, Judicial Panel must make affirmative determination that transfer will be for convenience of parties and witnesses and will promote just and efficient conduct of action.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Balance of conveniences, parties and witnesses

para.paratext:
Convenience of parties and witnesses does not bar transfer of an action to sister district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings since normally there is no necessity for the parties to participate in pretrial conferences held by the transferee court and, also, depositions of the parties and witnesses can be taken in the district in which they reside; however, inconvenience and expense caused by transfer is to be balanced against any overall savings from convenience of including all suits in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation (East Coast), 471 F. Supp. 1089 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Action in which claims admittedly duplicated claims already involved in securities litigation in transferee district would be transferred to that district for inclusion in pending coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, despite contention that convenience to one party from the transfer in connection with proposed settlement would outweigh inconveniences to other parties in disruption of ongoing proceedings of the transferee district and that stay order in the transferor district had effectively prevented duplication of discovery and other pretrial efforts.
In re Viatron Computer Systems, 462 F. Supp. 382 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Centralization in District of Colorado, rather than District of Idaho, would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, where actions shared numerous factual questions concerning cause or causes of crash of commercial aircraft during attempted takeoff at Denver airport, aircraft wreckage was stored in Denver, and pertinent witnesses and documents could be found there.
In re Air Crash Disaster At Stapleton InternationalRT, Airport, Denver, Colorado, On November 15, 1987, 683 F. Supp. 266 (J.P.M.L. 1988).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in 19 actions and 27 potential tag-along actions, pending in various districts, alleging that defendants conspired to fix prices, conspired to circumvent competitive bidding and independent pricing, and committed other anticompetitive practices designed to unlawfully fix, raise, maintain and stabilize the prices at which liquid aluminum sulfate was sold in the U.S. over a 13-year period, in violation of the Sherman Act; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Liquid Aluminum Sulfate Antitrust Litigation, 159 F. Supp. 3d 1382 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

In light of fact that actions in multidistrict litigation involving antitrust claims pertaining to the title insurance industry encompassed different regulatory regimes in the states in which they were pending, along with variances in insurance regulation and law, centralization of those actions was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Title Ins. Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) & Antitrust Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

While antitrust action filed in Northern District of California and action in transferee district shared some questions of fact, transfer of case to Central District of California would neither serve convenience of parties and witnesses nor promote just and efficient conduct of litigation and, thus, transfer would not be ordered.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 476 F. Supp. 455 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

Where antitrust actions against gas meter manufacturers involved common questions of fact, transfer of action pending in one district to another district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with three actions pending in transferee district would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Gas Meter Antitrust Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 391 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

Actions involving allegations of fraud, misrepresentation, breach of warranty, and violations of federal antitrust laws in respect to sales of automobiles containing engines manufactured by a division of manufacturer other than one from which vehicles were purchased were transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions sharing common questions of fact where transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re General Motors Corp. Engine Interchange Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 933 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

In view of common questions of fact and because transfer would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, all armored car antitrust cases pending in districts other than the Northern District of Georgia were transferred to that district.
In re Armored Car Antitrust Litigation., 441 F. Supp. 921 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Counterclaim issues in California private antitrust action, involving effect of prior bankruptcy proceedings on California plaintiff's standing to sue for antitrust damages, were purely legal in nature and could be easily resolved by judge of Washington District Court to which action was to be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, thus transfer was not precluded on theory that inconvenience of transfer could be fatal to plaintiff in view of its bankruptcy proceedings.
In re West Coast Bakery Flour Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 808 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Convenience of parties and witnesses and just and efficient conduct of litigation involving question of whether enforcement of reserve clause in professional hockey players' contracts violated antitrust laws warranted consolidation for pretrial proceedings except for cases pending in the Eastern District of New York where motions for preliminary injunction were sub judice.
In re Professional Hockey Antitrust Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Except in respect to New Mexico action, civil actions arising out of alleged antitrust conspiracies in regard to sale of concrete pipe would be transferred to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania for consolidation or coordinated pretrial proceedings where to do so would be for the convenience of parties and witnesses and would promote the just and efficient conduct of such actions.
In re Concrete Pipe, 302 F. Supp. 244 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954
