Multidistrict civil antitrust actions were to be transferred to single district for coordinated pretrial proceedings, where convenience of all parties and all witnesses would be served by such transfer, even though it was to the interest of each plaintiff to have all proceedings in his suit handled in his district.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Bankruptcy proceedings, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Where numerous cases raised common questions of fact concerning defendant's sale of short-time promissory notes of transportation company which was in financial difficulty, convenience of parties and witnesses and just and efficient conduct of litigation would be served by consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 309 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Contract actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would not transfer action brought in District of New Jersey by company that marketed movie presentation for breach of contract, unfair competition, and tortious interference with business relationship to Southern District of Florida for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action brought there by same plaintiff, involving identical allegations against common defendants and related allegations against noncommon defendants, where transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re 21st Century Productions Inc. “Thrilsphere” Contract Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 271 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict action which involved eight subcontractors who were allegedly fraudulently induced by defendant financiers of warehouse to continue construction on warehouse after construction was halted by owners and which was commenced in Northern District of Georgia would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action by six of same plaintiffs against same defendants, in light of fact that transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of litigation and prevent duplication of discovery and inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Warehouse Const. Contract Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 734 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Civil rights actions, parties and witnesses

para.paratext:
Equal Employment Opportunity Commission's motion to centralize five employment discrimination suits against same company in Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied, since, although some or all of the actions might involve some common questions of fact, transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Sears, Roebuck & Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1362 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2953

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would deny motion to transfer employment discrimination action, alleging that employer had engaged in pattern and practice of employment discrimination on basis of race and national origin, from Southern District of Texas to Northern District of Texas for consolidation with action pending there in which Equal Employment Opportunity Commission alleged that same employer engaged in employment discrimination on basis of race, sex and national origin where transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Texas Instruments Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 928 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with class action challenging airline's weight restrictions, of individual action by suspended flight attendant challenging utilization of the weight requirements would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, although the actions might involve some common questions of fact, the individual action involved chiefly allegations of discriminatory treatment relating to the main plaintiff alone while the class actions raised broader issues.
In re Delta Airlines, Inc., Flight Attendant Weight Standards Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 795 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Discrimination actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Equal Employment Opportunity Commission's motion to centralize five employment discrimination suits against same company in Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied, since, although some or all of the actions might involve some common questions of fact, transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Sears, Roebuck & Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1362 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2953

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would deny motion to transfer employment discrimination action, alleging that employer had engaged in pattern and practice of employment discrimination on basis of race and national origin, from Southern District of Texas to Northern District of Texas for consolidation with action pending there in which Equal Employment Opportunity Commission alleged that same employer engaged in employment discrimination on basis of race, sex and national origin where transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Texas Instruments Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 928 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with class action challenging airline's weight restrictions, of individual action by suspended flight attendant challenging utilization of the weight requirements would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, although the actions might involve some common questions of fact, the individual action involved chiefly allegations of discriminatory treatment relating to the main plaintiff alone while the class actions raised broader issues.
In re Delta Airlines, Inc., Flight Attendant Weight Standards Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 795 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Motor vehicle accident actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Multidistrict action commenced in Connecticut by highway accident survivor in her individual and representative capacities against owner of truck involved in accident, truck driver and driver of third vehicle involved in accident, would not be transferred to Eastern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action by survivor in her individual and representative capacities against lessee of truck, where requested transfer would not serve convenience of parties and their witnesses duplication of discovery sought by plaintiff could be avoided by defendants' cooperation and request for transfer was motivated by desire to circumvent obstacles of personal jurisdiction.
In re Highway Acc. Near Rockville, Connecticut, on December 30, 1972, 388 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Though Texas suit to obtain injunctive relief and damages for alleged patent infringement, unfair competition and breach of distributorship contract involves some of the same questions of fact as were involved in Mississippi action, transfer of Mississippi action to Northern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Sicilia Di R. Biebow & Co. Contract Litigation, 490 F. Supp. 513 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2956

Patent infringement actions in the Middle District of Pennsylvania, Eastern District of New York, and Southern District of New York would not be transferred to the District of Delaware for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings there, where transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, inasmuch as two of actions were well advanced and had already benefitted from participation in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, no party advocated that any discovery remained to be accomplished on central issue of patent validity, and no adequate demonstration was made that infringement issue in one action shared factual questions with infringement issues in other actions.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro, 464 F. Supp. 966 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Centralization of nine class actions, pending in nine districts, all arising out of claims for product defects and false advertising relating to manufacturer's resurfacing and coating products, was not necessary for the convenience of the parties and witnesses or to further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; parties in two actions had recently reached agreement on a nationwide class settlement, for which preliminary approval was anticipated in less than a month, and all interested parties asserting same claims would have opportunity to object to or otherwise raise issues as to adequacy of proposed settlement when motion for preliminary approval was filed.
In re Behr Deckover Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 285 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 64 actions, filed by cities, counties, and states and pending in nine districts, alleging that manufacturers of prescription opioid medications overstated benefits and downplayed risks of use of their opioids and aggressively marketed them to physicians, and that distributors failed to monitor, detect, investigate, refuse and report suspicious orders of prescription opiates; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would substantially reduce the risk of duplicative discovery, minimize the possibility of inconsistent pretrial obligations, and prevent conflicting rulings on pretrial motions.
In re National Prescription Opiate Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of three different actions in three different Districts, all brought by the same plaintiff and alleging that defendants — different defendants in each action — used improper means to capture a higher share of the Brazilian market for medical devices — was not necessary to serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of the litigation; since different defendants were sued in each action and there was no allegation that they conspired or coordinated with one another, the factual issues presented in each action would be primarily case-specific, any overlapping discovery would pretrial likely be limited to discovery of the common plaintiff, and there would be no significant risk of inconsistent rulings.
In re Brazilian Prosthetic Device Bribery Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in five actions, pending in four districts, involving allegations of anticompetitive conduct or unfair methods of competition with respect to an epinephrine delivery system; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Epipen (Epinephrine Injection, USP) Marketing, Sales Practices and Antitrust Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2954; Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that the use by women of defendants' talcum powder products resulted in the development of ovarian or uterine cancer; actions involved common questions of fact which were sufficiently complex to merit centralized treatment, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to discovery, privilege, and Daubert motion practice, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of California was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that a widely-used herbicide could cause non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and that the manufacturer failed to warn consumers and regulators about alleged risks; two of the earliest-filed and most procedurally advanced of the actions were pending in the district, the district was convenient and easily accessible for all parties and had the necessary judicial resources and expertise to efficiently manage the litigation, and centralization in the district allowed the litigation to be assigned to a skilled jurist who had not yet had opportunity to preside over a docket in multidistrict litigation.
In re: Roundup Products Liability Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1346 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of six actions, pending in four districts, was not necessary for convenience of the parties and witnesses or to further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, even though all the actions arose out of allegations that polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) manufactured by defendant contaminated certain marine environments and that plaintiffs had or will incur costs to remediate PCBs from urban runoff, stormwater, sediment, and bodies of water; since each action involved a different body of water, factual questions relating to the alleged contamination would differ, particularly since it was not alleged that defendant directly contaminated those waters, but rather that PCBs it manufactured and incorporated into other products thereafter leached into the environment, facts relating to regulation of the allegedly affected waters and plaintiffs' remediation efforts were likely to differ significantly, fact that all of the actions were pending within same Circuit reduced potential for inconsistent pretrial rulings, discovery would be facilitated by the personal injury and other lawsuits brought against defendant, and defendant had committed itself to cooperating with plaintiffs' counsel to avoid duplicative discovery.
In re Monsanto PCB Water Contamination Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of 12 product liability actions to District of Massachusetts for centralized pretrial proceedings was warranted, where actions involved common questions of fact arising from allegations that name brand drug and its generic equivalent, a prescription medication for treatment of nausea, caused birth defects in children when their mothers ingested drug while pregnant, and centralization in District of Massachusetts, where five actions were pending, including first-filed action, would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re Zofran (Ondansetron) Products Liability Litigation, 138 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization, of 11 actions, pending in ten districts, arising out of allegations that the drug metoclopramide caused neurological injuries, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, since there was no single common defendant, some defendants were named in only one or two actions, and a significant amount of the common discovery had already taken place, and any remaining common questions of fact were not sufficiently complex and/or numerous to justify transfer.
In re Reglan/Metoclopramide Products Liability Litigation, 622 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of action, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions alleging neurological injuries caused by exposure to manganese in welding fumes, was not warranted; transfer would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of the litigation, since plaintiff was complaining that he developed laryngeal cancer from welding on used oil-field piping covered with naturally occurring radioactive material.
In re: Welding Fume Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of Illinois was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in seven actions, pending in six districts, arising out of the design and manufacture of a product and the adequacy of a voluntary recall of that product; district was relatively conveniently located in relation to documents and witnesses located at one defendant's Canadian headquarters, and all parties agreed upon the choice.
In re Aqua Dots Products Liability Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Motions filed by two groups of plaintiffs in products liability litigation to centralize in a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings 92 actions pending in federal district court would be denied since proposed transfer would neither serve convenience of parties and witnesses nor further just and efficient conduct of litigation in view of fact that, although actions in litigation involved some common questions of fact, such questions would not predominate over individual questions of fact present in each action.
In re Rely Tampon Products Liability Litigation, 533 F. Supp. 1346 (J.P.M.L. 1982).
Federal Courts  2953

Conditional transfer of five products liability suits involving claims for injuries allegedly sustained through use of intra uterine devices to District of Kansas would be vacated where transfer would not serve convenience of the parties or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc., 505 F. Supp. 221 (J.P.M.L. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

Products liability action pending in Montana and Louisiana, in each of which plaintiff had suffered eye infection following implantation of an intraocular lens manufactured by defendant as part of the same lot, would not be transferred to the Central District of California on motion of defendant for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, over opposition of plaintiffs, though sharing some common questions of fact, where transfer would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the action, there were significant individual factual questions, and pretrial proceedings in the Louisiana action were well advanced.
In re Luminex Intern., Inc. Products Liability Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 668 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that company violated securities laws by misleading investors about the nature of its investments and its financial condition; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Citigroup Inc. Securities Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Evidence, in proceedings on order to show cause why three related securities actions should not be transferred to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, indicated that, although actions shared some common questions of fact, transfer would not necessarily serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of actions, and accordingly, order to show cause would be vacated.
In re Hamilton Bank (of Atlanta) Securities Litigation, 438 F. Supp. 940 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Even though action pending in Southern District of Florida and action pending in District of Delaware, both of which charged that certain merger constituted fraud upon public shareholders of surviving corporation in violation of securities laws, involved common questions of fact, where transfer of either action would result in inconvenience to plaintiffs and actions were not so complex and accompanying discovery so time consuming as to overcome such inconvenience, neither action would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Royal American Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 242 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Trademark actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Five actions filed in five districts, involving the issue whether “light” is a generic or common descriptive word when applied to beer and whether that word or its phonetic equivalent may be appropriated as a trademark for beer, would not be transferred to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, since a recent determination by the Seventh Circuit in one action could have a dispositive effect on the others, since discovery was substantially completed in two actions and both were nearing trial, since the parties were nearly unanimous in opposing transfer, and since, in short, transfer would not necessarily serve the convenience of parties and witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re “Lite Beer” Trademark Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 754 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, parties and witnesses, convenience

para.paratext:
Centralization of 19 actions that posed question whether employees were properly compensated for meal and rest breaks while on call was not necessary to serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or to further just and efficient conduct of litigation; although the cases involved common factual questions, the alternatives were preferable, including transfer and voluntary cooperation and coordination among parties and courts to avoid duplicative discovery or inconsistent pretrial rulings, given that actions were pending before three judges in adjacent districts and the parties were represented by common counsel.
In re Comcast Corp. Employee Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1344 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization, of 10 actions, pending in four districts, alleging misleading marketing of infant formulas and cereals, was not necessary; since there was some reasonable prospect that the multidistrict character of the litigation could be resolved through resolution of pending motions for transfer of venue, centralization would not serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Gerber Probiotic Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 899 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings in three actions, pending in two districts, alleging misrepresentations in a food product manufacturer's marketing practices, was not necessary for the convenience of the parties and witnesses or the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; any shared factual questions among the actions were not sufficiently complex or numerous as to justify transfer.
In re: Nutella Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation of multidistrict litigation for pretrial proceedings in the Southern District of Florida would serve the convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of litigation; actions shared factual questions relating to allegations that defendants failed to perform adequate due diligence before investing money from mutual fund in investment firm, actions would likely focus on a significant number of common events, defendants, and/or witnesses, and one defendant was headquartered in Southern District of Florida and two actions were already pending there, including the first-filed action.
In re Optimal Strategic U.S. Equity Fund Securities Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions, in multidistrict litigation, alleging that the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) was undercapitalized during the relevant time period, and that defendants concealed that fact from investors in order to raise capital; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Federal Home Loan Mortg. Corp. (Freddie Mac) Securities Litigation, 643 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation arising out of insurance company's policies and practices for reimbursing its plan members' visits to “non-participating” or “out-of-network” providers; actions involved complex common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Aetna, Inc., Out-Of-Network UCR Rates Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of 26 separate actions against employer, alleging violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), pending in 22 districts would not serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further the just and efficient conduct of litigation; plaintiffs, who were employed as hourly-paid maintenance workers in various apartment communities throughout the country who had opted into a conditionally certified collective action in the District of District of Columbia which was subsequently decertified, brought motion after discovery on common factual issues had occurred in the District of Columbia action, and any remaining and unresolved common questions of fact among these actions were not sufficiently complex and/or numerous.
In re AIMCO, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in 19 actions pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or failures to disclose material information concerning mortgage investment company and its financial condition and prospects; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re American Home Mortg. Securities Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 11 actions and seven potential tag-along actions, pending in seven districts, arising out of the production of defendants' toys in China with surface paints that allegedly contained elevated levels of lead, and the sale of those toys in the United States; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Mattel, Inc., Toy Lead Paint Products Liability Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings were warranted for five actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in four districts and alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix, maintain and/or stabilize the price of refined petroleum products in the United States; actions shared factual questions, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Refined Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of 20 actions against peanut butter manufacturer in 13 separate districts was warranted, where all the actions involved common questions of fact, given that plaintiffs in all actions alleged harm from consuming and/or purchasing contaminated peanut butter that was manufactured at same plant, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re ConAgra Peanut Butter Products, 495 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL) would transfer eight class actions, alleging defendant violated Drivers' Privacy Protection Act by performance of contracts involving motor vehicle departments in six states, to Middle District of Florida for consolidated pretrial proceedings, since first action was filed in that district, and was relatively more procedurally advanced; actions involved common questions of fact, plaintiffs' allegations could spawn challenging procedural questions, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re Imagitas, Inc., Drivers' Privacy Protection Act Litigation, 486 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of 16 actions against energy company, consolidated for pretrial proceedings, to District of Minnesota was appropriate, in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentation or omissions regarding operations and business prospects; 14 of the 16 actions were currently underway there, and district was conveniently located for many parties and witnesses.
In re Xcel Energy, Inc., 254 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Although there might be some common factual issues among removed state foreclosure actions pending in federal district courts in Districts of Florida and Illinois and antitrust action pending in Eastern District of Pennsylvania which involved common parties, transfer of foreclosure actions to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would neither serve convenience of parties and witnesses nor promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Brandywine Associates Antitrust and Mortg. Foreclosure Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 236 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: JUST AND EFFICIENT CONDUCT OF ACTIONS
Just and efficient conduct of actions generally

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings in actions, in multidistrict litigation, alleging that defendants violated the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) and, in some cases, analogous state law, by using an automatic dialing system to repeatedly make debt collection calls to plaintiffs' cell phones without their express consent, appeared unlikely to produce significant efficiencies, weighing against centralization; although most of the actions shared certain factual issues, those common issues appeared to be relatively straightforward, such that discovery was unlikely to be unusually burdensome or time-consuming, whereas the amount of individualized discovery into various matters seemed likely to be quite significant, there was procedural disparity among the cases, since some of the actions had been pending far longer than the others, and many of the cases might be susceptible to fairly quick resolution.
In re Kohl's Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1363 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

Inclusion of three actions in centralized pretrial proceedings for actions, in multidistrict litigation, involving alleged infringement of patent and licensing rights by defendants' large-scale commercial printers, was not appropriate; inclusion of the three actions in the centralized proceedings was unlikely to result in just and efficient conduct of the litigation as a whole, since the potential to reduce duplicative discovery and motion practice was limited, if any, considering the advanced status of discovery and substantive motions in the three actions and fact that two of them involved significant sealed proceedings, likelihood that inclusion of the actions in the centralized proceedings would create efficiencies was further diminished because the actions did not share significant issues of fact with the centralized actions, and one of the three actions would not require any patent claim construction or raise patent validity issues that might overlap with the centralized proceedings.
In re: Indus. Print Technologies, LLC, Patent Litigation, 98 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

Judicial Panel, after determination of question on its own initiative, declined to transfer for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceeding two actions in another district where it was convinced that the just and efficient conduct of these actions would not be furthered by transfer.
In re Westec Corp., 307 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Access to proof, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Private civil treble damage litigation involving plumbing fixtures was transferred from Oklahoma to Pennsylvania for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings where transfer would insure that evidence acquired by the government for use in criminal prosecution would be uniformly available and best way of insuring lack of conflict between Oklahoma class action claims and those in other cases was to have single judge make necessary determinations, notwithstanding that only remaining questions of fact may have concerned damages.
In re Plumbing Fixtures, 311 F. Supp. 349 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Breadth of action, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Breadth of semiconductor patent infringement action, which involved preliminarily a breach of contract dispute, in comparison with all other actions warranted its exclusion from coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in order to best promote the expeditious processing of actions.
In re Western Elec. Co., Inc. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 378 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Class actions, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Putative class action that asserted claims against both ride-sharing company and smartphone manufacturer would be included in centralization of litigation in nine other putative class actions and seven potential tag-along actions that were brought only against ride-sharing company, all of which arose from company's announcement that personal information of 57 million drivers and riders was inappropriately downloaded by individuals outside the company; the complaint alleged an “entitlement” given by manufacturer to company allowed the company's smartphone application to capture screen images and other data on an smartphone without the user's knowledge, and so this alleged entitlement and the data breach were related with respect to the scope of personal information accessed by the alleged hackers.
In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Data Security Breach Litigation, 304 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of eight actions, pending in six districts, arising out of allegations that bank employees used confidential information to open fraudulent accounts in customers' names to meet sales goals, and that bank encouraged, knew of, or should have known of the practice, was not necessary to serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of the litigation; since parties in one of the actions had recently reached a nationwide class settlement in principle, with a motion for preliminary approval of the proposed settlement due in less than a month, centralization could delay a class-wide settlement with little or no benefit to the parties and putative class members.
In re Wells Fargo Fraudulent Account Opening Litigation, 282 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Multiple putative class actions brought by consumers against sellers of grated parmesan cheese arose from a common factual core, as would support centralization of all cases into a single docket; consumers all claimed that sellers mislabeled their products as 100 percent grated parmesan cheese when the products instead contained a food additive known as cellulose, so centralization of the 16 actions brought in nine different districts against four sellers and five potential tag-along cases would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 201 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Convenience factors did not support centralization of pretrial proceedings for two purported class actions against Secretary of the United States Department of Health and Human Services concerning Medicare fee schedules; actions involved distinctly separate classes, and actions did not involve common questions of fact that were sufficiently complex and/or numerous.
In re Medicare Fee Schedule Locality Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1344 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Matters concerning class action certification should be included in the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in order to prevent inconsistent rulings and promote judicial efficiency.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

Consolidation of multidistrict litigation in one district would not be delayed pending determination of propriety of class action in each district in that matters concerning class action certification should be included in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in order to prevent inconsistent rulings and promote judicial efficiency.
In re Piper Aircraft Distribution System Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Oil spills, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Personal injury and wrongful death actions arising out of the explosion and sinking of an offshore drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico would be included in centralized pretrial proceedings for actions, arising out of the same incident, alleging only economic claims, even though they would require some amount of individualized discovery; the personal injury and wrongful death actions overlapped factually with the economic damages actions, and the transferee judge would have broad powers to employ any number of pretrial techniques to address any differences among the cases and efficiently manage the various aspects of the litigation.
In re: Oil Spill by the Oil Rig Deepwater Horizon in the Gulf of Mexico, on April 20, 2010, 731 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in the numerous actions arising out of the explosion and sinking of an offshore drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico; actions shared factual issues concerning the cause or causes of the incident and the role, if any, that each defendant played in it, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary, it might facilitate closer coordination with administration of the compensation fund that was set up, and it would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the more just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Oil Spill by the Oil Rig Deepwater Horizon in the Gulf of Mexico, on April 20, 2010, 731 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Costs or expenses, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
In complex multi-district litigation, it would be equitable to require state plaintiffs' attorneys to pay their proportionate share of the time and costs incurred by plaintiffs' steering committee (PSC), which was formed in federal cases in order to allow for coordinated action during the pretrial and settlement phases, in its work for the common benefit of all plaintiffs, state and federal.
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 467 F. Supp. 2d 256 (E.D. N.Y. 2006).
Attorney And Client  151; Attorney And Client  152

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 100 actions and two potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that certain employees of a company were entitled to overtime compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); actions involved one or more common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re C.H. Robinson Worldwide, Inc., Overtime Pay Litigation, 502 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Inclusion of corporation named as a defendant in three Illinois' antitrust actions in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in Northern District of California would not result in an unreasonable financial burden upon corporation since, in absence of a conflict, corporation would likely be compelled to defend against related actions in three separate forums and, with transfer and concomitant streamlining of all endeavors in actions in which it was a defendant, would achieve an overall savings in terms of both efforts and resources not only for itself but also for all other parties to actions.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 427 F. Supp. 1018 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

One of purposes of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is to streamline efforts of parties and witnesses, their counsel and the judiciary in order to effectuate an overall savings of cost and a minimum of inconvenience to all concerned.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Where it was likely that adjuster who brought antitrust action against adjustment firm would achieve a savings of expenses by pooling his efforts with other adjusters who had brought similar actions, action would be transferred and consolidated with other actions.
In re General Adjustment Bureau Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Delay, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization was not necessary for convenience of parties and witnesses or to further just and efficient conduct of litigation, in consumers' actions against provider of medical alert products and services, alleging that provider or agent acting on its behalf placed automated or prerecorded telemarketing calls to consumers' residential and wireless numbers without their consent, in violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA), where centralization was likely to delay resolution of two of the three actions, given that proceedings in those actions were significantly advanced, actions were already being managed in orderly and efficient manner, and issues presented were not particularly complex.
In re Lifewatch, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1342 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

It was inappropriate to transfer, for centralized pretrial proceedings, three antitrust actions relating to the animal pancreas gland industry and the finished insulin industry where one action was brought by a relatively small, collector of pancreas glands, the second was brought as a class action on behalf of all nongovernmental purchasers of insulin and the third was brought as a class action on behalf of all meat packers selling animal pancreas glands and where the first action had been pending for two years and considerable discovery had occurred so that inclusion of that action in centralized proceedings could delay its termination without producing any overriding benefits to the litigation as a whole and, with respect to the other two actions, movants did not meet their burden to show that the common factual questions were sufficiently complex and that the accompanying discovery would be so time consuming as to justify transfer.
In re Insulin Mfg. Antitrust Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1359 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2954

Securities and Exchange Commission's injunction action involving acquisition of Nevada hotel-casino was not required to be exempted from order transferring private multidistrict antitrust litigation involving the acquisition to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings on ground that such action would cause delay in securing prompt injunctive relief since the transferee judge was free to gauge the extent of coordination appropriate between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the private actions without inhibiting the Securities and Exchange Commission's push for prompt injunctive relief.
In re Caesar's Palace Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1256 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Transfer of multidistrict trademark cases to Southern District of New York would neither serve convenience of parties and witnesses nor promote just and efficient conduct of litigation where cases contained limited common questions of fact, original action was nearly ripe for decision, and transfer would needlessly entangle third parties in fundamental dispute and only tend to delay expeditious handling of action.
In re Grand Funk R. R. Trademark Litigation, 371 F. Supp. 1084 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Familiarity of court, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
District of New Jersey was appropriate transferee district for multidistrict litigation arising out of insurance company's policies and practices for reimbursing its plan members' visits to “non-participating” or “out-of-network” providers; the judge in that district was well-versed with the issues involved in the litigation, and two other related actions with similar claims were pending before her.
In re: Aetna, Inc., Out-Of-Network UCR Rates Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of pretrial proceedings in the District of Maryland was warranted for nine actions against poultry producer alleging improper marketing of chicken as “Raised Without Antibiotics” or “Raised Without Antibiotics that impact antibiotic resistance in humans”; nine actions involved common questions of fact, two of the nine actions were already pending in District of Maryland, District of Maryland and particular judge were favored by both movants and all responding plaintiffs, judge had developed a significant familiarity with the facts underlying the litigation, having recently overseen a trademark dispute brought by two of producer's competitors involving the same marketing practices, and judge's issuance of preliminary injunction against producer in the trademark litigation did not disqualify him from overseeing multidistrict litigation involving similar issues.
In re: Tyson Foods, Inc. Chicken Raised Without Antibiotics Consumer Litigation, 582 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

District of Minnesota was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 100 actions and two potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that certain employees of a company were entitled to overtime compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); approximately one-fourth of the actions were pending in that district, and the transferee judge had developed a familiarity with the issues, parties, and counsel involved.
In re C.H. Robinson Worldwide, Inc., Overtime Pay Litigation, 502 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for centralization for pretrial proceedings of three actions by franchisees challenging oil company's elimination of its variable rent program as violation of franchisee agreements and Petroleum Marketing Practices Act; one action was pending in district before judge who already had some familiarity with allegations in litigation as result of presiding over related predecessor action.
In re Shell Oil Products Co. Dealer Franchise Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of New York was proper transferee forum of multidistrict litigation arising from an airplane crash in New York state; the flight originated at John F. Kennedy International Airport, crash occurred in New York City metropolitan area, of the 79 known actions arising from the crash, 24 were pending in the District, and the judge to whom action was assigned had pertinent experience in complex air crash litigation.
In re Air Crash at Belle Harbor, N.Y. on November 12, 2001, 203 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2955

Nine cases which were being transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings would be transferred to the Northern District of California where the judge hearing the three cases brought in that district had become thoroughly acquainted with the factual background of all the actions because more extensive discovery and other pretrial proceedings had proceeded in the actions before him than in the other action.
In re Capital Underwriters, Inc. Securities Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 955 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Six private antitrust actions, three of which were brought in the Eastern District of Texas, two of which were brought in the Western District of Louisiana, and one of which was brought in the Middle District of Louisiana, by various classes of bakery product purchasers would be transferred, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, to the Middle District of Louisiana since, although no district clearly stood out as the most appropriate transferee forum, the judge to whom the one case brought in that district had been assigned was well acquainted with the facts involved in the litigation.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1122 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

head.headtext: Foreign parties, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Consolidation of lawsuit brought by United States against tobacco company with lawsuits brought against tobacco company by foreign governments would not promote the just and efficient conduct of the United States' lawsuit, which was filed in same court as actions brought against tobacco company by union trust funds; most of the factual similarities between the action filed by the United States and the foreign government cases were also shared by the union trust fund cases and the foreign governments' suits were previously transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (MDL Panel) to different judge for pretrial purposes in order to decide issues specific to foreign governments.
In re Tobacco/Governmental Health Care Costs Litigation, 76 F. Supp. 2d 5 (D.D.C. 1999).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

head.headtext: Pending actions, just and efficient conduct of actions—Generally

para.paratext:
Consolidation was warranted, although second action was filed because court would not let surety file third-party complaint for indemnification in first action because court was concerned about delay that would have resulted from adding new claims and parties; second action included only two new parties, rather than expected impleader of 70 new parties, first action had been delayed with consent of all parties to pursue settlement discussions and alternative dispute resolution to resolve both cases, and both cases arose out of same facts and transactions.
Villafane Elec. Corp. v. Reliance Ins. Co., 2004 WL 385041 (S.D. N.Y. 2004).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

Centralization of personal injury and wrongful death actions against manufacturers of proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) pharmaceutical products, consisting of 161 actions and 34 potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts and alleging that taking one or more PPIs could result in kidney injury and that defendants failed to adequately warn of negative effects and risks associated with their PPI products, was warranted; the number of involved actions, districts, and plaintiffs' counsel had increased significantly since prior denial of a similar motion, many more cases likely would be filed, there were a significant number of related state court actions, and informal coordination and cooperation were not practicable to manage the litigation, and centralization would facilitate a uniform and efficient pre-trial approach to the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent rulings on Daubert and other pretrial issues, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 261 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization, of three actions, pending in three districts, alleging that various manufacturers of capacitors conspired to fix prices of aluminum and tantalum electrolytic capacitors, as well as film capacitors, used in electronic products, was not necessary; since there was a reasonable prospect that the multidistrict character of the litigation could be resolved through motions for transfer of venue which defendants stated would soon be filed, centralization would not serve convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Capacitors Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 223 F. Supp. 3d 1340 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization, of two actions pending in two districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, since any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Insurance Industry Discriminatory Sales Practices Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of three actions pending in two districts was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any remaining common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, since two of the actions had been pending for a lengthy period of time and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Indian Tribes Contract Support Costs Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of five actions pending in multidistrict litigation was not warranted, where pending action on a motion for transfer of venue in two actions might eliminate the docket's multidistrict character.
In re ATM Interchange Fee Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation arising from bus-truck collision in Nebraska, transfer to Nebraska of bus passenger's Utah action against truck driver's employer, in order to consolidate it with three pending Nebraska actions against bus company, truck driver and others, was not justified; number of actions and districts was minimal, any common questions of fact and law were insufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize any possibility of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Highway Accident in Buffalo County, Nebraska, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation, six actions pending in four districts would be centralized in the Middle District of Florida for the convenience of the parties and witnesses and to promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; actions all involved automobile manufacturer's investment in a new company that was purchasing certain assets of a Korean automobile manufacturer undergoing insolvency proceedings in Korea.
In re Daewoo Motor Co., Ltd., Dealerships Litigation, 246 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of eight actions against corporations, centralized for pretrial proceedings, to Southern District of New York was appropriate, in multidistrict litigation alleging that corporations made fraudulent misrepresentations and omissions in connection with sale of interests in securitized loans to certain institutional investors; seven constituent actions were pending in district and had been consolidated before one judge, and relevant witnesses and documents could be expected to be found within district.
In re Enterprise Mortg. Acceptance Co., LLC Securities Litigation, 237 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957

Transfer of state's suit against pharmaceutical companies to judicial district where other class actions against companies were pending, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was warranted; limitations on judicial panel's authority to transfer parens patriae actions for trial did not preclude their transfer for pretrial proceedings.
In re Pharmaceutical Industry Average Wholesale Price Litigation, 237 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Where there were 38 actions pending in 7 districts, arising out of airplane crash, such litigation was multidistrict litigation within this section providing for transfer to single district.
In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

Where 21 cases arising from aircraft disaster were pending in five different federal district courts, there was clearly “multidistrict litigation” for purposes of motion to consolidate.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Falls City, Neb on August 6, 1966, 298 F. Supp. 1323 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Court of appeals, pending actions, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Transfer of multidistrict actions, for breach of contract by Navy in failure to pay reenlistment bonuses to plaintiffs, to the Southern District of California in which four actions were pending, would not serve the convenience of the parties and their witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation where appeals were pending before Court of Appeal in two circuits and disposition of those appeals could have a substantial if not dispositive effect on all the actions pending in districts within those circuits, and where questions of law rather than common questions of fact were significantly preponderant.
In re U. S. Navy Variable Reenlistment Bonus Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, pending actions, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of two antitrust and patent actions was not necessary for convenience of parties and witnesses or to further just and efficient conduct of litigation, although actions involved most of same parties and involved issues of infringement and validity of patents held by common defendant, where there were only two actions pending, actions were in vastly different procedural postures, and there was insufficient factual overlap given that each action would involve multitude of other issues and claims not involved in other action.
In re Pilepro Antitrust and Patent Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2954; Federal Courts  2956

Although case brought by two companies engaged in processing, handling, distribution and sale of milk against an agricultural cooperative marketing association contained allegations of federal antitrust violations that raised questions of fact common to those in previously transferred actions, its transfer would not serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, particularly in light of facts that case had been pending for over four and one-half years without any motion for transfer and that, not only had pretrial proceedings already been concluded in lead action in transferee district, lead action had been in trial for over two years.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 823 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2954

Transfer of price-fixing antitrust action against sugar refiners to the Northern District of California for inclusion in proceedings pending in that district would not promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation where the eastern defendants refined primarily cane sugar and the western defendants, for the most part, refined beet sugar, only a small amount of refined sugar was shipped from one part of the country to the other, and where plaintiffs' proposal would eliminate the possibility that any party, except refiner which transacted business nationwide, would be subjected to duplicative discovery.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 399 F. Supp. 1397 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, pending actions, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Northern District of Texas was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in seven actions, in multidistrict litigation, involving alleged infringement of patent and licensing rights by defendants' large-scale commercial printers; several accused infringers had operations in or near that district, which provided an easily accessible location, the District was participating in the national Patent Pilot Program, in which the assignee Judge was a participant, and that judge was an experienced jurist who had presided over complex patent litigation and could be counted on to steer the matter on a prudent course.
In re: Indus. Print Technologies, LLC, Patent Litigation, 98 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of six actions pending in multidistrict litigation and arising out of efforts by a pharmaceutical company to enforce patents relating to collection and storage of umbilical cord blood and/or placentas for future therapeutic uses, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Pharmastem Therapeutics, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Motion to transfer action involving patents covering one-piece plastic cable ties to the Northern District of Illinois for pretrial proceedings to be coordinated or consolidated with three related suits pending in that district was denied where, though the actions involved common questions of fact, the transfer would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation in that two of the Illinois actions had been pending for over three years and discovery concerning the common questions of fact was well advanced and where the parties involved in the more advanced actions had demonstrated their ability and willingness voluntarily to cooperate concerning pretrial matters.
In re Cable Tie Patent Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1351 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, pending actions, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in multidistrict litigation involving 13 actions and eight potential tag- along actions relating to whether the defendants' mesh product was defectively designed or manufactured, whether defendants knew or should have known of the alleged propensity of the mesh to result in an allergic or inflammatory response, and whether adequate instructions and warnings were provided; actions involved complex common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Atrium Medical Corp. C-Qur Mesh Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of 102 actions and multiple potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts and alleging that the use of ambulatory pain pumps and/or the anesthetic drugs used in those pumps caused chondrolysis, would, taken as a whole, neither serve the convenience of the parties nor promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation; an indeterminate number of different pain pumps and anesthetics were at issue, individual issues of causation and liability were likely to overwhelm any efficiencies that might be gained by centralization, and the actions were at widely varying procedural stages.
In re Ambulatory Pain Pump-Chondrolysis Products Liability Litigation, 709 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of two actions, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions involving allegations that certain of automobile manufacturer's vehicles were equipped with defective or defectively-installed speed control deactivation switches, was warranted; actions involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Ford Motor Co. Speed Control Deactivation Switch Products Liability Litigation, 543 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Claims presented in 78 actions pending in 33 federal district courts against manufacturers of silicone gel breast implants would be centralized for pretrial proceedings.
In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 1098 (J.P.M.L. 1992).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Pending motions, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Transfer of an otherwise transferable action to a single district for pretrial proceedings is not subject to being delayed because of pendency of a motion to dismiss and of other motions in actions pending in transferee district.
In re New Mexico Natural Gas Antitrust Litigation, 482 F. Supp. 333 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Pendency in one action of motions to dismiss was not persuasive reason to delay transfer of litigation for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings; such motions could be presented to and decided by transferee judge following transfer.
In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel would not postpone decision on question of transfer of action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings until remand motion by plaintiff in that action had been decided, where such action showed a commonality with other actions in the litigation and transferee judge could easily resolve the remand issue.
In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Fact that notice of appeal from order denying motion for preliminary injunction was filed in district from which private civil antitrust action was proposed to be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings did not, where circumstances otherwise warranted transfer, preclude transfer.
In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Stage of pretrial proceedings generally, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was not warranted in seven actions, pending in seven districts, alleging that company which facilitated the transportation of passengers in private vehicles misclassified their transportation providers as independent contractors rather than as employees, failed to provide reimbursement of business expenses, and withheld gratuities; centralization would not serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, particularly since the determination of whether a plaintiff was an employee or independent contractor would rest on state-specific legal and factual inquiries and the actions involved nonoverlapping certified and putative state-specific classes, and denying centralization would keep the actions pending in the states where plaintiffs and the putative class members worked and where relevant witnesses and documents were likely to be found.
In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Creation of new multidistrict litigation docket for centralized pretrial proceedings was not warranted in four actions, pending in two districts, alleging that a manufacturer of automobiles equipped certain diesel engines with software designed to defeat emissions testing; in light of the existence of a previously-ordered multidistrict litigation docket involving manufacturer's parent company and similar allegations, creation of a docket involving only the defendant manufacturer was not necessary to serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Porsche "Clean Diesel" Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict copyright litigation consisting of 20 actions pending in 10 districts, centralization of pretrial proceedings in specified district was not necessary for convenience of the parties and witnesses or to further just and efficient conduct of the litigation; while most actions would involve common factual questions regarding validity of common plaintiff's copyright and proper measure of damages, there was a trend of quick dismissals, as, a little more than two months after filing of centralization motion, more than a third of the actions involved had been resolved, and these actions thus far had not required significant judicial attention, such that centralization would not promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, but, rather, it appeared that alternatives to centralization, such as employing a shared expert and coordinating common deposition, could minimize any overlap in pretrial proceedings.
In re Live Face on Web, LLC, Copyright Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

Class Action Fairness Act's (CAFA) bar to transfer, pursuant to statute governing centralization of cases in multidistrict litigation, of actions removed to federal court as “mass actions,” does not prohibit Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation from ordering centralized pretrial proceedings for actions removed pursuant to CAFA's mass action provision so long as another ground for removal is asserted.
In re Darvocet, Darvon and Propoxyphene Products Liability Litigation, 939 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953; Removal Of Cases  115

Civil rights action instituted in Eastern District of Kentucky and alleging discriminatory employment practices by railroads would not be transferred to Southern District of Ohio for coordination with pending civil rights action raising same allegations even though actions involved common questions of fact and classes certified in Ohio action and class for which certification was sought in Kentucky action overlapped, where pretrial status of two actions was different and transfer would not serve convenience of parties and witnesses.
In re Southern Railway Employment Practices Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Advanced stage in transferee courts, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization, of five actions pending in four districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; four of the actions were at a significantly advanced stage, the fifth action had been stayed pending resolution of two of the other actions, and no remaining and unresolved common questions of fact were sufficiently complex and/or numerous to justify transfer.
In re Allianz Life Ins. Co. of North American Deferred Annuity Marketing and Sales Practice Litigation, 517 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Even though ten additional antitrust actions brought by operators of motion picture theatres against motion picture distributors shared questions of fact on economic and conspiratorial issues with eight other antitrust actions which had been previously consolidated, transfer of those ten actions for consolidation with previously transferred actions was not ordered where discovery in other pretrial proceedings were well advanced and/or parties in those actions expressed lack of interest in national or common discovery existing in previously consolidated actions.
In re Motion Picture Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 479 F. Supp. 581 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

Where all but three of related cases which had been transferred to the Eastern District of Virginia had been settled, where discovery on issue of validity of the patent had been completed in the transferee district, where trial in one of the three remaining cases in the district had been completed and where the transferee court's views on the issue of patent validity were well documented and thus would be available to the judge in the instant case, instant case, which dealt with similar issues, would not be transferred to Eastern District of Virginia.
In re Western Electric Co., Inc. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 404 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2956

Where patent litigation consisted of only three actions in two different districts, at least one action in transferee court was proceeding expeditiously toward trial, and if court in such action held patent invalid estoppel rule could eliminate any need for further discovery or trial concerning the litigant, transfer of action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was inappropriate.
In re Disposable Diaper Patent Validity Litigation, 362 F. Supp. 567 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2956

Concrete pipe private antitrust case pending in District of New Mexico would not be transferred to Central District of California for pretrial proceedings by Judicial Panel, even if claims arose from alleged west of the Rockies conspiracy and some of issues were common to Ninth Circuit cases, where pretrial proceedings were nearly complete in Ninth Circuit cases and transfer of case at that time would not promote just and efficient conduct of actions.
In re Concrete Pipe, 297 F. Supp. 1125 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Advanced stage in transferor courts, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings would neither serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; there were no common questions of fact that were sufficiently complex, unresolved, and/or numerous to justify transfer in which some actions had been pending for years, multiple decisions were on appeal, trial had been held in one action, and issues of state sovereignty would arise.
In re Master Settlement Agreement Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951
