Multidistrict antitrust litigation was not ordered transferred to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where substantial discovery had taken place in most of actions, several actions had been consolidated in their districts, most parties opposed transfer, defendants offered to stipulate that depositions of top management witnesses could be used in each action and parties expressed willingness to cooperate to eliminate duplicative discovery, notwithstanding that actions involved significant common questions of fact regarding alleged corporate policy decisions.
In re Women's Clothing Antitrust Litigation, 455 F. Supp. 1388 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Although five actions pending in five federal districts involving personal injuries resulting from use of intrauterine contraceptive device involved some common questions of fact, where pretrial proceedings had been completed in one action and a discovery cutoff and trial date had been set in another, those two actions should be excluded from transfer; in the three remaining actions common factual issues were not sufficiently complex and accompanying discovery time consuming enough to warrant a transfer for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings.
In re Ortho Pharmaceutical “Lippes Loop” Products Liability Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 1073 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Motion to transfer multidistrict milk antitrust case to Western District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied, since such case had proceeded in Southern District of Texas for over three and one-half years, pretrial activities were either completed or very near completion, and trial was imminent.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 930 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

California action would not be included with Washington and Minnesota actions in transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in connection with antitrust and other claims by former beer distributors against acquired and acquiring brewers, where it appeared that the California action was approaching its final stages.
In re Olympia Brewing Co. Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 398 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Actions arising from explosions caused by accidental detonation of a train of bomb-laden boxcars, brought against maker and owner of bombs, owner of train and railroad yard and maker of boxcars, belonged in a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, even though discovery in one case was at a significantly more advanced stage than in the other actions.
In re Bomb Disaster at Roseville, California, on April 28, 1973, 399 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Where defendant in multidistrict antitrust actions had been dismissed from one action prior to defendant's motion before Judicial Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, case was close to being ready for trial as to another defendant and none of the parties in other actions favored inclusion in coordinated or consolidated proceedings, case was not transferred.
In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

Actions by government against railroad for alleged losses of grain during shipment would not be transferred, with other similar cases, under this section where pretrial proceedings were almost complete and cases were nearly ready for trial.
In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

A multidistrict case in which discovery had been substantially completed and which was close to being ready for trial was not transferred for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings along with the other multidistrict litigation.
In re Protection Devices and Equipment and Central Station Protection Service Antitrust Cases, 295 F. Supp. 39 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Trial commencement, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Securities and Exchange Commission action seeking injunctive relief against parent corporation, one of its subsidiaries and individual officers and directors of those companies for alleged violations of federal securities laws in connection with sales programs of subsidiary would not be transferred for pretrial proceedings with other actions against two subsidiaries for alleged fraud and deceit in violations of state and federal securities laws, where the Commission made no claim concerning business of one of parent's subsidiaries, Commission action was far advanced and, in essence, trial on merits had begun in such action.
In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 355 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Although predicate common question of fact existed in multidistrict litigation and convenience of parties and their witnesses would generally be served by transfer, just and efficient conduct of presently pending actions, including one whose trial was scheduled to begin shortly and the other in which there had already been discovery, would not be promoted by transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings at this time, and Judicial Panel would retain jurisdiction of matter for six months in event additional actions might be commenced.
In re Photocopy Paper, 305 F. Supp. 60 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Trial imminent, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Where actions already transferred to the Eastern District of Virginia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings were all contract actions involving defendant's alleged breach of contracts to supply uranium to utilities, and trial was imminent in such action, common factual issues did not warrant transfer to the same district of other actions involving antitrust suit by the uranium supplier, suit by company that was to have provided uranium to supplier, and two securities suits against the supplier, alleging failure to disclose the long-term uranium supply contracts involved in the actions which had been transferred.
In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Uranium Contract Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 990 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954; Federal Courts  2957

When only a small number of actions are being considered for transfer for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings, immediacy of trial of one of the actions is an additional factor weighing against institution of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Mt. Vernon, Illinois, Times Square Shopping Center Contract Dispute Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 310 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Discovery completion, just and efficient conduct of actions—Generally

para.paratext:
Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) claim in pending action would be severed and transferred for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions alleging failure to perform due diligence prior to investments of funds; claim involved common questions of fact with the other actions, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Rye Select Broad Market Prime Fund Securities & Employee Retirement Income Sec. Act (ERISA) Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1385 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2953

Although two actions to obtain royalty interests assertedly due on sale of Ecuadorian oil interests involved common questions of fact, transfer for centralized pretrial proceedings was inappropriate, where the actions had each been pending for almost three and one-half years and extensive document discovery was virtually complete, where movants failed to show that remaining common factual questions were sufficiently complex as to justify transfer, and where suitable alternatives to transfer were still available to the parties.
In re Ecuadorian Oil Concession Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1364 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions arising out of explosion and fire on offshore oil well platform would not be transferred to Southern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where plaintiffs in actions in Western District of Louisiana contended that their discovery was virtually complete and they would not benefit from such a transfer and none of plaintiffs in actions in Southern District of Texas claimed that transfer would be beneficial to them and bulk of remaining discovery related primarily to intradefendant litigation all of which was pending in Southern District of Texas.
In re Galveston, Texas Oil Well Platform Disaster, 322 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, discovery completion, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
A motion to transfer for consolidated pretrial proceedings four actions challenging defendants' franchising program as violative of federal antitrust and securities laws would be denied, since the relevant discovery in two of the four actions was substantially completed, there was no possibility of duplicative discovery with regard to remaining actions, counsel for defendants had agreed to binding stipulation that all discovery in any of the actions could be used in other actions as if taken in those actions, and consultation and cooperation among concerned district courts, coupled with continued cooperation of parties, would minimize possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings.
In re McDonald's Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 111 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954; Federal Courts  2957

Fact that discovery procedures had been largely completed in one of six antitrust actions brought by various classes of bakery product purchasers did not preclude transfer of the six cases to a single court for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings since procedures were available whereby any discovery completed in the one case could be made available to all interested parties in all actions.
In re South Cent. States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1127 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, discovery completion, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Plaintiffs' several infringement actions, subsequent to action in which certain claims were held invalid, would not be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where discovery in one action was complete and trial was imminent and it appeared that decision in that case might obviate need for further discovery.
In re Bourns Patent Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1260 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, discovery completion, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in 19 actions and 18 potential tag-along actions alleging injury resulting from ingestion of a prescription medication used in the treatment of osteoporosis; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Fosamax Products Liability Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Where reopened common discovery proceedings in Dalkon Shield actions that had been transferred to district of Kansas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings were just about complete, transfer of additional Dalkon Shield cases would not serve convenience of the parties or just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and motions for transfer and retransfer were accordingly denied.
In re A.H. Robins Co., Inc. Dalkon Shield IUD Products Liability Litigation, 570 F. Supp. 1480 (J.P.M.L. 1983).
Federal Courts  3973

Alabama action, although it shared common factual questions with other actions, would not be included in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where discovery in that action had apparently been completed.
In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability Litigation, 68 F.R.D. 502 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, discovery completion, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization was not necessary to serve convenience of parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of securities and derivative litigation, although three securities actions consolidated in Southern District of New York and two derivative actions pending in Eastern District of New York shared some factual questions arising from defendants' alleged conduct, where actions were pending in adjacent districts and involved only small number of counsel and judges, and alternatives to transfer were available to minimize potential for duplicative discovery and inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Forcefield Energy, Inc., Securities and Derivative Litigation, 154 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).

Completion of discovery and pretrial proceedings in California action involving various alleged securities violations by defendants operated to preclude transfer of New York securities action involving same defendants to Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where suitable alternatives were available in that parties could ask judge supervising New York action to issue an order to show cause why discovery already completed in California action should not be made applicable to New York action or parties could simply stipulate that completed discovery could be used in New York action.
In re Raymond Lee Organization, Inc. Securities Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 1266 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2957

Notwithstanding existence of common questions of fact, motions to transfer class action, filed in California on behalf of certain holders of $40 common stock purchase warrants of defendant corporation against corporation and two of its former directors and officers for alleged violation of federal security laws and breach of fiduciary duty, to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with three similar actions pending there would be denied where, in contrast to New York actions wherein discovery was not estimated to be completed for several months, discovery was completed and trial imminent in California case, no possibility of duplicative discovery was envisioned, and transfer would accordingly not serve convenience of parties or witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re American Financial Corp. Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1232 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

Where discovery and all pretrial proceedings in securities case were complete, trial of action was imminent, and question of whether plaintiff's claims concerning certain securities were barred by final judgment in separate class action, which defendants claimed should be determined by transferee judge, had been determined adversely to defendants by transferor judge while motion to transfer was pending, there was no basis for transfer.

head.headtext: Duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions—Generally

para.paratext:
Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning plaintiff's financial condition and its 2003 insolvency; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Parmalat Securities Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

In re Progressive Corp. Ins. Underwriting & Rating Practices Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of 14 putative class actions was warranted, in multidistrict litigation alleging that energy company failed to disclose existence of deceptive energy trading practices; centralization served convenience of parties and witnesses and promoted just and efficient conduct of litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to questions of class certification), and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Allegheny Energy, Inc., Securities Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Suitable alternatives available to plaintiffs to avoid any duplication of discovery concerning common issues together with plaintiffs' apparent attempted misuse of § 1404 of this title required denial of plaintiffs' motion to transfer Texas actions to Western District of Oklahoma for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions pending there.
In re Truck Acc. Near Alamagordo, New Mexico, on June 18, 1969, 387 F. Supp. 732 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of multidistrict litigation to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings may be ordered where it is necessary to avoid needless duplication of discovery and to promote the just and efficient conduct of litigation as well as to preclude possibility of inconsistent pretrial decisions by courts of coordinate jurisdiction.
In re Caesar's Palace Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1256 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Because all actions in multidistrict litigation clearly raised common factual issues, transfer for coordinated or consolidated trial proceedings was necessary in order to avoid duplication of discovery, and would also eliminate the possibility of inconsistent class terminations.
In re Sta-Power Industries Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1398 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Claims against New York firm involving facts already involved in coordinated or consolidated proceedings would be transferred to the District of Columbia in order to avoid duplication of discovery and unnecessary inconvenience to the parties and witnesses.
In re National Student Marketing Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 1303 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

Where plaintiff, who successfully resisted transfer on claim that his action was based on different theory than other actions transferred and consolidated, sought discovery which was duplicative of discovery sought in transferred cases, case would be transferred for pretrial proceedings.
In re Four Seasons Securities Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Voluntary avoidance by parties, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization, of three actions and one related action, pending in four districts, involving challenges to the rates and fees charged by a provider of electronic communications services for the provision of local and long distance inmate calling services to various correctional institutions and detention facilities, would neither serve convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further just and efficient conduct of the litigation; although the actions shared factual questions and stemmed from the same Federal Communications Commission proceedings, only a minimal number of actions were involved and circumstances indicated that voluntary coordination was a practicable and preferable alternative to centralization, particularly since plaintiffs were represented by just two groups of counsel and the sole defendant and its subsidiaries, which were represented by common counsel in all the actions, had a track record of successfully coordinating the litigation, and the plaintiffs in one action represented that they would consent to transfer of their action to the same district in which one of the other actions was already pending, resulting in only two districts having actions with claims pending against defendants.
In re Global Tel*Link Corporation Inmate Calling Services Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1338 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

While attempts at voluntary cooperation among parties and their counsel concerning discovery efforts are always laudable, possibility of such cooperation is no bar to transfer of an action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings especially where transfer will insure the streamlining of discovery and all other pretrial proceedings in the litigation as a whole.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation (East Coast), 471 F. Supp. 1089 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Though voluntary coordination among parties as a means of avoiding duplicative discovery is commendable, if actions under considerations are otherwise appropriate for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation prefers to place the actions under the control of a single judge in order to ensure that the objectives of this section are met.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Inclusion of action in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, in product liability actions arising out of airplane crashes, was no longer necessary to achieve just and efficient conduct of the litigation, even though the action shared factual issues with the previously centralized actions, where all common discovery had been completed in the transferee district and the transferee judge had issued many substantive rulings that would help shape the litigation of individual remaining cases.
In re: Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of five actions, pending in two districts, concerning the cause of the crash of a sightseeing helicopter, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Meadview, Ariz., on Aug. 10, 2001, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Because factual questions in each of four actions pending in four districts focused on what caused airplane accident, it was likely that various defendants would be involved with discovery in each action either as parties or nonparties, and thus transfer under this section governing multidistrict litigation was necessary in order to avoid duplicative discovery conducted by plaintiff and others, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, conserve judicial resources and ensure cooperation of all parties and counsel.
In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict actions arising from helicopter crash on oil production platform in Gulf of Mexico would be transferred to western district of Louisiana for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with similar actions pending there where there were common questions of fact among actions concerning cause or causes of accident and liability of various defendants and transfer was necessary to prevent duplicative discovery, eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings and conserve time and efforts of parties and judiciary.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Marsh Island, La., on December 8, 1977, 461 F. Supp. 675 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict civil actions involving the air crash disaster at Huntington, West Virginia, on November 14, 1970 were consolidated and transferred to the Southern District of West Virginia, notwithstanding contentions that only two actions were pending as result of the disaster, where six of the ten actions commenced following crash had not been dismissed, although allegedly settled, there was risk of duplication of effort in the three remaining actions, notwithstanding they were brought by the same plaintiff, and questions of fact common to all ten actions concerning cause of crash made them appropriate for pretrial assignment to a single judge.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Huntington, W. Va. on November 14, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted for fifteen actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix or maintain prices on international passenger air travel to or from the United States; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Intern. Air Transp. Surcharge Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of six actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in three districts and alleging conspiracy to fix the price of international shipments of liquid chemicals in the United States, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact relating to the existence, scope and effect of the alleged conspiracy, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Parcel Tanker Shipping Services Antitrust Litigation, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation on behalf of overlapping putative classes and alleging that one or more of defendant insurance company's entities violated notification and disclosure requirements of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) in their use of consumer reports for the qualification, underwriting and rate-setting processes for certain policies of insurance; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, particularly with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Farmers Insurance Co., Inc., Insurance Premiums Litigation, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of six actions and one potential tag-along action alleging violations of federal antitrust laws with respect to medical waste services in four states, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and could be expected to focus on a significant number of common events, transactions, defendants, and witnesses, and centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Medical Waste Services Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Motion to transfer antitrust actions was denied by the Judicial Panel in view of progress already made in two districts, in view of alternatives available to minimize possibility of duplicative discovery and failure of movants to show that a transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Chiropractic Antitrust Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 811 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict milk antitrust cases would be transferred to Western District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated proceedings, in view of fact that such actions shared questions of fact with actions pending in such district, so that transfer of actions was necessary to prevent needlessly duplicative discovery.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 930 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Where private antitrust actions raised common questions of fact concerning existence, scope and effect of alleged conspiracy transfer was necessary to prevent duplication of discovery, eliminate possibility of inconsistent pretrial rulings, and streamline rest of pretrial proceedings as well, and centralization was especially important to insure consistent treatment of class action issues.
In re Hawaiian Hotel Room Rate Antitrust Litigation, 438 F. Supp. 935 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict antitrust actions, questions concerning the existence, scope and effect of alleged conspiracy among several defendants necessitate transfer in order to prevent duplicative discovery, eliminate the possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings and streamline the remainder of the pretrial proceedings.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

In order to minimize duplication of pretrial proceedings, claims of plaintiffs, who alleged that defendants had violated federal antitrust laws by combining to monopolize and restrain trade in sugar and by adopting and utilizing pricing structure that resulted in unlawful price discrimination, against one defendant, which transacted business primarily in eastern United States and which was not named as defendant in litigation currently pending in California but was so named in Pennsylvania litigation, were severed and transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for inclusion with similar antitrust action involving sugar industry.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Inasmuch as counterclaim of milk buyer, sued for milk sold and delivered, alleged antitrust law violations similar to allegations made against the same milk marketing cooperatives in actions previously transferred to the Western District of Missouri, transfer of the counterclaim was necessary to avoid duplication of discovery on economic and conspiratorial issues.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict securities antitrust cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Northern District of California in order to avoid duplication of discovery and eliminate possibility of inconsistent class determinations in that litigation clearly raised common factual issues and contained similar class allegations.
In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 806 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Transfer, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, of one of two actions brought in separate districts against oil company for alleged violation of antitrust laws by fixing retail prices and by requiring dealers to sell only products approved by the oil company was necessary to avoid duplication of discovery and eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings in view of complexity of factual issues presented and presence of competing requests for class designation.
In re Clark Oil & Refining Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 458 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2954

Where antitrust action involved same relevant market as was basically involved in consolidated cases pending in another district for pretrial proceedings and absent transfer there would be duplicitous discovery, Judicial Panel would transfer case for centralized management of pretrial proceedings.
In re IBM Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 200 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Insurance actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of farmers' actions alleging that federal officials unlawfully and unilaterally imposed modifications to multiple peril crop insurance policy was warranted, despite statutory provision requiring that actions on crop insurance claims be brought only in district court for district in which insured farm was located, where centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re Peanut Crop Ins. Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Where transfer and consolidation of action brought by insured against insurance adjusting firm with actions brought by other adjusters against the firm would prevent needless duplication of discovery which, in turn, would avoid unnecessary inconvenience to parties and witnesses, case would be transferred and consolidated, even though instant action might also involve unique discovery issues, particularly with regard to damage issue.
In re General Adjustment Bureau Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Negligence actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Action pending in District of Columbia against owners of inn where Bronx junior high school student drowned while on a field trip would not be transferred to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in action against city, board of education and company which arranged the tour inasmuch as only two relatively simple negligence actions were involved and plaintiff could take other measures to avoid unnecessary duplication of discovery.
In re Drowning Incident at Quality Inn Northeast, Washington, D. C., on May 3, 1974, 405 F. Supp. 1304 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of four patent infringement actions dealing with validity of two complex pharmaceutical patents was appropriate; centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Metoprolol Succinate Patent Litigation, 329 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Michigan patent infringement action would not be transferred to District of Massachusetts for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with pending action for judgment declaring patent invalid, where Massachusetts action involved other patents, claims and counterclaims while Michigan action focused solely on infringement and validity, there was little likelihood that any common discovery would be duplicated if transfer were denied, and, if either court found patent invalid, estoppel rule would eliminate need for further discovery or trial relating to validity issue.
In re Shipley Co., Inc. Patent Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 847 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in multidistrict litigation involving 13 actions and eight potential tag- along actions relating to whether the defendants' mesh product was defectively designed or manufactured, whether defendants knew or should have known of the alleged propensity of the mesh to result in an allergic or inflammatory response, and whether adequate instructions and warnings were provided; actions involved complex common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Atrium Medical Corp. C-Qur Mesh Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 33 actions, pending in 16 districts, alleging that defendants' chemotherapy drug caused permanent hair loss, that they were aware of that possible side effect but failed to warn patients, and that they marketed the drug as more effective than other chemotherapy drugs when other drugs were equally effective without the associated permanent hair loss; the actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings. and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Taxotere (Docetaxel) Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

In litigation consisting of 13 actions pending in eight districts, stemming from recall of pet food products allegedly tainted by melamine found in wheat gluten imported from China and used in pet food products, centralization in the District Court for the District of New Jersey, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was warranted, where centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, avoid inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary, and pretrial proceedings were advancing well in the District of New Jersey and about one-third of all pending actions were already there.
In re Pet Food Products Liability Litigation, 499 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging tax preparer's breach of fiduciary duties to its clientele in connection with the marketing and sale of an investment product; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to issue of class certification), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re H & R Block, Inc., Express IRA Marketing Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of five overlapping putative class actions brought on behalf of purchasers of gasoline that contained high levels of sulfur was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary; centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation since the actions shared claims of negligence and products liability arising from the affected fuel, which led to the suspension of gas sales at certain service stations and allegedly caused damage to the fuel gauges of purchasers' vehicles.
In re High Sulfur Content Gasoline Products Liability Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 2d 755 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of 14 actions and approximately 200 potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that manufacturers of ephedra-containing products knew of and concealed, misrepresented, or failed to warn of side-effects; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Ephedra Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of product liability actions brought by various motor vehicle owners and operators against automobile manufacturer was warranted in order to permit coordinated pretrial proceedings, based on existence of common questions of fact and consequent likelihood of duplication of discovery and inconsistent or repetitive pretrial rulings; even though cases were to be transferred to court that was handling other actions brought by counties, municipalities, and other political subdivisions, all actions focused on allegations that vertical behind-axle fuel tank in particular model resulted in increased risk of injury or death from fuel-fed fire in event of rear-end collision.
In re Ford Motor Co. Crown Victoria Police Interceptor Products Liability Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Fourteen actions involving mortar additive and manufacturer's knowledge of allegedly injurious effects of mortar additive brought by plaintiffs claiming that manufacturer's conduct violated federal racketeering laws, and which made claims under various common-law theories including negligence, breach of warranty, and strict liability, would be centralized in District of Colorado in order to avoid duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, conserve resources of parties, their counsel and the judiciary, except New York action which had been pending for over three years and was sufficiently advanced in stage to warrant its exclusion from centralization proceeding.
In re Dow Chemical Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 650 F. Supp. 187 (J.P.M.L. 1986).
Federal Courts  2953

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would transfer multidistrict actions for injuries or deaths allegedly resulting from, among other causes, failure and separation of multipiece truck wheels to most appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings, to prevent duplication of discovery and eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings as to common factual issues concerning the overall design of multipiece rims, the state of knowledge within industry of risks involved in use of multipiece rims, and the alleged failure of defendants to warn adequately of risks.
In re Multi-Piece Rim Products Liability Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 969 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Railroad accident actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of pretrial proceedings was warranted with respect to 19 nineteen actions pending in District of New Jersey, Eastern and Southern Districts of New York, and Eastern District of Pennsylvania in connection with claims for personal injury or wrongful death arising from derailment of Amtrak train; Amtrak conceded liability for compensatory damages but not for punitive damages sought by most plaintiffs, and thus common discovery relating to derailment likely would be necessary and duplication thereof would be avoided by centralization, which would also prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings and conserve resources of parties, counsel and judiciary.
In re: Amtrak Train Derailment In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, On May 12, 2015, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1347 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Nineteen actions pending in six federal district courts, arising out of collision between passenger train and three locomotives in Maryland, in which 16 persons were killed and approximately two hundred others injured, involved common questions of fact, making centralization necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve judicial resources of parties, counsel and judiciary, and most appropriate transferee forum was district of Maryland wherein collision occurred, pertinent witnesses and documents were located and which was centrally located for many parties and witnesses.
In re Rail Collision Near Chase, Md. on Jan. 4, 1987, 661 F. Supp. 69 (J.P.M.L. 1987).
Federal Courts  2953

Where four actions arising from passenger train derailment in Tennessee were pending in the Middle District of Tennessee and one in the Northern District of Illinois, latter would be transferred to Tennessee for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to prevent duplicative discovery and eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings, though many of the documents and witnesses relevant to damages aspect of Illinois plaintiff's action were located in Illinois.
In re Amtrak Train Derailment at Frankewing, Tenn., on October 1, 1975, 431 F. Supp. 916 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in five actions and one potential tag-along action in multidistrict litigation, alleging that company misrepresented its financial condition to the public, engaged in improper accounting practices, or both, causing plaintiffs and others to purchase company's stock at artificially inflated prices; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re CP Ships Ltd. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation involving 14 actions and 3 potential tag-along actions seeking relief under federal securities laws or as shareholders suing derivatively, on basis of alleged artificial inflation of price of company's securities; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary, and transfer to a single judge would have streamlining effect.
In re Fleming Companies Inc. Securities and Derivative Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2957

Seventeen securities law actions pending in two different districts, all of which were rooted in allegations of misrepresentations or omissions of material facts during public offering of securities, would be centralized in single district in order to avoid duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re Computervision Corp. Securities Litigation, 814 F. Supp. 85 (J.P.M.L. 1993).
Federal Courts  2957

With respect to individuals who purchased collapsed corporation's securities before trading was suspended and who filed actions against brokers and representatives alleging violations of securities laws those actions necessarily involved the primary fraud and in order to eliminate possibility of duplicated discovery and inconvenience to parties and witnesses these actions should be transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings; if separate treatment was warranted the plaintiffs might address arguments to transferee judge who could fashion pretrial program to suit needs of these plaintiffs.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Judicial Panel would transfer action for consolidation with other actions against various defendants for alleged violations of securities laws where alleged fraud and misrepresentations arose out of virtually same documents, where both groups of plaintiffs would be seeking same documentary evidence and deposing many of the same witnesses, where attempts to voluntarily coordinate discovery had failed and where transfer would eliminate possibility of conflicting rulings regarding confidentiality of trade secrets and auditing techniques.
In re Boise Cascade Securities Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 459 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Where initial question, in action brought by principal alleging that broker had violated federal securities laws, could be effect of class settlement in 19 actions already transferred to Oklahoma for coordinated pretrial proceedings and, if plaintiff was determined to be outside of settlement for any reason, pretrial discovery which plaintiff would require would be largely common to transferred actions, such action would be transferred to Oklahoma, even though defendant was not a defendant in the multidistrict cases already transferred and defendant opposed transfer on ground that it had completed discovery and was ready for trial.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 964 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Action pending in Southern District of Ohio and involving related claims of securities laws violations against the same principal defendants would, on the motion of one defendant, be transferred to District of Colorado for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings being conducted there, since, despite one plaintiff's opposition, it appeared that transfer was necessary to avoid duplication in discovery, unnecessary inconvenience to the parties and their witnesses, and the possibility of inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 975 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

Six actions arising out of public sale of common stock to finance purchase of department store business were ordered transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings where all plaintiffs alleged that registration statement and prospectus contained material misstatements and omissions, five of six individual plaintiffs represented variously defined classes of stockholders, claims involving corporation submitting exchange offer would involve review of many of the same documents and witnesses involved in claims against issuing corporation and corporation operating business to be sold and majority of remaining defendants were located in the Southern District and transactions under attack occurred in that district.
In re Atlantic Dept. Stores, Inc., Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 971 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, duplicative discovery, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization was warranted for convenience of parties and witnesses and to promote just and efficient conduct of actions regarding Office of Personnel Management (OPM) data security breach, which were pending in Districts of District of Columbia, Northern District of California, and District of Kansas; actions shared factual issues concerning cybersecurity incidents involving OPM in which personally identifiable information of millions of federal government employees, contractors, and others was compromised, centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings on class certification and other issues, and conserve resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re: U.S. Office of Personnel Management Data Security Breach Litigation, 138 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2951

Eight of 11 multi-state class actions involving common questions of fact as to tobacco companies' allegedly deceptive marketing and sales practices for light cigarettes, and/or manipulation of design of cigarettes to deliver more tar and nicotine when smoked than when tested by government, warranted centralization of pretrial proceedings in District of Maine where earliest filed and most advanced action was pending, in order to serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, since centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re: Light Cigarettes Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in 13 actions and five potential tag-along actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging failure by investment fund managers to perform adequate due diligence before investing fund assets in an investment firm; actions involved complex common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Tremont Group Holdings, Inc., Securities Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1338 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in 35 actions pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or omissions relating to a company's improper accounting practices; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Peregrine Systems, Inc., Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in ten actions and three potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts and arising out of a company's collapse; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and it was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Refco Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 14 actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in nine districts and arising out of defendants' manufacture and/or distribution of toys alleged to contain elevated levels of lead in their surface paint; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re RC2 Corp. Toy Lead Paint Products Liability Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of nationwide products liability actions was warranted in Northern District of Georgia, where eleven actions had been filed in eight districts alleging injuries resulting from use grout sealer, additional related actions were likely to be filed, centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary, and two of five corporate defendants had their principal places of business in district.
In re Stand 'n Seal Products, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in three actions, pending in multidistrict litigation and seeking reimbursement of the communications excise tax on certain long-distance telephone service; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Long-Distance Telephone Service Federal Excise Tax Refund Litigation, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of actions challenging defendants' alleged improper marketing of estate or financial planning services to senior citizens solely to obtain financial information in order to target prospective purchasers of deferred annuities was appropriate; centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re American Investors Life Ins. Co. Annuity Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Discovery impairment, just and efficient conduct of actions

para.paratext:
Transfers of two actions, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions alleging predatory lending practices, by mortgage company or a related entity, in soliciting and closing residential mortgage transactions, would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; actions alleged individual claims based on specific loan transactions which would likely require unique discovery and other pretrial proceedings.
In re Ameriquest Mortg. Co. Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Two multidistrict computer industry monopoly cases would not be transferred to District of Minnesota for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where scope and breadth of discovery were likely to be substantially different.
In re IBM Antitrust Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 509 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict actions alleging antitrust and common law violations arising from computer manufacturer's marketing of typewriter and magnetic tape composition device were not ordered transferred to district in which actions alleging similar violations arising from separate package marketing of computer hardware, software and related services were pending where it was admitted that discovery in pending actions would be seriously impaired and no question was raised concerning manufacturer's alleged tie-in of computer software with the computer hardware sales.
In re IBM, 316 F. Supp. 976 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: COMMONALITY OF ACTIONS
Claims and counterclaims, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Amended counterclaim asserting claims similar to those asserted by plaintiffs in other actions transferred to district court was properly transferred to district court under this section.
In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 67 F.R.D. 57 (W.D. Mo. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Action commenced in Mississippi district court by sugar seller charging buyer with breach of contract, in which buyer filed two counterclaims under state antitrust law and one counterclaim charging price-fixing under Sherman Act, sections 1–7 of this title, was ordered transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, with actions pending in the latter district charging conspiracies under Sherman Act, sections 1–7 of this title, to fix sugar prices in Eastern United States since antitrust and contract claims were intertwined with conspiracy allegations and class sought to be represented in one state antitrust claim was at least partially encompassed within class certified in litigation pending in the Eastern District.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation (East Coast), 471 F. Supp. 1089 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust counterclaim filed in declaratory judgment action brought by a mining company which sought a declaration that it had fulfilled all of its agreements under a contract would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with four antitrust actions which involved similar claims of monopolization of the sale of uranium despite contentions by the counterclaimant and by other parties involved in the pending actions that the counterclaim was essentially only one part of a complex contractual dispute which would turn upon state law rather than on federal antitrust law.
In re Uranium Industry Antitrust Litigation, 466 F. Supp. 958 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

Where eight of nine private actions arising out of corporation's disclosure that some of its financial statements were erroneous were pending in Northern District of Illinois, where complaints in all nine private actions made same basic allegations, that action pending in California District would be transferred to Northern District of Illinois for pretrial, despite fact that California action involved some unique factual issues and California District Court expressed its willingness to monitor discovery and to take all steps necessary to avoid duplication or conflict between that action and the Illinois actions.
In re Cenco Inc. Securities Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1237 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Where only one of the four actions against common employer and various local and international unions centered on systemwide issues regarding collective bargaining contract while the other actions chiefly involved allegations of discriminatory discharges of named plaintiffs only, consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings would not necessarily serve the overall convenience of parties and witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of litigation and motion for transfer was denied; and additional ground for denial was that considerable discovery had been accomplished in one action and trial date had been set in another.
In re Braniff Airways, Inc. Employment Practices Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 798 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

Action in Colorado against defendant corporation, alleging that defendant conspired with others to unreasonably restrain trade in sale of bakery flour in violation of the federal antitrust laws, would be transferred to the Western District of Washington where, in a complaint filed in the transferee district, defendant corporation was also charged with participating in the same alleged conspiracy, where complaint in Colorado action was almost identical to complaint filed in transferee district, and where defendant failed to advance any argument to persuade the Panel that the statutory criteria for transfer had not been satisfied.
In re West Coast Bakery Flour Antitrust Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 842 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Where main thrust of copyright infringement actions went to the issue of whether copyright protection extended to the various types of alleged exploitation and where marketing of items which allegedly infringed the copyright occurred at different levels and the nature and degree of use of the allegedly infringed cartoon character varied widely, fact that all of the actions included generalized allegations of the use of the same cartoon character was insufficient to warrant transfer of all the actions to the same district.
In re “Truckin" Cartoon Characters Copyright Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

Since actions relating to trading, underwriting and rescission claim arising out of collapse of financial services corporation were actuated by the alleged primary or underlying fraud which actuated entire litigation and to some extent conditioned the rights of various plaintiffs to recover in all of the action, the trading, underwriting and rescission claim actions would be consolidated with the primary fraud actions for purpose of pretrial proceeding.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Facts, commonality of actions—Generally

para.paratext:
Transfer of cases for centralized proceedings in multidistrict litigation does not require a complete identity or even a majority of common factual or legal issues as a prerequisite to transfer.
In re: Gadolinium Contrast Dyes Products Liability Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Statute governing transfer of actions pending in multidistrict litigation, for centralized pretrial proceedings, does not require a complete identity or even majority of common factual issues as a prerequisite to transfer.
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

The mere showing of common questions of fact between action sought to be transferred and action pending in transferee district is not sufficient, in and of itself, to warrant transfer by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation.
In re Cessna Aircraft Distributorship Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 159 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

The existence of common questions of fact between actions is but one condition precedent to transfer under this section.
In re Drowning Incident at Quality Inn Northeast, Washington, D. C., on May 3, 1974, 405 F. Supp. 1304 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of action to another district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with an action pending there is not dependent on a strict identity of issues and parties but rather on the existence of one or more common questions of fact.
In re Japanese Electronic Products Antitrust Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 565 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

A mere showing that common questions of fact exist amongst actions for which treatment under this section is proposed is not sufficient, in and of itself, to warrant transfer by Judicial Panel.
In re Truck Acc. Near Alamagordo, New Mexico, on June 18, 1969, 387 F. Supp. 732 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Existence of common questions of fact among civil actions pending in different districts is the initial criterion which must be satisfied before any such actions may be transferred under this section relating to coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings for multidistrict litigation.
In re Photocopy Paper, 305 F. Supp. 60 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Existence of one or more common questions of fact is statutory predicate for transfer of cases to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

This section is not operative only where there is multidistrict litigation involving common plaintiffs or defendants; the initial criteria is whether litigation involves one or more common questions of fact.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport on November 20, 1967, 298 F. Supp. 353 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Complexity of facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of litigation was warranted in 10 putative class actions and seven potential tag-along actions, which were pending in nine districts, against ride-sharing company, all of which arose from company's announcement that certain personal information of 57 million drivers and riders was inappropriately downloaded by individuals outside the company; the actions shared complex factual questions arising from company's announcement of the data security breach of its network, and common factual questions were presented with respect to company's practices in safeguarding users' personal information, the investigation into the breach, the alleged delay in disclosing the breach, and the nature of the alleged damages.
In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Data Security Breach Litigation, 304 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of 13 pending Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) actions involving federal agencies' interpretation and implementation of executive order that restricted refugee admissions and entry of aliens from specified countries was not warranted, notwithstanding the potential for litigation cost savings, where the actions arguably shared a limited number of factual issues and there was little likelihood of complex pretrial proceedings.
In re American Civil Liberties Union Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Requests Regarding Executive Order 13769, 261 F. Supp. 3d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was not warranted in six actions, pending in five districts, alleging that a sperm bank failed to properly screen one of its donors and misrepresented that donor's qualities and characteristics to plaintiffs, each of whom conceived children through artificial insemination using that donor's sperm; centralization was not necessary for the convenience of the parties and witnesses or to further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, since although the actions shared some common factual questions, those questions were not particularly complex and did not predominate over the plaintiff- specific factual and legal questions presented in the actions.
In re Xytex Corporation Sperm Donor Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of three actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in three districts, arising out of allegations that the labels on defendant's oatmeal cereals misled consumers into believing that the cereals were made with actual maple syrup or maple sugar, was not necessary to serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of the litigation; although the actions shared some factual questions, those questions were neither sufficiently complex nor numerous to justify centralization.
In re Quaker Oats Maple & Brown Sugar Instant Oatmeal Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1349 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in nine actions, pending in eight districts, alleging that manufacturer of a prescription medication for the treatment of breast cancer breached its warranties; the actions involved common complex questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Genentech Herceptin (trastuzumab) Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of three actions involving pro se litigants was not warranted, and thus litigants' motion to centralize actions in multidistrict litigation (MDL) in Central District of California would be denied; actions shared no common questions of fact, and indeed, only commonality among actions was litigants' participation, questions presented in actions were not sufficiently complex or numerous to warrant centralization, and centralization in district far from Districts of Maryland and District of Columbia would not enhance convenience of parties and witnesses or just and efficient conduct of actions.
In re: Kissi, 923 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial purposes, of two actions, pending in two districts, was not warranted where any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex and/or numerous to justify transfer; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Best Buy Co., Inc., Restocking Fee Sales Practices Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of three actions pending in three districts, was not warranted; centralization would not necessarily serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of the litigation, since any common questions of fact were not sufficiently complex and/or numerous to justify transfer, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re: Circuit City Stores, Inc., Restocking Fee Sales Practices Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of three actions pending in three districts was not warranted in light of the absence of any common questions of fact and law sufficiently complex and/or numerous to justify transfer; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Edward D. Jones & Co., Overtime Pay Litigation, 442 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of seven actions involving brokered group health plans was not warranted absent showing that any common questions of fact and law were sufficiently complex and/or numerous; two constituent actions with most commonality, brought respectively by employer and its employees, were already pending in same district.
In re Pullen & Associates, LLC, Brokered Group Health Plans Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of five actions pending in three districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Solaia Technology LLC Patent & Antitrust Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of six actions, pending in six districts in multidistrict litigation, was not warranted; centralization of the actions would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as no common questions of fact and law in the docket were sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer.
In re Soc. of Lloyd's Judgment Enforcement Litigation, 321 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings of six actions in multidistrict litigation against alleged promoters, financiers, sponsors, and supporters of September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks was warranted; all actions presented common, complex legal and factual questions, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re Terrorist Attacks on September 11, 2001, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of multidistrict litigation against cable television service provider was not warranted; only two actions were pending, and there was no showing that common fact questions were sufficiently complex, or that accompanying discovery would be so time-consuming, as to justify centralization.
In re AT & T Broadband Telecommunication Services Litigation, 237 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of two actions in different judicial districts was not warranted, since movant failed to show that any common questions of fact and law were sufficiently complex, unresolved, or numerous, and there were alternatives to transfer that could minimize whatever possibilities there might have been of duplicative discovery or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re W.E. Hall Co., Inc., Patent Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

In view of common complex factual questions and strong likelihood that discovery concerning such questions would be both complicated and time-consuming present transfer under multidistrict litigation provisions of this section would be appropriate even though only three actions were presently involved, and any related actions that might be filed would be treated as tag-along actions.
In re Amoxicillin Patent and Antitrust Litigation, 449 F. Supp. 601 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2951

Although actions brought by plaintiff pharmaceutical company against defendant pharmaceutical company wherein plaintiff charged that defendant's patents on pharmaceutical substances were invalid and unenforceable and that plaintiff's antibiotic did not infringe upon them did involve common questions of fact, movants did not meet their burden of convincing court that those common factual questions were sufficiently complex or that accompanying discovery would be so time consuming as to justify transfer.
In re Eli Lilly & Co. (Cephalexin Monohydrate) Patent Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 242 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2956

In patent infringement litigation consisting of actions, in three districts, in which patent owner sought transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, it was not shown that the common factual questions were sufficiently complex or that accompanying discovery would be so time consuming as to justify transfer, particularly in light of suitable alternatives in order to minimize possibility of duplicative discovery.
In re Wyeth Patent Infringement Litigation, 445 F. Supp. 992 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2956

Where, inter alia, any common factual questions that might exist in two pending sex discrimination actions against same employer were not complex enough or accompanying discovery sufficiently time-consuming to justify transfer of one action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with the other action, and it appeared that actions might raise different factual issues, and in view of fact that plaintiffs in both actions were represented by same counsel so that measures could be taken to avoid unnecessary duplication if and when commonality arose, insufficient basis for transfer existed.
In re Pan American World Airways, Inc. Maternity Leave Policies Litigation, 414 F. Supp. 1232 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953
