Analysis of pleading in former distributor's action against truck manufacturer along with the papers presented by parties disclosed that such action was a simple contract action capable of prompt resolution with should not be tangled in the complex antitrust matters previously transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings including distributor's antitrust action against truck manufacturer, so that even though the actions gave rise to some common factual nexus the subsequent action would not be transferred.
In re Mack Trucks, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Where complaints in actions brought by two states against major oil companies were substantially similar and raised extremely complex factual issues involving structure and business practices of petroleum industry, where 12 major oil companies were defendants in both actions, and where supervision by single judge would eliminate possibility of duplicative discovery and inconsistent pretrial rulings, cases would be transferred even though there were defendants and state law allegations unique to each action.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1091 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Persuasive reasons for ordering transfer for consolidated pretrial procedures existed even though only a limited number of actions were involved in litigation, where factual allegations in all actions were inextricably intertwined and raised sufficiently complex common issues concerning design and construction of road project and discovery of common underlying facts would involve complex engineering and scientific data as well as financial records and other documents of defendants.
In re Peruvian Road Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Motion by common defendant franchisee, in actions which were brought in Northern District of California and in Southern District of Florida, in which breaches of franchise contract and infringement of service mark were alleged and in which franchisee counterclaimed, alleging fraud in sale of franchises, invalidity of mark and violation of federal antitrust laws, for transfer of Florida action to California for pretrial proceedings would be denied, in that common questions of fact did not appear to be sufficiently complex to require transfer.
In re Homemakers Franchise Litigation, 337 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict litigation resulting from corporate merger was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, where action involved numerous, substantial and complex questions of fact common to most, if not all, of actions involved in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings then being conducted in New York, it did not appear that defendant would be seriously inconvenienced by transfer and it appeared that the other defendants would be seriously inconvenienced if they had to participate in pretrial proceedings being conducted by two different federal courts.
In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger, 331 F. Supp. 552 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2957

As litigation was relatively small in scope, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be inappropriate unless it involved exceptional cases sharing unusually complex questions of fact.
In re Iowa Beef Packers, Inc., 309 F. Supp. 1259 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

Just and efficient conduct of two antitrust actions involving distribution of Scotch whiskey would not be furthered by transfer of one of the cases to district in which the other case had been originally filed where the two suits were not exceptional cases sharing unusually complex questions of fact.
In re Scotch Whiskey, 299 F. Supp. 543 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Predominance of common or unique facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging intracranial hypertension injuries caused by the hormonal component of an IUD contraceptive system manufactured by defendants; except for two actions that appeared to be trial-ready and thus were not appropriate for centralization, the constituent actions involved common questions of fact regarding general causation, the background science, and defendants' labeling and regulatory history with respect to the alleged injury, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Mirena IUS Levonorgestrel-Related Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 249 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of 10 actions involving antitrust claims brought by direct purchaser plaintiffs relating to certain generic drugs, to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for inclusion in existing docket in multidistrict litigation, and to expand scope of that docket and rename it, was warranted; the subject actions involved common questions of fact with the actions previously transferred to that docket, transfers would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and expanding scope of the docket, and renaming it, would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Generic Digoxin and Doxycycline Antitrust Litigation, 222 F. Supp. 3d 1341 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 54 actions and multiple potential tag-along actions arising out of allegations that the manufacturer of two drugs belonging to a class of diabetes drugs known as Sodium Glucose Cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors failed to adequately test the drugs and warn of potential risks; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Invokana (Canagliflozin) Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Statute governing centralization of cases in multidistrict litigation does not require a complete identity or even a majority of common factual or legal issues as a prerequisite to transfer.
In re Darvocet, Darvon and Propoxyphene Products Liability Litigation, 939 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of actions pursuant to statute governing multidistrict litigation does not require a complete identity or even a majority of common factual or legal issues as a prerequisite to transfer.
In re Denture Cream Products Liability Litigation, 624 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in series of 10 actions against Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) that included securities actions, derivative actions, and actions brought under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA); actions shared factual questions arising out of alleged accounting irregularities at Fannie Mae, all actions could be expected to focus on significant number of common events, defendants and/or witnesses, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings especially with respect to questions of class certification, and conserve resources.
In re Federal Nat. Mortg. Ass'n Securities Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for consolidated pretrial proceedings, of three actions pending in two districts, was not warranted; number of actions involved was minimal, and actions did not involve sufficient common questions of fact, inasmuch as unique questions of fact in one action, as to each plaintiff's terms and conditions of employment and work history at one facility, predominated over any common questions relating to allegations of company-wide racial discrimination among the three actions, and that action was moving forward rapidly.
In re Boeing Co. Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 293 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for purpose of consolidated pretrial proceedings of multiple ERISA class actions brought by pharmacy benefit members against benefit managers (PBMs) was unwarranted, where unique questions of fact predominated over any common questions of fact; each plaintiff was member of different plan and sued PBM under different contract, only one PBM was defendant in each action, and there was no allegation that PBMs conspired with each other to violate ERISA.
In re Pharmacy Ben. Plan Administrators Pricing Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of 20 actions in asbestos school products liability litigation for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would neither serve convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation where common questions of fact did not predominate over individual questions of fact present in each action, where common questions of fact involved in the actions had been extensively litigated for the past ten years in connection with thousands of personal injury actions arising from alleged asbestos exposure, where one of the actions had already been tried and several others had been scheduled for trial within the next six months and where great majority of parties responding to the motion opposed centralization; thus, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would deny motion to transfer.
In re Asbestos School Products Liability Litigation, 606 F. Supp. 713 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
Federal Courts  2953

Plaintiffs' motion to centralize for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings 27 products liability actions against manufacturer would be denied, because common questions of fact were not shown to predominate over individual questions of fact present in each action, and transfer would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Eli Lilly & Co. Oraflex Products Liability Litigation, 578 F. Supp. 422 (J.P.M.L. 1984).
Federal Courts  2953

Cases pending in the Northern District of California, the District of New Jersey, the District of Hawaii, all of which arose out of alleged fraudulent conduct in the sale of limited partnership interests in one or more real estate projects marketed by a company and its affiliates and representatives would be transferred to the Northern District of California for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings despite objections that some unique factual questions were involved in certain actions and that voluntary cooperation among the parties was a suitable alternative to transfer.
In re Capital Underwriters, Inc. Securities Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 955 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Motion to transfer two actions, ending in the Middle District of North Carolina, to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with three actions pending there would be denied, since, although the allegations of racially discriminatory employment practices in all five actions might involve some common questions of fact, those common issues would not predominate over individual factual issues, since coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding would not necessarily serve the convenience of parties and witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and since communication and cooperation between the two, district courts, coupled with the parties' cooperation, would be sufficient to prevent any duplicative discovery and eliminate the possibility of conflicting class determinations or other pretrial rulings.
In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Employment Discrimination Litigation, 438 F. Supp. 937 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Where parties were virtually unanimous in opposition to transfer of actions involving claims for exposure of workers to asbestos, and the only questions of fact common to all actions related to the state of scientific and medical knowledge at different points in time concerning the risk of exposure to asbestos, and many factual questions unique to each action or to group of actions already pending in a single district clearly predominated, transfer would not serve convenience of parties and witnesses or promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Asbestos and Asbestos Insulation Material Products Liability Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 906 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Minnesota and Washington actions by former beer distributors, based on antitrust and other claims in connection with acquisition of one brewer by another, were appropriately subject to transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where common questions of fact predominated over any unique factual issues relating to different geographic product markets and where, though the Minnesota discovery was more advanced, transferee judge could make Minnesota discovery available to Washington plaintiff, though there was already voluntary cooperation among counsel in the various actions.
In re Olympia Brewing Co. Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 398 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Action commenced in the Western District of Arkansas against corporation which had acquired assets of another corporation, by the other corporation and class of those of acquiring corporation's stockholders who received their shares as part of the transaction, would not be transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions brought against the acquiring corporation and others in connection with a different acquisition, though there might be some common questions of fact, where the noncommon issues clearly predominated and the plaintiffs in the Arkansas cases seemed to have completed their discovery and were proceeding expeditiously toward trial.
In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger, 333 F. Supp. 911 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Previous resolution of questions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where, as to separate actions brought in District of Minnesota and District of North Dakota by nursing facility to recover medical assistance payments allegedly due from states, most relevant factual data had been previously elicited in state administrative and judicial proceedings, question of patients' residency did not appear to present questions of fact, and questions pertaining to residency did not appear so complex as to themselves warrant transfer, facility's motion to transfer Minnesota action to North Dakota for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings would be denied.
In re Interstate Medicaid Patients at Good Samaritan Nursing Center, 415 F. Supp. 389 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Specification of facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Transfer of four actions to District of Colorado for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied, with leave to reapply should circumstances later warrant, where motion of common defendant-corporation seeking the transfer stated need for transfer in summary terms without specifying common issues of fact, and other parties to such actions strongly opposed transfer.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1179 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Presumptions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
When two or more complaints assert comparable allegations against identical defendants based upon similar transactions and events, common factual questions are presumed for purposes of transfer for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings.
In re Air West, Inc. Securities Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 609 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Tag-along actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Based on the injury described in the complaint (hypomagnesemia) and the parties' arguments, potential tag-along action did not fall within scope of multidistrict litigation alleging that a drug prescribed for heartburn and other symptoms could cause a variety of bone ailments.
In re: Nexium (Esomeprazole) Products Liability Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 11 actions and three potential tag-along actions, pending in nine districts, involving the infringement or validity of a patent relating to wireless and position location reporting technology used in fleet management applications; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (particularly on claim construction issues), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Vehicle Tracking and Sec. System ("844) Patent Litigation, 807 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

Tag-along action which involved questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and which involved similar allegations focusing upon analogous violations of securities laws was properly transferred.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 767 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted for eight actions arising out of the disappearance and presumed loss of aircraft during an international flight, where 40 related actions were pending in four district courts, centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, particularly with respect to potential international discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and the judiciary, and given the number of actions and that they arose from same accident, centralization was more suitable than informal coordination.
In re Air Crash over the Southern Indian Ocean, on March 8, 2014, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2955

Although the actions shared certain factual issues, centralization for pretrial proceedings was not warranted in four actions, pending in four districts, concerning the cause or causes of the crash of a military helicopter while approaching a U.S. Army airfield in George; issues as to the liability of three of the five defendants appeared to be largely defendant-specific, the principal common issues among those three defendants appeared to be largely limited to damages, and, to extent that common issues existed, informal coordination and cooperation among counsel was practical, since plaintiffs were represented in all actions by the same law firm, and the relatively advanced status of one of the cases weighed against centralization.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Savannah, Georgia, on January 15, 2014, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2955

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in two actions, pending in two districts, concerning the cause or causes of the crash of an aircraft in Honduras; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In Re Air Crash at Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on May 30, 2008, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfers of six actions pending in two districts, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions concerning the testing, design and manufacture of the same model of an aircraft and that aircraft's deicing system, were warranted; actions involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfers would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2955

Centralization of three actions, pending in two districts and arising out of a helicopter crash, was not warranted; absent any common questions of fact and law sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Zachary, Louisiana, on Dec. 9, 2004, 484 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2955

Centralization, of two actions pending in two districts and arising out of the crash of an aircraft, was not warranted; given the minimal number of actions and parties involved, any common questions of fact were not sufficiently complex to warrant centralization.
In re Air Crash near Canandaigua, N.Y., on September 16, 2002, 427 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of ten actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in two districts, concerning the cause of the crash of an aircraft, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Air Crash Near Kirksville, Missouri, on October 19, 2004, 383 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of eight actions, pending in four districts, arising from air crash; actions involved common questions of fact concerning cause or causes of crash, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Air Crash Near Woodbury, Connecticut, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of four actions, pending in two districts and concerning the cause of the crash of a helicopter in British Columbia, Canada, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Wendle Creek, British Columbia on August 8, 2002, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Seven actions brought in two districts concerning crash of charter flight would be consolidated in District of Connecticut and assigned for consolidated or coordinated for pretrial proceedings; five actions were brought in District of Connecticut while two originated in Southern District of Texas, actions involved common questions of fact arising of single plane crash, and centralization in District of Connecticut would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, would promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and would conserve resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re Air Crash Near Castellon, Spain on October 10, 2001, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Actions were based on common questions of fact and centralization of the action would serve the convenience of all the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation arising from the crash of an air carrier in New York state; centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources.
In re Air Crash at Belle Harbor, N.Y. on November 12, 2001, 203 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Multiple actions arising out of airplane crash would be centralized in Eastern District of New York, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, in that actions shared factual questions concerning cause or causes of crash; centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, and no party to litigation contended that Eastern District of New York was unsuitable forum.
In re Air Disaster at Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988, 709 F. Supp. 231 (J.P.M.L. 1989).
Federal Courts  2955

Centralization for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings was appropriate for nine actions arising out of aircraft disaster in Sioux City, Iowa where all actions shared numerous questions of fact concerning cause or causes of air disaster and centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Sioux City, Iowa, on July 19, 1989, 128 F.R.D. 131 (J.P.M.L. 1989).
Federal Courts  2951

Where multiple actions arising from air crash disaster raised common questions of fact and their centralization in single federal district would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, action pending in other district would be transferred and assigned for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions already pending in such district.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near New Orleans, La., on July 9, 1982, 548 F. Supp. 1268 (J.P.M.L. 1982).
Federal Courts  2955

Action wherein plaintiffs, as parents of stewardess who was killed in crash of defendants' commercial aircraft, alleged that defendant was negligent in operation of its aircraft was subject to being transferred to Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with previously transferred actions where action shared common questions of fact with actions in transferee district not only on issue of negligence but also on threshold issue of choice of laws concerning applicability of workmen's compensation laws to actions initiated on behalf of airline employees and transfer would eliminate possibility of duplicated discovery and prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Pago Pago, Am. Samoa, on January 30, 1974, 424 F. Supp. 1075 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

Even though two of tort actions arising out of crash of airplane involved common factual issues, fact that third action raised substantially different questions of fact precluded any gain from including third action in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and precluded transfer, especially since possibility of duplicative discovery could easily be avoided through cooperative efforts among parties by use of suitable alternatives to transfer.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana, on September 20, 1973, 391 F. Supp. 765 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Where there were 17 actions pending in 5 districts, arising out of airplane crash, and all parties conceded that there were substantial common questions of fact relating to liability, transfer to single district would be ordered.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Hanover, N. H., 314 F. Supp. 62 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

Where many actions arose from collision of airliner and small plane, facts relating to cause of collision were common to all such death actions, and statutory criteria for transfers to single district for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings were met.
In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

Litigation arising out of single aircraft disaster involves common questions of fact and convenience of parties and witnesses is generally furthered by consolidation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Falls City, Neb on August 6, 1966, 298 F. Supp. 1323 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where monopoly and restraint of trade action had common questions of fact with numerous civil actions pending in other districts, action was proper for limited transfer by Judicial Panel, even though it was not the type of antitrust case ordinarily processed by the Panel.
Bayly Mfg. Co. v. Koracorp Industries, Inc., 298 F. Supp. 600 (D. Colo. 1969).

Suit alleging violations of state antitrust laws by securities dealers would not be remanded to state court, following removal to federal court and consolidation under federal multidistrict litigation procedures, even though complaint made reference only to state antitrust laws; facts contained in state complaint and federal complaints previously consolidated were nearly same, state statutes made illegal essentially same acts prohibited by federal antitrust laws, complaints were being made against dealers nationwide and courts of state in question had held that state statutes applied only intrastate, and multidistrict litigation management would become more difficult if parties could resist consolidation by resort to state courts.
In re NASDAQ Market Makers Antitrust Litigation, 929 F. Supp. 174 (S.D. N.Y. 1996).
Removal Of Cases  25(1)

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of two actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts and alleging that defendants engaged in anticompetitive conduct in the market for interest rate swaps, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Interest Rate Swaps Antitrust Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).

In re National Football League's "Sunday Ticket" Antitrust Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).

Centralization of antitrust actions for pretrial proceedings in District of District of Columbia was warranted, where actions involved common questions of fact arising out of alleged conspiracy by nation's four largest airlines to fix prices for domestic airline tickets, and centralization of litigation in District of Columbia, which possessed necessary judicial resources and expertise to manage litigation efficiently, would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re Domestic Airline Travel Antitrust Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1344 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).

In re: Aluminum Warehousing Antitrust Litigation, 988 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).

In re: Blue Cross Blue Shield Antitrust Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).

Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted for 17 actions in multidistrict litigation, arising out of allegations that defendants unlawfully monopolized, artificially inflated and/or otherwise improperly manipulated the price of TET propane in the United States; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.

In re: Packaged Ice Antitrust Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in four actions and two potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts, alleging a conspiracy to violate the Sherman Antitrust Act by refusing to compete for the purchase of raw Grade A milk produced, marketed and processed in the Southeast United States; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Southeastern Milk Antitrust Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).

Centralization of four actions and one potential tag-along action in multidistrict litigation, alleging Sherman Act violations arising out of an alleged conspiracy to prevent competition for concert promotion services, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.

In re Hydrogen Peroxide Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of two actions and four potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that thermostat manufacturer engaged in anticompetitive practices to exclude potential competitors by, among other things, misrepresenting the validity of its trademark; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Circular Thermostat Antitrust Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of four purported class actions and six potential tag-along actions, pending in seven districts and alleging that common defendants and/or their alleged co-conspirators engaged in a combination and conspiracy to affect the sale of insurance by rigging bids and allocating customers, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Insurance Brokerage Antitrust Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of nine actions and 15 potential tag-along actions, pending in 11 districts and alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix prices for publication paper, in violation of federal antitrust laws, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.

In re Mut. Fund Sales Antitrust Litigation, 361 F. Supp. 638 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Common questions of fact were presented in express common carrier's antitrust actions against railroads, in action by one railroad against carrier for transportation services rendered pursuant to regional master agreement alleged by carrier to be part of antitrust conspiracy, and in action by second railroad against carrier for transportation services rendered, warranting transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action pending in Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
In re REA Exp., Inc., 352 F. Supp. 803 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Where parties in various cases involving antitrust violations by professional basketball associations and contractual relations of professional basketball player did not establish that common questions of fact existed in cases and it did not appear that parties or witnesses would be inconvenienced or that just and efficient conduct of actions would suffer in absence of transfer, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied without prejudice to subsequent motion.
In re Professional Basketball Antitrust Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Count of government's complaint against seven drug companies, denominated as common law action of deceit for fraud on Patent Office [now Patent and Trademark Office], and count brought under Clayton Antitrust Act, §§ 12 to 27 of Title 15, involved sufficient common questions of fact to warrant transfer to Southern District of New York for consolidations of pretrial proceedings with private treble damage antitrust actions there pending against the drug companies.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 309 F. Supp. 155 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

Where issue of whether manufacturer's policy of recommending that only its brand of photocopy paper and supplies be used with its photocopy machine could be justified for technical reasons or rather was an attempt to create illegal tying arrangement was a question of fact common to all actions in multidistrict litigation, existence of manufacturer's practice satisfied requirement that common question of fact exists prior to coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Photocopy Paper, 305 F. Supp. 60 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Differences between underlying indictments in criminal cases and civil complaints arising out of alleged antitrust violations in regard to concrete pipe, in respect to geographic areas in which conspiracy was operative, and in respect to time periods, conspiratorial details and parties, did not militate against transfer.
In re Concrete Pipe, 302 F. Supp. 244 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

Common questions of fact relating to particular licensing agreement and its effect on prior licensees whose agreements contained a “most favored royalty” provision made this section clearly applicable to the 16 cases which involved patentee and which all presented issue of whether patentee had used its patents, trademarks, and licensing agreements to create a monopoly in restraint of trade.
In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Fact that civil antitrust actions involved antibiotic drug for use in animal feed when other cases transferred to single district for pretrial proceedings involved antibiotic drugs for human consumption did not preclude their transfer, where they shared with other cases common questions of fact with regard to alleged conspiracy.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Bankruptcy proceedings, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Actions by trustee in bankruptcy for related corporations against four national banks under federal securities and bankruptcy laws would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with other actions involving the investment activities of the corporations, despite contention that minimal common aspects were outweighed by predominance of unique issues among the actions, where all the actions involved substantial common questions of fact concerning the financial condition of the corporations and three of the four bank actions to be transferred shared questions of facts concerning alleged collective activities of the banks and others.
In re Investors Funding Corp. of New York Securities Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 1199 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Cargo actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Actions against railroads by federal government on behalf of Commodity Credit Corporation to recover damages for alleged losses of grain during shipment were transferred to the Western District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where, though each action involved different shipments of grain, dates of shipment, origins, destinations, routings, carriers, amounts of grain and railroad cars, the actions involved common questions of fact, notwithstanding opposition to transfer by some of defendants on ground that in former grain shipments litigation the expenses of counsel for traveling to and from pretrial conferences and depositions exceeded amount of damages claimed by plaintiff.
In re Commodity Credit Corp. Litigation Involving Grain Shipments (No. 11), 364 F. Supp. 462 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions by government against railroads for damages for alleged losses of grain during shipment would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where they involved many common questions of fact, although some questions of fact were of limited commonality, particularly since, although cases were of great importance to railroads, government, and general public, they involved relatively small damage claims.
In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Discrimination actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Actions relating to employment practices litigation would be transferred to the District of Oregon for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where they involved common questions of fact and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Petrol Stops Northwest Employment Practices Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions against unions, charging them with racially discriminatory employment practices and policies regarding apprenticeship training, union membership, hiring, career advancement, job referrals and disciplinary proceedings involved common questions of fact, and transfer of such actions to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Ironworkers Union Employment Practices Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 1072 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Contract actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Given limited factual overlap and minimal number of actions, informal coordination and cooperative efforts by parties and involved courts could minimize or eliminate duplicative discovery and other pretrial proceedings, and, thus, centralization for multidistrict litigation of two pending actions involving performance of oil well drilling contract was not warranted; common factual issues were limited to allegations that drilling operation was unnecessarily prolonged, and trucking companies were induced to falsify their invoices, while second action contained unique and expansive allegations that one party was a shell company, individual defendants operated a Ponzi scheme, and another party was slandered and libeled.
In re Energy Drilling, LLC, Contract Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1333 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of two breach of contract actions to the Eastern District of Missouri, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions involving allegations regarding the defendant's role in causing the contamination of commercial rice stocks with genetically modified rice, was warranted; actions involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Genetically Modified Rice Litigation, 543 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralized pretrial proceedings were not warranted in four actions pending in three districts and arising out of contracts between insurance companies and a preferred provider organization; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, since the actions were against different insurance companies and involved different contracts.
In re Insurance Companies “Silent” Preferred Provider Organization (PPO) Litigation, 517 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation involving actions alleging insurance company increased the monthly deductions for universal life policies in breach of the plain language of those policies; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including those with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Conseco Life Ins. Co. Cost of Ins. Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Motion for order transferring two actions pending in Southern District of Indiana to Southern District of Florida for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action pending there would be denied, where only the three actions were involved, much of factual inquiry in Florida action, as compared to that in Indiana actions, differed because of separate contractual relationships involved, any common factual questions were not so complex or accompanying discovery so time consuming as to warrant transfer, discovery in Florida action was substantially complete and that action was nearly ready for trial, so that transfer would neither serve convenience of parties nor promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Royal Typewriter Co. (Royal Bond Copier) Breach of Warranty Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 925 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Breach of contract action which was filed by subdeveloper of electronic countermeasures system for fighter aircraft in Eastern District of Missouri against prime developer for alleged failure to satisfy contractual commitments would not be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Southern District of New York where a second breach of contract action by another subdeveloper was pending, notwithstanding claimed factual commonality between actions arising from technical relationships between subsystems, and alleged overlap relating to prime developer's alleged failure to disclose knowledge in its possession stemming from certain study contracts which it had commissioned, where systems developed by subdevelopers were essentially different products and, therefore, raised predominantly different factual issues and, due to rapidly approaching trial in New York, transfer might cause a delay which could not be justified by a concomitant increase in expeditiousness with which Missouri case could be resolved.
In re McDonnell Douglas “Wild Weasel AN/APR-38” Contract Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 387 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

Common questions of fact existed in actions by public utilities against uranium supplier arising out of supplier's contention that its contractual obligations to furnish uranium to power present and future nuclear power plants of such utilities were excused under doctrine of commercial impracticability; transfer of such actions to Eastern District of Virginia would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Uranium Contracts Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 316 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Motion by pipeline corporation and its former parent corporation to transfer five actions for breach of contract brought against them by industrial customers of the pipeline to either the Eastern or Western Districts of Louisiana was denied where the pipeline and its parent had not yet filed answers and the complaints indicated that the various allegations of breach of contract gave rise to factual issues predominantly unique to each particular plaintiff's relationship to the pipeline.
In re United Gas Pipe Line Co. Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 774 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions against designer of highway brought in Southern District of Texas and actions against project's construction companies brought in District of Idaho, charging breach of contract and various torts, involved common questions of fact, and thus, in order to best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, actions in Southern District of Texas were transferred to District of Idaho for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Peruvian Road Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Copyright actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where pretrial motions in various actions brought for infringement of the same copyrighted cartoon character would be decided on their own facts and where there were no significant questions of fact common to the various actions, there was no possibility of inconsistent decisions on the motions such as would justify transferring all actions to the same district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re “Truckin" Cartoon Characters Copyright Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Labor and union actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
While common factual issues existed, centralization of multidistrict wage and hour employment practices litigation was not necessary either to assure convenience of parties and witnesses or for just and efficient conduct of litigation; the two actions in Northern and Central Districts of California contained similar allegations concerning whether employer's personal trainers were paid in accordance with California's wage and hour statute, but cases were not particularly complex and no great geographical chasm separated parties and cooperation among parties and deference among courts could easily minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re: Equinox Fitness Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that retailer used various means to avoid paying its hourly employees for all of their time worked; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In Re Wal-Mart Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of three actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that trucking company failed to give notice to its employees when it ceased operations, in violation of the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re USF Red Star Inc. Workers Notification Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, for pretrial proceedings, of four actions, pending in four districts and alleging that certain of defendants' employees were entitled to overtime compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Dollar General Corp. Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization of three actions involving allegations that casualty adjusters employed by insurance company were entitled to overtime pay under FLSA was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact arising out of similar allegations, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, while accordingly being necessary in order to avoid duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Allstate Ins. Co. Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Inasmuch as each airline would have unique defenses arising out of its labor relations with its flight deck crew members and its own views as to what constituted safe operating procedures, issues raised in 12 separate actions alleging that employment practices of eight different airlines violated Age Discrimination in Employment Act, section 621 et seq. of Title 29, raised insufficient common questions of fact; thus, transfer to one district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was inappropriate.
In re Airline “Age of Employee” Employment Practices Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 814 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2955

Labor litigations, which were pending in three districts in the metropolitan New York City area and which involved common questions of fact with regard to role of international union in alleged illegal secondary activities carried out by individual locals, were not exceptional cases sharing unusually complex common questions of fact and their just and efficient conduct would not be served by transfer to the District of New Jersey for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Iowa Beef Packers, Inc., 309 F. Supp. 1259 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Medical malpractice actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
District of Columbia medical malpractice action would not be transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with malpractice action pending there, where essential ingredient of liability in New York action was propriety of pathological tests performed by defendant and his resultant conclusion that specimen forwarded to him was benign, whereas in District of Columbia, action the question of liability turned on whether diagnostic procedures employed by defendant in that action and her subsequent reliance on report of defendant in New York action were in accordance with prevailing medical standards in that community.
In re Klein Medical Malpractice Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 679 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Motor vehicle accident actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Fact that two actions arise from same disaster does not ipso facto mean that their coordination or consolidation is appropriate under this section.
In re Highway Acc. Near Rockville, Connecticut, on December 30, 1972, 388 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in two actions, pending in two districts, which concerned the validity and enforceability of patents used in making drugs for treatment of glaucoma; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Brimonidine Patent Litigation, 507 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of ten actions and two potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and arising out of oil company's participation in California Air Resources Board's adoption of reformulated gasoline (RFG) regulations which overlapped company's patents; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Reformulated Gasoline (RFG) Antitrust & Patent Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of patent infringement actions pending in multiple districts was warranted, even though there were variations in defendants' allegedly infringing uses and pretrial litigation in some cases was more advanced than in others; all actions involved questions as to infringement and validity of same set of patents.
In re Acacia Media Technologies Corp. Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2956

Transfer for centralized proceedings, of seven actions and one potential tag-along action pending in multidistrict litigation and involving the validity of a patent relating to a recombinant DNA technology called co-transformation, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and law, and centralization would serve the convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to matters of claims construction, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Columbia University Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2956

Transfer, for inclusion with actions previously centralized for pretrial proceedings, of 17 actions and 28 potential tag-along actions in multidistrict litigation, involving the validity of a patent for a system for spraying self-tanning solutions and other compositions on the human body, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact with previously centralized actions, and inclusion in those proceedings would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Laughlin Products, Inc., Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2956

Common questions of fact concerning validity of patent in semiconductor patent infringement actions warranted transfer of actions to Eastern District of Virginia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, notwithstanding contention that trial date had been set in Virginia action and resolution of that action could dispose of the others either on collateral estoppel principles or by settlements.
In re Western Elec. Co., Inc. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 378 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2956

Even assuming that laches discovery were unique in each of six patent infringement actions against six separate defendants filed in three districts in same state, court would order transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, since actions all shared common questions of fact with respect to validity of patent and, in the circumstances, that was sufficient to justify transfer.
In re Smith Patent Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2956

Record showed that the four pending actions for patent infringement shared common questions of fact, particularly the invalidity defense, and that the transfer of the three actions pending in the Middle District of North Carolina to the Western District of North Carolina for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with the action pending in that district would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Panty Hose Seaming Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2956

Patent infringement action in Northern District of Illinois was transferred by Judicial Panel to Northern District of Ohio for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with two pending infringement actions involving same patents in that common questions of fact were involved and transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Triax Co. Patent Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 590 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2956

Where issue of patent validity raised in Louisiana and Texas actions presented common question of fact and consolidation for pretrial proceedings would avoid duplicative discovery and prevent inconsistent rulings, and all issues about patent validity raised in Louisiana action were also raised in Texas action, transfer of Louisiana action to Northern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with respect to all matters involving validity of any claim of any patent asserted in either action was appropriate, as was transfer of Louisiana defendants antitrust counterclaim.
In re Camco Patent Infringement Litigation, 343 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2956

In view of common questions pending in 35 cases, originally filed in four different district courts and all involving issue of validity of one or more of six basic patents which dominated the double knit yarn industry, immediate transfer to single transferee district was required in order to make possible consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings in the transferee district.
In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2956

In view of common questions pending in 16 cases, originally filed in 6 different district courts and all involving issue of whether patentee had used its trademarks, patents and licensing agreements to create a monopoly in restraint of trade, Judicial Panel determined that particular case, asserted to be relatively simple, must be included for consolidated or coordinated pretrial purposes, but if case and its concomitant discovery were as simple as urged it might be remanded as soon as limited discovery was completed.
In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Inclusion in centralized pretrial proceedings, in multidistrict litigation involving products liability claims relating to the design, manufacture, marketing or performance of components of defendant manufacturer's hip replacement system, and to complications arising from the use of a cobalt-chromium alloy, was not warranted for cases that did not involve claims related to defendant's components; defendant's components were subject to rigorous premarket approval procedure by U.S. Food and Drug Administration, whereas the other hip implant components at issue were cleared for marketing under a different procedure, and would require different discovery and pretrial motion practice.
In re Smith & Nephew BHR & R3 Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 249 F. Supp. 3d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of litigation was not warranted for nine actions pending in seven districts alleging that patients suffered injury or death as result of ingesting generic prescription drug and that manufacturers improperly marketed the drug for off-label uses; there were significant differences among the actions, including the defendants and allegations, and there was a limited number of counsel involved who were willing to cooperate and coordinate to avoid unnecessary duplication of discovery and other pretrial matters.
In re: Cordarone (Amiodarone Hydrochloride) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1346 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization in District of Kansas was warranted for 15 products-liability actions against manufacturer of power morcellators, including two actions in which another manufacturer was co-defendant; actions involved common factual questions arising from allegations that defects in design of power morcellators made laparoscopic hysterectomy or myomectomy procedures more likely to result in dissemination and upstaging of occult cancer and that manufacturer failed to warn patients adequately of these risks, centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, avoid inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary, and District of Kansas was centrally located and easily accessible for all parties.
In re Power Morcellator Products Liability Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was warranted as serving convenience of parties and witnesses and promoting just and efficient conduct of six putative class actions pending in five districts against automobile manufacturer in connection with alleged defects that caused vehicles to vibrate excessively; actions all shared factual questions with respect to defect allegations, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings on class certification and other issues, and conserve resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc., CR-V Vibration Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1336 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Since action which alleged that use of an intrauterine contraceptive system caused autoimmune disorders, and that the product's label failed to provide adequate warnings with respect to such disorders, shared no readily apparent common issues with other actions involving the same product, that action would not be transferred for inclusion in centralized pretrial proceedings involving those other cases.
In re Mirena IUD Products Liability Litigation, 938 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of 39 actions and two potential tag-along actions, pending in 21 districts, alleging that a drug prescribed for heartburn and other symptoms could cause a variety of bone ailments, and that the manufacturer failed to adequately warn of those potential side effects, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Nexium (Esomeprazole) Products Liability Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in four actions, pending in two districts, concerning two pharmaceutical patents for the drug Uroxatral; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Alfuzosin Hydrochloride Patent Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfers of actions, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions involving allegations that certain of a manufacturer's motor vehicles were equipped with defective or defectively-installed speed control deactivation switches, were warranted; actions involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfers would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Ford Motor Co. Speed Control Deactivation Switch Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfers of actions, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in products liability actions relating to the recall of several models of an allegedly defective prescription hernia patch, was warranted; actions involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfers would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Kugel Mesh Hernia Patch Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of action to District of Rhode Island, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in products liability actions involving allegations relating to the recall of several models of an allegedly defective prescription medical device known as the Composix Kugel Hernia Patch, was warranted; action involved common questions of fact with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Kugel Mesh Hernia Patch Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of action, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions involving allegations that a fast food chain misled the public regarding the presence of gluten, wheat or dairy derivatives in its french fries, was warranted; action involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: McDonald's French Fries Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of action, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions involving the allegedly adverse effects of a contact lens solution, was warranted; action involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Bausch & Lomb Inc. Contact Lens Solution Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of action, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions concerning alleged exposure to the herbicide known as “Agent Orange,” was warranted; action involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: “Agent Orange” Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of action to District of New Jersey, for inclusion in centralized pretrial proceedings in actions involving allegations relating to the recalls of pet food products allegedly tainted with melamine contained in components imported from China, was warranted; action involved questions of fact in common with the previously-transferred actions, and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Pet Food Products Liability Litigation, 544 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation alleging injuries resulting from certain antipsychotic prescription medications, centralization was not warranted for those actions which did not involve claims against the manufacturer of Seroquel; those actions did not involve common questions of fact, and their centralization would neither serve convenience of the parties and witnesses nor promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Seroquel Products Liability Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentations regarding the presence of gluten, wheat or dairy derivatives in french fries; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to issue of class certification), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re McDonald's French Fries Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1342 (J.P.M.L. 2006), adhered to, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008) and subsequent determination, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging personal and/or economic injury arising out of eye infections associated with defendant's contact lens solution; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Bausch & Lomb Inc. Contact Lens Solution Products Liability Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1336 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of multiple products liability actions against manufacturer of cardiac pacemakers, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was warranted, as all suits involved common questions of fact; centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to class certification, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of putative class actions sharing factual questions regarding whether certain of manufacturer's vehicles were equipped with defective or defectively-installed speed control deactivation switches was appropriate; although actions were based on differing theories, they arose from common factual core, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to questions of class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Ford Motor Co. Speed Control Deactivation Switch Products Liability Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005), subsequent determination, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of actions and potential tag-along actions pending in various districts and alleging that manufacturer of anti-inflammatory prescription medications failed to disclose that the medications carried increased health risks; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, avoid inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Bextra and Celebrex Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Products liability action involving several prescription drugs would not be included in multidistrict litigation involving one of those drugs.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Consolidation in single district of products liability actions against pharmaceutical company, alleging injuries from use of acne drug developed and marketed by company, was warranted, even though injuries alleged were not identical; actions involved complex common questions of fact concerning development, testing, manufacturing and marketing of drug, and company's knowledge concerning its possible side effects, and centralization in district where three of seven actions were already pending would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve parties' resources.
In re Accutane Products Liability Litigation, 343 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of three actions and eight potential tag-along actions in multidistrict litigation, alleging that defective engine pistons in automobile manufacturer's vehicles damaged the value of some vehicles, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re General Motors Corp. Piston Slap Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1386 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951
