Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of six actions and eight potential tag-along actions arising out of concerns as to the safety of a prescription drug used in the treatment of schizophrenia, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In light of order transferring personal injury/wrongful death actions brought against manufacturer of ephedra-containing products, centralization for pretrial proceedings, with other actions in multidistrict litigation, of one action related to the personal injury/wrongful death actions and alleging that the products had side-effects and that the manufacturer knew of and concealed, misrepresented, or failed to warn of those side-effects, was not warranted.
In re Ephedra Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of four actions in two districts alleging that manufacturers' defectively designed back-wire push-in electrical receptacles were unreasonably dangerous and caused an increased risk of fire or electrical shock, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Electrical Receptacle Products Liability Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of two actions in multidistrict litigation against manufacturers of blood products, alleging that hemophiliacs acquired the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) through the use of concentrate blood products, for inclusion in an ongoing docket in multidistrict litigation involving the same issues, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact with the actions in the ongoing docket, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re “Factor VIII or IX Concentrate Blood Products” Products Liability Litigation, 303 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Pretrial proceedings in personal injury actions against manufacturers of allegedly defective temporomandibular joint (TMJ) implants would be consolidated in District of Minnesota for consistent rulings; common factual questions existed on whether implants were defective, whether manufacturers adequately tested implants and constituent materials or warned of risks, and whether implant materials were prone to break down in recipients' bodies.
In re Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) Implants Products Liability Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 1553 (J.P.M.L. 1994).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

Pursuant to statute governing transfer in multidistrict cases, 26,639 actions involving allegations of personal injury or wrongful death caused by asbestos would be transferred to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania for pretrial proceedings, considering that actions involved common questions of fact, and that centralization of actions would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 771 F. Supp. 415 (J.P.M.L. 1991).
Federal Courts  2953

Where 15 actions were brought in 11 different districts against manufacturer of prosthetic heart valve and manufacturer's insurer, where actions concerned similar factual questions concerning design, development, manufacture, testing, and marketing of valve, state of medical knowledge regarding valve, manufacturer's knowledge of allegedly defective condition of valve, and reasons behind manufacturer's decision to remove valve from market, and where majority of parties favored selection of Eastern District of New York as transferee forum, centralization of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in Eastern District of New York was appropriate.
In re Cutter Laboratories, Inc. “Braunwald-Cutter” Aortic Heart Valve Products Liability Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1295 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions wherein plaintiffs alleged that they or their decedents developed a type of paralysis known as Guillain-Barre Syndrome, loss of sensation and death, or suffered injuries to lungs and respiratory system, eventually resulting in death, as a result of administration of swine flu vaccinations under the national swine flu immunization program of 1976 were transferred to the District of the District of Columbia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings notwithstanding claim that issues of proof of injury, causation and damages, remaining after the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare determined that it was not necessary to prove negligence to receive federal compensation, were unique with respect to each action.
In re Swine Flu Immunization Products Liability Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 949 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralized pretrial proceedings were appropriate in product liability litigation in view of actions of commonality of factual questions except that transfer of three actions wherein discovery had been completed would not be appropriate.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic “Cleocin” Products Liability Litigation, 450 F. Supp. 1168 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Cases, which were pending in number of different districts, in each of which plaintiff was an owner or operator of a commercial helicopter powered by gas turbine engine designed and manufactured by defendant, and each of which concerned the design, manufacture and installation of engine, would be transferred to the Southern District of Indiana for consolidated pretrial proceedings, as they involved common questions of fact and as the convenience of parties and witnesses and the just and efficient conduct of the litigation would be thereby promoted; but certain other designated cases would not be transferred where discovery would not involve common issues of fact or where discovery had been substantially completed.
In re Aviation Products Liability Litigation, 347 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict actions against drug manufacturer arising from use of one or more of manufacturer's oral contraceptive products would not be transferred in absence of showing that there were common questions of fact among the cases to be transferred and that transfer would serve convenience of parties and their witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the entire litigation.
In re Oral Contraceptives Products, 322 F. Supp. 1011 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of 17 state-law consumer-fraud and securities actions filed against financial services provider and two related declaratory judgment actions it filed was warranted; actions involved common factual questions surrounding plaintiffs' general allegations that provider intentionally misrepresented that its analysis of structured finance securities was independent, objective, and unaffected by existence of, or potential for, a business relationship with issuer of a security, and centralization allowed parties to obtain substantial efficiencies in dealing with common issues.
In re: Standard & Poor's Rating Agency Litigation, 949 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2957

Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted in six actions and one potential tag-along action pending in three districts and alleging that inappropriate investment of actively managed fixed income funds in risky subprime assets resulted in losses to investors; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: State Street Bank and Trust Co. Fixed Income Funds Inv. Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in 24 actions and one potential tag-along action, alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning company's financial condition, even though some actions entailed investigation of facts unique to allegations of violations of Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA); actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Delphi Corp. Securities, Derivative and “ERISA” Litigation, 403 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization was warranted, of 17 actions and five potential tag-along actions alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning a company's financial condition and alleged overvaluation of interest only strips—securities; actions shared common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Doral Financial Corp. Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in nine putative class actions pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning a company's financial condition; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings (especially with respect to questions of class certification), and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Sierra Wireless, Inc., Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in 23 actions brought under federal securities law and ERISA; actions involved common questions of fact arising from allegations that drug manufacturer misrepresented and/or concealed safety risks of its drugs, and that manufacturer's conduct affected its financial condition, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Pfizer Inc. Securities, Derivative & Erisa Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of four putative class actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that sellers of securities failed to disclose their participation in an unsustainable business scheme involving payment of illicit commissions; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Ace Ltd. Securities Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Inclusion of securities fraud case in order centralizing other cases against same defendants for pretrial proceedings was warranted, even though case raised both common and non-common issues.
In re Fleming Companies Inc. Securities & Derivative Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of three actions alleging violations of federal securities laws arising out of company's false and misleading statements concerning its operations at various cemeteries, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Service Corp. Intern., 323 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of seventeen actions and five potential tag-along actions, was warranted; whether brought by securities holders seeking relief under federal securities laws, shareholders suing derivatively, participants in retirement savings plans suing for violations of ERISA, or policyholders claiming improper denial of benefits under ERISA, actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Unumprovident Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 280 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Action against attorney for defendant in securities actions, seeking recovery of funds previously transferred in anticipation of approval of settlement agreement in the securities actions, to Western District of Pennsylvania for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with the securities actions already pending in such district was appropriate where present action shared questions of fact with actions previously transferred and transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation in that most of the money was under the custody of the transferee district and it was represented that all possible claimants to the money were before the transferee court.
In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 476 F. Supp. 459 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict cases involving alleged manipulative securities trading were transferred to Central District of California for coordinated pretrial proceedings where four actions involved raised common questions of fact and such transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Vernitron Securities Litigation, 462 F. Supp. 391 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2957

In view of common questions of fact and because transfer would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, actions arising out of tender offer for certain corporation stock were transferred from the Eastern District of Michigan and the Western District of Texas to the Central District of California.
In re Teledyne, Inc., Tender Offer Securities Litigation, 440 F. Supp. 58 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Actions brought against corporation to recover for wrongful disbursements by the corporation for unlawful political contributions, bribes, and related payments, for false and misleading entries made in books, for failure to disclose disbursements in regular reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and for false and misleading proxy statements involved common questions of fact and would be transferred to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Tenneco Inc. Securities Litigation, 426 F. Supp. 1187 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Although action by former shareholders of acquired corporation against various officers and directors of acquiring corporation, alleging violations of securities laws in connection with merger did share certain common questions of fact with earlier actions previously transferred for coordinated pretrial procedure motion for similar transfer of such action by former shareholders was denied where only one of the earlier actions remained active and did not share common questions of fact or parties and decisions of transferee court and Court of Appeals were available to guide determination of other issues.
In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 393 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Securities and Exchange Commission class and derivative actions arising out of failure of bank would be transferred to the Eastern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions pending in that district, where these actions involved common questions of fact and their transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote that just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Where securities action involved questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to Southern District of California, and its transfer to that district for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, transfer would be ordered despite contentions by plaintiffs that, because of narrow confines of their claims, which involved only one defendant common to other cases, it would be counter-productive to embroil them in irrelevant discovery proceedings and would be unduly burdensome and inconvenient to them.
In re U. S. Financial Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 586 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Action filed in Southern District of New York against four corporations and six individuals, alleging, inter alia, that defendants violated the antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws in connection with sale of certain securities, would be transferred to the Northern District of California, where the action involved factual issues common to previously transferred actions, and where transfer to Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Securities and Exchange Commission enforcement actions, which were instituted against insurance company, seven of its officials, its auditor, corporation in which the insurance company had substantial interest, its auditor and two other individuals and which alleged that defendants defrauded investors by concealing fact that the corporation was in dire financial condition, and 17 private actions, which were filed in three different districts and which involved same and additional defendants, involved common questions of fact justifying transfer to one district.
In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Actions which stood factually isolated from other actions would not be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with general securities and antitrust actions.
In re Bestline Products Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Where questions of fact pertaining to securities laws violations with respect to alleged untrue statements of material fact and failure to disclose material facts were common to actions previously transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania and plaintiffs in such transferred actions purported to represent a class comprised of all minority shareholders, which included plaintiffs in instant action, transfer of instant action to Eastern District of Pennsylvania to expedite pretrial processing and eliminate unnecessary duplication of documentary and depositional discovery was warranted.
In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Where first question to be faced, in action against broker, would be effect of class settlement entered in 19 multidistrict actions which had already been transferred to Oklahoma for coordinated pretrial proceedings and, in event plaintiff's cause of action was determined to be unaffected by settlement and she wished to proceed with pretrial discovery, she would be exploring many issues of fact common to claims of plaintiffs whose actions had already been transferred, such action would be transferred to Oklahoma, notwithstanding plaintiff's allegations of individual misconduct by broker's employees and fact that securities other than those involved in transferred actions had been purchased and sold for her account.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 964 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict private damage actions under federal securities laws by stockholders against corporation and others were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the District of Columbia, where common questions of fact were raised concerning corporation's acquisitions and also concerning the corporation's financial statements, press releases and other oral and written communications, where discovery in each case would cover much of same ground and where the convenience of parties and witnesses and the just and efficient conduct of litigation required that all pretrial activity be supervised by single judge.
In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Trademark actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, of two actions and one potential tag-along action, alleging either continuing trademark infringement or confusion caused by the use of the plaintiffs' TESTMASTERS trademark, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Testmasters Trademark Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Where, with possible exception of antitrust claims, common core of fact questions as to validity of trademark, manufacturer's alleged infringement of such trademark, and effect of settlement entered into in previous trademark infringement action existed in all four actions in question, and where such questions were sufficiently complex, coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings were warranted, without prejudice to subsequent separation and remanding of antitrust claims to court of origin prior to completion of pretrial proceedings.
In re Carrom Trademark Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1016 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Trade secret actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Actions by employer against former employees alleging use of and conspiracy to use trade secrets in competition with employer would not be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where former employees were employed by employer at different times in different capacities and were exposed to different portions of employer's alleged trade secrets, which would focus discovery on an individualized basis, and contracts not to compete or disclose confidential information that employer had with the former employees varied markedly from individual to individual.
In re Trade Secrets in Mfg. High Molecular Weight Polyethylene, 339 F. Supp. 1276 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Trust actions, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where actions filed by investor protective league against indenture trustees of debentures of collapsed corporation alleging that trustees violated fiduciary duties to protect right of bondholders did raise questions of fact common to the other numerous civil actions which involved in some respect alleged fraud, parties to action against indenture trustees would to some extent benefit from participation in the coordinated or consolidated pretrial programs and the actions would be transferred.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions transfer warranted, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Transfer of 10 actions, pending in four districts, involving allegations that an oral erectile dysfunction (ED) drug caused or increased the risk of developing melanoma, to the Northern District of California, for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in previously-created docket involving similar allegations against a different ED drug, was warranted; the ten actions shared questions of fact with the previously-transferred actions, including general causation questions as well as the likelihood of overlapping discovery, common expert witness issues, and duplicative pretrial motions, and transfers would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Viagra (Sildenafil Citrate) Products Liability Litigation, 224 F. Supp. 3d 1330 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in actions in multidistrict litigation challenging as false and misleading the labeling and advertising of a brand of cigarettes as “natural” and “additive free”; actions involved complex common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, particularly with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in putative nationwide class actions, pending in seven districts, arising from allegations that manufacturer violated its customers' privacy rights by installing software on certain television sets that allowed it to collect viewing data and share it with third parties; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Vizio, Inc., Consumer Privacy Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of 63 actions pending in various districts to Northern District of California for centralized pretrial proceedings was warranted, where actions involved common questions of fact arising from allegations that car manufacturer and its related companies sold vehicles with engines that contained software that enabled vehicles to engage emissions controls only when the vehicles underwent official testing, while at other times the engines emitted nitrous oxide well in excess of legal limits, and centralization in District of Northern District of California, where 30 actions were pending, including first-filed action, would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving resources of parties, counsel, and judiciary.
In re Volkswagen “Clean Diesel” Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of litigation involving four anti-diabetic medications that allegedly caused pancreatic cancer was warranted, where plaintiffs made highly similar allegations about each of four drugs and propensity of those drugs to cause pancreatic cancer, several plaintiffs took more than one of drugs at issue, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re: Incretin Mimetics Products Liability Litigation, 968 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2953

Inclusion of 11 actions and 18 potentially-related actions, pending in two districts and alleging unlawful conspiracies to inflate, fix, raise, maintain, or artificially stabilize prices of certain automobile components, in previously-created multidistrict litigation docket, rather than creation of three new such dockets separate kinds of components, was warranted; including all the actions in the already-created docket would lead to the most efficient handling of the cases, since similar conspiracies were alleged involving overlapping defendants and stemming from the same government investigation, the parties and counsel overlapped to a large extent, and the actions involved common questions of fact with the previously-transferred actions and transfer would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re: Automotive Wire Harness Systems Antitrust Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that defendants' sales of gift certificates/vouchers violated the federal Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility, and Disclosure Act as incorporated in the Electronic Funds Transfer Act, as well as state consumer protection laws; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and would eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, including with respect to class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: LivingSocial Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 807 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted in actions, under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), alleging failure to perform due diligence prior to investments of funds; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Rye Select Broad Market Prime Fund Securities & Employee Retirement Income Sec. Act (ERISA) Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1385 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2951

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 19 actions and two potential tag-along actions, pending in five districts, alleging that financial institution concealed its undercapitalization from investors in order to raise capital; 15 of the actions were already pending in the district, and many of the corporate defendants were headquartered there.
In re Fannie Mae Securities and Employee Retirement Income Sec. Act (ERISA) Litigation, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2957

Centralized pretrial proceedings were warranted in five actions and three potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts and alleging a global conspiracy to fix prices, rig bids, and allocate markets for marine hoses and related products; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Marine Hose Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 531 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Actions alleging that motor vehicle manufacturer failed to disclose and fraudulently concealed vehicles' defective speedometers involved common questions of fact, and thus centralization of litigation for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was warranted, where centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, avoid inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re: General Motors Corp. Speedometer Products Liability Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization was warranted, of 18 actions and two potential tag-along actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that certain of defendants' employees were entitled to compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Tyson Foods, Inc., 502 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization was warranted in actions alleging breaches of company's fiduciary duties in connection with management of its 401(k) plan subsequent to its bankruptcy and sale; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was desirable to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Standard Automotive Corp. Retiree Benefits ”ERISA” Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Separation of claims, in three actions in multidistrict litigation, relating to one prescription medication from those relating to two other medications, and transfer of the actions for inclusion in ongoing coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings involving those respective medications, was warranted; actions involved questions of fact in common with the ongoing litigations, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Vioxx Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings, of actions alleging failure, by the manufacturer of an erectile dysfunction medication, to disclose an alleged risk of non-anteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Viagra Products Liability Litigation, 414 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of three actions in multidistrict litigation, alleging that bank failed to properly disclose that a fee would be charged to its customers who used its automatic teller machine (ATM), was warranted; actions shared factual questions, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Bank of America ATM Fee Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of putative class actions brought against razor manufacturer was appropriate; actions shared factual questions regarding whether manufacturer misrepresented certain aspects of its razor system during advertising of the product, including its claim that the system lifted individual hairs before they were cut, and centralization was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, especially with respect to questions of class certification, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re M3Power Razor System Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization was warranted, of two putative class actions and two potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning the financial condition of a company; actions shared common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Rhodia S.A., Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of 14 actions and 21 potential tag-along actions, alleging that credit card companies' imposition of a no-surcharge rule and/or establishment of an interchange fee caused the merchant discount fee to be set at supracompetitive levels in violation of federal antitrust laws; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings involving Iraqi and Afghan detainees who brought four separate actions against United States, alleging unlawful conditions of detention by military, would be properly transferred to District of Columbia district court; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would have served convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, and District of Columbia provided appropriate forum for action.
In re Iraq and Afghanistan Detainees Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of eight actions and three potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that manager of pharmaceutical benefits unlawfully enriched itself through, among other things, undisclosed dealings with pharmacies and drug manufacturers; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Express Scripts, Inc., Pharmacy Benefits Management Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of four actions, pending in three districts, alleging that mortgage lenders conspired with mortgage broker to include certain undisclosed fees and costs in residential mortgage settlements; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Community Bank of Northern Virginia Mortgage Lending Practices Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of two actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that mortgage company violated Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act by its payment and/or non-disclosure of mortgage settlement/referral fees paid to its unlicensed limited liability corporations; actions involved common questions of fact and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Novastar Home Mortgage Inc. Mortgage Lending Practices Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in 14 actions in multidistrict litigation, alleging ERISA violations; all actions shared factual questions arising from allegations that drug manufacturer misrepresented and/or concealed safety risks of drug, and that this conduct affected manufacturer's financial condition, such that all actions could be expected to focus on significant number of common events, defendants, and/or witnesses.
In re Merck & Co., Inc., Securities, Derivative & ERISA Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, of 13 actions and 10 potential tag-along actions arising out of an alleged test scoring anomaly which caused schoolchildren to receive incorrect non-passing scores, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Educational Testing Service PLT 7-12 Test Scoring Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of eight actions in multidistrict litigation arising out of airline's failure to provide air transportation for ticket holders, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Nigeria Charter Flights Contract Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, of five actions involving factual questions arising out of the sale of a company's subordinated notes, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Thaxton Group Inc. Securities Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of five actions in multidistrict litigation, brought by Department of Labor (DOL) and alleging that defendant pension plans and their trustees had violated Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), was warranted; all actions shared factual questions arising out of investments in particular limited liability corporation's collateralized note program, and thus centralization was necessary in order to avoid duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent or repetitive pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Capital Consultants, LLC, ERISA Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1385 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of nine actions from California, Illinois, and Connecticut was warranted pursuant to statute governing multidistrict litigation, in that all actions shared factual questions arising from allegations that bank and other defendants engaged in unfair loan servicing or debt collection practices in violation of Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA), Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), Truth-in-Lending Act (TILA), Fair Credit Billing Act, Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), and state consumer protection or unfair trade practices statutes, or were liable under common-law theories, making centralization necessary to avoid duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent or repetitive pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Ocwen Federal Bank FSB Mortgage Servicing Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of two actions and seven potential tag-along actions alleging that internet service provider created unauthorized accounts for certain of its subscribers, charging them additional subscription fees and conspiring to prevent them from obtaining refunds for the unauthorized charges, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re America Online Spin-Off Accounts Litigation, 310 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation alleging that accounting irregularities at Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) resulted in understatement of earnings for fiscal years 2000 through 2003; actions shared common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Federal Home Loan Mort. Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation (No. II), 303 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, of 22 actions and 22 potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging failure to adequately warn of the danger to persons exposed to respirable silica products; actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Silica Products Liability Litigation, 280 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation, centralization for pretrial proceedings, of ten actions alleging an unlawful conspiracy to prevent new motor vehicles sold in Canada from being imported into the United States, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re New Motor Vehicles Canadian Export Antitrust Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Common questions of fact were involved in 23 actions filed against promoter, alleging nationwide investment scheme to defraud investors in commercial equipment leases, as would support centralization of the actions in multidistrict litigation; all the actions involved issues of validity or continuing validity of underlying leases and enforceability of surety bonds or insurance policies, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery, conserve resources, and prevent inconsistent rulings.
In re Commercial Money Center, Inc., Equipment Lease Litigation, 229 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of actions arising from discovery of human remains on land near a crematorium in Georgia, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was warranted; plaintiffs in different proceedings commonly alleged that certain defendants misrepresented that they were properly cremating bodies when instead they were concealing human remains and that funeral services defendants failed to inspect, monitor, or supervise, and centralization would eliminate duplicative discovery and facilitate coordination with related state court actions.
In re Tri-State Crematory Lit., 206 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2951

Credit card holders' separate class actions would be transferred to the Central District of California, where actions shared sufficient complex common questions of fact as to whether credit card company imposed excessive finance charges and late fees on payments received on specified “due date” but after specified cutoff time; centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, avoid duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and judiciary.
In re Capital One Bank Credit Card Terms Litigation, 201 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Multiple actions alleging defects in hair straightener products were properly consolidated and centralized in the geographically central Eastern District of Michigan where six actions were already pending; all actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings and conserve resources of parties, counsel and judiciary.
In re Rio Hair Naturalizer Products Liability Litigation, 904 F. Supp. 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1995).
Federal Civil Procedure  8

Where, in each action which charged different candidates for public office and their campaign committees with accepting from affiliated labor organizations political contributions which exceeded maximum contribution permitted the key factual inquiry under the Federal Election Campaign Act, section 431 et seq. of Title 2, would focus upon structure of the AFL-CIO and the activities of its officials to determine whether commonly-established, financed, maintained or controlled political activities of its member labor organizations, actions would be centralized in the District of Columbia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Federal Election Campaign Act Litigation, 511 F. Supp. 821 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Seven class actions pending in three Texas districts and challenging limitation of V.T.C.A. Education Code § 21.031 of free public education to citizens and legally admitted aliens would be transferred to Southern District of Texas for consolidated and coordinated pretrial proceedings with respect to actions against Texas education agency, in view of common questions of fact, but, with respect to actions against individual school districts, each of which had their own implementing rules so that there were no common questions of fact, actions would be severed and not transferred.
In re Alien Children Ed. Litigation, 482 F. Supp. 326 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Nineteen actions, which were pending in four districts, and which each challenged same United States Department of Energy regulation, raised common questions of fact, and thus centralization under this section of all actions would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Dept. of Energy Stripper Well Exemption Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 1282 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Thirty actions, each pending in a different federal district, brought by physicians allegedly qualified to practice naturopathy, students thereof and persons either receiving or desiring to receive such treatment and others against various federal agencies as well as state and county defendants challenging constitutionality of statutes and regulations allegedly restricting, practice of naturopathy involved common questions of fact, and their transfer to the district of Maryland for coordinated or consolidated pretrial procedures would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Effect of antibiotic drugs upon animals and poultry was sufficiently factually related to human consumption cases to justify transfer of agricultural cases to court handling human consumption cases for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceeding.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 303 F. Supp. 1056 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

Where book publishers had brought actions in diverse federal district courts to enjoin Postmaster General and local postmasters from enforcing certain postal regulations, and resolution of constitutional issues presented would require determination of common underlying facts, many of which could be obtained from Post Office Department [now United States Postal Service] officials, and motions for preliminary injunctions suspending enforcement of regulations during pendency of litigation had been granted in some districts and denied in others, transfers should be ordered for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Fourth Class Postage Regulations, 298 F. Supp. 1326 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions transfer not warranted, facts, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization was not warranted in three separate doctoral program actions and a potential tag-along action arising from alleged misrepresentations in regards to a doctoral program, even though the actions involved common factual issues; there were only three actions and one pending tag-along action, one of the actions was an individual pro se action, two of the actions were brought by plaintiffs who were represented by common counsel, and defendants' pending motions under the first-to-file rule in one action and the tag-along action that was pending in the District of Minnesota carried the potential to streamline the litigation without resort to centralization.
In re Walden University, LLC, Doctoral Program Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was not warranted in 15 actions and multiple current and potential tag-along actions arising from allegations in products liability actions that taking proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) could have resulted in various types of kidney injury, even though the actions shared certain factual issues; the named defendants varied from action to action, the defendants were competitors, a significant amount of discovery appeared almost certain to be defendant specific, the actions involved different medications, and the motion encompassed only 15 cases and 24 tag-alongs.
In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was not warranted in six actions pending in four federal districts brought against the alleged promoters and organizers of a music festival arising from the festival's cancellation, even though the actions shared common factual questions, where there was a small number of actions, the common defendants did not enter an appearance in any action or in the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation proceedings and default proceedings against them commenced in two of the actions, just one common defendant was likely to appear in the actions, the remaining defendants that appeared to date were sued solely in one action, and thus the actions required little, if any, coordination between them.
In re Fyre Festival Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization was not warranted for eight actions pending in five districts, alleging violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) based on debt collector's use of an automatic dialing system to repeatedly make debt collection calls to plaintiffs' cell phones without their express consent; although actions shared common factual issues, they appeared to be relatively straightforward, discovery was unlikely to be unusually burdensome or time-consuming, and since two of the actions were set to close soon, centralization was unlikely to result in substantial efficiencies.
In re Credit Protection Association, L.P., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1342 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization of three actions, pending in three districts, arising out of allegations that a common insurance company denied coverage of insurance claims, was not warranted; the actions involved no common factual issues aside from broad fact that, in each action, a common insurance company had denied coverage of an insurance claim, and movant failed to specifically identify any discovery that would be common to the actions other than such evidence as “underwriting files” or “all writing correspondence,” which would be far too broad to provide a basis for centralization.
In re: The Great West Casualty Company Insurance Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization in District of Massachusetts was not warranted with respect to arrestee's pro se actions against federal government and officers, which were pending in Districts of Massachusetts and New Hampshire in connection with arrest for making false claim of citizenship; motion encompassed only two actions, common factual issues were limited and not particularly complex, and each action involved a number of unique defendants and allegations, such that informal cooperation and coordination on the part of the involved parties and courts were both practicable and preferable.
In re Mohammed Ahmed Hassan Abdallah Omran Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1334 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfers, for centralized pretrial proceedings, of multiple actions and multiple potential tag-along actions, all pending in federal District Courts in State of California, was not warranted, even though the actions all involved the application to various retailers of a ruling by the California Supreme Court regarding a California statute; although the cases involved common factual and legal issues, they appeared to be relatively straightforward, and preferable alternatives to centralization were available.
In re: Best Buy Co., Inc., California Song-Beverly Credit Card Act Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2953

Claims in Northern District of Alabama action relating to the conduct of the Corps of Engineers regarding the flow of water in the Alabama, Coosa, and Tallapoosa (ACT) River basin did not share sufficient questions of fact with claims, arising in multidistrict litigation, relating to the flow of water in the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint (ACF) River basin to warrant inclusion of the action in centralized pretrial proceedings involving the ACF basin.
In re Tri-State Water Rights Litigation, 481 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

Inclusion, in centralized pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation arising out of allegations of failure to provide adequate warnings as to possible side-effects of two drugs, was not warranted for case involving claims regarding a different drug; that case did not share sufficient questions of fact with the claims in the other cases.
In re Celexa and Lexapro Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of 23 actions pending in two districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, given that pretrial proceedings had been ongoing for over four years in the district in which 22 of the actions were pending.
In re Qwest Communications International, Inc., Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of three actions pending in two districts, was not warranted; centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, inasmuch as any common questions of fact and law were not sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, and alternatives to transfer existed that could minimize possibilities of duplicative discovery and/or inconsistent pretrial rulings.
In re Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Patent Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in seven actions and two potential tag-along actions against a package delivery service, pending in nine districts, was not warranted; there were no common questions of fact and law sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, such that centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and some of the constituent actions had been pending for over two years.
In re FedEx Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of two actions, pending in two districts, was not warranted; absent any common questions of fact and law sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous to justify transfer, centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Bally Total Fitness Holding Corp. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Notwithstanding numerosity of actions, transfer to centralize 28 actions brought against healthcare providers in 21 districts would neither serve convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further just and efficient conduct of litigation, and thus was not warranted, given movants' failure to show that actions shared sufficient common questions of fact to justify transfer.
In re Not-For-Profit Hospitals/Uninsured Patients Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization of five actions pending in three districts was not warranted; actions did not share sufficient common questions of fact to warrant transfer and centralization would not serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses or further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Midpoint Development, LLC, Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Interests, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel declined to transfer action initiated in Eastern District of Kentucky by trustee in corporation's pending bankruptcy proceeding under § 501 et seq. of Title 11 to Southern District of Ohio, where actions were pending by Securities and Exchange Commission for injunctive relief to prevent further alleged security laws violations and by investors' in corporation on behalf of all investors, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where actions sought to protect markedly different interests, requested different relief, and were at different stages of development.
In re Harmony Loan Co., Inc. Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: Law questions, commonality of actions—Generally

para.paratext:
Where common factual issues exist among actions in multidistrict litigation, the presence of different legal theories among the subject actions is not a bar to centralization.
In re: Bank of New York Mellon Corp. Foreign Exchange Transactions Litigation., 857 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of actions for consolidated pretrial proceedings is unwarranted where questions of law rather than common questions of fact are significantly preponderant.
In re U. S. Navy Variable Reenlistment Bonus Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Where the commonality between or among actions rests solely on questions of law, transfer of actions for consolidated pretrial proceedings would be inappropriate.
In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

This section providing for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in case of multidistrict litigation requires existence of common questions of fact but not common questions of law.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Huntington, W. Va. on November 14, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

This section does not authorize the transfer of cases (for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings) which only share common questions of law, rather than common questions of fact.
In re Air Fare Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1013 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Damages, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Since actions shared few, if any, questions of fact, but involved only common question of law pertaining to measure of damages applicable for partial loss with respect to released value of shipments, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was inappropriate in connection with three pending actions against a number of motor carriers and freight forwarders.
In re American Home Products Corp “Released Value” Claims Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 276 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Theory of actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
For purposes of determining whether four actions pending in four districts should be transferred to any one district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, pursuant to this section governing multidistrict litigation, the presence of different legal theories in some of actions with regard to alleged liability of each defendant did not negate existence of common questions of fact regarding cause or causes of airplane crash and attendant circumstances, given fact that all four actions arose from same airplane accident.
In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Six actions pending in three districts to recover from, among others, vessel owner, builder and charterer for environmental damage and economic loss sustained when vessel broke up off the coast of France and disgorged cargo of crude oil were ordered transferred to Northern District of Illinois, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, with limitation of liability proceeding pending in that district, notwithstanding presence of different legal theories, since actions involved common questions of fact, many documents and witnesses were located at limitation plaintiffs' office in transferee district and related actions were pending in Illinois state courts.
In re Oil Spill by “Amoco Cadiz” Off Coast of France on March 16, 1978, 471 F. Supp. 473 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

For purpose of determining whether consolidated pretrial proceeding was proper, in multidistrict litigation arising out of airplane crash, the fact that there were differing legal theories with regard to the alleged liability of aircraft manufacturer, airline and for individual defendants did not negate the existence of common questions of fact regarding the cause of the crash and the attendant circumstances.
In re Air Crash Disaster in Ionian Sea on September 8, 1974, 438 F. Supp. 932 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Mere fact that divergent legal theories are asserted arising out of the same substantive claims and allegations presents no bar to transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Air West, Inc. Securities Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 609 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2951

Where it appeared that legal theory and factual basis of student's action would rest on individual conduct of personnel in stockbroker's office, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with various actions by stockholders alleging violations of federal securities laws by corporate officers, directors, underwriter and others appeared inappropriate.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 331 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2957

Applicability of different legal principles will not prevent transfer of action to another United States district court for purpose of consolidation with other proceedings if the requisite common questions of fact exist.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 309 F. Supp. 155 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

Different legal theories present no bar to transfer of multidistrict civil actions for consolidated pretrial proceedings, where common questions of fact are present.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Class actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Law of transferor circuit controlled when considering motion for class certification in case transferred under multi-district statute, since question of whether to certify action on behalf of class was not merely pretrial issue; requirements of class certification were inherently enmeshed with considerations of trial and authority of transferee court in multi-district proceeding ended once pretrial proceedings were completed.
In re Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE) Products Liability Litigation, 241 F.R.D. 185 (S.D. N.Y. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Multidistrict class actions, attacking constitutionality of statutes establishing and providing for administration of pension funds for policemen and firemen in Cities of Houston, Dallas, San Antonio, El Paso and New Orleans, would not be transferred to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where such actions predominantly involved questions of law, and where transfer would neither serve convenience of parties and witnesses nor promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Pension Fund Class Action Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Presence of different legal theories regarding alleged liability of each defendant in some of the actions arising out of crash of private plane did not negate existence of common questions of fact regarding cause or causes of crash and attendant circumstances so as to preclude transfer of actions to single district for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Air Crash at Schenley Golf Course, Pittsburgh, Pa., on August 21, 1977, 509 F. Supp. 252 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2955

Airline's third-party claims against federal government would be transferred for pretrial proceedings with passenger claims arising out of air crash disaster, notwithstanding there were admittedly different questions of law involved in the two categories of claims, where both types of claims involved common factual background concerning events surrounding crash and would benefit from assignment to a single judge.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Huntington, W. Va. on November 14, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where defendant in licensing agent's patent infringement suit raised same issues of collateral estoppel, patent validity and enforceability as were raised by defendants in other actions, which such agent brought against other alleged infringers of same patent and which were transferred to Western District of Pennsylvania for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, transfer of such suit to such district for such pretrial proceedings was warranted, though discovery with regard to the alleged infringement was not common to the other actions.
In re Suess Patent Infringement Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

Where there was common legal question as to whether plaintiff had title to patents on which he sued in three patent infringement, unfair competition and breach of contract actions filed in two districts which could only be resolved by discovery of common set of facts involving effect of plaintiff's original contractual agreement, return by one of defendants of patents to plaintiff and its formal reassignment of patents to plaintiff, the three actions were appropriate for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and warranted transfer of Ohio action to Eastern District of Michigan, where the other cases were pending.
In re Willingham Patent, 322 F. Supp. 1019 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Transfer of product liability action to judicial district where other actions were pending, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, was not warranted, absent showing that any common questions of fact and law were sufficiently complex, unresolved and/or numerous.
In re Zimmer, Inc., 237 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Products liability action against manufacturer of a cellular plastic insulation material was not appropriate for transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with three other actions pending against the same manufacturer, despite contention that the actions shared questions of fact concerning, inter alia, flammability of the insulation, where discovery on the common questions of fact had been completed and parties had entered into stipulation whereby discovery could be made applicable to all four actions and plaintiff conceded that the only common matters left to be accomplished were questions of law.
In re Dow Chemical Co. “Polystyrene Foam” Products Liability Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1035 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where litigation concerning disputed stock ownership consisted of four actions pending in three districts, with one in the Western District of Oklahoma, two in the Eastern District of Louisiana, and one in the Northern District of Illinois, where each of the questions involved in the litigation was, at best, a mixed question of fact and of law, where legal aspects of questions predominated, where, apart from constitutionality of state statute, Illinois action shared no questions of fact with any other action in the litigation, and where common factual questions were not complex, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would deny motion to transfer actions to the Western District of Oklahoma for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action pending there.
In re Oklahoma Ins. Holding Co. Act Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 961 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, law questions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of nine pending actions challenging rules promulgated to interpret jurisdictional phrase “waters of the United States,” in the Clean Water Act, for centralized pretrial proceedings would not serve convenience of parties and witnesses or further just and efficient conduct of litigation, where resolution of actions would involve only very limited pretrial proceedings, discovery would be minimal, since actions would be decided on administrative record and turned on questions of law with respect to whether defendants exceeded their statutory and constitutional authority when they promulgated rules, and centralization would require transferee judge to navigate potentially uncharted waters with respect to law of the case.
In re Clean Water Rule: Definition of “Waters of the United States”, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1340 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Where nine separate actions seeking declaratory judgment that certain data which had been submitted to Environmental Protection Agency in connection with pesticide application was exempt from disclosure contained common questions of law but shared few, if any, questions of fact, transfer of such actions to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied.
In re Environmental Protection Agency Pesticide Listing Confidentiality Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1235 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953
