Where principal aspect which actions had in common was legal question of Federal Energy Administration's statutory authority to regulate natural gas liquids and such issue had already been resolved regarding Michigan actions, Oklahoma actions and one Texas action involved no other issues and remaining issues involved in other actions were predominantly unique to actions pending within each district, and there was no danger of conflicting appellate determinations on common legal questions, transfer of 11 actions challenging statutory authority of Federal Energy Administration to regulate natural gas liquids and/or requesting review of pricing and allocation orders for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was unwarranted.
In re Natural Gas Liquids Regulation Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 665 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Parties or witnesses, commonality of actions—Generally

para.paratext:
Centralization of actions in multidistrict litigation does not require a complete identity of parties.
In re: Bank of New York Mellon Corp. Foreign Exchange Transactions Litigation., 857 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2951

Fact that case might involve parties and issues not present in other actions pending in litigation was no obstacle to transfer of case for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 1077 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, parties or witnesses, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where all 11 defendants in one antitrust action were defendants in litigation which had been transferred to the District of Connecticut, where all of the defendants except for one favored transfer, and where there was great commonality of factual issues, the instant action would be transferred to the District of Connecticut for consolidated pretrial proceedings even though it was alleged that there were a great number of uncommon factual issues and that the market involved in the instant case was separate from the markets involved in the other antitrust cases with which it would be consolidated.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 249 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust actions filed by restaurant franchisees against franchisor would be transferred by the Judicial Panel to the Western District of Missouri for pretrial proceedings with other antitrust litigation brought against the same defendant by current or former franchisees of another restaurant chain, where it appeared that, though two different franchises were involved, the common defendants, the similarity of operating procedures and the possible overlap in defendants' supervisory personnel would certainly produce at least some common areas of discovery which would benefit from assignment to a single judge.
In re International House of Pancakes Franchise Litigation, 343 F. Supp. 948 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Twenty-three concrete pipe antitrust cases, filed in the Northern District of Texas and proceeding expeditiously in that district, were not ordered transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania where defendants in east of the Rockies concrete pipe cases were entirely different, there were no common witnesses and cases stemmed from different criminal proceedings and cases were also not ordered transferred to the Central District of California for coordination or consolidation with West Coast pipe cases even though Texas cases and West Coast cases involved several common defendants, some common witnesses and the potential for common discovery.
In re Texas Concrete Pipe, 302 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Bankruptcy proceedings, parties or witnesses, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel ordered transfer of three actions to district in which there was pending reorganization proceedings and numerous related actions for purpose of consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings, where the three actions involved parties which were all defendants in trustee's action and the three actions and the pending actions shared a great many common questions of fact.
In re Westec Corp., 307 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Civil rights actions—Parties or witnesses

para.paratext:
Where action which was brought in Texas against trucking companies and which was based on alleged discrimination in employment appeared to be entirely local in nature, where California action against other trucking companies contained only a few questions of fact which were in common with District of Columbia action brought by government against trucking companies, where there were close to four hundred defendants in the government's action, with only a handful of them being common to the California action, where only one defendant in the Texas action was common to the other two actions, motion of Texas plaintiffs to transfer the three actions to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied.
In re Trucking Industry Employment Practices Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 614 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Discrimination actions, parties or witnesses, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Where action which was brought in Texas against trucking companies and which was based on alleged discrimination in employment appeared to be entirely local in nature, where California action against other trucking companies contained only a few questions of fact which were in common with District of Columbia action brought by government against trucking companies, where there were close to four hundred defendants in the government's action, with only a handful of them being common to the California action, where only one defendant in the Texas action was common to the other two actions, motion of Texas plaintiffs to transfer the three actions to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would be denied.
In re Trucking Industry Employment Practices Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 614 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, parties or witnesses, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization was warranted for pretrial proceedings in 18 actions, pending in 10 districts, along with 49 potential tag-along actions, alleging that defects in defendants' hernia mesh product could lead to complications when implanted in patients; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Ethicon Physiomesh Flexible Composite Hernia Mesh Products Liability Litigation, 254 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Mere fact that, in addition to helicopter manufacturer which was defendant in all of the actions in question, manufacturer of helicopter's engines was a defendant in some of them did not warrant exclusion of the latter actions from coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where all actions in question involved key common factual questions concerning the causes of crash of the helicopter in Germany. In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, parties or witnesses, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of actions involving market timing and late trading allegations against six different families of mutual funds into single multidistrict docket, rather than centralization on a fund-by-fund basis, was appropriate; all the actions involved common questions of fact, and could be expected to focus on similar mutual fund trading practices and procedures with some common defendants or witnesses, regardless of whether they were brought by securities holders seeking relief under the federal securities laws or shareholders suing derivatively on behalf of the involved mutual funds.
In re Janus Mut. Funds Inv. Litigation, 310 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Four securities actions would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with two other securities actions, all involving the same defendant corporation among others, involving numerous common questions of fact concerning allegedly fraudulent activities that resulted in artificially inflating the value of the securities of such defendant corporation, and involving overlapping classes, though plaintiffs in two of the suits acquired their stock pursuant to merger and not on the open market.
In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Uranium Contract Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 990 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

In view of significant common questions of fact and number of common defendants which existed in actions instituted in the District Court of Massachusetts and in the Southern District of New York relating to alleged conspiratorial and fraudulent conduct of defendants in connection with securities transaction, Massachusetts action was transferred to the Southern District of New York for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceeding.
In re Haven Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 396 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Where three actions which were commenced against the same defendants in three federal district courts shared numerous complex factual questions concerning alleged violations of federal securities laws and where two of the actions were being processed on behalf of virtually the same class and it was likely that motions for partial dismissal and summary judgment grounded in part on a related state court proceeding would be filed in all three actions, transfer to the Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated discovery and other pretrial proceedings was warranted.
In re Transocean Tender Offer Securities Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 382 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings were required for actions against subsidiary corporations for fraud and deceit and violations of state and federal securities laws, and notwithstanding contention that each of subsidiaries operated independently, selling different products by different promotional methods and contracts, claims against subsidiaries would be transferred to single forum, where businesses conducted by subsidiaries were allegedly conceived and promoted by same individuals, the two subsidiaries allegedly had interlocking ownership and directors and parent corporation was defendant in all of actions.
In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 355 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2957

Fact that four mutual fund defendants in two security law actions were among parties in antitrust counts seeking recovery against investment advisers managing those funds, directors affiliated with funds and advisers, and others and that one of the alleged securities law violations was failure to disclose alleged antitrust violations was not a sufficient common factual background to tie the otherwise quite different groups of cases together for purpose of coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Kauffman Mut. Fund Actions, 337 F. Supp. 1337 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

Multidistrict derivative suits against acquiring and acquired corporation and individual defendants were transferred to Southern District of New York for consolidated pretrial proceedings where issue of whether acquisition was part of scheme to enrich insiders to detriment of general stockholders of both companies was central issue in one group of cases and of some importance in second group of cases arising out of same merger, and where one corporation was principal defendant in all action, and ten individuals were defendants in both groups of cases.
In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger, 312 F. Supp. 909 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, parties or witnesses, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Centralization of eleven actions, pending in ten districts, arising out of allegations that the defendant credit unions' assessment of overdraft fees was unlawful and contrary to defendants' member agreements and marketing materials, was not warranted; since each action was brought against a different credit union on behalf of a different class, such that there was no overlap among the plaintiffs, the defendants, or the putative classes, there appeared to be little or no risk of duplicative discovery or conflicting pretrial rulings on discovery disputes, class certification, or other matters, inasmuch as discovery in each action would be chiefly, if not entirely, unique to that action, the actions were brought under the laws of at least nine states, and to extent that discovery might overlap, informal coordination appeared practicable, especially since all plaintiffs were represented by the same two law firms., and there was a possibility that the scope and complexity of the proposed docket could expand beyond the bounds of manageability, given that it was unclear how many of the approximately 6,000 credit unions across the country utilized similar overdraft programs.
In re Credit Union Checking Account Overdraft Litigation, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1363 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Where action alleging failure of life insurance company's directors and officers to divulge material information to investing public differed from ten similar actions pending in other districts, in that only corporate rather than individual defendants were named, documents relied upon by plaintiffs to prove their claims were different from those relied upon in other litigations, plaintiffs relied on oral misrepresentations while other actions focused on alleged written misrepresentations, and action involved struggle for actual control of two insurance agencies which required substantial involvement by court in daily business operations of two agencies, action would remain in Eastern District of Michigan despite consolidation of ten other actions in Central District of California.
In re Pennsylvania Life Co. Securities Litigation, 389 F. Supp. 981 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Since action involving contractual dispute concerning sale of collapsed financial services corporation's debentures, based on claim that defendant breached contract to purchase debentures and misrepresented willingness to pay for them under all circumstances, clearly had nothing in common with other numerous actions arising out of collapse of corporation based in some respects on fraud, no purpose would be served by transfer of contractual dispute for consolidated pretrial proceedings and such action would remain in district in which it was instituted.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1378 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Miscellaneous actions, commonality of actions

para.paratext:
Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings of seven actions in multidistrict litigation was warranted; all actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary.
In re Global Crossing Ltd. Securities Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Nine actions against insurers and associations, arising out of allegations that the insurers engaged in a scheme to sell health insurance by fraudulently concealing their relationships to the associations, would be centralized in single district; each action sought to redress harm allegedly caused by the defendants in their sale of health insurance to the plaintiffs, including their failure to disclose relationships between certain of the defendants, and the allegations of wrongful conduct were substantially similar across all actions.
In re UICI “Ass'n Group” Ins. Litigation, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings was warranted, in multidistrict litigation involving actions alleging conspiracy to mislead with respect to the financial stability of certain insurance companies providing professional malpractice coverage, despite differences in the putative classes among the actions; actions shared factual questions arising from substantially similar relationships and transactions, and centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Reciprocal of America (ROA) Sales Practices Litigation, 281 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization for pretrial proceedings of six out of seven pending actions, to resolve appeals affecting water rights in the Missouri River Basin states, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact concerning the conduct of the Army Corps of Engineers vis-a-vis the flow of the River, such that centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and a settlement had been reached in the seventh action which would not affect the interests of the other parties not involved in that action.
In re Operation of Missouri River System Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of 23 actions in multidistrict litigation against a railroad involved in a derailment, was warranted; actions shared common questions of fact as to causes of the derailment and any liability resulting therefrom, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses, promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was desirable in order to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re Train Derailment Near Amite, LA, on October 12, 2002, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Consolidation and centralization for pretrial proceedings, of 16 actions against energy company, was warranted in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentation or omissions regarding operations and business prospects; centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation by eliminating duplicative discovery, preventing inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserving resources, inasmuch as actions involved common events, defendants, and witnesses.
In re Xcel Energy, Inc., 254 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of multiple product liability class actions against automobile manufacturer was warranted in order to permit coordinated pretrial proceedings, based on existence of common questions of fact and consequent likelihood of duplication of discovery and inconsistent or repetitive pretrial rulings; all actions focused on allegations that vertical behind-axle fuel tank in particular model used by various police forces resulted in increased risk of injury or death from fuel-fed fire in event of rear-end collision, and all actions were brought by counties, municipalities and other political subdivisions.
In re Ford Motor Co. Crown Victoria Police Interceptor Products Liability Litigation, 229 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

Private antitrust case against manufacturer of asphalt composition used for tennis courts was unrelated to private antitrust actions involving liquid asphalt used in highway construction and case would not be consolidated with highway liquid asphalt antitrust cases pending in Northern District of California.
In re Western Liquid Asphalt, 309 F. Supp. 157 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, shared allegations

para.paratext:
Centralization of pretrial proceedings was warranted in six separate marketing, sales practices, and products liability actions, and 14 potential tag-along actions, which alleged that certain vehicles were equipped with emissions-cheating devices that engaged emissions controls only when emissions testing was being performed; the actions shared factual allegations arising out of announcements by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Board that they issued notices of violation to a defendant, plaintiffs' complaints contended that a defendant marketed many of the vehicles at issue as environmentally friendly, and plaintiffs' complaints shared allegations that defendants employed software to make the vehicles EPA compliant only during emissions testing.
In re Chrysler-Dodge-Jeep EcoDiesel Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2956

Consolidation of pretrial proceedings was not warranted in 16 actions and potential tag-along actions brought in six federal districts arising from products liability allegations that heating and cooling systems contained defects that made the devices susceptible to bacterial colonization to which patients were exposed during surgery, even if the actions shared allegations; any overlapping pretrial proceedings were and could continue to be handled through informal coordination, 10 of the actions were pending before a single judge in one district and were brought by just two groups of plaintiffs' counsel, four of the remaining actions were brought by the same counsel, and not a single party to any of the six actions pending outside of the moving plaintiffs' district supported centralization.
In re Sorin 3T Heater-Cooler System Products Liability Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: SELECTION OF TRANSFEREE DISTRICT
Advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
One factor to be considered by the Judicial Panel in the selection of a transferee district is whether the pretrial proceedings in the action or actions in a particular forum are significantly more advanced than those in any of the actions in the other jurisdictions.
In re L. E. Lay & Co. Antitrust Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 1054 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Eastern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for six actions and 52 potential tag-along actions, pending in eight districts, concerning the cause or causes of the mid-air collision of two aircraft in Brazil; the first two filed actions were pending in that district, and were procedurally more advanced than the actions pending elsewhere.
In re Air Crash Near Peixoto De Azeveda, Brazil on September 29, 2006, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2955

The District of Columbia was preferable transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings of various actions arising out of airplane crash, where discovery schedule in District of Columbia action was most advanced, judge in such district had developed familiarity with litigation as result of pretrial proceedings that had already been conducted in action before him, and records maintained by Federal Aviation Administration pertaining to evaluation of plane, its engines and propellers prior to issuance of airworthiness certificate, and records pertaining to investigation of crash conducted by National Transportation Safety Board, were located in District of Columbia.
In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict federal actions arising out of crash of commercial aircraft in Alaska would be transferred to the Northern District of California in which six actions had been filed and discovery had been completed, over government's request that actions be transferred to the District of Alaska where several actions had been filed and the electronic equipment and personnel involved in the events surrounding the crash were located.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Juneau, Alaska on September 4, 1971, 350 F. Supp. 1163 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
District of New Jersey was appropriate forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 19 actions and 27 potential tag-along actions, pending in various districts, alleging that defendants conspired to fix prices, conspired to circumvent competitive bidding and independent pricing, and committed other anticompetitive practices designed to unlawfully fix, raise, maintain and stabilize the prices at which liquid aluminum sulfate was sold in the U.S. over a 13-year period, in violation of the Sherman Act; several defendants were located in or near the District, including defendants named in most actions, such that relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be found there, a related criminal action was pending in the District, and a majority of the constituent actions were already pending there.
In re Liquid Aluminum Sulfate Antitrust Litigation, 159 F. Supp. 3d 1382 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would centralize seven antitrust actions which raised common questions of fact regarding defendants' conduct with respect to acquisition of stock, and would transfer litigation to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding, since pretrial proceedings in New York actions were somewhat ahead of pretrial proceedings in Rhode Island actions, New York City was where negotiations among defendant occurred, and where many documents and witnesses relevant to litigation could be found, and New York forum was choice of plaintiffs in four of seven actions and all of defendants, including defendants who were headquartered or resided in or near Rhode Island.
In re Amtel, Inc. Securities Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 466 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Private civil antitrust class actions, pertaining to an alleged conspiracy to fix prices of electrical wiring devices, pending in six districts would be ordered transferred to the Eastern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with the actions pending there, since, inter alia, pretrial proceedings in the actions in the Eastern District of New York were relatively advanced in comparison to the status of other actions in this litigation.
In re Wiring Device Antitrust Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 1348 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Two private antitrust actions instituted in the District of Nevada and the Southern District of Florida were transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with seven other private antitrust actions and an action by the Securities and Exchange Commission since all of the complaints, which involved acquisition of Nevada hotel-gambling casino, presented common questions of fact, discovery in New York actions was more advanced than in any other action and most of the parties, potential witnesses and relevant documents were located in that district.
In re Caesar's Palace Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1256 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Common questions of fact concerning alleged pyramidal recruiting and marketing techniques of common defendant in general securities and antitrust actions and similar class allegations of nationwide groups of common defendant's distributors warranted transfer of actions for purpose of discovery to single district where discovery had progressed further than in any of other actions and where a great number of relevant documents were located.
In re Bestline Products Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Complaints in multidistrict securities and antitrust actions raised common questions of fact encompassing same transactions as were involved in cases presently pending in Eastern District of Pennsylvania and actions would be transferred to that district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in order to avoid repetition of discovery already accomplished as well as duplication of anticipated discovery.
In re Pittsburgh & L. E. R. Co. Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Two antitrust treble damages class actions filed, respectively, in the Southern District of New York and the Southern District of Florida would not be transferred to the Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with an antitrust suit filed there by the United States, since, though Los Angeles was defendant's corporate headquarters, relevant documents were located in various regional headquarters of defendant throughout the United States, and since little, if any, discovery had been had in the California action; instead, the New York action would be transferred to the Southern District of Florida, since pretrial proceedings were further advanced there and transfer would result in the expeditious development of both cases without duplication of effort.
In re Nissan Motor Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 960 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2954

Action commenced in Southern District of New York would on defense motion be transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with case pending there, since, though there were no common defendants in the actions, the complaints of the common plaintiff were substantially similar and involved legality of same type of licensing agreements and since, considering fact that judge to whom Philadelphia case was assigned had already disposed of several questions likely to recur in New York action, transfer was likely to produce substantial savings of time and effort and would result in minimal inconvenience to parties.
In re CBS Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 511 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict civil actions involving alleged multistate combination and conspiracy within ticket industry were transferred to Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where all ten defendants were named in cases pending in that district and two of the remaining seven active cases were located in that district and one of those two cases was only one in which meaningful discovery had occurred and judge had been assigned in that case for all purposes and the case was larger in amount of damages than aggregate of cases pending in other two districts.
In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

Multidistrict civil antitrust actions involving antibiotic drug tetracycline were transferred under this section, to Southern District of New York for pretrial proceedings where pretrial processes in the 16 actions assigned to a judge in that district were further advanced than in any other action, and collection in that district of relevant data and documentary information on issues common to actions was substantially greater than in any other district.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 295 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict plumbing fixture private antitrust cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Eastern District of Pennsylvania, where two cases in that district were fairly representative of litigation and judge of that district had actively conducted pretrial proceedings and had adopted comprehensive discovery schedule and as result of intervention the two actions in that district involved more claims for relief than were involved in any other district.
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 295 F. Supp. 33 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Copyright actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Where, inter alia, copyright infringement actions which were pending in four different districts focused on a single allegedly infringing motion picture, and questions of fact common to all actions necessitated transfer to prevent duplication of discovery, to eliminate possibility of inconsistent pretrial rulings and to conserve judicial effort, actions were transferred to district where action pending was considerably more advanced and where district judge had become acquainted with issues and was in best position to supervise pretrial proceedings.
In re “The Exorcist” Copyright Infringement Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 793 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Eastern District of Missouri was appropriate transferee district for centralized patent infringement actions dealing with validity of two complex pharmaceutical patents; district was the location of the first-filed action and pretrial proceedings were already well under way, and it was an accessible, metropolitan district that was well equipped with the resources that the docket was likely to require.
In re Metoprolol Succinate Patent Litigation, 329 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2956

Multidistrict actions for patent infringement would be transferred to most appropriate transferee district wherein extensive discovery had already been conducted and wherein some tentative findings on issue of patent validity had been made, in view of fact that key issue in each action was whether patent could withstand charges of invalidity, despite contention that, since motions to dismiss had been filed in several actions, question of transfer was premature.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 794 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

Even though transferee district might not have been one chosen at outset of litigation, and was not particularly convenient, that district was only practical transferee forum for multidistrict litigation in view of advanced state of discovery in several actions pending there and judge's familiarity with litigation.
In re Frost Patent, 316 F. Supp. 977 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

Multidistrict patent infringement action against manufacturer of alleged infringing device, two wholesalers or jobbers and six retailers was ordered transferred for coordinated consolidated pretrial proceedings to the District of Maryland where actions against wholesalers/jobbers and manufacturer were pending and pretrial proceedings were somewhat advanced.
In re Kaehni Patent, 311 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Pension actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Northern District of Texas was appropriate transferee forum for centralized actions alleging that company breached its fiduciary duties, under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), by continuing to offer its stock as part of its retirement plans; three of the four actions were pending in that district, and documents and witnesses were likely to be found there, since company was headquartered there.
In re Radioshack Corp. “ERISA” Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

Where actions shared common questions of fact that were predominant, transfer would eliminate possibility of overlapping or inconsistent class determinations by courts of coordinate jurisdiction, and pretrial proceedings in New Jersey action appeared to be more advanced than those in Missouri action; Missouri action brought by retirement fund participants questioning legality of proposed plan of termination of fund would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with New Jersey action brought by insurer which issued group annuity contract to fund retirement plan and which served as fiduciary thereof for judgment declaring proper disposition of actuarial surplus upon termination of fund.
In re Litigation Arising from Termination of Retirement Plan for Emp. of Fireman's Fund Ins. Co., 422 F. Supp. 287 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Western District of Washington was clearly the most appropriate transferee forum for multidistrict litigation where pretrial proceedings in actions consolidated in that district were further advanced than those in Missouri action and where parties favoring transfer agreed that Washington District was more convenient for majority of parties and witnesses.
In re Boise Cascade Securities Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 459 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, advanced stage of pretrial proceedings, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
In light of the advanced stage of pretrial proceedings in two actions alleging misrepresentations in the design, marketing and sale of life insurance policies used to fund defined benefit pension plans for small businesses, and failure to disclose that such policies might be deemed by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to be invalid tax shelters, their inclusion in centralized proceedings was not warranted; their inclusion would not serve convenience of the parties and witnesses or promote just and efficient conduct of the actions or the litigation as a whole.
In re: Indianapolis Life Ins. Co. I.R.S. 412(I) Plans Life Ins. Marketing Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2951

Centralization, of 22 actions, pending in two districts, was not warranted; in light of the fact that proceedings in one of the districts were at a very advanced stage, centralization would neither serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses nor further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Zimmer, Inc., Centralign Hip Prosthesis Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 366 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

In multidistrict litigation in which seven actions and 18 potential tag-along actions, alleging questions concerning the disclosure and/or propriety of line-item fees charged by wireless telephone service providers, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Western District of Missouri was appropriate; district was site of the furthest advanced action, included the headquarters of a principal defendant, such that significant discovery was likely to take place there, and district was accessible and geographically central.
In re Wireless Telephone Federal Cost Recovery Fees Litigation, 293 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

In view of facts that over half of cases had their situs in District of New Jersey, that a substantial amount of discovery had been completed in case which was pending there, that Chief Judge of District of New Jersey, to whom all New Jersey cases had been assigned, was familiar with litigation, and that much of discovery would take place in Washington, D.C., District of New Jersey was district to which actions pending in other districts should be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Fourth Class Postage Regulations, 298 F. Supp. 1326 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Bankruptcy proceedings situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Desired coordination between bankruptcy court and court to which a case has been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings does not require transfer of actions to situs of bankruptcy proceedings.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 567 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Actions concerning sale of preorganization limited partnership subscriptions in oil and gas ventures would be transferred to the District of Kansas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where there was a potential for conflicting class determinations by the transferor courts, bankruptcy proceedings were pending in the District of Kansas and one of the actions had been transferred to that district, but action pending in the Eastern District of California in which plaintiff alleged breach of oral contract to redeem partnership interest but did not allege security laws violations would not be transferred.
In re Natural Resources Fund, Inc., Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Action by corporation's reorganization trustee against bank to recover for bank's alleged fraud committed in connection with issuance of corporation's securities to incorporator was transferred by Judicial Panel from District of Montana to Northern District of California, where corporation's reorganization petition was pending, other actions arising out of same transaction were on file which involved common questions of fact, where transfer would prevent duplication of discovery and eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings and serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Great Western Ranches Litigation, 369 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions by dissatisfied stockholders and bondholders of companies related to transportation company the subject of reorganization proceeding under § 205 of Title 11 would not be assigned to judge who had responsibility for the reorganization proceedings in that, in addition to question of whether any one judge would be equal to the mammoth task of supervising pretrial proceedings in the stockholder cases and the reorganization, there were questions of possible conflicts of duties to which such an assignment might give rise.
In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1021 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Judges  24

Action for libel was transferred by Judicial Panel to district in which there were pending corporate reorganization proceedings and related actions for purpose of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where the facts necessary to establish defenses to action were sufficiently related to facts necessary to establish liability in the other related actions that a transfer would clearly serve convenience of plaintiff and witnesses.
In re Westec Corp., 307 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Cause of action situs, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
Southern District of Alabama was appropriate transferee court on consolidation of five actions pending in Southern District of Florida, Northern District of Texas, and Southern District of Alabama all arising out of litigation involving loss of cargo from barge between Alabama and Puerto Rico, where cargo was loaded on barge in Alabama and several parties, witnesses and documents could likely be found there.
In re Cargo Losses From Gulf Fleet 265 in Dec. 1990, 142 F.R.D. 182 (J.P.M.L. 1992).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, cause of action situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Eastern District of Missouri was appropriate transferee forum for ten actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in two districts and centralized for pretrial proceedings, concerning the cause of the crash of an aircraft; that district contained a majority of the actions, and relevant discovery would likely be found there or in neighboring Tennessee, inasmuch as the accident occurred in Missouri and airline personnel were located in Tennessee.
In re Air Crash Near Kirksville, Missouri, on October 19, 2004, 383 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2955

District of Arizona was appropriate transferee forum for five actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, concerning causes of the crash of a sightseeing helicopter; district encompassed the site of the crash, such that pertinent witnesses and documents would likely be found there, and four of the actions were pending in that district before a judge who had been presiding over three of the actions for nearly two years.
In re Helicopter Crash Near Meadview, Ariz., on Aug. 10, 2001, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2955

In multidistrict litigation concerning causes of the crash of an aircraft, centralization for pretrial proceedings of three actions and two potential tag-along actions pending in three districts, to Western District of North Carolina, was appropriate; district encompassed the site of the crash, such that pertinent witnesses and documents would likely be found in the area, one tag-along action was pending there, and all parties except one defendant supported centralization there.
In re Air Crash at Charlotte Intern. Airport, 290 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2955

Convenience of parties and witnesses and promotion of just and efficient conduct of litigation required centralization under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 of actions arising from crash of aircraft in district where crash occurred and where pertinent witnesses and documents would be found, where actions involved common questions of fact concerning cause or causes of accident.
In re Air Crash at Dallas/Fort Worth Airport on Aug. 2, 1985, 623 F. Supp. 634 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
Federal Courts  2955

Suits arising out of airplane crash would be transferred to district in which situs of crash was located for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where centralization of actions in such district would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and would promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Washington, D. C. on January 13, 1982, 533 F. Supp. 1350 (J.P.M.L. 1982).
Federal Courts  2955

Sixteen actions arising out of airplane crash would be transferred to the Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, since transfer would prevent repetitious pretrial proceedings, the Northern District of Illinois was where the crash occurred, where many eyewitnesses lived, where numerous relevant photographs, video tapes and films were located, and where the Federal Aviation Administration office responsible for approving the airplane's engine was located, and since such district was centrally located.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Chicago, Ill., on May 25, 1979, 476 F. Supp. 445 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2955

Generally, most efficient and expeditious resolution of domestic air disaster litigation can normally be achieved by transferring all actions to the district of the situs of the crash.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana, on September 20, 1973, 407 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2955

Record established that numerous actions arising out of air disaster and which were commenced in three federal district courts, other than Eastern District of New York, involved common questions of fact and that their transfer to Eastern District of New York for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, where crash occurred in Eastern District of New York where most of the anticipated key witnesses on issue of liability resided and where tape recordings and other relevant documents were located.
In re Air Crash Disaster at John F. Kennedy Intern. Airport on June 24, 1975, 407 F. Supp. 244 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2955

The Judicial Panel would transfer actions arising out of airliner crash to district in which crash occurred and which would be focal point for discovery on issue of liability rather than to proposed forum near such district, in which majority of actions were already pending and in which most of the passengers were residents.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Charlotte, North Carolina, on September 11, 1974, 393 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Judicial Panel would transfer cases, arising out of aircraft crash, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, to district where crash occurred, wherein were likely subjects of discovery and wherein overwhelming majority of actions were already pending, rather that to district where carrier and manufacturer had major facilities.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Upperville, Virginia, on December 1, 1974, 393 F. Supp. 1089 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Litigation arising out of commercial aircraft crash in which more than 80 persons perished would be transferred, for purposes of coordinated or consolidated trial proceedings, to District of Massachusetts, in which crash occurred and in which many of relevant documents and anticipated witnesses were located, rather than to New Hampshire or Vermont Districts in which majority of victims had resided.
In re Delta Airlines Crash at Boston, Mass., on July 31, 1973, 373 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2955

Actions pending in the District of Utah and in the Western District of Washington, arising out of air crash disaster, would be transferred to the Central District of California, where mid-air collision out of which the actions arose occurred in that district, both planes involved in the collision originally departed from locations within that district, the lone survivor of the crash and the majority of the witnesses resided in that district, and where, furthermore, the majority of the litigation had been filed in the Central District of California.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Duarte, Cal. on June 6, 1971, 346 F. Supp. 529 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

Judicial Panel generally assigns air disaster litigation to district in which crash occurred because of presence of important witnesses and documents there.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tweed-New Haven Airport on June 7, 1971, 343 F. Supp. 951 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

Generally, air crash litigation will be assigned to district in which crash occurred, unless facts of the particular litigation make another district more appropriate.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Huntington, W. Va. on November 14, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1972). See, also, In re Air Crash Disaster at Florida Everglades on December 29, 1972, 360 F. Supp. 1394 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Where airplane crash giving rise to multidistrict litigation occurred in District of New Hampshire, majority of witnesses and electronic instrumentation which may have contributed or caused deaths were located in that district, such district was only district in which all defendants could be sued by any plaintiff and one court had chosen New Hampshire as appropriate district for transfer for all purposes, all cases would be transferred to New Hampshire for pretrial proceedings even though more actions were pending in District of Vermont.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Hanover, N. H., 314 F. Supp. 62 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

Situs of collision of airliner and small plane was most appropriate transferee district for multidistrict litigation consisting of number of death actions arising from collision, where there were numerous eyewitnesses to collision in that district, much of potentially relevant material evidence was located there, and owner of small plane was corporation of that state with its principal office therein.
In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

Five civil actions arising from crash of commercial airliner as it made its approach to greater Cincinnati airport on evening of November 20, 1967 were transferred to Eastern District of Kentucky, the situs of the crash, where the actions presented common questions of fact and transfer would be for convenience of parties and witnesses and would promote just and efficient conduct of them.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport on November 20, 1967, 298 F. Supp. 358 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2955

Ten civil actions arising from crash of commercial airliner as it made its approach to greater Cincinnati airport on evening of November 20, 1967 were transferred to Eastern District of Kentucky, the situs of the crash, where the actions presented many common questions of fact and transfer would be for convenience of parties and witnesses and would promote just and efficient conduct of them.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport on November 20, 1967, 298 F. Supp. 353 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict civil actions involving air crash disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport (Constance, Kentucky) on November 8, 1965 were consolidated and transferred to Eastern District of Kentucky for pretrial proceedings, where situs of crash, many of witnesses and most of documents were located within or convenient to that district.
In re Civil Actions Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 295 F. Supp. 51 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict civil actions involving the air crash disaster at Ardmore (Gene Autry), Oklahoma, on April 22, 1966 were consolidated and transferred to Eastern District of Oklahoma, where situs of crash, many of witnesses and many of documents were in that district, and trials had been had and settlements and been made in that district.
In re Civil Actions Air Crash Disaster at Ardmore Oklahoma, 295 F. Supp. 45 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, cause of action situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
The Northern District of California was a proper transferee district for the centralization of pretrial proceedings in six antitrust actions in addition to a couple dozen potential tag-along actions; four of the actions in the motion to centralize and 20 of the potential tag-along actions were pending in the district, many of the potential witnesses in the litigation were located in or near the district, and the district was also convenient for third parties and witnesses based in Asia.
In re Qualcomm Antitrust Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict litigation in which six actions and one potential tag-along action, alleging violations of federal antitrust laws with respect to medical waste services in four states, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to District of Utah was appropriate; district was only suggested transferee district in which more than one action was pending, Utah attorney general investigated the conduct at issue and reached a settlement with the defendants, and Utah was location of the primary incineration facility at issue in all actions.
In re Medical Waste Services Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict antitrust action concerning alleged conspiratorial conduct of hotels in imposing certain telephone charges on their guests would be transferred to the Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, except as to defendants with whom settlement had already been reached, where the first action was filed in the transferee district, where it appeared that a substantial number of the involved hotels were located there, and where it appeared that some of the initial facts pertinent to plaintiffs' allegations of conspiratorial action occurred in California.
In re Hotel Telephone Charge Antitrust Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 771 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Explosive, nuclear and radioactive material actions, cause of action situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Common question of fact, convenience of parties and witnesses and just and efficient conduct of litigation permitted transfer, for purposes of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, of action pending in Louisiana District to the District of the District of Columbia where radioactive material in question had been packaged and shipped and where five of six actions were pending which arose from an incident in which all plaintiffs were allegedly exposed to ultrahazardous radioactive material packaged by one defendant and transported by defendant airline, despite contention that factual issues relating to damages were unique to each action.
In re Radiation Incident at Washington, D. C. on April 5, 1974, 400 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, cause of action situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would transfer to Southern District of New York securities cases, eight out of ten of which were already pending in New York where each case involved alleged violations of federal securities laws in connection with marketing of New York City's securities and where generally the city, its chief financial officers and various financial institutions were accused of conspiring, and in view of familiarity which judge in such district had developed with litigation as result of pretrial proceedings.
In re New York City Municipal Securities Litigation, 439 F. Supp. 267 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Northern District of Illinois was the most appropriate transferee forum for securities litigation where, inter alia, tender offer which assertedly violated federal securities laws was drafted in Chicago and thus many key documents and witnesses were in Chicago area, and where principal corporate defendant had headquarters in Chicago and Illinois action was more advanced and district judge to whom Illinois action was assigned was more familiar with complex issues.
In re Transocean Tender Offer Securities Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 382 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Where three related actions were all brought against the same single defendant where actions alleged fraud with respect to securities transactions which were based on research and operations of defendant which took place in New York, where action which was instituted in Southern District of New York was at a more advanced stage than the other actions, and where trial court hearing the action in the Southern District of New York had denied two motions by defendant to transfer the New York action to Texas, actions instituted in Northern District of Texas and Western District of Kentucky would be transferred to the Southern District of New York.
In re Scientific Control Corp. Securities Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 791 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: Center of gravity, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Western District of Missouri was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in actions alleging failure to adequately warn that store-branded motor oil products were unsuitable for use in most modern automobile engines, where center of gravity of litigation was in central portion of the country, and transferee district provided a geographically central forum that was both convenient and accessible to parties and witnesses.
In re Dollar General Corp. Motor Oil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1361 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was most appropriate transferee district for centralization of pretrial proceedings with respect to 19 nineteen actions pending in District of New Jersey, Eastern and Southern Districts of New York, and Eastern District of Pennsylvania in connection with claims for personal injury or wrongful death arising from derailment of Amtrak train; 35 of 64 related actions were pending in Eastern District of Pennsylvania and center of gravity of litigation was located in that district, which was where derailment occurred, track at issue was maintained, and emergency medical services were provided, and Eastern District of Pennsylvania was both convenient and accessible for parties and witnesses, most of whom were located on eastern seaboard.
In re: Amtrak Train Derailment In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, On May 12, 2015, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1347 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Louisiana was most appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in the numerous actions arising out of the explosion and sinking of an offshore drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico; district was closest to any geographic and psychological “center of gravity” in the resulting litigation, and the transferee judge had considerable experience with multidistrict litigation and had already been actively managing dozens of the cases in the docket.
In re: Oil Spill by the Oil Rig Deepwater Horizon in the Gulf of Mexico, on April 20, 2010, 731 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2953

Thirteen actions involving alleged violations of securities laws arising from issuance and sale of nuclear power generating facility revenue bonds would be centralized in the Western District of Washington, in light of questions of fact common to the actions, overlapping class certifications which had been sought, and other factors indicating that the state of Washington was center of gravity of the litigation and focal point for discovery.
In re Washington Public Power Supply System Securities Litigation, 568 F. Supp. 1250 (J.P.M.L. 1983).
Federal Courts  2957

Where all three defendants in action brought in Western District of Missouri for alleged violations of federal securities laws were also defendants in one or more of five similar actions pending in Eastern District of Virginia and were faced with substantially similar charges in both the Missouri and Virginia actions, all actions shared common questions of fact and focal point of litigation was in Eastern District of Virginia, action brought in Western District of Missouri would be transferred to Eastern District of Virginia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Industrial Wine Contracts Securities Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 909 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict private antitrust treble damage suits involving library editions of children's books were consolidated and transferred to Northern District of Illinois for pretrial proceedings, where the litigation's center of gravity was Chicago.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Central location, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
District of New Jersey was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that the use by women of defendants' talcum powder products resulted in the development of ovarian or uterine cancer; that district was a convenient and accessible forum for the nationwide litigation and was located in close proximity to a large number of similar pending state court actions, defendant was headquartered in New Jersey, such that relevant evidence and witnesses likely were located there, and the assignee judge was experienced in multidistrict litigation, had the willingness and ability to manage the litigation efficiently, and was presiding over the most procedurally-advanced of the actions.
In re Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of seven actions in multidistrict litigation, involving alleged infringement of patent and licensing rights by defendants' large-scale commercial printers, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Indus. Print Technologies, LLC, Patent Litigation, 98 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization in Southern District of Iowa was appropriate for putative class actions against manufacture of non-stick cookware coating; actions all alleged that cooking products coated with manufacturer's product could release potentially harmful substances that could be carcinogenic, and Southern District of Iowa provided a geographically central location without other multidistrict litigation dockets.
In re Teflon Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of four actions arising out of design and manufacture of an aircraft and its de-icing system, for centralized litigation in the District of Kansas, was warranted, where actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; District of Kansas was likely to be location of significant discovery because sole common defendant was headquartered there and airplanes at issue were manufactured there, District of Kansas was geographically convenient district and was well equipped with resources that litigation was likely to require, and District of Kansas was the choice of all parties that had expressed a preference on the selection of transferee forum.
In re Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2955

In multidistrict litigation involving alleged antitrust conspiracy to fix, reduce, cap and ultimately eliminate base commissions paid to travel agents, in which three actions were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Northern District of Ohio, where one action was pending, was appropriate; no district stood out as focal point for docket given geographic dispersal of constituent actions in California, Ohio and Texas, and Ohio district had capacity to handle litigation.
In re Travel Agent Com'n Antitrust Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict litigation in which three actions and nine potential tag-along actions, alleging a conspiracy to fix and maintain the price of ethylene propylene diene monomer, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to District of Connecticut was appropriate; district was geographically convenient, given the location of principal defendants and potential defendants and witnesses in the eastern United States and in Europe, and district was equipped with the resources that the complex antitrust docket was likely to require.
In re Ethylene Propylene Diene Monomer (EPDM) Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

Transfer to Northern District of Oklahoma of nine actions arising out of Mississippi air crash would result in most expeditious resolution of the action and thus was appropriate, where discovery and other pretrial proceedings concerning liability issues focused on at least six different geographic areas, and the Northern District of Oklahoma was more centrally located and easily accessible transferee forum than was Southern District of Mississippi where the crash occurred.
In re Air Crash Near Van Cleve, Miss., on Aug. 13, 1977, 486 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2955

Where two actions were pending in adjacent districts and either district could be described as appropriate transferee forum for litigation in that parties, anticipated witnesses and relevant documents were located throughout Oklahoma and in other states, transfer to Western District of Oklahoma, situs of which was in a major metropolitan area, for consolidated pretrial proceedings was preferable rather than to the Western District, the situs of which was in a much smaller locality.
In re First Nat. Bank, Heavener, Okl. (First Mortg. Revenue Bonds) Securities Litigation, 451 F. Supp. 995 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Fifty-seven actions pending in 23 different districts and involving claims for damages arising out of use of intrauterine contraceptive devices revealed commonality of factual issues sufficient to justify transferring such actions to single district for coordinated pretrial proceedings; district of Kansas, because of its geographically central location, was most suitable district.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 406 F. Supp. 540 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Where five treble damage antitrust actions had been brought in five different districts against major manufacturers of special mileage commercial tires used by transit companies charging combination and conspiracy in violation of Sherman Antitrust Act, §§ 1 to 7 of Title 15, and all involved common factual matters and were currently pending in four widely separated states, the actions were transferred to the Western District of Missouri for pretrial proceedings in view of its central location which would provide a more convenient forum to all parties, especially since it was quite likely that similar actions would be filed and the district was current with respect to its civil docket.
In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 1165 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Geographical convenience

para.paratext:
District of New Jersey was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that the use by women of defendants' talcum powder products resulted in the development of ovarian or uterine cancer; that district was a convenient and accessible forum for the nationwide litigation and was located in close proximity to a large number of similar pending state court actions, defendant was headquartered in New Jersey, such that relevant evidence and witnesses likely were located there, and the assignee judge was experienced in multidistrict litigation, had the willingness and ability to manage the litigation efficiently, and was presiding over the most procedurally-advanced of the actions.
In re Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of seven actions in multidistrict litigation, involving alleged infringement of patent and licensing rights by defendants' large-scale commercial printers, was warranted; actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve the resources of the parties, their counsel and the judiciary.
In re: Indus. Print Technologies, LLC, Patent Litigation, 98 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2956

Centralization in Southern District of Iowa was appropriate for putative class actions against manufacture of non-stick cookware coating; actions all alleged that cooking products coated with manufacturer's product could release potentially harmful substances that could be carcinogenic, and Southern District of Iowa provided a geographically central location without other multidistrict litigation dockets.
In re Teflon Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of four actions arising out of design and manufacture of an aircraft and its de-icing system, for centralized litigation in the District of Kansas, was warranted, where actions involved common questions of fact, and centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation; District of Kansas was likely to be location of significant discovery because sole common defendant was headquartered there and airplanes at issue were manufactured there, District of Kansas was geographically convenient district and was well equipped with resources that litigation was likely to require, and District of Kansas was the choice of all parties that had expressed a preference on the selection of transferee forum.
In re Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2955

In multidistrict litigation involving alleged antitrust conspiracy to fix, reduce, cap and ultimately eliminate base commissions paid to travel agents, in which three actions were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Northern District of Ohio, where one action was pending, was appropriate; no district stood out as focal point for docket given geographic dispersal of constituent actions in California, Ohio and Texas, and Ohio district had capacity to handle litigation.
In re Travel Agent Com'n Antitrust Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict litigation in which three actions and nine potential tag-along actions, alleging a conspiracy to fix and maintain the price of ethylene propylene diene monomer, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to District of Connecticut was appropriate; district was geographically convenient, given the location of principal defendants and potential defendants and witnesses in the eastern United States and in Europe, and district was equipped with the resources that the complex antitrust docket was likely to require.
In re Ethylene Propylene Diene Monomer (EPDM) Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

Transfer to Northern District of Oklahoma of nine actions arising out of Mississippi air crash would result in most expeditious resolution of the action and thus was appropriate, where discovery and other pretrial proceedings concerning liability issues focused on at least six different geographic areas, and the Northern District of Oklahoma was more centrally located and easily accessible transferee forum than was Southern District of Mississippi where the crash occurred.
In re Air Crash Near Van Cleve, Miss., on Aug. 13, 1977, 486 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2955

Where two actions were pending in adjacent districts and either district could be described as appropriate transferee forum for litigation in that parties, anticipated witnesses and relevant documents were located throughout Oklahoma and in other states, transfer to Western District of Oklahoma, situs of which was in a major metropolitan area, for consolidated pretrial proceedings was preferable rather than to the Western District, the situs of which was in a much smaller locality.
In re First Nat. Bank, Heavener, Okl. (First Mortg. Revenue Bonds) Securities Litigation, 451 F. Supp. 995 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Fifty-seven actions pending in 23 different districts and involving claims for damages arising out of use of intrauterine contraceptive devices revealed commonality of factual issues sufficient to justify transferring such actions to single district for coordinated pretrial proceedings; district of Kansas, because of its geographically central location, was most suitable district.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 406 F. Supp. 540 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Where five treble damage antitrust actions had been brought in five different districts against major manufacturers of special mileage commercial tires used by transit companies charging combination and conspiracy in violation of Sherman Antitrust Act, §§ 1 to 7 of Title 15, and all involved common factual matters and were currently pending in four widely separated states, the actions were transferred to the Western District of Missouri for pretrial proceedings in view of its central location which would provide a more convenient forum to all parties, especially since it was quite likely that similar actions would be filed and the district was current with respect to its civil docket.
In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 1165 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Choice of parties, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Eastern District of Kentucky was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 41 actions, pending in 23 districts, along with 43 potential tag-along actions, arising out of allegations that the use of certain medications for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus resulted in heart failure or other conditions; that District was relatively accessible, its choice was supported by defendants and certain plaintiffs, the longest-pending action was proceeding apace in that District, and the transferee Judge could be counted on to steer the litigation on a prudent course.
In re Onglyza (Saxagliptin) and Kombiglyze XR (Saxagliptin and Metformin) Products Liability Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Missouri was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in nine actions, pending in five districts, arising out of allegations involving the development, testing, and marketing of certain seeds and herbicides, as well as allegations of injury from the use of those herbicides; four of the constituent actions, as well as one tag-along action, were pending in that district, its selection was supported by numerous plaintiffs, as well as all defendants, one defendant, which was headquartered in the district, represented that various relevant activities took place there, and the transferee judge was an experienced jurist who was already presiding over the two earliest-filed of the actions.
In re Dicamba Herbicides Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of Georgia was appropriate transferee district for pretrial proceedings for consumer class actions, pending in various state and federal districts, against credit reporting agency for its role in cybersecurity incident in which personally identifiable information of consumers was compromised, notwithstanding slight variations in claims alleged, where there was substantial factual overlap among all actions, credit reporting agency was headquartered in transferee district, which was where relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be found, consolidation in transferee district was supported by credit reporting agency and vast majority of responding consumers, and far more actions were pending in transferee district than in any other court in nation.
In re: Equifax, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1322 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953
