Northern District of California was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in two actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that thermostat manufacturer engaged in anticompetitive practices to exclude potential competitors by, among other things, misrepresenting the validity of its trademark; no district stood out as a focal point, one action was already pending in that district, and defendant and responding plaintiffs agreed that district was a suitable alternative choice.
In re Circular Thermostat Antitrust Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization of drug manufacturer's patent infringement actions against generic drug manufacturers in Southern District of New York was warranted, where actions involved one or more patents related to active ingredient in manufacturer's product, and all parties agreed to transfer to Southern District of New York.
In re Rivastigmine Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of three actions, pending in multidistrict litigation and consolidated for pretrial proceedings, against manufacturers of welding equipment, alleging personal injuries caused by exposure to welding fumes, to Northern District of Ohio, was appropriate; all responding parties agreed to centralization in that district, corporate headquarters for several defendants were located in district, and judge was an able jurist with experience in multidistrict products liability litigation.
In re Welding Rod Products Liability Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Where Northern District of California or District of Kansas were favored by plaintiffs in 65 of the 78 actions being centralized and Southern District of Ohio was favored by plaintiffs in nine of the actions, nine potential tag-along actions, and approximately 75 law firms of the defendants, but where various parties opposed the others' favored location and sought to denigrate each others' forum choices, litigation strategies, and underlying motives, actions would be transferred to the Northern District of Alabama to be heard by experienced multidistrict transferee judge.
In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 1098 (J.P.M.L. 1992).
Federal Courts  2953

Action brought by aircraft manufacturer against United States in Eastern District of Virginia to recover for alleged tortious interference with contractual relations would be transferred to the District of the District of Columbia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with manufacturer's action against Central Intelligence Agency and others to recover for alleged conspiracy to boycott and disparage manufacturer's products, in view of fact that the two actions involved common questions of fact and transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, and in view of fact that District of Columbia was the choice of majority of parties, all depositions that had been noticed had been noticed in the District, and many of alleged acts of defendants were alleged to have occurred there.
In re General Aircraft Corp. Antitrust/Tort Claims Act Litigation, 449 F. Supp. 604 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2955

Common factual questions between securities action in Eastern District of Washington and actions pending in Southern District of New York were complex enough to justify transfer of Washington action to New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, particularly since all three actions involved same seven defendants, notwithstanding plaintiff's concern that transfer might be financially burdensome and might not conserve convenience of parties and witnesses, where most of the relevant documents and many of the key witnesses were located in New York and, in addition, majority of parties in all three actions preferred Southern District of New York over any other district.
In re Sunshine Min. Co. Securities Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 223 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict antitrust cases challenging manufacturer's alleged vertical integration of wholesale and retail operations would be transferred to the Western District of Washington, all parties favoring transfer of all claims to that district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Mack Truck, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 503 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Softwood plywood private antitrust cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Eastern District of Louisiana, where actions involved common questions of fact, transfer of actions would serve convenience of parties and witnesses, transfer would prevent possibility of duplicative discovery concerning defendants' alleged misconduct, class allegations were overlapping, majority of parties favored Eastern District of Louisiana, and discovery in Louisiana actions had already commenced before judge who was totally familiar with all of issues involved in litigation.
In re Plywood Antitrust Litigation, 376 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Actions, which were brought against corporation and certain of its subsidiaries and franchisees and in which wrongful cancellation of such defendants' agreements to buy computerized cash registers from plaintiff was claimed, would be transferred to United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings where vast majority of common discovery would concern operation of prototype unit installed at a defendant subsidiary's place of business in Illinois and where all parties favored transfer to such district.
In re AMF Computerized Cash Register Contract Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2953

Fact that 18 of 23 named plaintiffs in multidistrict actions favored transfer to Central District of California would not justify transfer to that district in view of possibility of transferee judge establishing class action on behalf of all franchisees of defendant corporation.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 753 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

Civil actions pending in the Northern District of Texas arising out of air disaster were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the Western District of Tennessee, despite contention that no transfer was necessary since most of the cases were being settled, where all the actions, with the possible exception of interpleader action filed by insurer, shared common questions of fact relating to cause of the crash, certain of the actions would have to be tried because of insufficient insurance coverage and such trial would probably take place in the Western District of Tennessee, and the litigation had been pending for more than a year and a half and no discovery had taken place.
In re Air Crash Disaster at New Orleans, (Moisant Field), La. on March 20, 1969, 331 F. Supp. 554 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2955

Where defendant aircraft servicer had moved its maintenance facilities from Oklahoma to Texas, Central District of California was inconvenient forum for defendant aircraft manufacturer, Eastern District of New York was inconvenient forum for servicer, which appeared to be the principal defendant, and plaintiffs, who brought two actions in such New York District and one each in such Oklahoma and California Districts wherein recovery was sought for death and injuries resulting when aircraft crashed in Venezuela, preferred California District as forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, Central District of California was appropriate choice as forum for such pretrial proceedings.
In re Air Disaster at San Antonio, Venezuela, 331 F. Supp. 547 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict civil actions involving violations of Securities Act of 1933, § 77a et seq. of Title 15, by false representations and by sale of unregistered stock would be transferred to District of Massachusetts where more plaintiffs favored transfer to Massachusetts, substantially greater number of shares were involved in Massachusetts actions and all Massachusetts actions had been assigned to one judge who was willing to accept responsibility for conducting coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Revenue Properties Co., 309 F. Supp. 1002 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: Convenience of attorneys, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Fact that one federal district court would be a more conveniently located forum for majority of attorneys involved in multidistrict litigation than would another district was not by itself a factor to be considered in deciding by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation whether to order transfer or in selecting transferee forum for group of actions.
In re Anthracite Coal Antitrust Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 402 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Convenience of parties, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Northern District of California is appropriate transferee district for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation arising out of allegations that a drug caused or increased the risk of developing melanoma and that defendant manufacturer failed to warn consumers and health care providers of the alleged risk; district, which had unanimous support of all responding plaintiffs and defendant, provided a convenient and easily accessible location for the geographically dispersed litigation, nine of the actions (including potential tag-alongs) were pending in the district, and the assignee judge was an experienced transferee judge who was willing and able to efficiently manage the litigation and could be counted on steer it on a prudent course.
In re Viagra (Sildenafil Citrate) Products Liability Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Middle District of Florida was appropriate transferee forum for three actions pending in two districts and raising questions concerning the conduct of the Corps of Engineers with regard to the flow of water in the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint (ACF) River basin and/or the role of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (Service) in the Corps's conduct; litigation primarily affected parties and interests located in the Eleventh Circuit, and judge, who was already sitting in the Middle District of Florida pursuant to an intercircuit assignment, was experienced in water rights litigation.
In re Tri-State Water Rights Litigation, 481 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Missouri was appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in eight actions and three potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that manager of pharmaceutical benefits unlawfully enriched itself through, among other things, undisclosed dealings with pharmacies and drug manufacturers; district was conveniently located for many parties and witnesses, including defendant, which was headquartered there, and documents and witnesses would likely be found there.
In re Express Scripts, Inc., Pharmacy Benefits Management Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in three actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that trucking company failed to give notice to its employees when it ceased operations, in violation of the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act; two of the actions were already pending in that district, and the district was relatively conveniently located for parties and witnesses located primarily in the Northeastern United States.
In re USF Red Star Inc. Workers Notification Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Nebraska was appropriate transferee district for three other Title VII actions, pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that railroad discriminated against female employees by excluding coverage for prescription contraception as benefit of employment, where the four actions were being centralized for pretrial proceedings; many of purported class members likely resided in Nebraska, documents and witnesses could be found at railroad's Nebraska headquarters, and Nebraska district had capacity to handle litigation.
In re Union Pacific Railroad Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation to resolve appeals affecting water rights in the Missouri River Basin states, centralization for pretrial proceedings of six out of seven actions pending in four districts, in District of Minnesota, was appropriate; district was located in same Circuit as most of the parties and interests involved in the actions, and was an accessible and geographically convenient district equipped with the resources that the complex docket was likely to require.
In re Operation of Missouri River System Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation in which centralization was ordered of more than 1100 actions alleging that underwriters and initial public offering (IPO) issuers were responsible for misrepresentations in prospectuses and/or in underwriter research analyst reports, and manipulated prices of securities in the IPO aftermarket, Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum; district was conveniently located for many parties and witnesses and possessed necessary resources to be able to devote substantial time and effort to pretrial matters.
In re Initial Public Offering (IPO) Securities Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2957

Centralization in the Southern District of New York of actions brought by persons who purchased identical or substantially similar annuities issued by defendant's insurance companies and who alleged fraud and/or violation of federal and state securities laws in connection with sale of the annuities would best serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Baldwin-United Corp. Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 739 (J.P.M.L. 1984).
Federal Courts  2957

Nineteen actions pending in Kentucky, Texas, and California arising from in-flight fire on flight of plane which landed in Kentucky would be centralized in the Central District of California to best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and to promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Covington, Ky., on June 2, 1983, 579 F. Supp. 1057 (J.P.M.L. 1984).
Federal Courts  2955

Seven class suits against corporation for violation of federal securities laws involving alleged misstatements of fact and omissions of material information in corporation's reports and prospectuses involved common questions of fact, and their centralization in Northern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation; transfer to such district would therefore be ordered.
In re LTV Corp. Securities Litigation, 470 F. Supp. 859 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2957

Convenience of travel was not a compelling factor requiring transfer of multidistrict litigation to the Northern District of Illinois rather than to the Eastern District of Wisconsin.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 753 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Convenience of witnesses, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
In multidistrict litigation involving actions alleging conspiracy to mislead with respect to the financial stability of certain insurance companies providing professional malpractice coverage, Western District of Tennessee was appropriate transferee forum; district had strongest nexus to the litigation among the districts with actions pending, and two insurance defendants were in receivership in Tennessee, such that witnesses and documents would likely be found there.
In re Reciprocal of America (ROA) Sales Practices Litigation, 281 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Western District of Kentucky was appropriate venue for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings in actions brought in various districts stemming from crash in Newfoundland of aircraft containing returning military personnel, most of whom were stationed at installation located in the Western District of Kentucky.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Gander, Newfoundland, on Dec. 12, 1985, 633 F. Supp. 50 (J.P.M.L. 1986).
Federal Courts  2955

Actions, which were brought in Texas and California by crew members of aircraft that crashed during takeoff from Denver, Colorado airport, involved common questions of fact and their transfer to the District of Colorado, where air traffic controllers who were responsible for flight, ground witnesses to crash and significant documentary evidence were located, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, as well as providing a ready forum for inclusion of any newly filed actions.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Stapleton Intern. Airport in Denver, Colo., on August 7, 1975, 447 F. Supp. 1071 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2955

Thirty actions which challenged restrictions on practice of naturopathy and which were pending in 30 federal districts would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the district of Maryland where federal defendants common to all actions, and several relevant documents and witnesses were located in nearby Washington, D.C. and the several parties anticipated that litigation would involve many expert medical and pharmaceutical witnesses likely to be found at larger companies and major medical schools in east.
In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Four antitrust actions brought by fisherman against owners of canneries involved complex common questions of fact requiring transfer of Alaska action to Western District of Washington for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with three actions there pending, since, inter alia, corporate headquarters and records of all defendants were located in or near Washington district as well as, for most of year, the personnel of defendants likely to be called as witnesses, majority of discovery would take place in that vicinity and actions pending in Washington district were further advanced than action in Alaska.
In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict actions brought by former controlling officers and shareholders of bankrupt against banks who allegedly violated federal securities laws and committed common law fraud would be transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, even though bankruptcy proceeding and bankrupt's home offices were in the Western District of New York, where much of plaintiffs' discovery would concern witnesses and documents in New York City, and judge of Southern District of New York was familiar with issues in litigation as well as those in another multidistrict securities litigation involving bankrupt.
In re Multidistrict Litigation Involving Banking Agreements with Stirling Homex Corp., 388 F. Supp. 572 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Action pending in the Eastern District of California arising from crash of airplane in Arizona was properly subject to transfer to District of Arizona, where 11 other actions arising from crash were pending, to serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, where many relevant documents and anticipated witnesses, including all eyewitnesses, were located in Arizona, consolidated discovery proceedings had already commenced in Arizona actions and counsel were attempting to coordinate federal discovery with discovery in Arizona state actions, and where vast majority of cases were pending in District of Arizona and all parties except plaintiff in California action favored such district as transferee forum.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Collidge, Arizona, on May 6, 1971, 362 F. Supp. 572 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Four actions filed in Northern District of California against Washington aircraft manufacturer for four of five deaths which occurred in New Jersey air crash, action filed by ground serviceman in New Jersey against airline for injuries resulting from crash and airline's third-party action against manufacturer would be transferred to Western District of Washington for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action pending in that district against manufacturer for the remaining death where all the actions presented common questions of fact and all witnesses and documents of manufacturer relevant to design and manufacture of the aircraft and formulation of operating procedures and instructions were located there.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Atlantic City, N. J., on July 26, 1969, 352 F. Supp. 969 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Cases arising from airplane crash would be transferred to the District of Colorado for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, despite contentions that voluntary coordination of discovery would be sufficient, that flying counsel to Colorado would be prejudicially expensive to party which was defendant only in a California case, and that cases of certain passenger plaintiffs should not be transferred for pretrial proceedings with actions brought by representatives of two deceased crew members, where the cases all shared a common factual background, and where plane crashed near Denver airport, so that many eyewitnesses, the air traffic controllers involved, and various records and documents were located in that area.
In re Air Crash Near Denver, Colo. In re Air Crash Near Denver, Colo. on October 3, 1969, 339 F. Supp. 415 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

Where plaintiffs alleged, in 15 actions, which arose out of crash of passenger aircraft in Nevada and which were pending either in Southern District of California, Eastern District of Wisconsin, or Northern District of Texas, that crash resulted from fire caused by gas heater in nose of aircraft, heater was installed in Texas and approved by Texas regional office of Federal Aviation Administration, all witnesses and documents relating thereto were located in Northern District of Texas and much of discovery was likely to center on such witnesses and documents, such district was appropriate forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, though flight originated in California and many of passengers lived in California.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Las Vegas, Nev. on October 8, 1968, 336 F. Supp. 414 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: Discovery situs, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
Multidistrict home study and in-residence study course cases would be transferred to the Eastern District of Wisconsin where the majority of plaintiffs' discovery would be centered and where defendant's documents and substantial number of its witnesses were located.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 753 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Documents and records generally, discovery situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
District of District of Columbia was proper transferee district for centralization of actions regarding Office of Personnel Management (OPM) data security breach, which were pending in Districts of District of Columbia, Northern District of California, and District of Kansas; relevant documents and witnesses likely would be found in District of Columbia because federal government defendants were located there and non-government defendant had office in nearby Fairfax, Virginia, defendants as well as plaintiffs in two of the three constituent actions, as well as a potential tag-along action, supported centralization in District of Columbia, and judge to whom litigation would be assigned was experienced jurist.
In re: U.S. Office of Personnel Management Data Security Breach Litigation, 138 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 10 actions and three potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts and arising out of a company's collapse; relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be found within that district since the company and various involved investment banks were headquartered there, related criminal proceedings were also pending there, and the transferee judge had already developed familiarity with the issues presented.
In re: Refco Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2957

District of District of Columbia was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation seeking reimbursement of the communications excise tax on certain long-distance telephone service; most, if not all, discovery would likely come from the federal government, vicinity provided an easily accessible location, and coordination of discovery between the transferee judge and the judge handling the related case in the Court of Federal Claims would likely be easier.
In re Long-Distance Telephone Service Federal Excise Tax Refund Litigation, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

District of New Jersey was appropriate transferee forum for actions, in multidistrict litigation alleging that company made misrepresentations that affected its financial condition; documents and witnesses were likely to be located at corporation's New Jersey headquarters, and New Jersey was relatively conveniently located for parties and witnesses taken as a whole.
In re Merck & Co., Inc., Securities, Derivative & ERISA Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of Texas was appropriate transferee forum for three putative class actions and one potential tag-along action, centralized for pretrial proceedings and arising out of an airline's disclosure of its passengers' personally identifiable travel information to the Transportation Security Administration, and subsequent disclosure of that information to four private research companies; district was likely to be the location of significant discovery inasmuch as airline was headquartered there, district was more convenient for most parties and witnesses than a proposed alternative district, and the district had the resources available to manage the litigation.
In re American Airlines, Inc., Privacy Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred actions involving claims seeking adjustment of United States Census Bureau tabulations to District of Maryland, relevant records and documents being located at the census Bureau's national records center located in such district.
In re 1980 Decennial Census Adjustment Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 648 (J.P.M.L. 1981).
Federal Courts  2953

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred products liability litigation to closest district to Kalamazoo wherein action was pending in view of relevant documents and witnesses to be found in Kalamazoo and fact that extensive discovery, at defendant's headquarters in Kalamazoo, of records and research files would assertedly be necessary for complete and full prosecution of the litigation.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic “Cleocin” Products Liability Litigation, 450 F. Supp. 1168 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Despite fact that no related action was pending in the Western District of Washington, five actions involving the validity of patents on components of a ground proximity warning system for aircraft were transferred to the Western District of Washington for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where none of the districts in which actions were pending offered a strong nexus to the common factual questions and most of the relevant documents and witnesses were located in the vicinity of the transferee forum and the transfer made possible the coordination of the federal actions and a related action pending in a Washington state court.
In re Sundstrand Data Control, Inc. Patent Litigation, 443 F. Supp. 1019 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2956

Actions arising from air crash in the Republic of China would be transferred to the District of Columbia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings despite contention of plaintiffs that the Southern District or New York would be most convenient because it was closest to Connecticut, which was residence of decedents, their survivors, and survivors' guardians, where plaintiffs had brought five separate actions in five districts, including the transferee forum, and where it was likely that Washington, D.C., would be the only place within the United States where documents and data relating to defendant airline's operations might be found.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Taipei Intern. Airport on July 31, 1975, 433 F. Supp. 1120 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2955

Where four actions arising from passenger train derailment in Tennessee were pending in the Middle District of Tennessee and one in the Northern District of Illinois, latter would be transferred to Tennessee for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to prevent duplicative discovery and eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings, though many of the documents and witnesses relevant to damages aspect of Illinois plaintiff's action were located in Illinois.
In re Ownership of Longoria Bank Deposits Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 913 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

Where nine of the actions arising out of crash of airplane in Paris were in the Central District of California and one each in Eastern and Southern District of New York, and all documents and witnesses were located at airplane manufacturer's production facilities in Long Beach, California, all actions would be transferred to the Central District of California, and the mere proximity of east coast to situs of the crash was not in and of itself a persuasive reason to support transfer of all actions to the east coast forum.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Paris, France, on March 3, 1974, 376 F. Supp. 887 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2955

Actions involving defendant corporation's alleged illegal monopolization of market for electronic data processing devices would, for purposes of consolidated pretrial proceedings, be transferred from Central District to Northern District of California, in which other such actions were pending and in which corporation's laboratory and plant and many relevant documents and witnesses were located, though, inter alia, same judge was designated to sit in both Central and Northern Districts, and all such actions had been assigned to him.
In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1376 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict litigation involving actions against food franchisors should be transferred to the Northern District of Illinois, where, inter alia, transfer was necessary to avoid duplication of discovery and the possibility of inconsistent class determinations, and where defendants' documents and the majority of witnesses were located in that district.
In re Convenient Food Mart Franchise Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 1166 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2953

Civil actions growing out of alleged fraud on United States perpetrated through prime contractors in production of rocket launchers were transferred to District of Columbia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where a number of fact questions concerning alleged fraud were common to each of the involved actions, all parties were agreed on primacy of government's claim and handling of that claim could be expedited while going forward with discovery efforts in other actions and government files were likely to be subject of much discovery.
In re Alsco-Harvard Fraud Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 315 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

Because of the enormous quantity of relevant documents located in New York City with respect to the more than 150 related civil antitrust actions which have been transferred to the Southern District of New York and the fact that the files and records in the related criminal case were also located there, such factors precluded the transfer of the 58 remaining nonsettled cases to any other district for completion of coordinated pretrial proceedings in absence of a strong showing that some other district had a nexus with litigations.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 320 F. Supp. 586 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

Fact that largest single concentration of documents in multidistrict private antitrust action was in district from which actions were proposed to be transferred, that total number of documents scattered elsewhere throughout country greatly exceeded number in that district and majority of defendant's documents were in or near district to which action was proposed to be transferred were important factors for Judicial Panel but were not controlling on question of whether to transfer cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

In view of such factors that 9 of the 13 transferable cases were pending in the Northern District of California and that virtually all documentary evidence involving particular licensing agreement would come from corporate offices of patentee located in California, the four cases pending elsewhere would be transferred to Northern District of California for coordinated pretrial proceedings of actions which all involved issue of whether patentee had used patents, trademarks, and licensing agreements to create monopoly in restraint of trade.
In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2956

Actions by government against railroads to recover damages for alleged losses of grain during shipment, subject to transfer under this section, would be transferred to District of Kansas as most appropriate forum, although government suggested District of Maryland, where most grain involved moved in central states, government records were located in Kansas City, and judge of Kansas District was willing to accept responsibility.
In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict protection devices and equipment and central station protection service private antitrust cases were transferred to Southern District of New York for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings, where most relevant documents were in New York, most of the defendants had their principal officers there, and document production had already commenced in New York.
In re Protection Devices and Equipment and Central Station Protection Service Antitrust Cases, 295 F. Supp. 39 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Grand jury, discovery situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
In multidistrict litigation in which twelve actions and four potential tag-along actions alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix, raise, maintain, or stabilize prices for foundry resins were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Southern District of Ohio was appropriate; it was likely that relevant documents and witnesses would be found in that district inasmuch as two of the defendants maintained their headquarters there, and there was a government investigation and a federal grand jury in the district.
In re Foundry Resins Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

That portion of 66 antitrust actions relating to marine construction industry brought in districts other than the Eastern District of Louisiana were to be transferred to that district, where relevant grand jury proceedings occurred, for centralized pretrial proceedings with the actions pending there to serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Marine Const. Antitrust Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1355 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2954

Where plaintiffs in three antitrust actions against gas manufacturers in Pennsylvania district had obtained access to many of documents produced to Pennsylvania grand jury investigating gas meter industry, and United States had commenced criminal and civil actions against manufacturers in Pennsylvania district, Pennsylvania district was appropriate transferee forum for similar action in Illinois district in that transfer to Pennsylvania district would best facilitate orderly access to documents and any necessary coordination between private actions and government proceedings.
In re Gas Meter Antitrust Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 391 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred multidistrict coal price-fixing antitrust case to Middle District of Pennsylvania, in which grand jury investigation and related criminal action occurred, resulting in considerable number of documents to which plaintiffs in several actions had sought access by petitioning judges assigned to criminal action, since transfer to that forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best facilitate any necessary coordination of document discovery between government's criminal action and private civil actions.
In re Anthracite Coal Antitrust Litigation, 436 F. Supp. 402 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict motor vehicle air pollution control equipment civil antitrust actions were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Central District of California where grand jury documents which plaintiff cities, states and individuals sought to use had been impounded and where certain conspiratorial activity allegedly occurred and where many air pollution experts, who were likely to be deposed, resided.
In re Motor Vehicle Air Pollution Control Equipment, 311 F. Supp. 1349 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Docket conditions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Northern District of Texas was appropriate transferee district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in two actions, pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations in the design, marketing and sale of life insurance policies used to fund defined benefit pension plans for small businesses, and failure to disclose that such policies might be deemed by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to be invalid tax shelters; the judge assigned to the action pending in that district had a relatively low case load, and the action was progressing well.
In re: Indianapolis Life Ins. Co. I.R.S. 412(I) Plans Life Ins. Marketing Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of Georgia was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in two actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that mortgage company violated Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act by its payment and/or non-disclosure of mortgage settlement/referral fees paid to its unlicensed limited liability corporations; that district was site of the first-filed action, which was proceeding well, and had the capacity to handle the litigation.
In re Novastar Home Mortgage Inc. Mortgage Lending Practices Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Louisiana was appropriate district for centralization of products liability actions against manufacturer and wholesaler of prescription drug, where 148 actions were pending in 41 federal districts, no district stood out as geographic focal point for nationwide docket, judge had experience in complex multidistrict products liability litigation, and district had capacity to handle litigation.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of 22 actions and 22 potential tag-along actions alleging failure to adequately warn of the danger to persons exposed to respirable silica products, pending in multidistrict litigation and centralized for pretrial proceedings, to Southern District of Texas, was appropriate; no federal district stood out as a focal point in the litigation, which involved plaintiffs and defendants from across the U.S., and judge was experienced in multidistrict litigation and had a relatively low civil caseload.
In re Silica Products Liability Litigation, 280 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of nine consolidated actions seeking determination whether operation of computer advertising network constituted trademark or copyright infringement to Northern District of Georgia for pretrial proceedings was appropriate; district provided accessible metropolitan court that was not overtaxed with other multidistrict dockets, and possessed necessary resources and expertise to be able to devote time and effort to pretrial matters that consolidated actions were likely to require.
In re Gator Corp. Software Trademark & Copyright Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2956

In determining which federal district should be site of consolidated pretrial proceedings for multiple antitrust actions, where none of three districts in which actions were pending served as predominating nexus for litigation and at least two of three were accessible urban districts equipped with necessary resources, actions would be transferred to district where judge was not currently burdened with another complex multidistrict docket.
In re Compensation of Managerial, Professional and Technical Employees Antitrust Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2954

Although either the District of Massachusetts or the Eastern District of Virginia could be described as an appropriate transferee forum for litigation challenging airline's weight standards for flight attendants, action would be transferred to Eastern District of Virginia which had a significantly lighter civil action docket than the District of Massachusetts.
In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Factors militating in favor of Idaho forum, rather than Texas forum, on motion for transfer of Texas actions to Idaho were: (1) familiarity of transferee judge with issues raised by defendants' motion to dismiss, and (2) fact that District of Idaho had a significantly lighter civil action docket than Southern District of Texas and thus transferee judge would be able to devote quick attention to litigation.
In re Peruvian Road Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Fact that court calendar in Eastern District of Wisconsin was two to three months behind Northern District of Illinois in disposition of cases was insignificant in determining whether to transfer multidistrict cases to Milwaukee or Chicago.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 753 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

Multidistrict private antitrust and securities laws actions against mutual funds, investment advisers managing those funds, directors affiliated with funds and investment advisers and trade association representative fund industry would be ordered transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the District of Massachusetts where transfer to a single district was the only way in which duplication of effort by coordinating counsel and possible inconsistent judicial treatment could be avoided, 44 defendants had their principal offices in the District of Massachusetts, while 51 had their offices in Southern District of New York and remaining 13 defendants would find it no more convenient to travel to either district and docket was 15 months more current in District of Massachusetts.
In re Kauffman Mut. Fund Actions, 337 F. Supp. 1337 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Experience of court, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
District of South Carolina was appropriate transferee district for six actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in 10 districts, alleging that design defects in certain of manufacturer's aluminum-clad windows resulted in premature deterioration, even though no constituent action was pending in that district; litigation was nationwide in scope, such that almost any district would be an appropriate forum, and transferee Judge had experience with a similar docket.
In re: Pella Corp. Architect and Designer Series Windows Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 996 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for nine actions, pending in two districts, concerning the cause or causes of a train derailment near Tyrone, Oklahoma, and the respective liability of the parties under various bills of lading; the consolidated actions in that District were proceeding expeditiously there before a judge who had already developed familiarity with the issues involved.
In re Train Derailment Near Tyrone, Okl., On April 21, 2005, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Delaware was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in 15 actions in multidistrict litigation involving allegations of the infringement and/or invalidity of one or more of nine patents relating to the provision of high-speed internet and related services; cases would be heard by a seasoned jurist in a readily accessible district with the capacity to handle the litigation.
In re Rembrandt Technologies, LP, Patent Litigation, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2956

Given that no district stood out as the geographic focal point for the nationwide docket, District of Kansas was appropriate transferee district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in 12 actions and 25 potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts, relating to the sale of motor fuel at temperatures greater than 60 degrees Fahrenheit; judge there had the time and experience to steer the litigation on a prudent course, and was sitting in a district with the capacity to handle the litigation.
In re Motor Fuel Temperature Sales Practices Litigation, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

Central District of California was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 25 actions and one potential tag-along action in multidistrict litigation, involving allegations of infringement and invalidity of one or more interactive call processing patents; transferee judge had prior judicial experience with some of the patents involved and was already familiar with the underlying technology.
In re Katz Interactive Call Processing Patent Litigation, 481 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2956

Transfer to Northern District of California, of actions and potential tag-along actions, pending in various districts and alleging that manufacturer of anti-inflammatory prescription medications failed to disclose that the medications carried increased health risks, was warranted; no district stood out as a focal point in the litigation, judge in that district was experienced in complex multidistrict litigation, and district had capacity to handle the litigation.
In re Bextra and Celebrex Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Delaware was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in six actions pending in multidistrict litigation and arising out of efforts by a pharmaceutical company to enforce patents relating to collection and storage of umbilical cord blood and/or placentas for future therapeutic uses; transferee judge was already familiar with many technological and legal issues posed by the actions, inasmuch as he had already presided over a related action, and he would have the flexibility to structure any proceedings with any pretrial proceedings that might later arise on appeal of the prior action.
In re Pharmastem Therapeutics, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2956

Northern District of Alabama was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in four actions pending in four districts and alleging that certain of defendants' employees were entitled to overtime compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); the constituent action in that district was further advanced procedurally than the actions in the other districts, and the judge in that action had gained familiarity with issues involved in the litigation through, inter alia, his certification of an opt-in collective action under FLSA.
In re Dollar General Corp. Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in 27 purported class actions and nine potential tag-along actions, pending in 21 districts, alleging illegal promotion and sale of the drug Neurontin for “off-label” use; a False Claims Act qui tam action predicated on the same facts had been pending for eight years and had proceeded to a very advanced state before being settled, and the judge who presided over that action, who was thus thoroughly familiar with the issues of fact and law raised, had been assigned to the four constituent Massachusetts actions.
In re Neurontin Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2956

In multidistrict litigation in which three actions, alleging violations of federal securities laws arising out of company's false and misleading statements concerning its operations at various cemeteries, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Southern District of Texas was appropriate; company was headquartered in that district, such that witnesses and documents relating to alleged violations would likely be found there, and transferee judge had gained helpful experience in presiding over similar litigation against company.
In re Service Corp. Intern., 323 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2957

In light of the geographic dispersal of current and anticipated constituent actions, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, of six actions and eight potential tag-along actions in multidistrict litigation, arising out of concerns as to the safety of a prescription drug used in the treatment of schizophrenia, to Eastern District of New York, was appropriate; no district stood out as the focal point for the litigation, and the transferee judge was experienced.
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation in which ten actions and 16 potential tag-along actions, alleging an unlawful conspiracy to prevent new motor vehicles sold in Canada from being imported into the United States, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to District of Maine was appropriate; no single district stood out as a geographic focal point for the litigation, given the geographic dispersal of the actions, judge in that district had time and experience, and district was located in close proximity to Canada.
In re New Motor Vehicles Canadian Export Antitrust Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Fact that the district court for the District of Columbia had already processed many Securities and Exchange Commission actions involving allegations similar to those involved in the instant cases did not make it better qualified than any other district to supervise pretrial proceedings in litigation involving violations of the securities laws.
In re Tenneco Inc. Securities Litigation, 426 F. Supp. 1187 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Availability of experienced and capable judge familiar with the litigation is one of the more important factors in selecting a transferee forum.
In re Ampicillin Antitrust Litigation, 315 F. Supp. 317 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Familiarity of court, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Northern District of West Virginia was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that a home security system and alarm monitoring company's telemarketing calls violated the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA); the first-filed and most advanced of the actions was pending in that district, the sole opposing plaintiff supported it as an alternative forum, and the judge in that district, who was presiding over the most advanced of the actions, was an experienced jurist who was in a particularly favorable position to structure the litigation so as to minimize delay and avoid unnecessary duplication of discovery and motion practice.
In re: Monitronics Intern., Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act Litigation, 988 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013).
Federal Courts  2956

Middle District of Florida was appropriate transferee forum for numerous actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging injuries resulting from use of Seroquel, an atypical antipsychotic medication; centralized proceedings could be assigned to a transferee judge with prior experience overseeing Seroquel litigation, who could steer the litigation on a steady and expeditious course.
In re Seroquel Products Liability Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in 14 actions and 21 potential tag-along actions, alleging that credit card companies' imposition of a no-surcharge rule and/or establishment of an interchange fee caused the merchant discount fee to be set at supracompetitive levels in violation of federal antitrust laws; the judge in that district was already familiar with the operation of the credit card networks.
In re Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2954

District of Nevada, adjacent to California and still within Ninth Circuit, was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in multidistrict wholesale natural gas litigation; litigation had strong California nexus, but potential recusal issues affected assignment of class actions in litigation to California resident judge, and Nevada transferee judge could steer litigation on expeditious course and might bring additional familiarity with some of issues presented as result of his previous assignment to antitrust litigation involving aspects of California natural gas market.
In re Western States Wholesale Natural Gas Antitrust Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

Western District of Kentucky was appropriate transferee forum for centralization of litigation of four actions relating to standardized agreements between optometry and ophthalmology practices and provider of services; judge in district with favorable caseload had been presiding over one of the actions for several months.
In re PrimeVision Health, Inc. Contract Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Kansas was appropriate transferee forum for multidistrict litigation challenging same United States Department of Energy regulation, where majority of actions were already pending there, fact that judge of such district had had opportunity to become familiar with legal and technical questions in such litigation meant that he was in best position to supervise pretrial proceedings in such litigation to their just and expeditious termination, and fact that such litigation was nationwide meant that geographically central location of District of Kansas commended its selection as transferee district.
In re Dept. of Energy Stripper Well Exemption Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 1282 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, multidistrict actions, concerning violation of antitrust laws, wrongful use of trade secrets and restraint of trade in sale of mini-computers and licensing of software, to Northern District of California, in which three of six actions were pending before judge who was familiar with legal and technical questions and was in best position to supervise pretrial proceedings to just and expeditious termination, thereby preventing duplication of discovery, avoiding inconsistent pretrial rulings and economizing judicial effort.
In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 470 F. Supp. 855 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2954

Western District of Missouri was most appropriate transferee forum for multidistrict litigation where judge of that district through his supervision of four pending actions and a prior related action had become familiar with issues involved in litigation, where the actions were pending throughout country and parties represented that discovery would be nationwide, so that geographically central location of Missouri was a commendable factor, and where more actions were pending in that district than in any other.
In re Multi-Piece Rim Products Liability Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 969 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2958

Four actions, each of which involved alleged conspiracy to increase the price of uranium and to divide portions of the world uranium market, involved common questions of fact and thus three actions brought by the Tennessee Valley Authority would be transferred to the Northern District of Illinois, where the judge had opportunity to become acquainted with litigation and was in best position to supervise pretrial proceedings, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with similar Illinois action.
In re Uranium Industry Antitrust Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 1223 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

The Judicial Panel would transfer multidistrict antitrust and patent cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in the District of Columbia where judge of that district had become familiar with chemical and historical matters relating to semisynthetic penicillin industry and assignment of litigation to him would promote expeditious processing.
In re Amoxicillin Patent and Antitrust Litigation, 449 F. Supp. 601 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2956

In view of familiarity with litigation that had been developed by one judge and where transfer to his district would also best facilitate coordination of private antitrust actions with seminal government civil actions still pending there, and where documents on which grand jury relied were located in that district and much of conduct at issue allegedly there occurred, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation transferred private antitrust cases to such district.
In re Hawaiian Hotel Room Rate Antitrust Litigation, 438 F. Supp. 935 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Sugar price-fixing actions would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions already pending in transferee district court, where inclusion of transferred actions was necessary to ensure prevention of duplicative discovery and eliminate possibility of inconsistent class and other pretrial rulings, inclusion of action would not unduly prolong them, and judge of transferee court had become thoroughly familiar with all issues involved in the complex litigation, so that transferee court was in best position to fully consider and monitor effects of all of issues presented by one transferee concerning its participation in alleged price-fixing.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation (East Coast), 437 F. Supp. 1204 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Where actions, which concerned family ownership of extensive and complex business enterprises, share numerous complex factual questions, and there was complete identity of parties, action brought in California would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with pending action in Northern District of Texas, in which action was more advanced and in which judge before whom action was pending had had opportunity to become thoroughly familiar with complex factual issues presented, in order to best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Ownership of Longoria Bank Deposits Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 913 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Various actions arising out of crash of airplane after takeoff from airport at Papeete, Tahiti, on July 22, 1973 which were pending in the Northern District of California, the Central District of California, and the District of Rhode Island would be transferred and consolidated for pretrial proceedings in the Central District of California.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Papeete, Tahiti, on July 22, 1973, 397 F. Supp. 886 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Where action brought in the District of Connecticut was more advanced than action brought in Kansas, so that judge who was handling the action in Connecticut had gained a familiarity with complicated issues involved in actions brought by states of Connecticut and Kansas against major oil companies, District of Connecticut was the most suitable forum for the cases even though the two states involved contended that the Northern District of Georgia was appropriate transferee district because of its convenient location.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1091 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict actions involving sale of stock of bankrupt would be transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings even though reorganization proceedings and bankrupt's home offices were in the Western District of New York, where judge of Southern District of New York was familiar with the litigation, and majority of documents and witnesses relevant to plaintiffs' claims were located in the Southern District.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 567 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Where actions against the same defendants based on same alleged violations of federal securities laws had been brought in the District of Nevada, the Northern District of California, and the District of Arizona, and where discovery in the Northern District of California had progressed steadily and that court was thoroughly familiar with all factual issues raised in the litigation, and where the only opposition to transfer of all actions came from the plaintiff in that district, Northern District of California was the appropriate transferee forum.
In re Air West, Inc. Securities Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 609 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Where antitrust allegations asserted by defendants in patent infringement action brought by drug manufacturer involved issues raised in antitrust litigation pending against drug manufacturer in the District of Minnesota, where judge in the District of Minnesota had extensive familiarity with the issues and parties involved in litigation and where transferee judge could separately schedule and expeditiously process matters not in the main stream of the consolidated proceedings, motion to transfer would be granted even though plaintiff in the infringement action alleged that discovery on issues allegedly common to the two proceedings was finished in the District of Minnesota.
In re Antibiotic Drugs Antitrust Litigation, 384 F. Supp. 607 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict patent infringement suits were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Western District of Pennsylvania, where two additional infringement actions were pending before judge, who was well acquainted with facts of litigation and was in position to deal with preliminary questions as to whether prior adjudication collaterally estopped plaintiffs from suing defendants on the same patent, and only by transfer could duplicative proceedings and risk of inconsistent decisions be eliminated.
In re Suess Patent Infringement Litigation, 331 F. Supp. 549 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2956

Actions in question would be transferred to Southern District of New York for consolidated pretrial proceedings where judge to whom New York case had been assigned had become acquainted with factual background of cases, where discovery was well advanced in case before such judge, and where parties either were already engaged in litigation in such district or were located in or adjacent to district.
In re Carrom Trademark Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1016 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict computer industry private antitrust cases were transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings to the District of Minnesota, where the only case in that district had been assigned to a judge, who had conducted pretrial conference and under whose supervision discovery had progressed for almost three months, three remaining cases, filed in Southern District of New York, had not been assigned to judge, question of relationship between hardware and software was core question of all cases and chief judge of District of Minnesota had consented to proposed assignment.
In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Parties' situs, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
New York fraud action filed on behalf of all series B bondholders was ordered transferred to District of Massachusetts for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings where, although there was little likelihood for conflicting class determination absent transfer, there were sufficient common questions of fact between lawsuits brought by series A and series B bondholders to warrant transfer to single district, in that common questions concerned alleged misrepresentation in same offering prospectus and whether certain defendants were successors to bond underwriter and vast majority of parties were already present in the District of Massachusetts.
In re Evergreen Valley Project Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 510 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Doing business, parties' situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
In order to minimize duplication of pretrial proceedings in federal antitrust case involving sugar industry, plaintiffs' claims against defendants other than defendant which transacted business primarily in eastern United States were transferred to Northern District of California, where all but one of the remaining defendants transacted business primarily in western United States, claims involved factual issues similar to those involved in California litigation, and transfer as to remaining defendant, which transacted business both in eastern and western United States, increased likelihood that east-west dichotomy, which was justified by substantial east-west distinction between defendants, markets and economic and conspiratorial issues, would remain intact.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Headquarters of corporate defendants, parties' situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
The Central District of California was appropriate transferee district for centralized litigation in 10 putative class actions and seven potential tag-along actions against ride-sharing company, including one action that also asserted claims against smartphone manufacturer, all of which arose from company's announcement that certain personal information of 57 million drivers and riders was inappropriately downloaded by individuals outside the company; three actions were pending in this district, California had significant connection to this litigation, as company had its headquarters in the state, much of the common evidence, including witnesses, would be located there, and judge to whom the litigation would be assigned was an experienced transferee judge.
In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Data Security Breach Litigation, 304 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

District of New Mexico was appropriate transferee district for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation challenging as false and misleading the labeling and advertising of a brand of cigarettes as “natural” and “additive free.” The manufacturer of the cigarettes was headquartered in that district and it represented that key witnesses resided there, four of the actions (including potential tag-alongs) were pending in the district, the district provided a convenient and accessible location for the litigation, and the litigation could be assigned to an able and experienced jurist who had not had the opportunity to preside over a multidistrict litigation docket.
In re Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

Central District of California was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in putative nationwide class actions, pending in seven districts, alleging that manufacturer violated its customers' privacy rights by installing software on certain television sets that allowed it to collect viewing data which it shared with third parties; both defendants and a majority of the plaintiffs supported centralization there, eight of the twenty related actions (including potential tag-along actions) were pending there, manufacturer's headquarters was located there, the district was a convenient and accessible forum, and the transferee judge was an able and experienced jurist who had not yet had opportunity to preside over a docket in multidistrict litigation.
In re: Vizio, Inc., Consumer Privacy Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee district for 80 actions or potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts, involving allegations of improper or illegal conduct by the operators of two online daily fantasy sports contests; choice of that district was supported by both defendants and plaintiffs in at least seven actions, a significant number of related actions were pending in the district, the district presented a convenient and accessible forum with a significant connection to the litigation, since one of the defendants was headquartered there and individual defendants resided either in the district or nearby, which would facilitate discovery, and the transferee judge was an experienced jurist with the willingness and ability to steer the litigation on an efficient and prudent course.
In re Daily Fantasy Sports Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2951

District of New Jersey was appropriate transferee forum for three actions, pending in three districts, alleging that department store's printing of certain credit and debit card information on customer receipts violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act; all three actions were pending in neighboring districts which were a relatively short distance from store's headquarters in Reading, Pennsylvania, the transferee district had the capacity to handle the litigation, and the transferee judge had the time and experience to steer the litigation on a prudent course.
In re Boscov's Dept. Store, LLC, Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA) Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1341 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Rhode Island was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 13 actions and 18 potential tag-along actions pending in multiple districts and alleging defects in various models of hernia patches; witnesses and relevant documents were likely to be found in the district, since defendant's headquarters were located there.
In re Kugel Mesh Hernia Patch Products Liability Litigation, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

District of District of Columbia was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in four putative class actions and ten potential tag-along actions, pending in six districts and alleging various claims arising out of wireless telephone company's rebate plan; many relevant witnesses and documents were likely to be found in district, since it was the location of company's headquarters and related offices, and district was also the situs of a related proceeding.
In re InPhonic, Inc., Wireless Phone Rebate Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of Illinois was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging misrepresentations regarding the presence of gluten, wheat or dairy derivatives in french fries; district was a likely source of relevant documents and witnesses since defendant was headquartered there, and it offered a relatively geographically central and accessible forum for the litigation.
In re McDonald's French Fries Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1342 (J.P.M.L. 2006), adhered to, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008) and subsequent determination, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization in transferee District of Minnesota was appropriate with respect to actions filed in several locations nationwide, arising from alleged defects of implantable defibrillator devices, since, inter alia, the defendant had its headquarters in Minnesota, thus facilitating discovery; fact that there might be some non-common issues among the various actions or that motions were pending in some of them did not militate against transfer.
In re Medtronic, Inc., Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Virginia was appropriate transferee forum for actions alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning a company's financial condition and accounting practices; district was a likely source of relevant documents and witnesses inasmuch as company's headquarters were located there, contained company's pending bankruptcy proceedings, and had relatively favorable caseload statistics.
In re Xyberbaut Corp. Securities Litigation, 403 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for centralized litigation against razor manufacturer that allegedly misrepresented certain aspects of its razor system during advertising of the product; District of Massachusetts was a likely source of relevant documents and witnesses, since manufacturer's headquarters were located there.
In re M3Power Razor System Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2956

Central District of California was appropriate transferee forum for ten actions and two potential tag-along actions, pending in multidistrict litigation and centralized for pretrial proceedings, arising out of oil company's participation in California Air Resources Board's adoption of reformulated gasoline (RFG) regulations which overlapped company's patents; several of the actions were already pending in that district before a judge already familiar with many of the factual and technical issues, and documents and witnesses would likely be found in district inasmuch as company was headquartered there.
In re Reformulated Gasoline (RFG) Antitrust & Patent Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2956

In multidistrict litigation in which five actions, involving factual questions arising out of the sale of a company's subordinated notes, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to District of South Carolina was appropriate; company whose notes were at issue was headquartered there, such that witnesses and documents were likely located there, and all parties agreed that South Carolina was appropriate transferee forum.
In re Thaxton Group Inc. Securities Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2957

In multidistrict litigation in which seven actions and four potential tag-along actions, involving the financial collapse of a corporation, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Southern District of Ohio was appropriate; many parties, witnesses and documents were likely to be found in district inasmuch as corporation was headquartered and bankruptcy proceedings were pending there, and district was geographically central, not currently occupied with multiple other multidistrict litigation, and equipped with the resources likely to be required.
In re National Century Financial Enterprises, Inc., 293 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Arizona was appropriate forum for centralization of multidistrict litigation concerning alleged liability for collapse of corporation and wholly owned subsidiary savings and loan; corporation was headquartered in Arizona, several other defendants and witnesses were located in that state, document depository containing millions of documents was established in forum, and corporation's bankruptcy action was pending there.
In re American Continental Corporation/Lincoln Sav. and Loan Securities Litigation, 130 F.R.D. 475 (J.P.M.L. 1990).
Federal Courts  2957

Although none of seven forums suggested by the parties could be characterized as nexus of litigation involving disaster which took place in foreign country, Southern District of New York would be appropriate transferee forum for the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, given facts that, inter alia, defendant corporation was a New York corporation, relevant witnesses and documents might be located at its corporate headquarters in nearby Connecticut city, and that district had more pending actions than any other district and was therefore relatively more convenient for many parties.
In re Union Carbide Corp. Gas Plant Disaster at Bhopal, India in Dec., 1984, 601 F. Supp. 1035 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
Federal Courts  2953
