Inasmuch as several government agencies located in or near District of Columbia would likely be principal targets of discovery, and inasmuch as Korean airline disaster of September 1, 1983 and resultant litigation implicated sensitive areas of national policy, international relations and military intelligence, the District of Columbia was the proper district for centralization of discovery in 42 actions pending in eight districts, which actions shared numerous fact questions.
In re Korean Air Lines Disaster of Sept. 1, 1983, 575 F. Supp. 342 (J.P.M.L. 1983).
Federal Courts  2955

Forty-five product liability actions pending in 22 districts would be transferred to Southern District of Ohio where defendant drug manufacturer carried on its operations, where common factual questions arose from allegations in each action that birth defects were caused by mother's ingestion during pregnancy of combination drug and centralization was therefore necessary in order to prevent duplication of discovery, avoid inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Richardson-Merrell Inc., 533 F. Supp. 489 (J.P.M.L. 1982).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions brought under the Sherman Act, sections 1 to 7 of Title 15, alleging that eight corporate defendants had violated the terms of a 1951 Federal Trade Commission cease and desist order pertaining to a conspiracy to fix the prices, terms or conditions of sale of “corn derivatives,” would be transferred to the District of New Jersey for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding with the action there pending, since the litigation had an eastern tilt by reason of the location of all eight of the major defendants' headquarters in the eastern half of the country, and since the District of New Jersey stood out by reason of the fact that it was in the best position to process the litigation toward its most expeditious conclusion.
In re Corn Derivatives Antitrust Litigation, 486 F. Supp. 929 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  3826

Sixty-three cases brought by residents of India in the Central District of California and two brought on behalf of foreign domiciliaries in the District of Columbia against manufacturer of aircraft and manufacturer of instruments on the aircraft as a result of the crash of an airplane in Bombay, India, would be transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings in the Western District of Washington which was the place of residence of the aircraft manufacturer and also the place where the Federal Aviation Administration's regional office having custody of the records relating to certification of the aircraft was located.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Santa Cruz Airport, Bombay, India on January 1,1978, 463 F. Supp. 158 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2955

District of Columbia was the preferable transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in swine flu litigation, even though none of the actions yet filed in the litigation was pending there and despite arguments of some plaintiffs that transferee district should be in the central part of the country, where administrative control over the program had been exercised by officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare headquartered in the District of Columbia.
In re Swine Flu Immunization Products Liability Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 244 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions arising from helicopter crash in Germany, causing the deaths of a number of military personnel, would be transferred to Connecticut for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, though one of them had previously been transferred from Florida to California at time where no actions were pending in any other district and all of the then parties were in agreement with the transfer, where subsequently other actions were commenced, five of them in Connecticut, Connecticut was where helicopter was assembled and its headquarters, and second defendant manufactured helicopter engines in adjoining state of Massachusetts, while relatively few documents or witnesses relevant to the crash were located in California.
In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2955

Two derivative actions would be transferred to Northern District of Ohio, where third action was pending and where corporation had headquarters, where all actions claimed illegal corporate expenditures in violation of securities law and presented common questions of fact, despite claim that voluntary cooperation could avoid duplicative discovery efforts and although one action was a class action.
In re General Tire & Rubber Co. Securities Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1032 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Actions by franchisees against franchisor charging antitrust violations in franchise contracts involved common questions of fact and transfer of two actions pending in Southern District of Florida to Southern District of New York, where franchisor's corporate headquarters was located, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action pending there would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Amerada Hess Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Record established that ten private actions which were pending in five different districts and which involved alleged violation of federal securities laws by furnishing false and misleading information to purchasers of securities of multifaceted real estate company should be transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings and that best transferee forum was the Southern District of California where corporate headquarters were located and majority of relevant documents and anticipated witnesses were located.
In re U. S. Financial Securities Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Transfer for actions which involved common questions to the Northern District of California would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses, and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, where home office of defendant was located in that district, and where the vast majority of documents and anticipated witnesses were located there, in relation to actions alleging that activities of defendants concerning multilevel sales and distribution systems were fraudulent and in violation of the federal securities and antitrust laws.
In re Sta-Power Industries Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1398 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict federal securities laws cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Kansas, where defendants' corporate headquarters and vest majority of relevant documents and anticipated witnesses were located and where related proceeding by Securities and Exchange Commission was pending.
In re Clinton Oil Co. Securities Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 813 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Eastern District of Wisconsin was preferable transferee district in which to conduct coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions brought in Eastern District of Wisconsin and Northern District of Illinois against oil company for violation of federal antitrust laws by allegedly fixing retail prices and by requiring dealers to sell only products approved by the oil company where oil company's home office was in Eastern District of Wisconsin and many of anticipated witnesses and relevant documents were located there.
In re Clark Oil & Refining Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 458 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2954

Where movant requested transfer of multidistrict actions to the Southern District of New York on grounds that many defendants and documents were located there and that interstate acquisition occurred there, but where defendant corporation's business was conducted through its Washington, D.C., offices, Washington office of movant provided necessary accounting services to the corporation, and many accounting personnel of the corporation and movant resided in Washington area, where most New York defendants were charged in secondary claim, and where docket comparison indicated desirability of transfer to the District of Columbia, the District of Columbia was the most appropriate transferee district.
In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict stockholder and debenture holder actions alleging that corporation made false and misleading statements were transferred for coordinated pretrial proceedings to District of Colorado, where common questions of fact existed concerning alleged securities law violations of corporation and its individual officers and directors, discovery would proceed along same lines of inquiry, and the district was home of corporation and many defendant individuals and entities and was place where reorganization proceeding under § 501 et seq. of Title 11 involving such corporation was pending.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1179 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

Where allegations in multidistrict actions against corporation charged with violating federal antitrust laws raised common issues of fact, making transfer necessary to avoid duplication in discovery and inconsistent pretrial rulings and to avoid inconsistent class action determinations, actions would be transferred to the Eastern District of Wisconsin where corporation had its principal place of business.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 753 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Manufacture and design, parties' situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Southern District of Ohio was proper transferee district for centralization of six putative class actions pending in five districts against automobile manufacturer in connection with alleged defects that caused vehicles to vibrate excessively; manufacturer had substantial presence in Ohio, including manufacturing and research and development facilities, and thus relevant documents and witnesses would be found there, majority of plaintiffs supported centralization in Ohio, and judge to whom litigation would be assigned was experienced jurist.
In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc., CR-V Vibration Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1336 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
Federal Courts  2953

Three related actions, filed in New York, Colorado and California, arising out of an airplane crash in Denver would be transferred to Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings on ground that such district was preferable transferee forum because the aircraft involved was designed and built there and many of the witnesses and relevant documents were located there.
In re Air Disaster at Denver, Colo., on Nov. 16, 1976, 486 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1980).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Residence of individual defendants, parties' situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Where all operative facts occurred in states other than state in which antitrust action was commenced and great masses of documentary evidence, physically present in those locations, would be necessary for conduct of litigation and all defendants were amenable to suit in state where individual and three corporate plaintiffs were located, case would be transferred to such district even though similar case was pending within district where action was commenced.
Ralph Williams, Inc. v. Chrysler Corp., 327 F. Supp. 469 (E.D. Pa. 1971).
Federal Courts  2908

Middle District of Florida was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that the personally identifiable information of more than two million of the defendant health care providers' patients was compromised in a data breach; the defendants were headquartered in that district, the witnesses and documents relevant to facts of the litigation were located there, the defendants and some plaintiffs supported selection of that district, the vast majority of the actions were already pending there, and the assignee judge was an experience jurist who had not yet had opportunity to preside over a case in multidistrict litigation.
In re 21st Century Oncology Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

Where 40 actions were brought arising from collision of two jet aircraft on runway in the Canary Islands, where surviving pilot and first officer of one aircraft resided in New York area, where investigators of collision from Federal Aviation Administration and National Transportation Safety Board resided in either New York area or Washington, D.C. area, where one airline's headquarters were located in New York and many relevant documents and witnesses were in New York vicinity, and where other centers of discovery in liability phase would be Netherlands, Spain, and the Canary Islands, actions would be transferred to southern district of New York rather than any of the California districts.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tenerife, Canary Islands on March 27, 1977, 435 F. Supp. 927 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2955

Action brought in federal district court in Maryland against corporations and certain officers and employees of such corporations based on alleged violations of securities laws would be transferred to Eastern District of Louisiana for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with similar action pending there, in view of fact that nine common parties were named defendants in both actions, actions involved common questions of fact, and eight of nine common defendants resided or were headquartered in Louisiana.
In re Ascot Oils, Inc. Securities Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1118 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Where actions alleging violations of securities laws, focusing primarily upon alleged failure of corporation's directors and officers to divulge material information to investing public concerning nature and extent of various business dealings which assertedly had substantial adverse effect upon corporation's financial condition and consequently upon failure of its securities, involved common questions of fact, and most corporate and individual defendants could be found in Central District of California along with their records and documents, transfer to Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Pennsylvania Life Co. Securities Litigation, 389 F. Supp. 981 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict cases involving validity of a reissue patent were transferred to the Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where, of the eight real parties in litigation, four either resided in or had a principal place of business in the Central District of California while two of remaining four parties had a principal place of business in the Southern District of California and were represented by counsel with offices in the Central District of California, and in addition five of the seven attorneys active in the litigation maintained offices in the Central District of California and the inventor of the patent resided in the Central District of California.
In re Embro Patent Infringement Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 507 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Residence of individual plaintiffs, parties' situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Actions for death of Kansas university football players in Colorado accident in airplane supplied by Oklahoma corporation and owned by Oklahoma company would be transferred to Kansas district court, where most plaintiffs lived and key witnesses were available and where majority of state court actions were pending, so that state and federal courts might coordinate discovery efforts.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Silver Plume, Colo., on October 2, 1970, 352 F. Supp. 968 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: Pending actions, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
Possibility of promoting state/federal coordination is a factor in selecting a transferee district for purpose of coordinating or consolidating pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation; pendency of related state proceedings is a factor favoring transfer to a district court sitting in such state and before which one of the multidistrict suits is pending.
In re Oil Spill by “Amoco Cadiz” Off Coast of France on March 16, 1978, 471 F. Supp. 473 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

Judicial Panel is reluctant to transfer multidistrict litigation to district wherein none of constituent actions is pending.
In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2951

Transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings may be made to any district regardless of whether or not there are any related actions pending in transferee district.
In re Motor Vehicle Air Pollution Control Equipment, 311 F. Supp. 1349 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Government action situs, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Pendency of a related government action in a particular district is an important factor in the selection of transferee forum by the Judicial Panel.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1271 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Four private treble damage antitrust actions commenced in the Northern District of Illinois and two similar actions commenced in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania and the District of the District of Columbia were transferred, for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings, to the Eastern District of Michigan where a similar suit was pending and all suits were spawned by a criminal indictment and a companion government civil enforcement action filed in the Eastern District of Michigan, and underlying documents were under control of that court.
In re Toilet Seat Antitrust Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust actions against automobile manufacturers by fleet operators, on account of termination of fleet discounts, were ordered transferred to same district to which similar actions by government fleet purchasers had been sent, although manufacturers apparently operated separate discount programs for government purchasers and commercial fleet operators and method of allowing discounts varied, where it appeared that operation of programs was related.
In re Government Auto Fleet Sales Antitrust Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 966 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict treble damage and antitrust actions against manufacturers and wholesalers of refrigerant gases, wholesalers' trade association, two of which were pending in the Southern District of Florida, and one in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, were transferred to the Northern District of Ohio, the situs of government actions against the defendants, for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where the extensive common issues of fact were identical and the class allegations overlapped, and the grand jury which returned original indictments in prosecution of defendants sat in Ohio, no discovery on the merits had occurred in any of the districts, and coordination was necessary between the plaintiffs and the government.
In re Refrigerant Gas Antitrust Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2954

The Judicial Panel transferred actions by states, competing drug manufacturers and private parties for criminal damages and various types of equitable relief to the District of Columbia where government antitrust action was pending even though action was pending in District of New Jersey before judge who was familiar with the litigation.
In re Ampicillin Antitrust Litigation, 315 F. Supp. 317 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——First filed actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
There was sufficient similarity between parties in Hawai'i and Seattle disability discrimination cases to warrant application of first-to-file rule; one named plaintiff in Hawai'i case was charging party in Seattle action filed by Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and accordingly was prevented from bringing independent ADA claim based upon her charge, named Hawai'i plaintiffs were permitted to intervene in Seattle action and they filed complaint in intervention and participated for almost two years therein, and narrow class of persons who were part of proposed class in Hawai'i action but would not be covered by Seattle action did not differentiate parties sufficiently to warrant disregarding first-to-file rule.
Lovell v. United Airlines, Inc., 728 F. Supp. 2d 1096 (D. Haw. 2010).
Federal Courts  3940

Northern District of California was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in two actions, pending in two districts, alleging that defendants' printing of certain credit and debit card information on customer receipts violated the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA); the first-filed action was pending there, and the choice was unopposed.
In re Oilily Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA) Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for centralized actions for breaches of company's fiduciary duties in connection with management of its 401(k) plan subsequent to its bankruptcy and sale; first-filed action was pending in that district, pretrial proceedings were underway there, and most defendants and the responding plaintiffs supported that district.
In re Standard Automotive Corp. Retiree Benefits ''ERISA'' Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization of litigation in the Southern District of Indiana, with regard to three actions involving abusive tax shelter, was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of the parties, their counsel, and the judiciary, where actions involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, and Southern District of Indiana had first-filed action, support of common defendant, and resources that litigation was likely to require.
In re Cobra Tax Shelters Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in multidistrict litigation alleging that bank failed to properly disclose that a fee would be charged to its customers who used its automatic teller machine (ATM); that district contained the first-filed of the actions, and enjoyed the support of all parties.
In re Bank of America ATM Fee Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for ten actions, pending in two districts, alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning company's financial condition and accounting practices; that district contained the first-filed action, and had more favorable caseload statistics than the other proposed transferee district.
In re Veeco Instruments Inc. Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for nine putative class actions, centralized for pretrial proceedings, pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning a company's financial condition; that district contained the majority of the actions, including the first-filed action, and enjoyed the support of all responding parties.
In re Sierra Wireless, Inc., Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

Northern District of California was appropriate transferee forum for four actions, brought in multidistrict litigation under the Sherman Act, to recover for violations arising in context of an alleged conspiracy to fix the price of rubber chemicals, and centralized for pretrial proceedings; that district was the site of the first filed and most advanced action, and was the choice of all responding parties.
In re Rubber Chemicals Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

Centralization of claims adjusters' actions against insurance company for overtime pay under Fair Labor Standards Act in Middle District of Florida was warranted, where actions involved common questions of fact arising out of similar allegations, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, first-filed and most advanced action was pending in district, and district had sufficient resources to manage litigation.
In re GMAC Ins. Management Corp. Overtime Pay Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Nevada was appropriate forum for actions pending in multidistrict litigation and involving claims of fraud and misrepresentation in connection with the sale of an island in the Bahamas; the first-filed constituent action was proceeding in that district, and district was equipped with the resources the docket was likely to require.
In re Mush Cay Litigation, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Number of pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
District of Minnesota was appropriate transferee district for centralized proceedings in 10 actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in multidistrict litigation, arising out of allegations that a large consumer debt arbitration company operated a biased arbitration process and concealed from the public its ties to the collection industry; seven of the actions were already pending in the district, defendants' headquarters were located there, plaintiffs had filed a consolidated amended complaint, a scheduling order was in place, discovery was underway, and the judge overseeing the actions there was an experienced transferee judge with the time and experience to steer the litigation on a prudent course.
In re: National Arbitration Forum Antitrust Litigation, 682 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of California was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in 35 actions pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or omissions relating to a company's improper accounting practices; 34 of the actions were already pending in that district, relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be found there, since the company was former headquartered in San Diego, and the motion proposing selection of the district was unopposed.
In re: Peregrine Systems, Inc., Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2957

In multidistrict litigation in which seventeen actions and five potential tag-along actions were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Eastern District of Tennessee was appropriate; corporate defendant had its headquarters and many individual defendants resided there, majority of actions were pending in that district, and centralization would facilitate coordination between federal court actions and related state court litigation pending in Tennessee.
In re Unumprovident Corp. Securities, Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 280 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

While number of actions pending in potential transferee district is relevant to selection of most appropriate district for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings, such factor is not controlling where actions are nearly equally divided between two districts and where filing of more actions in one district may well be expected.
In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951

Pendency of 9 of the 13 transferable cases in one district was not dispositive of question of choice of forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings but was certainly relevant to selection of proper transferee forum.
In re Koratron, 302 F. Supp. 239 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
In multidistrict litigation concerning causes of the crash of an aircraft, centralization for pretrial proceedings of five actions pending in two districts, to District of Massachusetts, was appropriate; four of the actions were pending in that district, many witnesses and documents would likely be found in district, given situs of the crash, and no party opposed transfer.
In re Air Crash Near Edgartown, Mass., on October 6, 2000, Jud.Pan.Mult.Lit.2003, 269 F.Supp.2d 1370.
Federal Courts  2955

District of District of Columbia was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in actions arising out of disappearance and presumed loss of aircraft during an international flight, where three actions were pending there and District of Columbia offered a convenient and accessible forum for parties and witnesses.
In re Air Crash over the Southern Indian Ocean, on March 8, 2014, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2955

Northern District of Illinois was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in six actions, pending in three districts, concerning the cause or causes of the crash of an aircraft near Medan, Indonesia; four of the actions were already proceeding in that District, such that the transferee judge had developed familiarity with the issues, and the District was a geographically central forum located approximately midway between the defendants' relevant headquarters.
In re Air Crash Near Medan, Indonesia, On September 5, 2005, 544 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2955

District of Connecticut was appropriate transferee forum for seven actions that were brought concerning crash of charter flight, in that District and in Southern District of Texas, before they were consolidated or coordinated for pretrial proceedings; majority of actions were already pending in District of Texas, and judge to whom litigation was assigned had relatively favorable caseload for accepting assignment.
In re Air Crash Near Castellon, Spain on October 10, 2001, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2955

Two actions arising out of crash of private airplane would be transferred to Western District of Pennsylvania, where three actions arising from that crash were already pending there, actions involved common questions of fact and transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation; however, action pending in Utah would not be transferred, since nexus between Utah action and other actions appeared to be too tenuous.
In re Air Crash at Schenley Golf Course, Pittsburgh, Pa., on August 21, 1977, 509 F. Supp. 252 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2955

In air disaster litigation in which a motion is made for transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, Judicial Panel is extremely reluctant to select a district in which no related action is pending.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

Where cases involving airplane crash on the Island of Bali were pending in the Central District of California, the Northern District of California, the Southern District of New York, and the Eastern District of Virginia, where more cases were pending in the Central District of California than in any of the other districts, and where all responding parties recognized the need for transfer of the litigation, cases would be transferred to the Central District of California even though it was alleged that transfer to one of the other districts where cases were pending, or even to the Northern District of Iowa, where one defendant was located, would be more convenient for discovery and for witnesses.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Bali, Indonesia, on April 22, 1974, 400 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Even if one defendant was target defendant and bulk of discovery likely to occur where such defendant was headquartered, where no cases were pending in federal district court where such defendant was headquartered, Judicial Panel would be extremely reluctant to transfer cases to such district for consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Papeete, Tahiti, on July 22, 1973, 397 F. Supp. 886 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict air disaster actions, two of which were pending in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, two in the District of Maryland and one in the Northern District of California, would be transferred to the Southern District of New York where nine actions were pending, in view of common questions of fact and corresponding need for centralized pretrial proceedings.
In re Air Crash Disaster in Ionian Sea on September 8, 1974, 407 F. Supp. 238 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict actions for wrongful death and property damage arising from airplane crash were transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with wrongful death actions already pending, where facts bearing on issues of liability were common to each action and transfer would eliminate possibility of duplication of discovery and avoid unnecessary inconvenience to parties and witnesses.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Pellston, Michigan, on May 9, 1970, 357 F. Supp. 1286 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Where 33 of 34 wrongful death actions arising out of airplane crash were pending in the Central District of California, the Central District of California was most appropriate transferee district for the purposes of pretrial with respect to matters common to all the cases and the necessity for the presence of the plaintiff in the other case for pretrial purposes was de minimis, the other case would be transferred for purposes of pretrial from the Northern District of Illinois to the Central District of California, notwithstanding plaintiff's claim of hardship which formed basis of denial by Illinois court of transfer to California for purposes of trial.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Toronto International Airport on July 5, 1970, 346 F. Supp. 533 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

Where 10 plaintiffs in three districts were asserting liability of common defendant arising out of same airplane crash in Connecticut and 7 of 10 actions were pending in Connecticut and 15 of 28 passengers aboard were Connecticut residents, actions would be transferred to District of Connecticut for pretrial proceedings to further convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tweed-New Haven Airport on June 7, 1971, 343 F. Supp. 951 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2955

In light of substantial common questions of fact relating to cause of airplane crash, fourteen actions were ordered transferred from Southern District of New York, Eastern District of Pennsylvania and Middle District of Pennsylvania to District of Puerto Rico for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with thirteen related pending actions.
In re San Juan, Puerto Rico Air Crash Disaster, 316 F. Supp. 981 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2955

The judicial Panel transferred thirteen actions resulting from collision of airplanes to the Southern District of Ohio where vast majority of pending actions had been filed in or transferred to that district and common questions of fact existed necessitating some type of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and crash had occurred in that district.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Dayton, Ohio, 310 F. Supp. 798 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict cases arising out of airplane crash were transferred to the Northern District of California for consolidated pretrial proceedings where common questions of fact existed in 24 actions resulting from plane crash, the majority of which were pending in the Northern District of California, and where transfer to one district would be for convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of actions.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Hong Kong on June 30, 1967, 298 F. Supp. 390 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Northern District of California was appropriate forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in fifteen actions alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix or maintain prices on international passenger air travel to or from the United States; the actions already pending in that district were proceeding apace before an able judge experienced in the management of complex and multidistrict litigation, and the district was well equipped with the resources the complex docket was likely to require.
In re Intern. Air Transp. Surcharge Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2956

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was preferable transferee forum for centralization for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings of litigation consisting of two actions, and 11 potential tag-along actions, under the Sherman Act to recover for injuries sustained as a result of an alleged conspiracy engaged in by overlapping defendants to fix, raise, maintain, or stabilize prices for hydrogen peroxide and its downstream products sodium perborate and sodium percarbonate, where Eastern District of Pennsylvania had majority of pending actions, the support of plaintiffs in several potential tag-along actions, endorsement of all responding defendants, and a nexus to litigation.
In re Hydrogen Peroxide Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2954

District of Connecticut was appropriate forum for centralized antitrust actions alleging price fixing in the market for polychloroprene rubber (CR); claims of a price-fixing conspiracy involving another rubber product and involving some of the same plaintiffs and defendants was already pending in that district, and not all of the actions subject to transfer motion were limited to allegations of a CR price-fixing conspiracy, but included allegations of conspiracy with regard to the other product as well.
In re Polychloroprene Rubber (CR) Antitrust Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2954

District of Connecticut was appropriate transferee forum, in multidistrict litigation, for centralized pretrial proceedings in nine actions and 15 potential tag-along actions alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix prices for publication paper, in violation of federal antitrust laws; a large number of the actions were pending in that district, transfer there was supported by plaintiffs in nearly all the actions as well as all responding defendants, and many of the defendants, including the largest domestic defendant, were present there.
In re Publication Paper Antitrust Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

Southern District of New York was appropriate forum for transfer of consolidated multidistrict litigation alleging antitrust claims; six of the nine actions were pending in that district, had been consolidated, and were proceeding apace before one judge, and three other actions were stayed pending decision on motion for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Pineapple Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict litigation in which seven actions alleging an unlawful conspiracy to fix the price of cotton yarn in the United States and/or to allocate the U.S. cotton yarn market and customers were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Middle District of North Carolina was appropriate; six of the actions were pending in that district, and it was likely that documents and witnesses would be found in that district or in the vicinity, given the locations of defendants' headquarters.
In re Cotton Yarn Antitrust Litigation, 336 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in three purported class actions and 41 potential tag-along actions, pending in twelve districts and alleging that pharmaceutical manufacturer violated federal antitrust laws by seeking to exclude generic competition; all moving and responding parties agreed, either primarily or alternatively, upon centralization in that forum, the majority of the actions, as well as related patent litigation, was pending in that district, the common defendant was present in the area, and the transferee judge had considerable experience with the issues presented.
In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict litigation in which eight actions and four potential tag-along actions, alleging a conspiracy to fix prices for carbon black, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to District of Massachusetts was appropriate; the majority of the actions were pending in that district, one defendant had its principal place of business there, all five domestic defendants, as well as plaintiffs in seven actions, supported centralization there, and the judge was experienced, with a caseload favorable to receiving the assignment.
In re Carbon Black Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

Action in Hawaii charging three car rental companies having concessions located at Honolulu International Airport with violating Sherman Act, sections 1 to 7 of Title 15, would be transferred to Northern District of California for coordination or consolidated pretrial proceedings with six actions charging major car rental companies which operated airport rental concessions with violation of Sherman Act notwithstanding that plaintiff in Hawaii action was defendant in California actions, where Hawaii action and California actions involved common questions of fact and discovery and other pretrial proceedings essential to development of claims in Hawaii action would overlap discovery and other pretrial proceedings integral to California actions.
In re Airport Car Rental Antitrust Litigation, 459 F. Supp. 1006 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Purported class action brought on behalf of independent corrugated box manufacturers who alleged that defendants, commencing about 1945 and continuing until late 1977, conspired, in violation of the Sherman Act, sections 1 to 7 of Title 15, to monopolize the manufacture, distribution, sale and shipment of corrugated boxes in the United States, and also conspired to restrain trade unreasonably in the manufacture, distribution, sale and shipment of Kraft liner board and corrugated boxes, was properly ordered transferred to the Southern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with corrugated container antitrust litigation pending there.
In re Corrugated Container Antitrust Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 468 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust action pending in the Northern District of California was transferred to the Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with similar action pending there where all parties agreed that actions belonged in the same district for pretrial proceedings but differed only over the more appropriate transferee forum, action shared complex questions of fact which made transfer necessary in order to prevent duplicative discovery, placing actions under supervision of same court would eliminate possibility of conflicting class determinations or other inconsistent pretrial rulings and transfer to Central District best served convenience of parties and witnesses in that key witnesses and other potential sources of discovery were located in the district.
In re Preferential Drug Products Pricing Antitrust Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1027 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Minnesota rather than Washington was appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where the vast majority of the actions were already pending there and pretrial proceedings in the Minnesota actions were further advanced than those in the Washington action.
In re Olympia Brewing Co. Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 398 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Multidistrict paperboard folding carton private antitrust cases would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the Northern District of Illinois where 14 of the 23 actions, involving common questions of fact, had been filed, to best serve convenience of parties and witnesses, to promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, to prevent duplication of discovery and to streamline rest of pretrial proceedings.
In re Folding Carton Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 384 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Where plaintiff's motions in Illinois were stayed pending ruling by the Judicial Panel, Panel would transfer Illinois action for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions already pending in Pennsylvania, in view of common factual issues; if plaintiff's motions were granted by court in Pennsylvania, plaintiff's claims, if appropriate, could be returned to Illinois.
In re REA Express, Inc., Private Treble Damage Antitrust Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

Even though either Northern or Central District of California could be described as appropriate transferee forum, balance favored Northern District of California, where majority of actions were already pending in that district and it appeared that pretrial proceedings in those actions had progressed further than those in actions in Central District.
In re Gas Vent Pipe Antitrust Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 799 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Private treble damage action pending in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania would be transferred to the Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with four private treble damage actions pending in that district, where all actions involved common questions of fact and transfer would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and further just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Commodities Exchange Rate Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Action pending in Southern District of New York would be transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania for pretrial proceedings with similar actions pending there where actions all involved common plaintiff's alleged inability to obtain licenses to manufacture and sell phonograph records and tapes, where actions shared many questions of fact and where transfer to Eastern District of Pennsylvania would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and further the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re CBS Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1177 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Plumbing fixtures case was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania where 370 actions were pending in that district as part of the litigation and plaintiff state's fears that transferee court would not apply laws of circuit in which action was filed in deciding whether state could maintain treble damage action against defendants under provision of § 15 of Title 15, were groundless.
In re Plumbing Fixtures Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 756 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust actions against computer manufacturer by purchaser of manufacturer's equipment which leased equipment to its own customers were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Minnesota where antitrust action against same manufacturer by competing manufacturer was pending and where actions involved common questions of fact concerning manufacturer's monopolization of computer field and would require exploration in depth of wide fields of both technical and economic data.
In re IBM, 319 F. Supp. 926 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict liquid asphalt private antitrust cases were transferred to Northern District of California for coordinated pretrial proceedings where there were common questions of fact between actions to be transferred to Northern District of California and actions originally filed in that district.
In re Western Liquid Asphalt, 309 F. Supp. 157 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict private civil treble damage antitrust suits involving water meters would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Northern District of California, since majority of cases involved in litigation had been filed in such district and cases clearly presented substantial common questions of fact relating to existence and effect of alleged conspiracy.
In re Water Meters, 304 F. Supp. 873 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict civil treble damage litigation involving gypsum wallboard would be transferred to Northern District of California where 94 percent of similar cases were pending in that district, and where it was manifest that convenience of parties and witnesses and the just and efficient conduct of all the actions would be furthered by a transfer of the three remaining cases.
In re Gypsum Wallboard, 297 F. Supp. 1350 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Cargo actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Where litigation included claims resulting from shortages in grain shipped in covered hopper cars and boxcars, and questions relating to “shrinkage factor” of grain remained common to all cases as were questions relating to equipment and procedures used for loading and weighing hopper cars and boxcars, conditional transfer order transferring case to District of Kansas where other actions were pending was proper.
In re Grain Shipments, 319 F. Supp. 533 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Employment actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Western District of Washington was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in two actions, pending in two districts, alleging that the United States Postal Service (USPS) violated the Privacy Act and was unjustly enriched when it disclosed employees' personal information to companies it authorized to disseminate targeted solicitations; the first-filed action was pending there, and the choice would not inconvenience USPS.
In re U.S. Postal Service Privacy Act Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Arizona was appropriate transferee forum for centralized multidistrict litigation; one of three subject actions was pending there, and that tribunal had resources available to manage litigation.
In re Allstate Ins. Co. Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Sixteen actions by labor unions against railroad, in which railroad was alleged to have violated section 2000e et seq. of Title 42 by engaging in illegal employment practices, raised common questions of fact, and transfer of one action pending in Western District of Texas to Southern District of Texas, where other 15 actions were pending, would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of such litigation.
In re Southern Pacific Transp. Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 529 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Actions against employer charging sex discrimination in pregnancy leave policies shared common questions of fact and transfer of action from Western District of Missouri and action from Western District of Oklahoma to Eastern District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with two actions pending in that district would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. Maternity Benefits Litigation, 400 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Explosive, nuclear, and radioactive material actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Eastern District of California was most appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in actions arising out of explosions caused by accidental detonation of a train of bomb-laden boxcars, where vast majority of the actions were already pending in that district, and much of discovery would occur there because it was situs of the explosions and the residence of many of the parties and witnesses.
In re Bomb Disaster at Roseville, California, on April 28, 1973, 399 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
District of Delaware was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in nine actions, pending in three districts, concerning two patents on a pharmaceutical product; seven of the actions were already pending in that district, and the transferee judge had the experience to steer the docket on a prudent course.
In re: Rosuvastatin Calcium Patent Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2956

Central District of California was appropriate transferee district for centralized proceedings in five actions, pending in four districts, concerning the validity of U.S. Patent No. 5,166,809, which claimed an apparatus and methods for “digital halftoning”; the action pending in that district was the only one that also involved patent No. 4,924,301, the parent of the '809 patent, and the purported holder of that patent was located in the district.
In re Halftone Color Separations ('809) Patent Litigation, 547 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2956

Northern District of California was appropriate transferee forum for eight actions in multidistrict litigation, centralized for pretrial proceedings; two of the constituent actions were already proceeding in that district, and the district was an easily accessible, metropolitan district well equipped with the resources that the complex docket was likely to require.
In re Compression Labs, Inc., Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for seven actions and one potential tag-along action, pending in multidistrict litigation and involving the validity of a patent relating to a recombinant DNA technology called co-transformation, which were centralized for pretrial proceedings; venue was convenient inasmuch as most of the parties were in the eastern part of the United States, half of the actions were pending in that district, and district was equipped with the resources likely to be required by the complex docket.
In re Columbia University Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2956

Western District of Washington, where patent action was first filed, rather than Northern District of California, where related action was pending, was appropriate district for centralization of the actions; Washington action was already proceeding apace in that district, while no constituent action or related proceedings were still pending in the Northern District of California forum, which was proffered by defendants as their choice of transferee district.
In re Mailblocks, Inc., Patent Litigation, 279 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2956

Multidistrict actions involving validity and alleged infringement of single patent were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Kansas Where two cases representative of litigation were pending, where discovery was more advanced and where judge of that district had had opportunity to become acquainted with the litigation.
In re FMC Corp. Patent Litigation, 422 F. Supp. 1163 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2956

Where patent holder instituted six patent infringement actions against six separate defendants in three different districts in same state, and actions involved common questions of fact, transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings was ordered to Middle District of North Carolina where patent holder resided, where a substantial amount of relevant discovery would occur and where more actions were pending than in any other district, notwithstanding individual defenses of laches asserted by defendants in all actions, since there was factual overlap with respect to laches discovery in all actions.
In re Smith Patent Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2956

Where damages for patent infringement in 19 different federal districts had in common question of laches, question relating to notice of infringement, and issues of scope of patent, and its validity, including questions of obviousness, invention, prior art and commercial success, and four of such actions were pending in Northern District of Illinois, actions, with exception of three related actions in Central District of California, pretrial proceedings of which had progressed considerably, would be transferred to Northern District of Illinois for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding.
In re Butterfield Patent Infringement, 328 F. Supp. 513 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2956

Cases involving patent would be transferred to district in which some cases were pending, at request of patent owner, in view of substantial and complex common questions of fact concerning validity and misuse, over objections that questions relating to infringement were unique to each defendant, claim that transferee district was not convenient forum, and claims by defendants in cases pending in transferee district that their actions would be delayed.
In re Frost Patent, 316 F. Supp. 977 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Central District of California was appropriate transferee District for centralized pretrial proceedings in 110 actions, pending in seven districts, arising out of allegations that a defective transmission was installed in certain of manufacturer's vehicles; vast majority of the actions were pending in California, including 35 actions in the Central District, centralization in the District would facilitate coordination with state court litigation involving the same alleged defect, transferee judge managed a related nationwide class action settlement involving the same vehicles and alleged transmission defect and thus was familiar with the factual and legal issues in the litigation, and he presided over the actions pending in the district.
In re Ford Motor Co. DPS6 PowerShift Transmission Products Liability Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of Ohio was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in 64 actions, filed by cities, counties, and states and pending in nine districts, alleging that manufacturers of prescription opioid medications overstated benefits and downplayed risks of use of their opioids and aggressively marketed them to physicians, and that distributors failed to monitor, detect, investigate, refuse and report suspicious orders of prescription opiates; Ohio had a strong factual connection to the litigation, the Northern District of Ohio presented a geographically central and accessible forum that was relatively close to defendants' various headquarters in New York, Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and the transferee judge, who was presiding over several opiate cases, had previous experience with multidistrict litigation which provided him valuable insight into the management of such litigation.
In re National Prescription Opiate Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in 53 product liability actions, pending in 17 districts, against drug manufacturers, alleging that medication caused severe bleeding and related injuries; two common manufacturers had corporate headquarters within the district, and thus, relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be located there, 16 actions on the motion and three potential tag-along actions were pending there, and the judge, who presided over all related actions in the district, was an experienced transferee judge with the willingness and ability to manage the litigation.
In re Eliquis (Apixaban) Products Liability Litigation, 282 F. Supp. 3d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

The Southern District of New York was a proper transferee district for the centralization of 18 products liability actions and additional tag-along actions alleging that ingestion of certain prescription drugs could have caused a variety of injuries, including diabetic ketoacidosis and kidney damage; one defendant was headquartered in New York which made it likely that many witnesses and relevant documents were likely to be found in or near the district, 13 of the constituent actions were pending in the district as well as four tag-along actions, and centralization in the district enabled assignment to an experienced jurist who had not had the opportunity to preside over multidistrict litigation.
In re Farxiga (Dapagliflozin) Products Liability Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee district for pretrial proceedings in six actions and 27 tagalong actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that defects in a brand of prosthetic hip replacement devices resulted in corrosion leading to failure of the implants or other serious health consequences; five of the cases in that district were pending before the transferee judge, who had not yet had opportunity to preside over a docket in multidistrict litigation, the district offered an accessible transferee forum for the litigation, which involved a product that was distributed nationwide, and the district was relatively close to defendant's New Jersey headquarters, where relevant documents and witnesses might be found.
In re Stryker Orthopaedics LFIT V40 Femoral Head Products Liability Litigation, 249 F. Supp. 3d 1353 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Louisiana was appropriate transferee forum in 33 actions, pending in 16 districts, alleging that defendants' chemotherapy drug caused permanent hair loss, that they were aware of that possible side effect but failed to warn patients, and that they marketed the drug as more effective than other chemotherapy drugs when other drugs were equally effective without the associated permanent hair loss; plaintiffs in six of the actions and potential tag-along actions, and a responding defendant, supported centralization in the district in the first instance or in the alternative, ten actions and potential tag-along actions already were pending there, the district was an easily accessible and reasonably central one, and the assignee judge was a seasoned jurist who was willing and able to handle the litigation but had not yet had opportunity to preside over a docket in multidistrict litigation.
In re Taxotere (Docetaxel) Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2953

District of South Carolina was appropriate transferee forum for numerous actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging pharmaceutical drug manufacturer's cholesterol-lowering drug caused female users to develop type 2 diabetes; district was the first choice of most plaintiffs and was agreeable to manufacturer, 14 of the 56 constituent actions were pending there, as well as at least a dozen potential tag-alongs, and transferee judge was already presiding over all of the cases in the district and was handling them in a coordinated fashion.
In re: Lipitor (Atorvastatin Calcium) Marketing, Salespractices and Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 997 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Louisiana was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in 21 products liability actions and more than 30 tag-along actions, pending in 22 districts, alleging that plaintiffs who used the defendants' medication suffered severe bleeding or other injuries and that defendants did not adequately warn prescribing physicians or consumers of the risks associated with the drug; one action on the motion and 12 of the potential tag-along actions were pending in that district, district had the support of a number of plaintiffs and the opposing defendants as an appropriate alternative, district provided a geographically central forum for the nationwide litigation, and the judge, who presided over three of the potential tag-along actions, was an experienced transferee judge with the willingness and ability to manage the litigation efficiently.
In re: Xarelto (Rivaroxaban) Products Liability Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1402 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of Illinois was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in multiple actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that several components manufactured by defendant for use in knee replacement surgeries were prone to premature loosening, causing recipients pain and loss of movement and often requiring revision surgery; ten of the constituent actions were pending in that district, and the district was relatively close to defendant's Indiana headquarters.
In re: Zimmer Nexgen Knee Implant Products Liability Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Minnesota was appropriate transferee forum for 15 actions, pending in multiple districts, alleging that the antibiotic Levaquin caused tendon rupture, and that warnings about that risk were inadequate; eight of the actions, including the first-filed action, were already pending in that district, discovery was already underway, and the transferee judge had familiarized himself with the litigation.
In re: Levaquin Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Central District of California was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in five actions, pending in five districts, concerning the marketing of two anemia drugs, which involved alleged violations of California statutory law, even though four of the actions, originally brought in that district, had been transferred elsewhere; centralization would entrust the litigation to a jurist with both a unique understanding of its history and considerable expertise in the applicable law.
In re Epogen and Aranesp Off-Label Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was appropriate transferee district for actions in multidistrict litigation alleging that certain diabetes drugs caused an increased risk of heart attack and other physical injury, and that manufacturer failed to provide adequate warnings concerning that risk; manufacturer's principal place of business was located in that district, which was thus a likely location in which to find relevant witnesses and documents.
In re Avandia Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Minnesota was appropriate transferee forum for 58 actions and 50 potential tag-along actions, pending in multiple districts, involving the alleged adverse side effects of a drug and the timeliness and adequacy of warnings concerning those side effects; district had the most advanced of the actions, the judge there had had an opportunity to become familiar with the litigation, and Minneapolis was easily accessible.
In re Mirapex Products Liability Litigation, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

District of South Carolina was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging personal and/or economic injury arising out of eye infections associated with defendant's contact lens solution; district was a likely source of relevant discovery since defendant had a manufacturing facility there, and it provided a logical situs in regard to the geographic dispersal of the constituent and potential tag-along actions.
In re Bausch & Lomb Inc. Contact Lens Solution Products Liability Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1336 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Minnesota was appropriate district for centralization of pretrial proceedings in multiple products liability actions against manufacturer of cardiac pacemakers; at least ten actions were already pending there, it was geographically central, metropolitan district equipped with resources that case was likely to require, and had nexus to case as location of key facilities involved in development and manufacturing of relevant devices.
In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Michigan was appropriate transferee forum for putative class actions sharing factual questions regarding whether certain of manufacturer's vehicles were equipped with defective or defectively-installed speed control deactivation switches; district contained the first-filed action, and was a likely source of relevant documents and witnesses, since manufacturer's headquarters were located there.
In re Ford Motor Co. Speed Control Deactivation Switch Products Liability Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005), subsequent determination, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Louisiana, where four of the five putative class actions brought on behalf of purchasers of gasoline that contained high levels of sulfur were pending before one judge, was an appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings; all parties are in agreement upon selection of that district, which encompassed the location of the refinery that produced the gasoline at issue.
In re High Sulfur Content Gasoline Products Liability Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 2d 755 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Centralization, in the Southern District of West Virginia, was warranted under statute governing multidistrict litigation with respect to three putative class actions against washing machine manufacturer and related defendants, inasmuch as actions, which sought damages for alleged defects in washing machines, involved common questions of fact, centralization would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, centralization was necessary to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel, and the judiciary, and selected district was appropriate forum, in that one action already was proceeding there and district was well-equipped with resources that docket was likely to require.
In re Maytag Corp. Neptune Washer Products Liability Litigation, 333 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Western District of Oklahoma was appropriate forum for transfer, in multidistrict litigation, of three actions and eight potential tag-along actions, centralized for pretrial proceedings and alleging that defective engine pistons in automobile manufacturer's vehicles damaged the value of some vehicles; the first of the constituent actions was proceeding in that district, and district was equipped with the resources likely to be required by the complex docket.
In re General Motors Corp. Piston Slap Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1386 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer, of 14 actions and approximately 200 potential tag-along actions pending in multidistrict litigation and centralized for pretrial proceedings, and alleging that manufacturers of ephedra-containing products knew of and concealed, misrepresented, or failed to warn of side-effects, to Southern District of New York, was appropriate; judge in that district was already presiding over related actions and was in the process of establishing procedures for the conduct of those actions.
In re Ephedra Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of four actions, pending in two districts and centralized for pretrial proceedings, which alleged that manufacturers' defectively designed back-wire push-in electrical receptacles were unreasonably dangerous and caused an increased risk of fire or electrical shock, to District of South Carolina, was appropriate; two of the four actions were pending there and the movant alternatively supported centralization in that district.
In re Electrical Receptacle Products Liability Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2915

Actions involving common question of fact should be transferred to district in which seven of the nine actions were pending and at a more advanced stage than other actions, rather than to district in which no actions were pending or district in which but single action was pending.
In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability Litigation, 68 F.R.D. 502 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation alleging that company violated securities laws by misleading investors about the nature of its investments and its financial condition; nine of the ten actions were already pending in the district before a judge who was also presiding over related litigation, and relevant witnesses and documents were likely in the vicinity, since the corporate defendants were located there.
In re: Citigroup Inc. Securities Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
Federal Courts  2957

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that financial services company issued materially false and misleading statements relating to its wholly-owned subsidiary, artificially inflating its stock price in violation of federal securities laws; company maintained business operations in that district, the conduct at issue allegedly took place in Pennsylvania, and relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be located there.
In re Sterling Financial Corp. Securities Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2957

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for 17 actions and five potential tag-along actions alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning a company's financial condition and alleged overvaluation of interest only strips—securities; nearly all of the actions were already pending there, and most of the responding parties favored that district.
In re Doral Financial Corp. Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for two putative class actions and two potential tag-along actions, pending in two districts and alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning the financial condition of a company; given that no district stood out as the focal point of the litigation, that district, in which one action was already pending, provided an accessible, metropolitan location which was not opposed by any party.
In re Rhodia S.A., Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

Appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in 23 actions brought under federal securities law and ERISA was the Southern District of New York, where defendant had its headquarters and many individual defendants resided in that district, majority of the related actions were pending in that district, and all parties agreed upon centralization in some form in that district.
In re Pfizer Inc. Securities, Derivative & Erisa Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2957

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was appropriate transferee forum for four putative class actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that sellers of securities failed to disclose their participation in an unsustainable business scheme involving payment of illicit commissions; district was the only suggested forum where was constituent action was already pending, district provided an accessible metropolitan court possessing the necessary resources and expertise, and district was adjacent to another district in which another action involving defendants was pending.
In re Ace Ltd. Securities Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

Middle District of Florida was appropriate transferee forum for five actions and one potential tag-along action, in multidistrict litigation alleging that company misrepresented its financial condition to the public, engaged in improper accounting practices, or both, causing plaintiffs and others to purchase company's stock at artificially inflated prices; three of the actions were already pending there, company had its major domestic office there, and all moving and responding parties agreed to that forum.
In re CP Ships Ltd. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2957

In multidistrict litigation in which plaintiffs in 14 actions and 3 potential tag-along actions sought relief under federal securities laws or as shareholders suing derivatively, on basis of alleged artificial inflation of price of company's securities, Eastern District of Texas was an appropriate transferee forum; 14 of the actions were already pending there, and judge had had opportunity to become familiar with the litigation.
In re Fleming Companies Inc. Securities and Derivative Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2957
