District in which 17 securities law actions relating to same public offering would be centralized was one where 14 of 17 actions were brought, where offeror was headquarter, and where pretrial order was entered establishing orderly structure for prosecution of actions.
In re Computervision Corp. Securities Litigation, 814 F. Supp. 85 (J.P.M.L. 1993).
Federal Courts  2957

Of 61 actions pending in 17 districts, 59 would be centralized for pretrial purposes in the Western District of Oklahoma where the 59 actions shared numerous factual questions relating to promotion and sale of limited partnership interests in oil and gas drilling programs, and centralization was necessary in order to avoid duplication of discovery, prevent inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties, their counsel and judiciary.
In re Longhorn Securities Litigation, 552 F. Supp. 1003 (J.P.M.L. 1982).
Federal Courts  2953

Action against brokerage firm and others would be transferred to district in which similar actions were pending for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings even though the individual action did not involve purchases of all of the stocks involved in the other pending proceedings where the action shared common questions of fact regarding the same claims of market manipulation and other violations of the securities laws.
In re Vernitron Securities Litigation, 469 F. Supp. 297 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2914

Claims in Bloor against the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver for national bank, which claims had been severed and transferred to the Eastern District of New York, would be ordered transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions pending there, since the Corporation action involved common questions of fact with the actions previously centralized in the Southern District of New York, and transfer of the Corporation action to that district would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Investors Funding Corp. of New York Securities Litigation, 461 F. Supp. 673 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Where action brought by corporation's bankruptcy trustee against certain former officers and directors of corporation and previously transferred actions against corporate officers and directors alleging violations of federal securities laws involved common questions of fact concerning conduct of individual defendants with respect to operation of corporation and sale of corporation's stock, action brought by bankruptcy trustee would be transferred to Southern District of New York for inclusion in proceedings pending there, despite fact that actions were based on different theories of liability and despite trustee's allegations of difficulty of discovery and delay.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 442 F. Supp. 547 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Where six similar actions had been brought against corporation, where four of those had been brought in the Southern District of Texas, where one had been brought in the district of Delaware, where, the sixth had been brought in the Southern District of New York, where corporation had its headquarters in the Southern District of Texas, and where three of the six plaintiffs supported the Southern District of Texas as the district for transfer, the cases would be transferred to the Southern District of Texas for pretrial proceedings despite contention that agencies of the federal government would be significantly involved and that the action should thus be transferred to the district for the District of Columbia.
In re Tenneco Inc. Securities Litigation, 426 F. Supp. 1187 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict litigation arising from alleged violations of various federal and state securities laws by false and misleading representations and omissions of material facts in connection with sales of loan participations were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Southern District of New York where actions raising common questions of fact were pending in order to prevent duplication of discovery, eliminate possibility of conflicting pretrial rulings, and conserve efforts of parties, witnesses, and judiciary.
In re Colocotronis Tanker Securities Litigation, 420 F. Supp. 998 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Customer's action against broker, based on broker's claimed misconduct in recommending purchase of corporation's securities when broker knew or should have known that corporation was perpetrating fraud, and wherein broker claimed right to arbitrate, was properly transferred to district in which actions involving corporation's alleged fraud were pending, particularly since other broker-dealer actions involving propriety of arbitration were currently pending in that district.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 396 F. Supp. 1277 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Where 13 of 18 actions involved in multidistrict litigation were already pending in the Southern District of New York and were proceeding expeditiously and where an important defendant's operations were conducted in that district, the Southern District of New York was the most appropriate transferee forum even though the major corporate defendant had its home office in the Northern District of Texas where several of the other actions were initiated.
In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2953

Action in the District of Minnesota to recover, under theories of common law fraud and federal securities law, for failure to disclose material facts concerning corporation's financial condition prior to time plaintiffs exchanged their interest in certain Iowa property for corporate stock was ordered transferred to the Southern District of Iowa for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings, in view of fact that two of three actions involving real estate project in Des Moines, Iowa, were pending in that district, actions involved many common questions of fact concerning corporation's financial condition and defendants would not be prejudiced by transfer.
In re Alodex Corp. Securities Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 790 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Stockholder's derivative action growing out of earlier action brought by Securities and Exchange Commission against agents and investment advisers of corporation would be transferred by Judicial Panel to Southern District of New York wherein two other such actions were pending, where there were extensive common factual issues, where defendants and many prospective nonparty witnesses were located in such district and where, unless conflicting overlapping claims of class representation were presented to one judge, there might be inconsistent determinations.
In re Value Line Special Situations Fund Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 999 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2957

Multidistrict actions by preferred stockholders in first corporation who complained of amount received upon merger with second corporation would be transferred to Southern District of New York, where some cases were pending, where first corporation had office in New York suitable as repository for records, second corporation had main office in New York, and most actions were brought as class actions on behalf of same class and there were complex questions of fact common to all cases.
In re Brown Co. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 307 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Miscellaneous actions, pending actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Northern District of California was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in four actions and one potential tag-along action pending in three districts and alleging that bank engaged in discriminatory residential lending practices that increased the cost of financing for minority borrowers; three of the actions, including the first-filed action, were pending in that district, and relevant documents and witnesses were likely to be found there, since bank was headquartered there.
In re Wells Fargo Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

Western District of North Carolina was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in nine actions and five potential tag-along actions, pending in multidistrict litigation, alleging that a company's store managers were entitled to overtime pay under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA); six of the actions were already underway in that district, and witnesses and documents were likely to be found there, since defendant was headquartered in the district.
In re Family Dollar Stores, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
Federal Courts  2953

District of Massachusetts was appropriate transferee forum for three actions pending in three districts and alleging that credit union's “pre-screened” letters of credit violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) because they were not “firm offers of credit” within the meaning of FCRA; the constituent action already pending in that district was clearly the most advanced of the three actions, and the district was the unopposed choice of the moving party.
In re Greenwood Credit Union Prescreening Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007).
Federal Courts  2953

Western District of Missouri was appropriate transferee forum for centralized proceedings in actions in multidistrict litigation alleging tax preparer's breach of fiduciary duties to its clientele in connection with the marketing and sale of an investment product; most of the actions were already pending in that district, and relevant documents and witnesses might be found in district since it was location of defendant's corporate headquarters.
In re H & R Block, Inc., Express IRA Marketing Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Three actions in multidistrict litigation relating to two prescription medications, which had been ordered separated and remanded from litigation involving a third medication, would be transferred to the Northern District of California for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, since proceedings were already occurring there.
In re Vioxx Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

Eastern District of Pennsylvania was appropriate forum for centralized actions challenging defendants' alleged improper marketing of estate or financial planning services to senior citizens solely to obtain financial information in order to target prospective purchasers of deferred annuities; five constituent actions were already proceeding in that district, including three that had been pending nearly a year longer than those filed outside this district, and the judge to whom the litigation was assigned had already developed familiarity with the issues.
In re American Investors Life Ins. Co. Annuity Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

Western District of Pennsylvania was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in four actions, pending in three districts, alleging that mortgage lenders conspired with mortgage broker to include certain undisclosed fees and costs in residential mortgage settlements; one of the actions was pending in that district, the district had the capacity to handle the litigation, and a similar action from Pennsylvania had been settled and was the subject of multiple appeals.
In re Community Bank of Northern Virginia Mortgage Lending Practices Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation involving actions alleging insurance company increased the monthly deductions for universal life policies in breach of the plain language of those policies, Central District of California was appropriate transferee forum; a plurality of the actions were pending in that district, and plaintiffs in all three actions pending before the Panel, as well as company, supported that district as their first or second choice for transferee district.
In re Conseco Life Ins. Co. Cost of Ins. Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Northern District of California was appropriate forum for centralized proceedings in 24 actions and 16 potential tag-along actions, pending in seven districts and alleging that various aspects of airline travel cause, or contribute to, the development of deep vein thrombosis in airline passengers; 22 of the actions and ten of the potential tag-along actions were already pending in that district.
In re Deep Vein Thrombosis Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2955

Transfer of eight actions arising out of airline's failure to provide air transportation for ticket holders, pending in four districts in multidistrict litigation and centralized for pretrial proceedings, to Eastern District of New York, was appropriate; five of the eight actions were already pending in that district and pretrial proceedings were already underway in those actions.
In re Nigeria Charter Flights Contract Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2955

Northern District of Illinois was appropriate transferee district for nationwide litigation arising from alleged unfair loan servicing and debt collection practices by bank and other defendants, given that no district stood out as focal point for action in light of the geographic dispersal of constituent actions and potential tag-along actions, that three actions and one potentially related action were pending in Illinois district, and that district was centrally located geographically.
In re Ocwen Federal Bank FSB Mortgage Servicing Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation in which two actions and seven potential tag-along actions, pending in seven districts and alleging that internet service provider created unauthorized accounts for certain of its subscribers, charging them additional subscription fees and conspiring to prevent them from obtaining refunds for the unauthorized charges, were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Central District of California was appropriate; all plaintiffs and defendants in two actions acquiesced to centralization in the district, and one action and one potential tag-along action were pending there.
In re America Online Spin-Off Accounts Litigation, 310 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation in which centralization, of 46 actions and 8 potential tag-along actions alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning the financial condition of a communications company, was ordered, Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum; a civil enforcement proceeding by the Securities and Exchange Commission, criminal proceedings against the individual defendants, and bankruptcy proceedings were pending in district, which provided a relatively convenient location and possessed necessary resources to be able to devote substantial time and effort to pretrial matters likely to be required.
In re Adelphia Communications Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation (No. II), 273 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2003), subsequent determination, 2003 WL 22047621 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of 23 actions against railroad involved in derailment, pending in multidistrict litigation and consolidated for pretrial proceedings, to Eastern District of Louisiana, was appropriate; more than 20 related actions were already pending there, derailment took place in Louisiana, witnesses could be expected to be found there, and actions were already proceeding in that district.
In re Train Derailment Near Amite, LA, on October 12, 2002, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation, Middle District of Tennessee would be appropriate forum for three centralized actions, brought under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) on behalf of participants in company's investment plan, which alleged breach of fiduciary duty; Tennessee court had already had opportunity to become familiar with the issues, two of the actions were already pending there, and the third action had only recently been filed in another court.
In re Nortel Networks Corp. Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer of centralized action, arising from discovery of human remains on land near crematorium in Georgia, to Northern District of Georgia, was warranted; crematory that was central to action was located in that district, associated criminal investigation and recovery effort was ongoing in that district, relevant documents, witnesses, and other evidence would likely be found there, and two of the three constituent actions were pending there.
In re Tri-State Crematory Lit., 206 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2908

Actions brought in the Southern District of West Virginia and Western District of Louisiana by present or former truck drivers to recover for chemical poisoning allegedly suffered while hauling liquid carbon monoxide from Geisman, Louisiana plant were ordered transferred to Eastern District of Louisiana for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions pending in the latter district since such actions shared common questions of fact and transfer would best serve the means of parties and witnesses and promote efficient conduct of litigation; however, whether consolidation was to include suits involving other defendants, statutes and issues was for discretion of transferee judge.
In re Liquid Carbonic Truck Drivers Chemical Poisoning Litigation, 423 F. Supp. 937 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

Eighteen actions against fabricator of steel used in bridge, bridge designer, the United States and the State of Ohio arising out of collapse of bridge spanning the Ohio River were ordered transferred from the Southern District of Ohio and the District of Maryland to the Southern District of West Virginia for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with 30 related pending actions.
In re Silver Bridge Disaster, 311 F. Supp. 1345 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: Personal jurisdiction, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Propriety of in personam jurisdiction in a proposed transferee district is not a criterion in considering transfer of actions to that district under this section.
In re Highway Acc. Near Rockville, Connecticut, on December 30, 1972, 388 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1975). See, also, In re Truck Acc. Near Alamagordo, New Mexico, on June 18, 1969, 387 F. Supp. 732 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

In view of importance of having owner of three of patents in issue present as party in consolidated proceedings to determine validity of six basic patents which predominated in double knit yarn industry in order to secure conclusive determination of all common issues, existence of grave doubt as to whether the patent owner could be made party defendant in Eastern District of New York for purposes of trial and fact that transfer to Southern District of Florida would be both for convenience of parties and witnesses and the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, the 35 cases, originally brought in four districts, would be consolidated for pretrial proceedings and for trial in Southern District of Florida.
In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: Previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
Actions, which arose from fatal explosion of grain elevator in Louisiana would be transferred to Eastern District of Louisiana for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with action pending there, where presence of differing legal theories in some of actions did not negate existence of common questions of fact, including myriad of questions relating to cause of explosion, 55 of 61 actions in this litigation were already consolidated in Eastern District of Louisiana, most of parties were located in Louisiana, action in Eastern District of Louisiana was clearly most advanced, and judge to whom Louisiana action was assigned was judge most familiar with this litigation.
In re Continental Grain Co., Inc., 482 F. Supp. 330 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2953

Class action against bank which allegedly played intimate part in fraudulent pyramid sales scheme would be transferred to district where actions against other alleged participants in scheme had been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings even though bank was not a defendant in any of the other actions.
In re Glenn W. Turner Enterprises Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 844 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2956

Actions involving enforcement of reserve clause of professional hockey players' contracts would be transferred to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania for co-ordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions previously transferred and pending in that district.
In re Professional Hockey Antitrust Litigation, 369 F. Supp. 1117 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Actions pending in the Eastern District of Missouri and in the Districts of Vermont and Delaware would be transferred to the District of Columbia in which six previously transferred actions involving common questions of fact concerning alleged fraud on government by contractors in production of rocket launchers were pending.
In re Alsco-Harvard Fraud Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Service of process, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Factors involved in multidistrict litigation in which numerous cases had previously been transferred pointed to desirability of transferring cases where significant number but not all defendants had been served.
In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Suit brought by representatives of estate of deceased airline stewardess against the United States, charging that Federal Aviation Administration air traffic controllers were negligent in directing ill-fated aircraft on its approach, would be transferred to the District of Massachusetts for inclusion in the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings pending in that district relative to actions brought against the airline by representatives of deceased passengers, since, inter alia, the question of the government's liability for the crash had been injected into the other litigation in the transferee district because of third-party claims filed by the airline against the United States, and since those third-party claims and the instant suit shared common factual questions.
In re Delta Airlines Crash at Boston, Massachusetts, on July 31, 1973, 395 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Where six actions arising from airplane crash were pending in district in which accident occurred and one was pending in another district, pursuant to the unopposed motion of defendant airline, the Judicial Panel transferred single action pending in another district to the district in which the six actions were pending for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, since actions involved common questions of fact and the transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Chattanooga, Tenn., on November 27, 1973, 393 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Action brought against aircraft manufacturer by relatives of crew members who perished in air crash would be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to the Central District of California, where action raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to that district and its transfer to that district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Paris, France, on March 3, 1974, 386 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2955

Action arising out of crash of Allegheny Airlines aircraft near Tweed Airport at New Haven, Connecticut, was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Connecticut, where other actions arising out of same crash and involving common issues had already been transferred.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tweed-New Haven on June 7, 1971, 368 F. Supp. 815 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Multidistrict civil actions involving air crash disaster at Everglades, Florida were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Southern District of Florida in order to eliminate possibility of duplicative discovery and conflicting pretrial rulings when actions involved questions of fact identical to those raised in actions previously transferred to that district.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Florida Everglades on Dec. 29, 1972, 368 F. Supp. 812 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Action for wrongful death of Marine Corps pilot, arising from midair collision with passenger plane, was transferred to Central District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, including rulings on motions to dismiss or quash process, with actions previously transferred.
In re Duarte, California Air Crash Disaster on June 6, 1971, 354 F. Supp. 278 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Treble damage antitrust suit brought by state against corporations offering armored car and related services shared questions of fact with similar actions previously transferred to Northern District of Georgia and, where transfer of state's action would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of such litigation, such suit would likewise be transferred to Northern District of Georgia.
In re Armored Car Antitrust Litigation, 462 F. Supp. 394 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict milk antitrust case would be transferred to Western District of Missouri for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions previously transferred there where cases in district were fairly representative of litigation and transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 930 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Where action pending in the Western District of Texas shared common questions of fact with actions previously transferred to the Northern District of California and where inclusion of pending action in pretrial proceedings there would best serve the convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of multidistrict antitrust litigation, action was transferred to the Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1122 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Where actions brought by individuals and companies engaged in the production and feeding of beef cattle against supermarket chains and others who had allegedly conspired to depress the wholesale price of beef and to raise the price of beef sold at retail had been transferred to the Northern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, subsequent actions brought by some of the same plaintiffs against certain beef packers would also be transferred to the Northern District of Texas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 432 F. Supp. 211 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Recently filed antitrust actions involving sugar industry were appropriate for transfer to Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where they were brought by or on behalf of western plaintiffs, involved only western defendants, and alleged solely western conspiracies and, therefore, shared common questions of fact with each other and with actions previously transferred to Northern District of California.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 427 F. Supp. 1018 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust actions by governments of two foreign countries against seven pharmaceutical manufacturers involved questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to District of Minnesota and their transfer to that district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Multidistrict Civil Antitrust Actions Involving Antibiotic Drugs, 405 F. Supp. 1302 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Action involving charges against milk seller of antitrust and fair trade law violations in Texas and Arkansas would be transferred for reasons of pretrial proceedings to court to which other similar actions against seller on claims of midwest milk monopolization had been transferred, despite claims that none of the active actions in transferee court involved alleged activity in Texas or Arkansas and that transfer would not necessarily accelerate discovery, particularly since seller had failed to agree with buyers' proposal to stipulate that discovery in transferred litigation should be applicable to instant case.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 676 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Actions charging manufacturer of electronic data-processing systems with illegal monopolization in the various product markets in which plaintiffs, the producers of defendant compatible peripheral equipment, are involved would be transferred to the Northern District of California for inclusion in the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings pending in that district, since the actions raised questions of fact common to the actions previously transferred and since their transfer to the Northern District of California would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 394 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict civil actions brought by automobile buyers against automobile company and dealers who allegedly engaged in nationwide conspiracy which violated antitrust laws would be transferred to the Southern District of Florida for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions previously transferred to that district, where these actions raised questions of fact common to the actions previously transferred to the Southern District of Florida and their transfer to that district would best serve the convenience of the parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
In re Nissan Motor Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1253 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Action alleging that several defendant hotels and motels engaged in a nationwide conspiracy to increase room rates by addition of telephone service charges in violation of federal antitrust laws was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Central District of California, where action raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to Central District, transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation and transfer would prevent needless duplication of discovery.
In re Hotel Telephone Charge Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Antitrust action brought by plaintiffs who purported to represent a class of franchisees in a limited geographical area would be transferred from the Eastern District of Pennsylvania to the Northern District of California for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where action raised questions of fact common to previously transferred actions brought by other present or former franchisees of defendant, despite contentions of plaintiffs that their action involved only local issues and that transfer should be denied on basis of transferee judge's finding that previously consolidated actions lacked sufficient commonality of facts to warrant class action treatment.
In re 7-Eleven Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 286 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2954

Where there existed substantial common question of facts, transfer would generally benefit parties and witnesses, and just and efficient conduct of litigation would be furthered by transfer, action for conspiracy to exclude distributors of gypsum wallboard from access to market could be transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings to court to which other cases had been transferred, notwithstanding that parties were not identical and that discovery had taken place in such case.
In re Gypsum Wallboard, 303 F. Supp. 510 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict antibiotic drugs private antitrust cases were transferred to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with other cases in that district where to do so would clearly be for convenience of parties and witnesses and would promote the just and efficient conduct of such actions, since the cases involved issues of fact common to each other and to previously transferred cases.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 297 F. Supp. 1126 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Cargo actions, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Action by government against railroad to recover damages for alleged losses of grain during shipment would be transferred to the District of Kansas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, in view of presence of complex and important questions of fact common to such case and to many of cases previously transferred to or originally filed in the District of Kansas, notwithstanding defendant's claim that case involved a different carrier, different points of origin and destination, and a different type of grain then involved in other cases.
In re Grain Shipments, 332 F. Supp. 588 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

Two cases filed by United States to recover for alleged losses of grain of Commodity Credit Corporation occurring during shipment on defendant lines were appropriate for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with previously transferred cases and was transferred to District of Kansas where the cases shared common questions of fact with the Kansas cases and if not transferred expeditiously the schedule which had been set up would be undermined and effectiveness of pretrial proceedings diminished.
In re Grain Shipments, 327 F. Supp. 1313 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict Commodity Credit Corporation litigation involving grain shipments were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Kansas, where cases transferred were not ready for trial, they involved many complex questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to District of Kansas, substantial discovery as to common questions of fact remained to be done, and convenience of parties and witnesses and just and efficient conduct of litigation would be served by transfer.
In re Grain Shipments, 325 F. Supp. 318 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2953

Where claim against railroad for damages due to loss of grain during shipment involved questions common to other similar actions consolidated for pretrial proceedings in the District of Kansas, and transfer of the claim would serve the overall convenience of the majority of parties and promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation as a whole, transfer was sustained even though the railroad claimed that to do so would result in expenses to it greater than the claim against it.
In re Grain Shipments, 304 F. Supp. 457 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2915

head.headtext: ——Patent actions, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Eastern District of Pennsylvania was appropriate transferee forum for 17 actions and 28 potential tag-along actions in multidistrict litigation, centralized for pretrial proceedings; allegations in the actions, which involved the validity of a patent for a system for spraying self-tanning solutions and other compositions on the human body, were similar to those in actions previously centralized in that District, and transfer would further the expeditious resolution of the litigation.
In re Laughlin Products, Inc., Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2956

Antibiotic patent infringement actions were transferred to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with other “antibiotic drug cases” previously transferred to New York.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 327 F. Supp. 617 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Products liability actions, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Actions arising from the swine flu immunization program would be transferred to the District of Columbia for inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings occurring in that district, despite contentions that one of the actions was the only pending action based on injuries sustained from fainting after receipt of vaccination and that plaintiffs were financially unable to enter an appearance in the District of Columbia or to participate fully in pretrial proceedings in that district.
In re Swine Flu Immunization Products Liability Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 648 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Three actions involving claims arising out of use of intrauterine contraceptive devices would be transferred to District of Kansas, since such actions raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to that District; fact that one such action involved solely New Jersey law did not render transfer inappropriate, and fact that majority of witnesses in remaining two actions resided in transferee district did not render transfer inappropriate, since witnesses did not usually participate in pretrial conferences, and depositions of such witnesses would probably occur in proximity to where they resided.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc., 438 F. Supp. 942 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Products liability action alleging that fire behavior characteristics of certain insulating materials had substantially impaired value of plaintiff's home, rendering it unsuitable for human habitation until corrected by covering or removing defective products, shared common questions of fact with previously transferred actions and transferred to District of Minnesota to join actions already pending there for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Celotex Corp. “Technifoam” Products Liability Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 1077 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2953

Multidistrict actions involving claims arising out of use of intrauterine contraceptive devices would be transferred to District of Kansas, where each action shared same factual questions concerning design, testing, manufacture, labeling and inspection of one device that predominated in actions previously transferred to that District, and number of actions already transferred involved both injuries and legal theories virtually identical to those involved in instant actions, so that their inclusion in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would eliminate duplication of discovery, prevent possibility of inconsistent pretrial rulings, conserve judicial effort and result in overall savings of time and expense for parties.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 710 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2953

head.headtext: ——Stocks and securities actions, previously transferred actions situs, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Securities fraud suit involved common questions of fact with actions previously transferred to Central District of California, and similar transfer of such action would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation.
In re Pennsylvania Life Co. Securities Litigation., 436 F. Supp. 406 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2957

Action brought to recover under federal securities laws raised factual questions common to previously transferred litigation concerning effect of class settlement on plaintiff's claims and concerning allegedly fraudulent activity detrimental to value of securities involved thus requiring transfer to Western District of Oklahoma for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions there pending.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 527 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Action for alleged violations of federal securities laws in failing to disclose material adverse facts and in making misleading statements in connection with purchase and sale of securities was transferred by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings where action raised questions of fact common to actions previously transferred to that district and transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation by avoiding duplicative discovery and by allowing plaintiffs to experience a net savings of time, effort and expenses through pooling of resources with other plaintiffs in transferee district who shared similar interests.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 314 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Where prior actions against the same defendant based on alleged violations of securities and antitrust laws had been transferred to the Southern District of Florida for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, additional actions which were brought against the defendant by former distributors who alleged violations of the Securities Act of 1933, section 77a et seq. of Title 15, and violations of common-law fraud and the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, V.T.C.A. Bus. & C. § 17.41 et seq. would be transferred to the Southern District of Florida, even though Texas state law claims were not involved in the Florida litigation.
In re Bestline Products Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 313 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Action brought in Southern District of Texas to recover from broker-underwriter for alleged failure to examine financial stability of issuer of corporate debentures was ordered transferred to Central District of California for consolidation for pretrial proceedings with other pending litigation involving issuer where instant tag-along action involved questions of fact common to actions previously transferred; commonality of factual issues arising from need to determine whether fraud existed at issuer dictated transfer, notwithstanding assertion that bankruptcy trustee's reports would provide sole source of discovery concerning underlying fraud issue.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 397 F. Supp. 884 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Action involving sale of stock of bankrupt would be transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, where action involved questions of fact common to previously transferred actions, and where transfer of action would prevent duplication of common discovery and unnecessary inconvenience to the parties and their witnesses.
In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 570 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2957

Action by State of Ohio alleging securities law violations was transferred to the District of Colorado where action involved factual issues common to actions previously transferred to that district, and transfer would best serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation, notwithstanding defendant's contention that Judicial Panel should defer ruling on propriety of transfer until the transferor court decided his motions to quash service of process and to dismiss, since the transferee court had the power to decide defendant's motions, and could possibly consider them currently with other similar motions already before it.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 588 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Action by former shareholders of acquired corporation against various directors, officers and agents of acquiring corporation based on alleged violations of federal securities laws would be transferred to Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions previously transferred to that district in order to serve convenience of parties and witnesses and to promote just and efficient conduct of the litigation, where plaintiffs' complaint contained allegations similar to those asserted by plaintiffs who still had causes of action pending in transferee district, and where many of defendants were also defendants in the actions in New York.
In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger Litigation, 362 F. Supp. 568 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2957

Action wherein State of Ohio asserted 11 causes of action involving purported violations of federal and state securities laws arising out of Ohio's purchase of certain notes issued by corporation, as well as third-party complaint filed by former president and director of corporation for indemnity, contribution and reimbursement in event he was adjudged to be liable to Ohio would be transferred by Judicial Panel to Western District of Oklahoma for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions previously transferred by Panel.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 361 F. Supp. 636 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2957

Action was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to District of Massachusetts where 14 actions arising out of the issuance and sale of securities of company had been transferred to that district and allegations of liability made against broker and its registered representative rested primarily on questions of fact concerning financial affairs of company and duplication of discovery would result unless case were transferred.
In re Revenue Properties Co. Ltd., 333 F. Supp. 558 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: Miscellaneous actions, selection of transferee district—Generally

para.paratext:
District of Colorado was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in two actions pending in multidistrict litigation and alleging that certain employees of an insurance company were entitled to overtime compensation and other relief, even though differences in caseload and other docket conditions did not strongly favor either district; over 120 individuals had opted into the collective action in District of Colorado, and District was not currently assigned to other multidistrict litigation dockets.
In re American Family Mut. Ins. Co., 416 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation, in which centralization for pretrial proceedings was ordered, of actions alleging that accounting irregularities at Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) resulted in understatement of earnings for fiscal years 2000 through 2003, Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum; two of the actions were already pending in that district, and district was readily accessible for parties and witnesses.
In re Federal Home Loan Mort. Corp. Securities & Derivative Litigation (No. II), 303 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2953

Transfer to Central District of California, of 12 actions and four potential tag-along actions, pending in 14 districts and centralized for pretrial proceedings, which alleged that pharmaceutical defendants knew of side effects of a widely-used anti-depressant drug and either concealed, misrepresented, or failed to warn of them, was appropriate; no federal district stood out as a focal point in the litigation, judge was experienced, and district had the capacity to handle the litigation.
In re Paxil Products Liability Litigation, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953

In multidistrict litigation on behalf of overlapping putative classes and alleging that one or more of defendant insurance company's entities violated notification and disclosure requirements of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) in their use of consumer reports for the qualification, underwriting and rate-setting processes for certain policies of insurance, Western District of Oklahoma was appropriate transferee forum; one action was pending in that district, district provided a convenient central forum, and district did not have any other multidistrict litigation on its docket.
In re Farmers Insurance Co., Inc., Insurance Premiums Litigation, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts 152

In multidistrict litigation alleging company's violations of federal securities laws or of Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), transfer of 21 actions to District of Maryland was appropriate; district had a nexus to the litigation inasmuch as company subsidiary which was focus of litigation was located there, pertinent documents and witnesses should be available there, and both defendants and moving plaintiffs supported transfer to district.
In re Royal Ahold N.V. Securities, “ERISA” Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2957

Transfer to Southern District of New York of 39 actions against telecommunications corporation alleging misrepresentations or omissions concerning its financial condition and accounting practices, consolidated for pretrial proceedings, was appropriate; district was one of several locations likely to be source of documents and witnesses relevant to litigation, constituent actions in district had already been coordinated or consolidated before single judge, district was venue for other important legal proceedings involving corporation, including corporation's bankruptcy case, and litigation of such scope benefitted from centralization in major metropolitan center.
In re WorldCom, Inc., Securities & “ERISA” Litigation, 226 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, miscellaneous actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
All pending cases arising out of aircraft disaster in Michigan would be transferred to United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in the interests of parties; no party lodged objection to transfer, nearly identical or identical evidence regarding liability issues would be produced in each case, district court had presided over discovery phase of litigation and was intimately familiar with controverted liability issues, transfer would obviate need for multiple liability trials, accident occurred in the judicial district, and no other judicial district was more convenient for parties and witnesses.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Aug. 16, 1987, 737 F. Supp. 391 (E.D. Mich. 1989).
Federal Courts  2955

Eastern District of New York was appropriate transferee forum for centralized pretrial proceedings in eight actions, pending in four districts, arising from air crash; one action was pending in that district, relevant discovery would likely be conducted within that district, where aircraft and pilot were based and aircraft's engine was overhauled, and aircraft's intended destination was airport within district.
In re Air Crash Near Woodbury, Connecticut, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2955

head.headtext: ——Antitrust actions, miscellaneous actions, selection of transferee district

para.paratext:
Southern District of New York was appropriate transferee district for centralized pretrial proceedings in two actions and four potential tag-along actions alleging that defendants engaged in anticompetitive conduct in the market for interest rate swaps; district had a strong factual connection to the litigation, since most defendants and two potential tag-along plaintiffs were based there and numerous events giving rise to the litigation were alleged to have occurred there, and the first-filed of the constituent actions was pending before the transferee judge, an able and experienced jurist who had not had opportunity to preside over a docket in multidistrict litigation but who would steer the litigation on a prudent course.
In re Interest Rate Swaps Antitrust Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
Federal Courts  2956

District of New Jersey was appropriate transferee forum, in multidistrict litigation, for four purported class actions and six potential tag-along actions, centralized for pretrial proceedings, alleging that common defendants and/or their alleged co-conspirators engaged in a combination and conspiracy to affect the sale of insurance by rigging bids and allocating customers; district offered an accessible metropolitan location geographically convenient for many of the docket's litigants and counsel, and was equipped with the resources that the complex antitrust docket was likely to require.
In re Insurance Brokerage Antitrust Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
Federal Courts  2954

District of Kansas was appropriate forum for transfer of consolidated multidistrict litigation alleging conspiracy to fix and maintain price of urethane and urethane chemicals; that district was geographically convenient location, given nationwide scope of litigation, and was equipped with resources that complex antitrust docket was likely to require.
In re Urethane Antitrust Litigation, 333 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
Federal Courts  2954

Transfer to District of Connecticut, of six actions and four potential tag-along actions pending in three districts and centralized for pretrial proceedings, and alleging conspiracy to fix the price of international shipments of liquid chemicals in the United States, was appropriate; four of the actions were pending in that district, one defendant was located there, and the district's caseload was relatively favorable for accepting the assignment.
In re Parcel Tanker Shipping Services Antitrust Litigation, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

In multidistrict litigation involving alleged antitrust violations from conspiracy to fix prices for pressure sensitive labelstock sold in United States, in which nine actions and potential tag-along actions were centralized for pretrial proceedings, transfer of actions to Middle District of Pennsylvania was appropriate; that district did not currently have multidistrict dockets and enjoyed general docket conditions permitting Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to effect assignment to court with present resources to devote to pretrial matters that docket was likely to require, and judge assigned to constituent action in that district was seasoned jurist with caseload favorable to receiving the assignment.
In re Pressure Sensitive Labelstock Antitrust Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
Federal Courts  2954

Appropriate transferee forum, upon consolidation of multidistrict litigation class action antitrust suits against computer memory manufacturers, was Northern District of California; that district was forum of choice for majority of both plaintiffs and defendants, and was both accessible and convenient forum for all parties.
In re Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) Antitrust Litigation, 228 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict West Coast bakery flour antitrust cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Western District of Washington, where that district was the most appropriate transferee forum because it was the center of gravity of the litigation, original criminal proceedings took place there, majority of relevant documents and witnesses were located in that district or immediately adjacent areas and the Washington action had progressed much further in pretrial proceedings than action transferred.
In re West Coast Bakery Flour Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 808 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2954

Multidistrict pipeline antitrust cases were transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to Central District of California, notwithstanding fact that opposing defendants had minimum sales in district and were not named in any other civil action or in any of the indictments, where original criminal proceedings were held in district, substantial discovery and document production occurred there, majority of cases were filed there, many of corporate defendants had principal place of business in same city in district, all defendants were charged with participating in combination and conspiracy, and any additional burden due to transfer would be offset by savings from and convenience of proceedings directed by transferee judge.
In re Concrete Pipe, 303 F. Supp. 507 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: Factual connection to litigation

para.paratext:
The Northern District of California was a proper transferee district for six separate marketing, sales practices, and products liability actions, and 14 potential tag-along actions, which alleged that certain vehicles were equipped with emissions-cheating devices that engaged emissions controls only when emissions testing was being performed; California had a strong factual connection to the litigation as the state with the most affected vehicles and pending cases, significant testing of the affected vehicles occurred in California, the California Air Resources Board appeared to have played an integral role in investigating and revealing the use of eight auxiliary emissions control devices, and the district enjoyed the support of several plaintiffs and a defendant.
In re Chrysler-Dodge-Jeep EcoDiesel Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953; Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: BIFURCATION, SEVERANCE, REMAND AND RETRANSFER OF ACTIONS AND CLAIMS
Bifurcation, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Just and efficient conduct of entire antitrust litigation involving sugar industry would best be advanced under a bifurcated format by maintaining coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in Northern District of California and in Eastern District of Pennsylvania where it was abundantly clear from record that proceedings were progressing expeditiously and that judges assigned in each had become extremely well acquainted with underlying facts of litigation and that experience of those judges would be invaluable in processing entire litigation to a just and efficient conclusion.
In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 427 F. Supp. 1018 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2954

California plaintiff's request for bifurcated pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation involving claims for damages arising out of use of intrauterine contraceptive devices would not be granted, where several California actions have been included in original order transferring multidistrict litigation to District of Kansas, the litigation had grown to include over 200 actions that were originally filed in 51 districts throughout the nation, and in only action involving one particular device presently remaining in California federal courts, except for one at bar, discovery on questions of fact in common with litigation in the transferee district was nearly completed.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 710 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Severance, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Claim for sums allegedly owed under tire mileage agreements, transferred because of counterclaim asserting claims similar to those raised in other transferred actions, would be severed from counterclaim that asserted different questions as to violation of antitrust laws along with suggestion that plaintiff's claim be remanded to court of origin.
In re Transit Co. Tire Antitrust Litigation, 67 F.R.D. 57 (W.D. Mo. 1975).
Federal Civil Procedure  1; Federal Courts  2954

Court conducting consolidated discovery, in multidistrict securities fraud litigation against investment banker alleged to have given high ratings to stocks in order to gain investment banking business, would sever and recommend for remand original “pump and dump” suit by investors against corporation and its officers, alleging misrepresentation of value and insider sales, which was entire case prior to complaint amendment, adding claim of conspiracy with investment banker and triggering consolidation; conspiracy claim was weak, and even if one existed conduct would be aiding and abetting, not cognizable under § 10(b).
In re Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc. Research Reports Securities Litigation, 214 F.R.D. 152 (S.D. N.Y. 2003).
Federal Civil Procedure  87; Federal Courts  2958

Actions arising as a result of the January 1977 sinking of motor vessel approximately 200 miles west of Key West, Florida would be transferred to the Southern District of Florida for consolidated pretrial proceedings where actions involved common questions of fact and consolidation would serve convenience of parties and witnesses and promote just and efficient conduct of litigation; however, inclusion in proceedings of claims of Texas crew members' action against two of defendants in action who allegedly failed to comply with certain discovery orders would be severed and remanded to Southern District of Texas for further proceedings, despite claim that until pending motions to quash service of process and to dismiss for lack of in personal jurisdiction in Florida actions were resolved, transfer would be premature.
In re Sinking of the Motor Vessel Ukola, 462 F. Supp. 385 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2953

Since objecting defendant's liability might rest on information, if any, concerning elements of alleged conspiracy to increase price of uranium and to divide portions of the world uranium market, exchanged between it and the other defendants, discovery involving such defendant was tied to discovery of the other defendants, and thus fact that it was a middleman and not a producer of uranium did not warrant exclusion of claims against it from transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with Illinois action.
In re Uranium Industry Antitrust Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 1223 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

In considering whether to include an action in a consolidation for pretrial proceedings, court is necessarily influenced by the pleadings.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 249 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

Where numerous cases were consolidated for pretrial proceedings in one district and defendant in such cases asserted claims against third parties which were identical to claims involved in other cases which had been consolidated for pretrial proceedings in a different district, defendant's third-party claims would be separated and transferred to latter district.
In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 309 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

Count of government's claim seeking cancellation of drug company's patent on ground that patent was procured by fraud would be severed from remainder of action involving claims against seven drug companies, and would not be transferred to Southern District of New York where private treble damage antitrust actions were pending against the drug companies.
In re Antibiotic Drugs, 309 F. Supp. 155 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2956

Request that issue of damages be severed prior to transfer of multidistrict litigation to allow respective transferor courts to determine questions of damages in advance of any determination was refused.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport on November 20, 1967, 298 F. Supp. 353 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: Punitive damages, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Punitive damages issue in asbestos cases was separate “claim” which Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation could properly retain while remanding compensatory damages issue for trial in transferor courts; “claim” was not synonymous with “cause of action.”
In re Collins, 233 F.3d 809 (3d Cir. 2000).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims—Generally

para.paratext:
Normally, after pretrial proceedings have drawn to conclusion in multidistrict case, each of cases transferred by Judicial Panel will be remanded to district from which it was transferred.
In re Air Crash Disaster at John F. Kennedy Intern. Airport on Jun 24, 1975, 479 F. Supp. 1118 (E.D. N.Y. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Courts to which multidistrict cases are transferred are obliged in their decision making to consider intent of this section that cases be returned to courts of their inception at conclusion of pretrial proceedings.
In re Career Academy Antitrust Litigation, 57 F.R.D. 569 (E.D. Wis. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

Once common pretrial proceedings and any other pretrial proceedings that transferee court considers appropriate have been completed in transferee district, each transferred action is remanded by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation for further pretrial and trial to the district from which each action was transferred.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Chicago, Ill., on May 25, 1979, 476 F. Supp. 445 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

Transfer of actions to single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, pursuant to rules of Judicial Panel, did not preclude possible future transfer for trial when pretrial proceedings were complete.
In re Mid-Air Collision, Fairland, Ind., 309 F. Supp. 621 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——To transferor court, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
When cases are coordinated or consolidated by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) referral, pursuant to multidistrict litigation (MDL) statute, they must be remanded to their original courts for resolution once pretrial proceedings have been completed.
In re Activated Carbon-Based Hunting Clothing Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 840 F. Supp. 2d 1193 (D. Minn. 2012).
Federal Courts  2958

Securities fraud action that was transferred by order of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation from federal district court in Texas to federal district court in New York, for consolidation with other New York actions arising out of sale of same securities, would not be remanded to transferor court, where factors relied upon by Judicial Panel for original transfer order, regarding common questions of fact between actions, remained valid, and certain of plaintiffs' claims were governed by New York law.
In re Integrated Resources, Inc. Real Estate Ltd. Partnerships Securities Litigation, 851 F. Supp. 556 (S.D. N.Y. 1994).
Federal Courts  2958

Power of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to remand is restricted to remanding actions, or claims separated therefrom, to transferor districts from which an action was transferred.
In re Delta Airlines, Inc., Flight Attendant Weight Standards Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 795 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Transferee court's recommendation, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Multidistrict litigation (MDL) court did not have any power to directly transfer cases brought by merchant mariners asserting asbestos-related claims to venue with personal jurisdiction over ship owners; any direct transfer would have thwarted ability of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) to remand to originating court at end of pretrial proceedings.
Kalama v. Matson Navigation Company, Inc., 875 F.3d 297 (6th Cir. 2017).
Federal Courts  2958

When cases are coordinated or consolidated by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) referral, pursuant to multidistrict litigation (MDL) statute, transferee court is expected to suggest to JPML that matter should be returned to transferor court for final resolution once pretrial proceedings have been completed; power to remand case to transferor court lies solely with JPML.
In re Activated Carbon-Based Hunting Clothing Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 840 F. Supp. 2d 1193 (D. Minn. 2012).
Federal Courts  2958

Under the totality of the circumstances at the conclusion of consolidated pretrial proceedings, and in light of transferee judge's determination that remand was appropriate, action previously transferred by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would be remanded.
In re Managed Care Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
Federal Courts  2958

In light of fact that transferee judge believed that he had completed his task in the litigation and that remand was appropriate for all actions transferred in which plaintiffs did not elect to opt into the consolidated causation trial, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would remand to their respective transferor courts 83 actions against drug manufacturer after jury in the consolidated trial had returned a verdict in favor of the manufacturer; however, in absence of a suggestion of remand directed to any of six additional actions, remand of those actions was not appropriate.
In re Richardson-Merrell, Inc. Bendectin Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 606 F. Supp. 715 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
Federal Courts  2958

The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, in considering remand of any action previously transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, places great weight on transferee judge's suggestion that remand has become appropriate; similarly, any party before Panel advocating remand of action without first obtaining a recommendation of remand from transferee judge bears a strong burden of persuasion.
In re Air Crash Disaster Near Chicago, Ill., on May 25, 1979, 476 F. Supp. 445 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2958

If and when an action or claim is, in fact, ready for trial, or otherwise ready for remand because transferee judge finds that centralized pretrial proceedings pertaining to that action or claim are completed, transferee judge may suggest to Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation that Panel remand action or claim to its transferor district.
In re Dept. of Energy Stripper Well Exemption Litigation, 472 F. Supp. 1282 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
Federal Courts  2951

In considering question of remand of action which has been transferred to another district for coordinated or pretrial consolidated pretrial proceedings, the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation gives great weight to transferee judge's determination that remand of action is appropriate; transferee judge has a special vantage point with respect to conduct of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, and his suggestion of remand to Panel demonstrates that he perceives his role to have ended.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 220 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

In considering whether to remand actions previously transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, the Panel on Multidistrict Litigation is greatly influenced by the transferee judge's suggestion that remand is appropriate.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 108 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

It is not contemplated that transferee judge will necessarily complete all pretrial proceedings and all actions transferred and assigned to him by the Judicial Panel but rather transferee judge in his discretion will conduct common pretrial proceedings with respect to actions and any additional pretrial proceedings as he deems otherwise appropriate, and thus, in considering remand, panel is greatly influenced by transferee judge's suggestion that remand of action is appropriate.
In re Evergreen Valley Project Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 923 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Where action which charged manufacturer of electronic data processing system with illegal monopolization and which had been transferred to Northern District of California involved certain factual dissimilarities from previously transferred actions, and transferee judge had suggested that continued inclusion of such action, which had been included for coordination and pretrial proceedings at relatively late date in progress of originally transferred cases, would be inefficient, awkward, and tend to interfere with scheduling for trial and trials of California cases, remand of such action was ordered to District of New Hampshire.
In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 254 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2954

Notwithstanding assertion that certain claims asserted by the State of Ohio had nothing in common with securities actions previously transferred by Judicial Panel to Oklahoma and should have been severed and remanded to Southern District of Ohio for further pretrial proceedings and trial, transferee judge, who had complete familiarity with all aspects of litigation and who was in best position to ascertain which of claims asserted by Ohio, if any, were immediately capable of remand, could recommend to Panel, when he deemed appropriate, which of Ohio's claims were ready for remand.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 361 F. Supp. 636 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Commonality of actions, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Where actions had been filed in various federal district courts for wrongful death of occupants of airplane which crashed in California, multidistrict litigation order transferred cases in Central District of California for coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceedings, there was only one operative set of facts for determination of liability and remand to various courts for trial might produce different results and each of cases might have been brought in California, the cases subject to the multidistrict orders should be transferred to California court on all issues for all purposes.
In re Aircrash Near Duarte, California, On June 6, 1971, 357 F. Supp. 1013 (C.D. Cal. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

In action against stock issuers and brokers, which along with three other actions had been transferred to District of Colorado for coordinated or consolidated pretrial procedures, broker claims would be remanded on showing that they related exclusively to San Francisco brokerage firm and alleged misrepresentations and nondisclosure by representatives of that firm and that, because brokerage firm and its representatives were not party to any of the other actions and its sales of securities in question were relatively small, discovery on broker claims would not duplicate discovery in coordinated proceedings or be of interest to the other parties.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 352 F. Supp. 974 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

Where action against stock brokerage firm and its San Francisco sales representative involved substantial question of fact as to whether the stock which was sold to plaintiff was properly registered for sale in United States which was common to other actions which were part of multidistrict litigation and convenience of parties and witnesses and the just and efficient conduct of the multidistrict litigation would not be served by remand to Northern District of California, plaintiff's motion to remand would be denied.
In re Revenue Properties Co., 314 F. Supp. 1255 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Convenience of parties and witnesses, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Although crash of aircraft occurred in New York, there existed no commonality of facts or considerations of party and witness convenience which would tie trial of damage issues to New York in action against airline and others, and consideration of convenience of parties and witnesses dictated that districts in which passengers resided were more appropriate forums for determination of damages, and thus motions for remand were granted by District Court for the Eastern District of New York which had determined liability in multidistrict litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster at John F. Kennedy Intern. Airport on Jun 24, 1975, 479 F. Supp. 1118 (E.D. N.Y. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

While the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation previously centralized several actions, in air disaster litigation, in the Southern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, plaintiffs in the instant action, wherein defendants had agreed they would not contest their liability for compensatory damages, established that remand of the action to the Central District of California would serve the convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of that action.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Tenerife, Canary Islands on March 27, 1977, 461 F. Supp. 671 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Completion of pretrial proceedings generally, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Although, under statute governing multidistrict litigation, Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation has the discretion to remand a transferred case when everything that remains to be done is case-specific, this does not mean that consolidated proceedings have concluded at the point that only case-specific proceedings remain; rather, the court can at that point exercise its discretion to remand “before the conclusion of pretrial proceedings.”
In re Patenaude, 210 F.3d 135 (3d Cir. 2000).
Federal Courts  2958
