Because there were numerous other plaintiffs who had not yet appealed in multidistrict FLSA litigation because final order rule precluded appeal prior to remand to transferor courts but who were dismissed by same transferee district court on essentially same grounds as one or more of appellants, multidistrict litigation statute required that other dismissed plaintiffs have opportunity to join in appeals; if dismissed plaintiffs were not permitted to do so, result could be piecemeal litigation that multidistrict scheme was intended to discourage.
In re Food Lion, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act Effective Scheduling Litigation, 73 F.3d 528 (4th Cir. 1996).
Federal Courts  3257

Order of Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) conditionally transferring action for inclusion in existing consolidated pretrial proceedings did not preclude, on textual or structural grounds, remand by district court where action was pending, during interval prior to transmittal of final transfer order to transferee court; there was no conflict between JPML local rule providing that transferor court's jurisdiction is unimpeded prior to transmittal of final transfer order and multidistrict litigation statute's provision that transferee court “shall” conduct pretrial proceedings in transferred case once it is transferred, and statute did not mandate consistency as to jurisdictional evaluations by all transferor courts hearing potential “tag-along” actions.
Illinois Mun. Retirement Fund v. Citigroup, Inc., 391 F.3d 844 (7th Cir. 2004).
Federal Courts  2958

Remand of those cases transferred to multidistrict judge in mass tort litigation arising from airplane crash that had not been consolidated in exemplar trial before determination of collateral estoppel effect of results of that trial upon the nonconsolidated cases would be contrary to court's duty to resolve common pretrial issues under multidistrict litigation statute.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Stapleton Intern. Airport, Denver, Colo., on Nov. 15, 1987, 720 F. Supp. 1505 (D. Colo. 1989).
Federal Courts  2958

When case has been transferred to Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML), a remand prior to the conclusion of pretrial proceedings is discretionary with the transferee court.
In re Baycol Products Litigation, 265 F.R.D. 453 (D. Minn. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

Remand of suit brought against drug manufacturer by state of Louisiana in Eastern District of New York to the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana would be premature where discovery and settlement negotiations were in progress; it would frustrate the purpose of procedures designed to prevent unnecessary duplicative discovery work by transferor courts.
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 2d 170 (E.D. N.Y. 2005).
Federal Courts  3973

One plaintiff's allegation, in an action alleging that a drug prescribed for heartburn and other symptoms could cause a variety of bone ailments, that she had ingested both the drug at issue and another drug, did not warrant remanding that case rather than including it in multidistrict litigation; excluding the case would result in duplicative discovery and pretrial practice, whereas the transferee judge could structure proceedings so that discovery with respect to any unique issues could proceed concurrently with discovery on common issues.
In re: Nexium (Esomeprazole) Products Liability Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
Federal Courts  2953

Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation will remand an action or actions prior to the completion of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings only on a showing of good cause.
In re South Central States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 462 F. Supp. 388 (J.P.M.L. 1978). See, also, In re CBS Color Tube Patent Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Gypsum Wallboard, 340 F. Supp. 990 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2958

Actions brought under federal securities laws, which had been transferred by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation to the District of Colorado for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, were appropriate for remand to the Southern District of Ohio, as recommended by judge of transferee court, following completion of pretrial procedures in action brought against several defendants for allegedly disseminating misleading information in connection with sale of securities, notwithstanding facts that pretrial procedures had not yet been completed in action against single defendant who sold securities on company's behalf and that one of defendants in other action had filed petition for writ of certiorari in the United States Supreme Court seeking review of judgment affirming imposition of discovery sanctions, thus possibly delaying trial of that action.
In re King Resources Co. Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 220 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2957

Request that Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation determine propriety of remand of action after transfer for centralized pretrial proceedings was premature in that such determination would infringe on the transferee judge's discretion in making orders he deems appropriate to effectuate the expeditious and harmonious conduct of the litigation.
In re Air Crash Disaster in Ionian Sea on September 8, 1974, 407 F. Supp. 238 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2958

Where all pretrial proceedings in more than 70 actions which arose from crash of passenger plane and which had been coordinated for pretrial purposes in one district were completed, cases would be remanded for trial in transferor forums.
In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 354 F. Supp. 275 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Federal Courts  2955

Derivative class action brought on behalf of subsidiary and its minority stockholders was transferred to Eastern District of Pennsylvania as a tag-along case in action against parent where claims related to subsidiary's interlocking directorships and eventual merger with a competitor, allegedly at direction of parent and in violation of federal antitrust and securities laws, and plaintiff's motion to remand action to Northern District of Texas for completion of pretrial proceedings and trial was denied, considering factual interrelationships between cases, but since it was possible that some future developments in litigation might make reconsideration of remand necessary, denial of motion for remand was made without prejudice to later consideration.
In re Penn Central Securities Litigation, 349 F. Supp. 1029 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2957

head.headtext: ——Completion of discovery, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
A multidistrict litigation (MDL) court cannot try the cases filed in, or removed to, federal courts across the country and transferred to the MDL court by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, but rather must remand them to the transferor forum when pretrial discovery is complete.
In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 478 F. Supp. 2d 897 (E.D. La. 2007).
Federal Courts  2958

Where pretrial discovery had ceased, remand of case to original district of New York would appear to be appropriate.
In re Viatron Computer Systems Corp. Litigation, 86 F.R.D. 431 (D. Mass. 1980).
Federal Courts  2958

Remand to original courts was proper, following consolidation by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML), pursuant to multidistrict litigation (MDL) statute, of numerous putative class actions against sellers of hunting clothing alleging consumer fraud and conspiracy, since primary purpose of consolidation had been achieved; discovery disputes had been resolved, discovery had been completed, scope of transferred cases had been narrowed as a result of settlement of claims against one defendant, class certification had been denied, settlement appeared unlikely, and remaining claims required individualized proof on state-specific issues.
In re Activated Carbon-Based Hunting Clothing Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 840 F. Supp. 2d 1193 (D. Minn. 2012).
Federal Courts  2958

Under circumstances including fact that transferee judge suggested that completion of remaining discovery and resolution of remaining issues could most expeditiously be effectuated by the transferor courts, actions involving claims for injuries allegedly sustained through use of intrauterine devices, previously transferred to the District of Kansas for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, were remanded to the transferor districts.
In re A. H. Robins Co., Inc. “Dalkon Shield” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 108 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Where transferee judge, to whom class action brought on behalf of class B bondholders had been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceeding with three pending actions, had found that because of pendency of related actions in state courts, further pretrial discovery in federal court concerning series A bondholders was unnecessary and that transferred action would therefore no longer benefit from multidistrict treatment, and since defendant's motion to dismiss could easily be presented to and determined by transferor court, class action brought on behalf of class B bondholders would be remanded to the Southern District of New York for further proceedings.
In re Evergreen Valley Project Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 923 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

On recommendation of transferee judge for remand, Security Exchange Commission's action arising out of failure of bank, which action had been transferred to Eastern District of New York for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with actions pending in that district, was remanded to Southern District of New York despite contention that remand was inappropriate until two defendants completed all discovery allegedly essential to their defense preparations for trial.
In re Franklin Nat. Bank Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 248 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2957

Plaintiff's action for violation of federal securities laws would be separated from third-party action which all parties agreed should be transferred to another district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and would be remanded to district court in which plaintiff's action had been instituted for further proceedings even if primary fraud upon which plaintiff's action was based constituted the principal common question of fact underlying previously ordered transfers, where plaintiff's discovery had been completed and his action was ready for trial.
In re Equity Funding Corp. of America Securities Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1262 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
Federal Courts  2957

Where action against plaintiff's broker and against corporation and others was transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with nine other actions involving the affairs of the corporation, where plaintiff would have to examine the records of the corporation to develop all the elements of its case against its broker, and where other plaintiffs were investigating the conduct of other brokers concerning the corporation, it was appropriate that common discovery with respect to the records of the corporation be completed before remand of plaintiff's claim against its broker was considered.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 758 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

While local discovery can be conducted during coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, it need not be, and actions may be remanded to original transferor courts for such local discovery.
In re Photocopy Paper, 305 F. Supp. 60 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2951; Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Motions pending in transferee court, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Neither motion before transferee court in multidistrict litigation and appeal from denial thereof nor earlier petition for writ of mandamus amounted to motion for remand brought before Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) so as to trigger obligation to remand transferred case; therefore, following completion of pretrial proceedings and final judgment in multidistrict litigation, transferee court properly proceeded to conduct trial on former defendant's remaining tort claim against counsel for plaintiff class.
In re American Continental Corporation/Lincoln Sav. & Loan Securities Litigation, 102 F.3d 1524 (9th Cir. 1996).
Federal Courts  2958

On suggestion of transferee court that remand of action would be appropriate, and where all actions comprising multidistrict litigation except one action had either been terminated in transferee district or remanded to appropriate transferor court, Judicial Panel would order such remand though motions in such remaining action were currently pending before transferee court, the same being not of any nature unique to the action and their resolution not requiring any particular expertise that transferee judge might have gained from supervising the litigation.
In re Multidistrict Civil Actions Involving Air Crash Disaster Near Dayton, Ohio, on March 9, 1967, 386 F. Supp. 908 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2958

In view of pendency before transferee judge of pretrial motion to have counterclaim filed by defendants in the Northern District of Illinois severed and transferred to the District of Massachusetts, Judicial Panel refused to consider motion to remand one of the two remaining patent infringement actions brought by plaintiff and consolidated for pretrial proceeding.
In re CBS Color Tube Patent Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Motions pending in transferor court, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
That seller had pending in Texas district court certain motions to dismiss claim under Robinson-Patman Act, §§ 13, 13a, 13b and 21a of Title 15, did not warrant that the claim be remanded to Texas court, despite transfer of antitrust claim to Missouri District Court for pretrial proceedings.
In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 676 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2956

head.headtext: ——Motions incorrectly decided by transferee court, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Where patent infringement action was placed by the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation in hands of the district court for pretrial proceeding and it improperly granted partial summary judgment, upon reversal Court of Appeals would not remand action to district in which it originated for completion of pretrial proceedings and trial on ground that district judge had made factual determinations that he might not be able to retract.
In re Coordinated Pretrial Proceedings in Antibiotic Antitrust Actions, 538 F.2d 180 (8th Cir. 1976).
Federal Courts  3780

head.headtext: ——Termination of action, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
“Termination” within this section permitting remand of case to district from which it has been transferred at or before conclusion of pretrial proceedings, unless it shall have been previously terminated, may result from voluntary dismissal or from action of the court.
Humphreys v. Tann, 487 F.2d 666 (6th Cir. 1973).
Federal Courts  2951

Where transferee court in multidistrict litigation has declined to suggest a remand, the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) has not ordered a remand on its own initiative, and litigant has failed to seek a remand before the JMPL, transferee court is entitled to terminate the proceedings by conducting trial.
In re American Continental Corporation/Lincoln Sav. & Loan Securities Litigation, 102 F.3d 1524 (9th Cir. 1996).
Federal Courts  2958

Plaintiffs in asbestos actions which had been consolidated by Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation would be ordered, with respect to 2,546 cases which had been listed as “closed” by transferee judge, to identify at least 150 cases which were suitable for remand, and indicate whether plaintiffs intended to seek remand of those cases before transferee court and if necessary Judicial Panel, and also to identify any other cases which had been “closed” by transferee court and indicate whether they would seek remand; otherwise, court would be compelled to conclude that cases were fully resolved, and should be formally terminated.
In re Asbestos Litigation, 7 F. Supp. 2d 93 (D. Mass. 1998).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Binding nature of transferee court's decisions, remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
After transfer for pretrial proceedings, transferor court when the case is returned to it is in position of third court on a second change of venue and takes case with all of its errors, if any.
Allegheny Airlines, Inc. v. LeMay, 448 F.2d 1341 (7th Cir. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

When case has been transferred by multidistrict panel, venue has been changed and transferor court no longer has any jurisdiction of the matter and can issue no further orders, but order remanding case back to transferor court is also change of venue and transferor court takes case with all errors that may have fastened upon it.
In re Upjohn Co. Antibiotic Cleocin Products Liability Litigation, 508 F. Supp. 1020 (E.D. Mich. 1981).
Federal Courts  2958

Pretrial ruling of transferee court in consolidated multidistrict litigation proceedings that resulted in dismissal of portion of qui tam action would not be reconsidered upon remand to transferor court for trial; reconsideration would have been contrary to the intent of, and would have impaired, multidistrict litigation scheme and transferee court's decision was law of case.
U.S. ex rel. Staley v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp., 587 F. Supp. 2d 757 (W.D. Va. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Issues for court on remand, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
When considering a motion for remand prior to conclusion of pretrial proceedings, of a case that has been transferred to Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML), the transferee court is to provide a suggestion or recommendation to the panel, and that suggestion carries great weight.
In re Baycol Products Litigation, 265 F.R.D. 453 (D. Minn. 2008).
Federal Courts  2958

Transferee judge in case of multidistrict litigation transfer to district in which some actions are pending can separate pending actions and set them for trial as soon as they are ready and can decide whether and to what extent questions should be covered during coordinated and consolidated pretrial proceeding or whether they should be left for local discovery following remand to court of origin.
In re Frost Patent, 316 F. Supp. 977 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Federal Civil Procedure  1993.1

Discovery relating to noncommon questions of fact involved in cases ordered transferred by Judicial Panel would be conducted following remand if transferee judge concluded that such procedure would be in the best interests of justice.
In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Civil Procedure  1261

head.headtext: Retransfer, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims—Generally

para.paratext:
When considering a motion to retransfer an action to its original forum, the transfer order binds the transferee court in the absence of clear error or manifest injustice; however, where the original purpose of the transfer is frustrated by changed circumstances after the transfer order has been entered, retransfer may be appropriate.
Scarborough v. National Ass'n of Sur. Bond Producers, 474 F. Supp. 2d 64 (D.D.C. 2007).
Federal Courts  2946

Retransfer of litigations will occur only in the most extraordinary instances.
In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2958

Only with reluctance will the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation retransfer litigation.
In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 712 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Considerations governing generally, retransfer, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Retransfer of defamation action against private defendant to original forum was appropriate due to changed circumstances, where action was originally transferred for purposes of consolidation with another action against federal agencies for trial and where private defendant no longer sought consolidation for all purposes including trial, but rather, sought consolidation for discovery purposes only; transferor court clearly contemplated that the case might be retransferred if transferee court deemed it appropriate and there was an undisputed likelihood that sensitive information would be disclosed during depositions in case against federal agencies to which the private defendant would not be entitled.
Scarborough v. National Ass'n of Sur. Bond Producers, 474 F. Supp. 2d 64 (D.D.C. 2007).
Federal Courts  2946

Where antitrust cases filed in Northern District of Illinois could have been commenced in District of Arizona, since plaintiff had moved its main base of operation and principal offices to Arizona, majority of anticipated material testimony from plaintiff's witnesses would come from individuals residing in Arizona and trial could be had at earlier date in District of Arizona than in Northern District of Illinois, cases would be transferred by district court to which they had been transferred for pretrial proceedings by Judicial Panel to District of Arizona in interest of justice and for convenience of parties and witnesses.
Greyhound Computer Corp. v. International Business Machines Corp., 342 F. Supp. 1143 (D. Minn. 1972).
Federal Courts  2909

head.headtext: ——Bias of transferee judge, retransfer, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Retransfer of multidistrict suit to district from which it was transferred would not be granted where ground asserted for retransfer was bias or prejudice of the transferee trial judge.
In re Plumbing Fixtures, 332 F. Supp. 1047 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: ——Dissatisfaction with transferee judge rulings, retransfer, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Dissatisfaction by a party with transferee judge's rulings in coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is an insufficient basis upon which to support a request to designate a new subgroup of related actions to proceed independently in a different transferee district.
In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
Federal Courts  2951

head.headtext: ——Recusal of transferee judge, retransfer, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Two of five private antitrust actions previously transferred to the Middle District of Louisiana would not be remanded to the Eastern District of Texas nor would litigation be retransferred to that district, despite contention that the Louisiana district was selected because of original transferee judge's familiarity with the facts involved and that recusal of such judge and the intended dismissal of the actions other than movant's actions dissolved the rationale for conducting coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in that Louisiana forum, where there was no assurance that the other actions would be dismissed and the class on whose behalf certification was sought in movant's actions included members of the classes in the other actions.
In re South Central States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 462 F. Supp. 388 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
Federal Courts  2954

head.headtext: ——Air accident actions, retransfer, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Motion for retransfer to the Northern District of California of claims against aircraft manufacturer arising out of airplane crash was denied in absence of any basis for such retransfer.
In re Air Crash Disaster in Ionian Sea on September 8, 1974, 438 F. Supp. 932 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
Federal Courts  2958

Judicial Panel, before which motion was pending to transfer all pending federal actions arising out of airplane crash to the United States District Court for Western District of North Carolina for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, declined transfer of case pending in Southern District of New York for such purpose only where that case had already been ordered transferred to Western District of North Carolina for all purposes and action of Panel could disrupt pending proceedings for review of transfer order.
In re Mid-Air Collision Near Hendersonville, N. C. on July 19, 1967, 297 F. Supp. 1039 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
Federal Courts  2958

head.headtext: Waiver, bifurcation, severance, remand and retransfer of actions and claims

para.paratext:
Venue waivers that were limited to first two bellwether trials on patients' product-liability claims alleging that manufacturer defectively designed, manufactured, and distributed hip-implant device were not global or permanent waivers of objections to venue and personal jurisdiction.
In re Depuy Orthopaedics, Incorporated, 870 F.3d 345 (5th Cir. 2017).
Federal Courts  2953

A Lexecon waiver of an objection to an multidistrict litigation court trying a case where venue is improper must be clear and unambiguous.
In re Depuy Orthopaedics, Incorporated, 870 F.3d 345 (5th Cir. 2017).
Federal Courts  2951

Plaintiffs in action transferred for consolidated pretrial proceedings pursuant to multidistrict-litigation statute did not waive their right to remand, i.e. did not evidence intent contrary to statutory mandate for remand, by filing consolidated complaint stating that venue was proper in transferee court; filing of consolidated complaint was done at behest of district court, statement that venue was proper in transferee court was not inconsistent with desire to seek remand, and parties' proposed case management order included statement that “remand … will occur once the case is substantially ready for trial.”
Armstrong v. LaSalle Bank Nat. Ass'n, 552 F.3d 613 (7th Cir. 2009).
Federal Courts  2958

Cable network operators did not waive their motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction by supporting consolidation of patent infringement action in multidistrict litigation, or by complying with transferor court's discovery deadlines, where operators filed timely motion to dismiss, which transferee court was authorized to decide during pretrial proceedings.
In re Mobile Telecommunications Technologies, LLC, 243 F. Supp. 3d 545 (D. Del. 2017).
Patents  1717(3)
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
